HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA: VOICES;
Blacks on a Brooklyn Street: Both Cynics and Optimists Speak Out

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
Far from Africa but so deeply connected to his roots that he considers himself African (no hyphenated ethnic label for him), a vegetable and fruit vendor from Brooklyn pondered the question for a moment and replied with a shrug: "I haven't really thought about it. I'm not into politics, you know,"
The topic he would rather not discuss is President Clinton's 11-days in Africa, the first significant visit of an American President to the region. The President also made history Monday when he told school children in Uganda that he regretted the role the United States played in slavery. 
 Told of Mr. Clinton's remarks, the vendor, who uses only one name, Jawara, lost his reticence "Now, why did he have to go there to do that?" Mr. Jawara, 42, said. "We are still enslaved here. We are still fighting for our so-called rights, are we not?"
Midway through Mr. Clinton's tour of six African countries, it may be too early to know how the trip has affected African-Americans -- Mr. Clinton's most faithful constituency. But conversations yesterday with several people in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood in Brooklyn revealed that Mr. Clinton's every move and word are being carefully dissected by African-Americans from all walks of life -- from unemployed factory workers and accountants to secretaries and store owners.
"I'm glad Clinton went," said Marlon Outler, a 38-year-old unemployed man. "They are poor and a visit like this can be uplifting, but, as far as what he said about slavery, well, it's a little too late for that, isn't it?"
"African Americans are still enslaved, but in a different form now," Mr. Outler said. "There are a lot of black young men locked up in jails. And, for what? A black man has a hard way to go, that's for sure. And if they see you moving forward, they try to knock you down again."
A block away, a shop owner who uses an American Indian name, Talks with Wolves, said Mr. Clinton's quasi-apology was directed to the wrong people.
"The question is, what was his original purpose going there?" said Talks with Wolves, a New Yorker who owns a store by the same name and describes himself as half Indian and half black. "Because if he went all the way to Africa to apologize, that makes no sense. The former slaves are here, not back in Africa."
Instead, Mr. Clinton should have apologized for the way American companies have stripped African countries of their natural resources, offering little compensation in return, he said.
"It's fine that he goes there," he continued. "But will economic help mean that Nigeria is going to look like Broadway? I hope not, but I'm told it already does."
But others were kinder to Mr. Clinton, noting that the trip has served to highlight Africa's needs. Mr. Clinton has promised aid for education, farming and police training in some of the countries he has visited and pushed the idea that the best way to help Africa is through trade.
"I think the President has seen that some of the countries really are trying to change in accordance with the new world order," said Lennox Norville, 44, standing in a bakery during a coffee break from his job as manager in an insurance company. "His visit will pressure them to step up initiatives to come in line with the rest of the free world."
Mr. Norville also said that Mr. Clinton's comments on slavery were right on target. "It is important for a powerful country such as the United States to accept its mistakes," he said.
Pam Morgan, 34, a marketing consultant chimed in when she heard the topic. She described her thoughts with just one word, "Garbage," she said.
Ms. Morgan elaborated later. "If he's apologized, what is he going to do for us now?" she said. "He can't go back and change it. He needs to take us from where we are now. Take a look at our needs. Proper education, adequate training, jobs, rampant crimes, kids shooting at each other in schools all over the country. That's what I'm talking about.
"If going to Africa is part of his job as a President, fine. Let him do it. But I couldn't care less. I don't know the issues in Africa, but I know there are things to be done here."
Others at the bakery seemed to agree with Ms. Morgan, nodding in silent approval. But outside, at the door of a club where she works as a secretary, Valda Dumbombe, 48, an immigrant from Jamaica, said the President's visit is symbolic of what many other Americans would like to do, but cannot.
"It's important for the morale of all African-Americans that the President goes to Africa," she said. "A lot of people are talking about it and wishing him well. I like what he is doing. He's gone back to my old, old home."

GRAPHIC: Photos: African-Americans in Brooklyn are watching the Clinton trip closely. Jawara, above, took issue with the President's comments on slavery, as did Marlon Outler, below, who also said, "I'm glad Clinton went." (William Lopez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA;
Clinton's Painful Words Of Sorrow and Chagrin

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: KIGALI, Rwanda, March 25

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address, as provided by the White House, at the Kigali airport to survivors of the mass killings in Rwanda in 1994:
I have come today to pay the respects of my nation to all who suffered and all who perished in the Rwandan genocide. It is my hope that through this trip, in every corner of the world today and tomorrow, their story will be told; that four years ago in this beautiful, green, lovely land, a clear and conscious decision was made by those then in power that the peoples of this country would not live side by side in peace. 
 During the 90 days that began on April 6 in 1994, Rwanda experienced the most intensive slaughter in this blood-filled century we are about to leave. Families murdered in their home, people hunted down as they fled by soldiers and militia, through farmland and woods as if they were animals.
From Kibuye in the west to Kibungo in the east, people gathered seeking refuge in churches by the thousands, in hospitals, in schools. And when they were found, the old and the sick, women and children alike, they were killed -- killed because their identity card said they were Tutsi or because they had a Tutsi parent, or because someone thought they looked like a Tutsi, or slain like thousands of Hutus because they protected Tutsis or would not countenance a policy that sought to wipe out people who just the day before, and for years before, had been their friends and neighbors.
The Government-led effort to exterminate Rwanda's Tutsi and moderate Hutus, as you know better than me, took at least a million lives. Scholars of these sorts of events say that the killers, armed mostly with machetes and clubs, nonetheless did their work five times as fast as the mechanized gas chambers used by the Nazis.
It is important that the world know that these killings were not spontaneous or accidental. It is important that the world hear what your President just said -- they were most certainly not the result of ancient tribal struggles. Indeed, these people had lived together for centuries before the events the President described began to unfold.
These events grew from a policy aimed at the systematic destruction of a people. The ground for violence was carefully prepared, the airwaves poisoned with hate, casting the Tutsis as scapegoats for the problems of Rwanda, denying their humanity. All of this was done, clearly, to make it easy for otherwise reluctant people to participate in wholesale slaughter. . . .
The international community, together with nations in Africa, must bear its share of responsibility for this tragedy, as well. We did not act quickly enough after the killing began. We should not have allowed the refugee camps to become safe haven for the killers. We did not immediately call these crimes by their rightful name: genocide. We cannot change the past. But we can and must do everything in our power to help you build a future without fear, and full of hope.
We owe to those who died and to those who survived who loved them, our every effort to increase our vigilance and strengthen our stand against those who would commit such atrocities in the future -- here or elsewhere.
Indeed, we owe to all the peoples of the world who are at risk -- because each bloodletting hastens the next as the value of human life is degraded and violence becomes tolerated, the unimaginable becomes more conceivable -- we owe to all the people in the world our best efforts to organize ourselves so that we can maximize the chances of preventing these events. And where they cannot be prevented, we can move more quickly to minimize the horror. . . .
I am directing my Administration to improve, with the international community, our system for identifying and spotlighting nations in danger of genocidal violence, so that we can assure worldwide awareness of impending threats. It may seem strange to you here, especially the many of you who lost members of your family, but all over the world there were people like me sitting in offices, day after day after day, who did not fully appreciate the depth and the speed with which you were being engulfed by this unimaginable terror. . . .
Secondly, we must as an international community have the ability to act when genocide threatens. We are working to create that capacity here in the Great Lakes region. . . .
Events here show how urgent the work is. In the northwest part of your country, attacks by those responsible for the slaughter in 1994 continue today. We must work as partners with Rwanda to end this violence and allow your people to go on rebuilding your lives and your nation.
Third, we must work now to remedy the consequences of genocide. The United States has provided assistance to Rwanda to settle the uprooted and restart its economy, but we must do more. I am pleased that America will become the first nation to contribute to the new Genocide Survivors Fund. We will contribute this year $2 million, continue our support in the years to come, and urge other nations to do the same, so that survivors and their communities can find the care they need. . . .
Fourth, to help insure that those who survived in the generations to come never again suffer genocidal violence, nothing is more vital than establishing the rule of law. There can be no peace in Rwanda that lasts without a justice system that is recognized as such.
We applaud the efforts of the Rwandan Government to strengthen civilian and military justice systems. . . .
Fifth, we must make it clear to all those who would commit such acts in the future that they too must answer for their acts, and they will. In Rwanda, we must hold accountable all those who may abuse human rights, whether insurgents or soldiers. . . .
I know that in the face of all you have endured, optimism cannot come easily to any of you. Yet I have just spoken, as I said, with several Rwandans who survived the atrocities, and just listening to them gave me reason for hope. You see countless stories of courage around you every day as you go about your business here -- men and women who survived and go on, children who recover the light in their eyes remind us that at the dawn of a new millennium there is only one crucial division among the peoples of the Earth.
And believe me, after over five years of dealing with these problems I know it is not the division between Hutu and Tutsi, or Serb and Croatian and Muslim in Bosnia, or Arab and Jew, or Catholic and Protestant in Ireland, or black and white. It is really the line between those who embrace the common humanity we all share and those who reject it.
It is the line between those who find meaning in life through respect and cooperation and who, therefore, embrace peace, and those who can only find meaning in life if they have someone to look down on, someone to trample, someone to punish and, therefore, embrace war. . . .
To those who believe that God made each of us in His own image, how could we choose the darker road? When you look at those children who greeted us as we got off that plane today, how could anyone say they did not want those children to have a chance to have their own children? To experience the joy of another morning sunrise? To learn the normal lessons of life? To give something back to their people?

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Strong Home Sales Report Pushes Price of 30-Year Issue Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday after a stronger-than-expected home sales report for February raised investors' concerns about how long the Federal Reserve could refrain from raising interest rates.
The price of the 30-year bond dropped 27/32, to 102 5/8. And the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.94 percent, from 5.88 percent on Tuesday. 
 While there is little threat of any action by the central bank at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday, the thinking is that the Fed might move to a more restrictive monetary policy after the effects of Asia's economic turmoil are out of the way.
The National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes jumped 8.7 percent in February, to a record annual 4.75 million units; the forecast was 4.42 million.
Before the home sales report, prices in the Treasury market had risen in response to the Commerce Department's report of durable goods orders for February. Orders fell 1.7 percent, which was worse than expected, led by weakness in aircraft and telecommunications.
However, Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago, said that a second look at the durable goods report showed underlying strength. After excluding aircraft, orders for durable goods were up five-tenths of 1 percent.
Traders said technical selling helped aggravate the drop in bond prices, which many thought would help yesterday's $11 billion Government auction of new five-year notes. But that assumption turned out to be wrong. The notes were awarded at the high yield of 5.620 percent. Mr. Davis called it a sloppy auction, with dealers selling on the way down, which could not generate enough retail demand to clean the market up.
"Investor surveys show investors are a little bit long on benchmark and didn't have as much room to buy new securities" despite relatively attractive yields, he said.
Bonds also came under pressure from rumors that Japan would sell United States Treasury securities to buy a trillion yen of stocks.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new five-year notes:

HEADLINE: Power Deregulation: Shadow, Substance and Politics

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration presented guidelines yesterday as to how it would like to see the utility industry deregulated, including an innovative way for consumers to easily compare deals offered by rival sellers of power. But it's unclear whether the proposals will help expedite the process of dismantling the economy's last major regulated monopoly.
Under some of the major guidelines presented by Energy Secretary Federico F. Pena, utilities would have to open themselves to competition by the year 2003, a fund of $3 billion would be established to help low-income people with their electric bills, and old laws governing the utility industry would be repealed. 
 Part of the reason Secretary Pena presented the guidelines at a news conference in Washington is that the drive to deregulate has stalled in Congress and in many states. Mr. Pena intends to get it going again.
"There is limited time left," he said in an interview. "We're going to press ahead as hard as we can to get something done this year."
But the Administration is still facing a clamor of divergent interest groups over how to proceed.
Part of the problem is the enormous size of the utility industry, which sold more than $212 billion worth of electricity last year. Moreover, many utilities have never contended with competition and are nervous about how to make the transition.
Consumers are already confused by a welter of offers in states like California, which soon plans to give residents a choice among electric utilities.
There are battles between state regulators and legislators over who should lead the deregulation. The utility industry itself is split.
Big utilities that have plenty of cheap power want to accelerate the process so they can sell outside their territory. Other utilities that sell expensive power want to slow the process, so they can make the transition without bankrupting themselves.
The most divisive issue has become how to insure that residential and other small consumers get a fair share of the savings that are promised from competition. As it stands now, most of the savings are falling to the larger industrial and commercial customers, who are cutting deals with power companies in anticipation of deregulation.
California had planned to give customers a choice as of Jan. 1, but was forced to delay that until March 31 because of computer glitches and concerns over transmission reliability. An announcement yesterday by the state's biggest utilities that more testing would be needed before the process could begin next Tuesday has not reassured the public either. Some already skittish consumers have said in surveys that they do not want to deal with more choices.
Deregulation has also drawn criticism from environmentalists, who fear that competitive pressure to cut the cost of power means that utilities will rely more on coal-fired plants. Such plants produce most of the cheapest electricity, which could make it more difficult to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, a possible cause of global warming.
The Clinton Administration's proposal calls for more efficient burning of fuels to lower emissions and for a tripling of the amount of power to be generated from renewable sources like wind and solar energy by 2010. But environmental advocates called such a measure inadequate.
David Hawkins, director of the air and energy program of the Natural Resources Defense Council, said it "fails to deliver on the President's promise to make a significant down payment on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and other air pollutants."
Mr. Pena, though, is optimistic that some kind of Federal legislation will result because states will have difficulty achieving common standards, such as a nationwide system that would enable consumers to compare what marketers are offering.
As proposed by the Administration, that information would also disclose what fuel utilities use to generate electricity so that consumers can choose from sellers that offer power from renewable sources.
"As consumers see more information and they get more clarity," he said, "they will be able to compare apples to apples."
And as they get more comfortable and see savings, support for deregulation will grow, the Energy Secretary predicted. In an effort to impart some lightness to a heavy subject, Mr. Pena ended his news conference by playing John Lennon's "Power to the People."

HEADLINE: Cutting Congestion, and Taxes

 BODY:
One manifestation of America's devotion to driving is a Federal tax rule that makes an employer-provided parking space a tax-free benefit, now worth up to $175 a month. This is far more generous than the nontaxable benefit for using mass transit or van pools, which is only $65 a month and governed by more restrictive rules that limit the number of people who would find it an attractive option. The disparity retards efforts to promote mass transit as the best road to cleaner air, less congestion, more efficient energy use and economic growth in metropolitan America.
But now the huge transportation bill recently approved by the Senate would bring the transit and van benefit under the same tax rules and principles that govern parking. The Senate provision, sponsored primarily by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, would not instantly catapult the monthly dollar value of transit and van pooling benefits to the same level parking enjoys. The monthly benefit is $65 now and would reach $100 in 2002. But the new provision would make it easier for employers to offer the benefits tax free and make it possible for an employee to convert a tax-free parking benefit into a tax-free transit or van pool benefit. 
 That is heading in the right direction. Making it possible for people to switch from cars to the subsidized use of transit or vans would help a lot of metropolises unclog roads and improve air quality. Today, when the House Ways and Means Committee meets to mark up its own transportation spending bill, it should incorporate the Moynihan provision.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Union Pacific Halts Some Traffic to Mexico

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 25

 BODY:
As shippers see it, this is the Union Pacific campaign to repeal the North American Free Trade Agreement.
An embargo announced late Tuesday by the clogged railroad on most freight through its primary gateway to Mexico, shippers say, will quickly disrupt trade and coordinated industrial production between the two nations. 
 Union Pacific, pointing to 5,500 railroad cars backed up into Kansas, about 1,000 miles to the north, said it has no choice but to stop most new southbound shipments through the Laredo, Tex., gateway until it can roll thousands of those cars on into Mexico.
The border mess is the latest signal that Union Pacific, the nation's largest railroad and dominant carrier along the Mexican border, has yet to unsnarl the chaos resulting from its acquisition of Southern Pacific in 1996.
Some shippers may be hurt especially severely because delays in moving trucks across the border have forced them to rely more on rail transport.
Union Pacific pledged to continue carrying automobiles, auto parts and containers designed for easy transfer to boat or truck. But beginning Saturday, the railroad will refuse new shipments through Laredo of other freight such as chemicals, plastics, coal, grain and a range of goods used in industrial production.
Bernard L. Weinstein, a University of North Texas economist, estimated that the embargo would affect shipments at a rate as high as $500 million a month.
Trade with Mexico has increased since the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect four years ago. Union Pacific handles 80 percent of all rail freight across the border, and 61 percent of the traffic through Laredo. Jim Shattuck, the railroad's marketing and sales chief, said the embargo should last two weeks to a month. The railroad can reroute some traffic to Mexico, he said, but rail cars already cleared through Laredo will have to wait to go there.
Despite evidence that congestion in some parts of Texas is easing, Union Pacific's past predictions of relief have been unreliable. Over the last two weeks, Mr. Shattuck said, slow shipments of soda ash have already caused three Vitro glass plants in Mexico to shut down for about a day each. Mr. Shattuck said that no other customers reported pending crises today.
But Jim Woodrick, president of the Texas Chemical Council, said the slowdowns and shutdowns already forced on United States plants could spread on both sides of the border. "If we can't get shipments to our customers," he said, "they can't run their factories, and pretty soon this turns into unemployment."
The swiftest freight across the border today was in the accusations between Union Pacific and Transportacion Ferroviaria Mexicana, which picks up its cars at the border, over who was to blame. Union Pacific ascribed the tie-ups to delays in Mexico, saying the Mexican railroad was able to handle fewer and fewer cars. The Mexicans called the embargo "a unilateral move by U.P. to give it time to relieve its own congestion," adding, "This decision comes at the expense of Nafta traffic between the United States and Mexico."
Union Pacific's customers point to a lack of spare capacity or management ability to handle challenges -- from weather, accidents or border delays. The point is far from academic because the railroad's customers have asked regulators to allow competitors to share more of Union Pacific's tracks or even undo the Southern Pacific merger. Chemical and plastics makers, including the nation's largest oil companies, are likely to be prime victims of the embargo, since they ship huge quantities to supply Mexico's toy, electronics, chemical and glass industries. Some of these final products end up back in the United States.
The Huntsman Corporation, which supplies chemicals and plastics to Mexico, has already had to track down errant rail cars, including one bound for a small Texas town that wound up in Mexico. Now, executives wonder how to keep shipping to Mexico. "It creates huge problems for us with our Mexican customers," a spokesman, Don Olsen, said.
Some other manufacturers, fearing retribution from Union Pacific, have been reluctant to speak except through their trade groups. Several that were called today, including Mobil, Shell, Exxon and Dow Chemical, either had no comment or said they were still assessing their situations.

HEADLINE: Swiss Banks Face Deadline And Sanctions

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
More than a year after the investigations of Nazi gold began to taint Switzerland's reputation, its banks are fighting the threat of politically damaging sanctions across the United States and a lobbying effort by New York State to block the merger of two giant Swiss financial institutions.
Late last year officials from state and local governments around the country gave Switzerland's banks three months to demonstrate that they were fulfilling their promise to find and return money to Holocaust victims and their survivors. That deadline is March 31, and officials of several states, including New York and California, have indicated that they are considering sanctions against the banks, which would exclude them from lucrative public financing deals. Last year New York City imposed such sanctions against the Union Bank of Switzerland but later suspended them. At hearings scheduled for Thursday in New York City, the banks, the Swiss Government, Jewish groups and others will make arguments about whether the moratorium on sanctions should end next week. 
 The sanction threat, however, is colliding with another problem for the banks: an accusation this week by the acting superintendent of banks in New York State, Elizabeth McCaul, that the Union Bank and the Swiss Bank Corporation have been "lax and uncooperative" in searching for accounts from the World War II era and have engaged in "perhaps even fraudulent conduct." While New York State cannot on its own block the banks from merging, it can refuse to license their New York branches. "For too long, Holocaust survivors and their heirs have been stonewalled about the fate of money rightfully belonging to them," Gov. George E. Pataki of New York said on Tuesday.
Mr. Pataki and other officials are following the lead of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, who has pressed the issue of bringing the banks to account. Mr. D'Amato, who is up for re-election this year, today urged Allan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, to block the merger of the two banks.
Beneath the political maneuvering, however, are two fundamental and difficult issues facing the banks.
The first is whether to offer a "global settlement" to Jewish groups and others, one that would end class-action suits and other claims against the banks.
But the second, and equally sticky problem, is what the Swiss banks should do with a preliminary report by a Swiss historical commission showing that Switzerland received $450 million in Nazi gold shipments in World War II, much of it stolen from the central banks of occupied countries or, in many cases, plundered from the assets of Holocaust victims. At today's prices that gold would be worth roughly $4 billion.
Both the Swiss Government and the Clinton Administration will argue at Thursday's hearings, which will be headed by Alan Hevesi, the New York City controller, that sanctions will only further poison the discussions between the two countries and any hopes of a global settlement of the suits.

HEADLINE: Nurses Get New Role in Patient Protection

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., March 25

 BODY:
Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest health maintenance organization, agreed today to let its Northern California nurses' union appoint "quality liaison" nurses to serve as watchdogs at each of the organization's hospitals in the region and to force prompt attention to abuses and oversights in the care of patients.
Because of the organization's size and influence, with nearly nine million enrollees in 18 states, analysts and Federal officials said the agreement was a striking breakthrough in both patient protection and labor-management relations in the health care industry. The agreement, part of a four-year contract subject to union member approval, follows more than a year of one- and two-day strikes that had contributed to Kaiser's loss of $270 million last year, the first in its 53-year history. 
 "We're going to try to set up an internal process to get problems dealt with before they become a public issue," Rose Anne DeMoro, executive director of the California Nurses Association, said.
Lila Petersen, a Kaiser spokeswoman, said, "It puts us at a new level of collaboration."
Today's agreement comes at a time of growing backlash to the managed-care industry, largely centered on complaints that H.M.O.'s are delaying or denying care, which has prompted a wave of patient protection legislation in state capitals and Congress. Kaiser invented managed care to help employers provide competent and cost-effective medicine for their workers, and its home base of Northern California became the crucible of innovation in care.
C. Richard Barnes, deputy director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, who helped expedite the negotiations, said the agreement ranked in importance with the teamsters union settlement last year with the United Parcel Service and the settlement this week of the long-running dispute between the United Automobile Workers and Caterpillar.
"And these are life-and-death issues, which are as important to the U.S. as any economic issue," Mr. Barnes said. "Nurses will play a greater role in the design of patient care. Now that's done primarily by management. We think this language will be a model for other health care negotiations across the country."
Karen Donelan, a senior research associate at the Harvard School of Public Health and co-director of a health care opinion research program there, said, "It's fascinating. People want some assurance that they can get the care they need when they need it. And they've always trusted the nurse at the bedside to be their advocate."
The settlement applies for now only to the organization's 2.7 million enrollees in Northern California and the 7,500 members of the California Nurses Association it employees in the region. The nurses had scheduled another strike for today, an ominous prospect for Kaiser, which says its cost in shifting patients and personnel in each strike was $10 million.
On economic issues, the union said it won important concessions. The nurses, who earn an average of $29 an hour or close to $60,000 a year, will receive 3 percent annual increases over the four years of the new contract.
"It sounds like the C.N.A. got exactly what they wanted," said Joanne Spetz, a health economist for the Public Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research organization in San Francisco.
But Ms. Spetz said it was the issue of the quality that the union emphasized most in its strikes, its Web page and its advertising.
Under the agreement, Kaiser will appoint 18 union-selected registered nurses to quality-liaison positions, one for each of 15 hospitals and the others to work with other Kaiser services.
"They will monitor what's going on and advocate basic patient standards, staffing levels and other things that impact the quality of care," Ms. DeMoro said.
The liaisons, she said, will bring problems in care to existing professional-practice committees at Kaiser's hospital and 28 clinics. If they are not resolved there, the liaisons will bring them to a new "labor-management quality facilitation committee" composed of three executives and three nurses.
Unlike senior management nurses who are often appointed to committees and participate in the organization's efforts to control costs, Ms. DeMoro said, the liaisons "will be independent voices independently bucking the system."
Ms. Spetz said that Kaiser management might find ways to ignore the liaisons' complaints, but that "given the C.N.A.'s history with Kaiser, I doubt that will happen."
Ms. Petersen, the Kaiser spokeswoman, said the agreement suited both sides' interest in good care.
"It's a win for Kaiser Permanente," she said. "It's a win for nurses. And it's a win for patients."
In promoting the quality issue, the union had characterized Kaiser's care as increasingly perilous for patients, with anecdotal accounts of deaths and inattention because of incompetent care by low-skilled workers and the stresses on nurses whose ranks had been reduced in layoffs.
But it produced little solid evidence of general deterioration in care. Ms. Spetz of the Public Policy Institute examined data on Kaiser staffing and found, she said, that "Kaiser has a richer skill mix than other hospitals in California on average."
She said there had been little change in the hours that registered nurses give patients in the last few years, although she said patients were typically sicker and needed more care. She looked at patient recovery from cardiac care and found that "Kaiser was right there in the middle of the pack" among hospitals.

HEADLINE: Zions to Buy Sumitomo California Bank

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Zions Bancorporation said yesterday that it would buy Sumitomo Bank Ltd.'s California bank for about $546 million in cash to expand into the state's growing Asian immigrant banking market.
Zions, of Salt Lake City, will pay Sumitomo $32.26 a share for its 85 percent stake in Sumitomo Bank of California, which is based in San Francisco. Public shareholders will get $38.25 a share, which is 24 percent below the shares' price of $50.50 at the close of trading yesterday. 
 Sumitomo, based in Osaka, Japan, said it would close its American commercial banking department, which lends to mid-size companies. The bank said it would continue capital markets operations and banking for large American corporations, which it says offer better growth and profit opportunities.
The retreat comes as Japanese banks prune operations to rebuild capital and profits. The banks are burdened by trillions of yen in bad loans, mostly real estate credits made during the "bubble" economy of the 1980's.

HEADLINE: Trade Group Is Opposing Bank Measure

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
The American Bankers Association, the Washington trade group that represents the nation's largest banks, said yesterday that it opposed a bill intended to break down barriers that separate the banking, insurance and securities businesses.
Opposition from the association, which wields significant lobbying power on Capitol Hill, throws a substantial roadblock in the way of the Republican-sponsored bill, which will go to the House floor for a vote on Tuesday. 
 Two weeks ago, Republican leaders in the House introduced the Financial Services Act of 1998, which would allow securities firms, insurance companies and commercial banks to merge under a holding company structure. Among other things, the bill would also expand the Federal Reserve's regulatory authority over these new financial groups.
Because of significant differences within the commercial banking industry on the matter, it was not entirely clear until yesterday how strongly the association would oppose the bill. But yesterday's announcement left little doubt about where the association stands.
In a letter to Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, chairman of the House Republican Conference, the party's policy-making group, the trade group said that "after giving the proposal the extensive consideration it deserves, the A.B.A. has determined it must oppose" the bill.
The association said the bill was problematic because it would weaken the regulatory authority of the Comptroller of the Currency, whose office charters national banks and who has historically been an advocate of allowing banks to pursue new lines of business. The group also cited concerns that the bill would allow state insurance regulators to limit banks' ability to sell insurance in favor of local insurance agents and that it would give the Securities and Exchange Commission unwanted authority to define banking products.
Representative Boehner said he was disappointed by the association's stance and held out hope that the trade group might still be swayed.
"We've heard from banks from across America who support this legislation, and many of them see opportunity for all in these reforms," Representative Boehner said. "I know we will have converts along the way, and we still hope to convert the members of the A.B.A. as the process continues."
Even with House approval, the bill would have to be passed by the Senate and signed by the President to become law, but even House passage promises to be much more difficult in light of the association's position. While the bill's proponents say the association's stance may be a negotiating ploy, the association is apparently committed in its opposition.
The separation of investment banking and commercial banking was required by the Glass-Steagall Act, passed in 1933 as part of Depression-era measures aimed at eliminating abuses thought to be responsible for the nation's financial collapse. Since then, any effort to change the law has been thwarted by the public's fear that broad deregulation would create a dangerous concentration of economic power or give rise to greater economic instability should a financial-services giant collapse.
Moreover, divergent interests among financial services concerns have stalled efforts to change the law, most recently in 1991 and 1995. The insurance and securities industries have largely backed the current legislation even though insurance agents once vigorously opposed it.
Small banks and savings institutions have traditionally opposed attempts to overhaul Glass-Steagall, and larger commercial banks are not speaking with one voice on the issue. Those that have big consumer banking operations and concerns about having to work with a hodgepodge of state insurance regulators, like Citicorp, oppose the bill. Others that have spent years building up their securities operations, like J. P. Morgan & Company, favor it.
"If the House doesn't act on this bill pretty fast, it's going to be hard to get something over to the Senate," said Cory Strupp, managing director for government relations with J. P. Morgan. "And if this Congress doesn't pass the financial modernization bill, it will be a fairly long time before they come back to it."
Many of the barriers separating banks and securities firms have eroded over the years as regulators and the rapidly shifting landscape in financial services have combined to allow these companies to pursue new lines of business. For example, many commercial banks now own brokerage firms or underwrite stock issues, while many brokerage firms offer mortgages or checking accounts.
But there remain limits on the revenue commercial banks can generate from securities operations, and both commercial and investment banks would like to play a much larger role in the insurance business.

HEADLINE: C. G. Sontheimer, Cuisinart Backer, Dies at 83

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Carl G. Sontheimer, a creative electronics engineer and successful entrepreneur who made his most visible contribution to the American economy -- and American kitchens -- after his retirement, died on Monday at a hospital near his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 83 and known as the man who revolutionized American cooking by bringing the Cuisinart to the United States.
His family said the cause was respiratory failure. 
 It's a shudder to think what would have happened -- or not happened -- to American cooking if Mr. Sontheimer had taken up golf.
There he was in 1971, a 57-year-old Massachusetts Institute of Technology graduate who had invented an array of technical devices, including a microwave direction finder that went to the moon, and started and sold two electronics companies, giving him the wherewithal to enjoy a well-deserved life of leisure. And he was bored.
So bored, in fact, that almost as soon as he had sold his last company, Anzac Electronics, in 1966, and completed a three-year consulting contract with the new owner, he had begun casting around for a new venture, among other things considering and rejecting a flier in home security systems.
Then, drawing on a lifelong passion for French food and French cooking, he decided to try to combine business with pleasure by finding French products suitable for an American franchising operation.
So Mr. Sontheimer, a native New Yorker who had grown up in France, where his father represented an American company, headed back to France in 1971 with his wife, Shirley, on a scouting trip.
It was there, at a French cookery show, that he spotted it, an ungainly but versatile machine designed to process food for restaurants. A sort of glorified blender whose multiple attachments allowed it to cut, slice, knead, chop, dice, grate, grind or even blend, it had been manufactured by a French restaurant supply giant, Robot-Coupe, for eight years, but Mr. Sontheimer immediately saw its possibilities for the home kitchen, specifically his.
As he told his wife, the machine would be ideal for making quenelles, those French delicacies whose meat or fish bases had to be chopped to a fare-thee-well, then laboriously forced through a sieve to achieve the proper consistency.
Moving swiftly, Mr. Sontheimer and his wife concluded an agreement to distribute a modified version of the commercial machine in the United States, then came up with the name that would soon become a household word.
"He always thought of French cooking as an art and he wanted it to be based on the word, 'cuisine,' " his wife said yesterday in explaining how they had come up with Cuisinart.
It was not until January 1973 that the Cuisinart was introduced at a show in Chicago, and for all its French lineage, the product had more than just an American touch. No wonder. Mr. Sontheimer had spent more than a year modifying virtually every component.
But then Mr. Sontheimer was never one to leave well enough alone, especially when it came to food. There was the time, for example, when he suffered such cuisine shock eating the food at his M.I.T. fraternity after years of fine dining in France that he went into the kitchen to help put things right.
He continued his interest in cooking throughout his varied career, which included stints with RCA and Maguire Industries before he founded the forerunner of Trak Electronics in 1947 and then, after selling his Trak stake in 1960, establishing Anzac to develop and manufacture precision microwave systems.
Along the way he studied French cooking in New York and became friends with James Beard, the enormous cooking master he only occasionally resembled. At a bit more than 6 feet tall, Mr. Sontheimer would periodically trim down to portly.
For all the Sontheimer improvements, the expensive Cuisinart sold sluggishly until 1975 when a rave review in Gourmet magazine and endorsements from Mr. Beard and others touched off a stampede of sales and created a new industry.
As Cuisinart sales soared, a host of competitors offered similar food processors, but although the clones were generally much less expensive, Cuisinart's acknowleded edge in quality, a Sontheimer obsession, led to a marketing anomaly in which the most expensive machine was the biggest seller.
The road to Cuisinart success was not always smooth. After winning permission from Robot-Coupe to use other suppliers, for example, Mr. Sontheimer created an improved model and had it manufactured in Japan, a move that led Robot-Coupe to market its own model in the United States, but without success.
There was also his battle with Zabar's, the Manhattan specialty food store, which sold Cuisinarts at such a deep discount that Mr. Sontheimer cut off the store's supply until his efforts ran afoul of Federal and state laws, leading to a $250,000 fine.
Partly because of fresh competition from Sunbeam's Oskar and other cheap, miniature processors, Cuisinart's sales declined in the 1980's, but when he and his wife sold the company to an investment group in 1987 the price was $42 million. The company is now owned by Conair.
After that, Mr. Sontheimer did not seek any more bold new ventures, but the man who never played golf didn't exactly retire. He continued to maintain an office in Greenwich to manage his real estate and other investments and he helped produce two cookbooks, "Classic Cakes and Other Great Cuisinart Desserts," and "The Pleasure of Cooking Fruits and Vegetables," both based on recipes from his acclaimed magazine, The Pleasure of Cooking.
And, of course, he continued to cook.
Shortly before he entered the hospital two weeks ago, his wife recalled yesterday, he had turned out a delicious rack of lamb.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by four children from a previous marriage, Peter and Henry, of Gettysburg, Pa., Katherine Rovine of Elkins Park, Md., and Barbara Young of Monroe, Conn.; a sister, Eleanor Tichner of New Canaan, Conn.; 10 grandchildren, and 3 great-granchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carl G. Sontheimer demonstrating the Cuisinart in 1982. He had discovered the machine at a cookery show in France in 1971. (Eddie Hausner/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON DECLARES U.S., WITH WORLD, FAILED RWANDANS

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: KIGALI, Rwanda, March 25

 BODY:
President Clinton came here today to talk to scarred and mutilated survivors of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda and to acknowledge that the world could have protected them, though it did not.
"We in the United States and the world community did not do as much as we could have and should have done to try to limit what occurred in Rwanda in 1994," the President told half a dozen people here who lost parents, siblings and children during three months of ethnic mass killing that claimed hundreds of thousands of lives. 
 After listening to the victims' stories of hiding among blood-soaked corpses, of being sliced with machetes, and of watching hundreds die, Mr. Clinton said in a later speech that "we cannot change the past," but that nations should learn from it. Excerpts, page A12.
Both in his meeting with the victims and the speech to an invited audience here, Mr. Clinton called for sharper vigilance against genocide and swifter prosecution of its perpetrators in a new permanent international criminal court.
He told the survivors, who gathered at the airport here, that the international community was not organized to deal with such violence.
"And we're still not organized to deal with it," he continued, citing as another example from his years in office the slow reaction to ethnic killing in Bosnia. Mr. Clinton said it took his Administration "more than two years" to reach consensus internally and with American allies "to go in and stop all that killing."
In April 1994, the United States decided to take no action in Rwanda, fearing the risks outweighed the potential rewards. The decision was codified in a Presidential directive, signed by Mr. Clinton the following month, which limited American participation in international peacekeeping operations.
And in those months, while the massacres were raging, the Clinton Administration successfully argued against a United Nations effort that, in retrospect, might have saved hundreds of thousands of lives, according to United Nations officers, former Administration officials and human-rights advocates. Page A12.
Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat who is traveling with the President, said Mr. Clinton felt guilty that the United States had not intervened early on to halt the Rwandan genocide. But in his speech here, the President did not go as far as he did in his talk with the survivors toward accepting blame for the United States.
In the speech, delivered to a couple of hundred diplomats and Rwandan Government officials, Mr. Clinton did not single out the United States, but said that the "international community, together with nations in Africa, must bear its share of responsibility for this tragedy, as well."
He called the genocide, which he said resulted in at least a million deaths in 90 days, "the most intensive slaughter in this blood-filled century we are about to leave."
Mr. Clinton repeatedly said that the genocide was planned. "It is important that the world know that these killings were not spontaneous or accidental," he said.
As at other stops on his 12-day tour, Mr. Clinton was greeted here by dancers and drummers as he arrived in a drizzle at the airport, which rests among hills quilted with dark green forests and light green fields. Two little girls in white dresses presented him with flowers. But the tone of the President's visit was pensive, and often sad.
The Clinton Administration had planned this trip as an upbeat tour of African nations with growing economies and strengthening democracies. In advance of the President's appearance today, officials said that Mr. Clinton would acknowledge inaction by the world, but not specifically by the United States, to stop the Rwanda massacres.
But they appear to have underestimated Mr. Clinton's signature willingness to empathize with suffering, and he went further than they expected, at least in his impromptu remarks to survivors. The White House permitted one newspaper reporter to attend the meeting as a representative of the press corps.
Mr. Clinton's remarks today followed a speech in Uganda on Tuesday in which he departed from his prepared text to express regret for American failures in Africa, from benefiting from the slave trade to dealing with dictators.
The United States was more resistant than some of its European allies to putting a large United Nations force in Rwanda after leaders of the majority ethnic group here, the Hutu, began a campaign to wipe out a minority, the Tutsi, in April 1994. The Clinton Administration had just been scalded by its peace mission in Somalia, in which 18 American soldiers died.
Tutsi rebels, operating from bases in Uganda, succeeded in replacing the Hutu regime that year with what is essentially a military government. The President here, Pasteur Bizimungu, is a Hutu, and the Clinton Administration is persuaded that the Tutsi-dominated Government is bent on national reconciliation and democracy.
But the genocide still reverberates here. Hutu insurgents are fighting in the northwest, and Rwandan troops have been accused of killing civilians in reprisals for their raids.
"Our post-genocidal society is fragile," warned President Bizimungu, in a speech in which he thanked Mr. Clinton for his "commitment to helping our people overcome the ravages of genocide." He said that in judging the progress of Rwanda, other nations should treat it as a "special case."
As he listened to the survivors' stories, the President appeared moved, thanking some in a voice choked with emotion. Venuste Karasira was among nearly 4,000 people who took refuge during the genocide in a school protected by Belgian paratroopers. But the troops were withdrawn; Hutu militia members entered the school and killed all but 400 of those hiding there.
"I had to find some dead corpses," said Mr. Karasira, who lost his right hand in the attack. "I swim in their blood to survive." He added, "We died because we were left by the United Nations soldiers." When he finished, Mr. Clinton appeared unable to speak. He simply nodded for the next account.
One of those who met with Mr. Clinton, Gloriosa Uwimpuhwe, said later that he "behaved as a real, real human being who felt what people were saying, even though he did not see it himself." Ms. Uwimpuhwe said that she considered Mr. Clinton's acknowledgment of United States inaction to be an apology. "He said that he not only is sorry, but he's looking forward to taking positive options for the future," she said.
The audience for his subsequent speech enthusiastically greeted Mr. Clinton today, and interrupted him with applause each time he acknowledged error by the international community.
Several Rwandans here said that the United States, like other nations, should have acted earlier to stop the genocide, but they seemed less interested in pointing fingers than in moving on. "Everybody is to blame," said Sam Nkusi, a government official. He said that "to feel the President of the United States shares our sadness and the tragedy with us is very good."
Rwanda was added late to Mr. Clinton's tour. Administration officials said Secret Service nervousness, not White House fears of addressing genocide, delayed the decision. After analyzing the situation here, the Secret Service agreed to a Presidential visit, officials said. But Mr. Clinton did not leave the airport during his three and a half hours here, and the engines of Air Force One never ceased idling. Mr. Clinton arrived in Cape Town, South Africa, early Thursday, Reuters reported.
To the disappointment of some Rwandan officials, Mr. Clinton did not even visit the genocide memorial built at the airport in advance of his visit. The Secret Service considered the site, on a hillock, to be too exposed to the surrounding hills, said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman.
In his speech, Mr. Clinton pointed to three errors by the international community: not acting quickly to halt the killing; permitting refugee camps in neighboring Zaire to become havens for Hutu killers, and not immediately labeling the slaughter "genocide."
Although the killing here was widely reported, Mr. Clinton suggested that he did not appreciate its magnitude at the time. "All over the world there were people like me sitting in offices, day after day after day, who did not fully appreciate the depth and the speed with which you were being engulfed by this unimaginable terror."
But Mr. Clinton looked to the future as well. "We must have global vigilance," he said. "And never again must we be shy in the face of the evidence."
The President said that "at the dawn of the new millennium there is only one crucial division" among people, and it was not that between Hutu and Tutsi or Arabs and Jews. "It is really the line between those who embrace the common humanity we all share and those who reject it."
Mr. Clinton then looked up and declared with emotion: "When you look at those children who greeted us as we got off that plane today, how could anyone say they did not want those children to have a chance to have their own children? To experience the joy of another morning sunrise? To learn the normal lessons of life? To give something back to their people?"

HEADLINE: BLOODSHED IN A SCHOOLYARD: THE REGION;
Six Leaders In East Africa Agree to Build Democracies

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ENTEBBE, Uganda, March 25

 BODY:
After a three-hour meeting at a lakeside hotel here, President Clinton secured a commitment from six East African leaders today to work toward building more democratic governments in their countries and to prevent genocide in this strife-torn region.
But beyond vague pledges about regional cooperation, a communique issued by the leaders was short on details about how a raft of lofty sounding goals, including protecting human rights and expanding trade, would be accomplished. On democracy, for instance, the agreement contains several loopholes and caveats that would allow one-party systems, like the one in Uganda, to continue. 
 The six African leaders pledged only to "pursue a dialogue on democratization" that "recognizes there is no fixed model for democratic institutions" and "explores alternative approaches to the democratic management of cultural diversity," according to the communique.
Mr. Clinton said: "America knows from our own experience that there is no single blueprint for a successful democracy. We're still working in our country to create what our founders called a more perfect union."
The meeting was the culmination of Mr. Clinton's two-day visit to Uganda, the second country in his tour of Africa to promote a new American policy toward the continent, which Mr. Clinton's aides say would stress trade and investment.
The meeting came just hours after the President visited neighboring Rwanda and gave a moving address in which he said the United States had not done enough to stop the genocide there in 1994, in which more than a half-million Tutsi people were killed by Hutu militias.
In their communique, the seven leaders promised to prevent massacres, among other things, denying safe havens to political extremists who advocate genocide.
"We have agreed to work together to banish genocide from this region," Mr. Clinton said after signing the communique. "Our efforts come too late for yesterday's victims. They must be in time to prevent tomorrow's victims."
The agreement was signed by the United States, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda, Congo (the former Zaire) and Ethiopia, as well as an envoy from the Organization of African Unity. In the talks Mr. Clinton held out the possibility that he would support more debt relief for East African countries and promised to restore direct American aid to Africa to its historically high level of about $813 million a year, said Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser.
But Mr. Clinton also made it clear that in return the United States expected economic and political changes that would insure human rights, expand their democracies and create a stable environment for investors, Mr. Berger said.

(Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Statehood

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It was sad to see Rosario Ferre choose statehood for Puerto Rico ("Puerto Rico, U.S.A.," Op-Ed, March 19). Like most Puerto Rican writers and artists, Ms. Ferre had been a supporter of independence for the island.
Most Puerto Rican writers and artists advocate independence for linguistic and cultural reasons. The Spanish language is the repository of Puerto Rican history and culture, and it could well be endangered under statehood. For most Puerto Rican writers, the possible loss of Spanish and the accompanying symbolic elements of Puerto Rican culture is tantamount to cultural death. 
 Ms. Ferre's argument that statehood for Puerto Rico no longer need mean being swallowed up by the majority culture because of the growth of the Hispanic community and the advances of multiculturalism in the United States is unconvincing.
Harsh economic and social realities are still faced by most Hispanic people, and there is opposition in many parts of the United States toward the use of Spanish in education and at work.
 
ANIBAL GONZALEZ
University Park, Pa., March 20, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of Spanish at Pennsylvania State University.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Indonesian Students Clash With Police

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 25

 BODY:
Rock-throwing students fought with the police and troops today in the most violent clash so far in a monthlong series of anti-Government protests on Indonesian campuses.
Security forces shot tear gas into the crowd and used sticks and clubs to beat back about 1,000 students who tried to stage an illegal street march in Solo, 250 miles east of Jakarta, witnesses said. 
 Witnesses said at least 10 police officers and 39 protesters were wounded at the public March 11 University, named for the date President Suharto assumed special powers to restore order during an earlier period of national instability.
Students have been protesting a lack of democracy in Indonesia and Mr. Suharto's failure to reverse a plunge in the value of Indonesia's currency.
The fighting broke out hours after the United States announced it would send $56 million in food and medical aid to ease the suffering of millions of Indonesians impoverished by their worst economic crisis in 30 years.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
This Time All Women, No Spiders

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON 

 BODY:
Entering the Intar theater for Manuel Puig's "Mystery of the Rose Bouquet," the audience encounters a woman asleep in a hospital bed. As the play begins, a nurse arrives, changes the flowers in a vase and is about to filch some sleeping pills from a night stand when the patient awakes. It is quickly established that the woman, identified only as the Patient, has been depressed since the death of her grandson 14 months ago and has been hospitalized for a nervous condition. We soon learn, of course, that she is as strong as a horse.
For the second offering in a joint project with the New Federal Theater and Pan Asian Rep to present three plays from three cultures over three months, Intar Hispanic American Arts Center has mounted a satisfying production of Puig's intriguing psychological comedy. 
 The Patient, a strong-willed, intelligent and wealthy widow, goes through nurses like tissues, and this one is her fourth in a week. The nurse presents herself as a poor and self-effacing wretch who eats her patients' leftover hospital food to economize, is separated from her husband and is so bereft of self-confidence she never even finished high school let alone earned her nursing certificate. By the end of the first act, however, it is clear that what little the audience has learned about these women may or may not be true.
Puig, an Argentine who died in 1990, is best known as the author of "Kiss of the Spider Woman," a novel that was turned into a play, a film and then a Broadway musical. "The Mystery of the Rose Bouquet," which was written in 1981, is similar in structure and theme: two characters from diverse backgrounds are thrown together in a confined space (a prison cell in "Spider Woman" and the hospital room in "Rose Bouquet") and through their initial confrontations discover mutual dependence, even affection.
For Puig a person's true self is known only through dreams, fantasies and fears, and in "Rose Bouquet" these are uncovered through stream-of-consciousness scenes that are spliced into the main narrative. It is through these sequences, played almost as asides, that the audience finally comes to know the truth about the characters. Both the Patient and the Nurse secretly carry a burden of betrayal that has come to define their outward lives.
Under Max Ferra's direction, the Intar production captures the vitality of Puig's modest tale, and the segueing in and out of the dream sequences, always difficult onstage, is fluid and seamless on Van Santvoord's functional set. Little directorial touches flesh out the characters, like having the Nurse continually tuck in the sheets of the hospital bed only to have the Patient absent-mindedly pull them out again. Virginia Rambal turns in a credible performance as the Patient, although at times during an early preview she seemed more concerned with the pillows at her back than what was happening onstage. Doris DeFarnecio delivers a fine low-key portrayal of the Nurse, who actually likes hospital food.
 
MYSTERY OF THE ROSE BOUQUET
 
By Manuel Puig; directed by Max Ferra; translation by Allan King from the Spanish; dramaturge, Lorenzo Mans; sets by Van Santvoord; costumes by Ricardo Morin; lighting by Robert Williams; sound by Johnna Doti; production manager, Kai Brothers; stage manager, Sergio Cruz. Presented by Intar Hispanic American Arts Center, Mr. Ferra, artistic director; Ellen Zisholtz-Herzog, managing director. At 420 West 42d Street, Clinton.

WITH: Virginia Rambal (Patient) and Doris DiFarnecio (Nurse).

CORRECTION-DATE: March 27, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A theater review yesterday Thurs about "Mystery of the Rose Bouquet" at the Intar Hispanic American Arts Center misspelled the surname of a star. She is Doris DiFarnecio, as shown in the credits listing, not DeFarnecio.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Up 4,000

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The number of newly idled workers filing for unemployment benefits edged up by 4,000 in the latest week to the highest level in a month, the Labor Department said today.
Initial jobless claims, which give an early reading on the resilience of the labor market, rose to 313,000 in the week that ended on Saturday, up from 309,000 in the previous week and the highest since 320,000 in the week ended Feb. 21, the Labor Department said. 
 The weekly jobs data, which Wall Street analysts had forecast at 308,000, remain at levels typical of a healthy United States economy, one that was entering its eighth year of uninterrupted expansion.
The four-week average, viewed as a more accurate indicator of longer-term labor conditions, measured 306,500 in the latest week, down from 308,250 a week earlier.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Party Backs $124 Billion Economic Plan

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 26

 BODY:
After hemming and hawing and hinting for weeks, the dominant Liberal Democratic Party today approved a package valued at $124 billion intended to spur the foundering Japanese economy and reduce the risk that Japan will set off a global economic slowdown.
This would be Japan's largest stimulant package ever, but it is still unclear whether it will revive the world's second-largest economy and help Asia escape its financial crisis. With wages, prices and corporate profits sliding, Japan is swerving toward a recession, and the Government has been forced to admit that even its one-tenth of a percent growth target for the 1997 fiscal year, which ends next Tuesday, may be too high. 
 The economic stimulus marks an about-face for Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, who had previously argued that Japan could not afford to spend more at a time when its budget deficit was rapidly expanding. Still, Mr. Hashimoto has been giving ground lately after coming under intense pressure from the Clinton Administration to take such dramatic steps to bolster the economy.
The package will take the form of extra Government spending, without any of the major tax cuts sought by Washington. But on the whole, the package is a major step toward what the United States had repeatedly advised. Moreover, this evening, Mr. Hashimoto revealed a willingness to consider a shift in the Government's steadfast policy of fiscal austerity to allow for bolder measures, such as large tax cuts, to boost the economy, according to Yomiuri Shimbun, a leading Japanese daily.
Governing party leaders have been divided over whether tax cuts to individuals would actually be spent, which would help invigorate the economy, or saved, which would not. Yomiuri Shimbun, however, said the Liberal Democratic Party was leaning toward a tax cut and might propose one in time for the economic summit meeting in May of the Group of Seven countries.
The business community had been hoping for tax cuts. But the Tokyo stock market still rose today on the news, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 jumping 322.28 points, or nearly 2 percent, to close at 16,980.62.
Mr. Hashimoto did not formally announce the new package today, but the Liberal Democratic Party, which Mr. Hashimoto heads, summoned Japanese reporters and leaked it to them. Cabinet ministers are expected to approve the proposal on Friday and details will be worked out after the annual budget is passed by the Parliament next month.
Information on the package was sketchy. But economists say the central question is how much money will actually be poured into the economy. In the past, the Government has assembled stimulus packages that included large sums of loans or other measures that did not actually put new money into the economy.
"It's certainly better than nothing, but the next question is how much of it is real water?" Richard Koo, chief economist at Nomura Research Institute, said of the latest stimulus plan. "Exactly how much the Government puts into the income stream is what matters at the end of the day, not how much money is spent -- but whether it is spent at all."
Mr. Koo said if even half of the package, $62 billion worth, "were indeed real money, then it will have a huge impact."
Most of the $124 billion package, the equivalent of about 3 percent of national economic output, would pour money into public works projects, according to Kyodo News Service. In the past, these have often been criticized as unnecessary pork-barrel projects, but economists said that money spent that way would nonetheless improve growth.
The package also offers loans for Japan's ailing Asian neighbors and it aims at reaching a broad swath of the economy. It will invest in the environment, in technology and telecommunications, such as fiber optics, and it includes measures to deal with the nation's aging population.
The Government will use public funds to encourage growth of the market for asset-backed securities to help banks dispose of bad real estate loans. It will channel cash from the nation's postal savings institution into stocks to strengthen the stock market. This move, however, is likely to be criticized by some economists as Government interference in the stock market.
Other measures that may not have a large fiscal impact include initiatives to encourage entrepreneurs to manage infrastructure projects and charge fees on roads they build; to ask local governments to spend their own money on public works, and to promote urban redevelopment and land purchases for public use.
The proposal also calls for examining tax breaks for social welfare and education and for considering cuts in income and corporate taxes to bring them in line with international standards.
The last time Japan poured so much money into the economy was in the fall of 1995, when it announced a package worth 14.2 trillion yen, about $110 billion at current exchange rates. The real spending amounted to slightly more than half of that amount, according to Mr. Koo, and the result was annual economic growth in 1996 of more than 3 percent, the highest growth rate among the Group of Seven nations.
The lower house of Parliament passed a $600 billion budget last week that essentially squeezed as much as $27 billion out of the economy, according to economists. So a fair amount of today's package will be compensating for that hole.
Some critics said that the package is aimed mainly at awarding public works projects in areas that will help politicians win votes in the coming election for members in the upper house of Parliament. Tax cuts would be less effective, critics say, in directly bringing in votes from constituencies.
"The Hashimoto administration is now considering how to cope with the upcoming election, and a tax reduction is another alternative, but it's not so useful in mobilizing people in the constituencies," said Toru Nakakita, a professor at Toyo University in Tokyo. "So the U.S. and outside pressure comes at a timely moment. It makes it easier for the L.D.P. to find a pretext for pouring money into its constituencies."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Morgan Stanley's Income Increases 21% in Quarter

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company said yesterday that net income for the quarter ended Feb. 28 increased 21 percent, to $691 million, or $1.10 a fully diluted share.
The earnings announcement, which continues the run of high profits from big Wall Street firms this week, beat analysts' estimates of $1.06 a share, said Charles Hill, director of research at First Call, a stock research firm in Boston. 
 While Morgan Stanley's earnings were good, they lost some of their impact because they came just a day after strong earnings from Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., and a couple of days after earnings numbers from Goldman, Sachs & Company, which on Monday reported record profits before taxes of more than $1 billion.
Earnings from Morgan Stanley's credit card business declined in the latest quarter, touching off renewed speculation that the firm might eventually sell its Discover credit card business, which some analysts say is neither sufficiently large nor sufficiently profitable.
These earnings, for Morgan Stanley's first fiscal quarter of 1998, were bolstered by the firm's securities business, where net income rose 31 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. Morgan Stanley, with its prosperous Wall Street capital markets business, has been able to use Dean Witter's network of offices and army of brokers to sell a lot more of its securities offerings.
Morgan Stanley & Company and Dean Witter, Discover & Company announced their merger just over a year ago, and this week voted at the firm's annual shareholder meeting to simplify the company's name to Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, dropping the word Discover, the name for the company's credit card business. This change of name "was a recognition that the name was quite a mouthful," the company's financial officer said in an interview yesterday.
Analysts generally praise the merger of the two firms. "They seem to have put this thing together in a way that enables both parties to do more," said James Hanbury, an analyst at Schroder & Company, commenting on Morgan Stanley's ability to push more of its products through Dean Witter's salesmen.
"The broker side was just fantastic," said Thomas P. Facciola, a Lehman analyst, who said Morgan Stanley Dean Witter was the only brokerage stock his firm was recommending. "The momentum continues to be building. We weren't expecting much for the card business, but it was a tad below our expectations."
"The environment is just incredible," Mr. Facciola added, remarking on the combination of low interest rates, low inflation, strong investor interest in stocks and soaring stock prices, that has helped to push the stock markets to new records in recent days."
"I thought they looked good," said Sallie L. Krawcheck, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a brokerage firm. "There is a lot of good news coming out of the firm's securities business, both market-driven and merger-driven." But, she added, "the market was disappointed with Morgan Stanley's credit card business," where first-quarter net declined 21 percent from a year ago, to $99 million.
Schroder's Mr. Hanbury pointed out that under the pooling arrangement that Morgan and Dean Witter used to complete the merger, the combined company would have to allow two years to pass after the merger date before any sale of its credit card business. As for whether there might be such a sale, Mr. Hanbury said: "A year ago, I'd have said 'no.' Today, I don't really know, but it's more of a possibility."
Morgan's Mr. Scott, however, denied that the firm had any such intention. "We're not abandoning Discover," he said.
Shares of Morgan Stanley fell $2.5625 yesterday, to $73.125.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall on Concern in Advance of Fed Meeting

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities prices were lower yesterday, weighed down by new supply and market uneasiness ahead of next week's Federal Reserve meeting on monetary policy.
Still, the 30-year bond slipped only 14/32, to a price of 102 6/32, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.97 percent, from 5.94 percent on Wednesday. The yield on the two-year note rose to 5.62 percent, from 5.57 percent the day before. 
 Contributing to the seeming lack of direction were several reports that painted a mixed picture of the economy. Initial claims for unemployment benefits rose last week, the Government said, suggesting that the labor market may be softening a bit. The Conference Board's help-wanted index, which measures the level of classified job advertising, strengthened, however.
But Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said of the help-wanted report, "Many investors have recently been taking the results of this survey with a grain of salt since it measures only the amount of advertising that takes place rather than the true intentions of firms." Meanwhile, final figures for growth in gross domestic product in the fourth quarter showed that the economy grew slightly more slowly than was indicated in the preliminary estimates. The Commerce Department also said that after-tax corporate profits slipped in the fourth quarter.
In trading yesterday, securities with shorter maturities led the market lower, as traders tried to distribute the new Treasury securities sold this week. The auctions began on Tuesday with a sale of two-year notes that was in line with expectations. The results of Wednesday's sale of five-year notes was disappointing, however, but yesterday's $11 billion auction of one-year bills went well enough, with the average rate at auction 5.110 percent, about as expected.
Many market participants said they thought that the shrinking size of recent bill auctions would help the bills get distributed after this week's sales. Others said, however, that they expected some difficulties because of a report on Wednesday of strong home resales during February; it hinted at possible inflationary pressure in the economy, which some traders fear could make the Federal Reserve react by raising interest rates. The short-maturity end of the Treasury market is particularly sensitive to interest rates.
Still, though the Fed's Open Market Committee meets next week, most analysts expect it to keep interest rates unchanged. Not including the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, the Treasury sold $36 billion in Government securities this week.
