HEADLINE: Corporations' Profits Fell In 4th Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The Asian financial crisis contributed to the first drop in corporate profits in more than a year despite a healthy rate of growth in the economy as a whole, the Commerce Department said today.
After-tax corporate profits slipped 2.3 percent in the fourth quarter of 1997, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $483.7 billion. 
 And the United States economy grew at a slower pace than previously estimated in last year's fourth quarter. The gross domestic product, the total output of goods and services, rose at a 3.7 percent annual rate, the Commerce Department reported, down from an earlier 3.9 percent estimate because consumer spending on services was not as robust as first calculated.
After-tax corporate profits in last year's fourth quarter, reported today for the first time, fell 2.3 percent after rising 4.2 percent during the third quarter. It was the first decline since the third quarter of 1996.
While a slowdown in exports and a rise in cheaper Asian imports may trim growth this year, analysts say the United States economy is on track for an eighth consecutive year of expansion. Consumer spending and housing "are going gangbusters," said Lyle Gramley, a former Federal Reserve governor who is now an economic consultant at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
In 1997, the economy expanded by 3.8 percent, topping 1996's 2.8 percent growth and the strongest showing in nine years. Not adjusted for inflation, the United States economy's output was $8.1 trillion in 1997, representing more than a quarter of total global output of goods and services.
In the first quarter, which ends Tuesday, the economy probably grew at a 3.5 percent annual rate, according to Russ Sheldon, an economist at MCM Moneywatch.
The final fourth-quarter gross domestic product figure is lower than the Government's previous growth rate estimates from February and January of 3.9 percent and 4.3 percent, respectively. The Government issues three estimates of each quarter's gross domestic product as more information becomes available. Analysts had expected no change in the latest report.
A lower estimate for fourth-quarter consumer spending on services more than offset a higher estimate for spending on aircraft, Commerce Department figures showed, accounting for the latest revision. Real final sales, which exclude the effects of inventory changes, rose 2.3 percent in the fourth quarter, previously reported as a 2.5 percent increase.
Inventories rose in the fourth quarter at a 1.4 percent annual rate. That inventory buildup accounted for much of the increase in growth during the final three months of the year.
Inflation, meantime, barely registered a blip on the Government's radar screen. The gross domestic product price deflator, a measure of prices followed by many investors, grew at an unrevised 1.4 percent annual pace in the fourth quarter. The deflator also rose 1.4 percent in the third quarter, the smallest since a nine-tenths of 1 percent increase in the second quarter of 1964.

HEADLINE: Senate Backs I.M.F. Funds, And Girds for Fight in House

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The Senate today overwhelmingly approved $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund, setting up a fight with the House, which has attached a divisive anti-abortion provision to the financing measure.
Underscoring the Senate's urgency for replenishing the monetary fund's treasury, which has been strained by the Asian financial crisis, Senators voted 84-16 to attach the new financing to a popular, $5 billion emergency spending bill for military operations and disaster relief for domestic flood and storm victims. Senators completed work on the spending bill and must now await House action on a companion bill. 
 Senate supporters hope the lopsided vote will persuade the House in a conference committee to act quickly on the disaster aid bill -- with the I.M.F financing tucked in -- or risk the wrath of catastrophe-hit constituents.
But House conservatives are balking. Republican leaders have separated the monetary fund financing from the House version of the disaster aid bill, and have said that the House will not vote on the financing package until late April, when lawmakers return from a spring recess.
Even then the I.M.F. bill in the House includes a measure, unpopular with many conservative Republicans, to pay $505 million in back dues of the nearly $1 billion that the United States owes the United Nations and other international organizations. House Republicans are also holding up the monetary fund financing until President Clinton agrees to an anti-abortion provision that the White House has said he would veto.
The House is also on a collision course with the White House by insisting that money for the emergency military spending and disaster aid package come from cutting $2.9 billion from some of Mr. Clinton's prized domestic programs. These include low-income housing and the Americorps national service program.
The Senate opposes this approach, but Republican leaders say it is the only way to pay for the military operations in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf and for the disaster aid while staying within the caps set in last year's balanced budget agreement.
By pursuing this path, the House risks replaying last summer's impasse over disaster aid just as Congress was leaving on a long recess, a public relations debacle that few Republicans want to remember, much less repeat.
"I urge you not to take actions that could result in gridlock and that would be detrimental both to our troops abroad and to our citizens at home at their time in need," said the White House Chief of Staff, Erskine Bowles.
The monetary fund financing has exposed deep divisions among House and Senate Republicans, and has become enmeshed not only in American international interests but also in fiercely partisan domestic politics.
Resolving the many differences between the two chambers will probably have to wait until House and Senate negotiators meet in late April to work out a final version of the emergency spending bill for the Pentagon and disaster aid. Much of what is happening now is jockeying for leverage to take into those negotiations.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin praised the Senate's action today, saying in a statement that the vote "is a major step toward providing the I.M.F. with the resources necessary to deal with risks to financial stability around the world."
The Senate has also prepared a back-up strategy, a stand-alone monetary fund financing bill that could be negotiated in a conference committee if the House approves its I.M.F. financing bill with the United Nations dues and anti-abortion provision.
The hurdles, however, are high. The abortion provision, which would bar the Government from giving aid to international organizations that lobby foreign countries to change their abortion laws, was contentious enough last year to stalemate a bill to pay the United Nations arrears and reorganize the State Department.
Today the House approved by voice vote to reprise the failed bill. That legislation approves the payment of nearly $1 billion in back dues to the United Nations, reorganizes the State Department and approves $38 million to finance democratic efforts in Iraq.
But this legislation, unlike the emergency spending bills, has no ready companion in the Senate, and contains the anti-abortion language. Tonight Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, urged Mr. Clinton to sign the bill.
The anger among Republicans over the monetary fund financing, which until now has largely bubbled below the surface, boiled over this week when some Senate Republicans, particularly from Pacific coast and farm states, accused their House counterparts of sabotaging American economic interests.
"If we don't act, the country better get ready for a slide" in the United States stock market, said Senator Ted Stevens, an Alaska Republican who heads the Appropriations Committee.
Earlier in the week, Senator Stevens said he did not want to see "games played with the I.M.F.," adding, "The I.M.F. is serious to us."
The monetary fund financing package includes $3.5 billion for a new line of emergency credit and $14.5 billion for the American portion of the I.M.F. reserves.
The package includes conditions on the $14.5 billion that would require the Treasury Secretary to certify that the Group of seven leading industrialized countries insure that borrowing countries live up to their international trade obligations and eliminate preferential subsidies.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
New East Harlem Co-op Is Priced for Wide Range

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
A vacant block along Madison Avenue in East Harlem from 123d to 124th Streets is coming back to life as a cooperative apartment complex designed to be affordable to people with low to upper-middle incomes.
The complex, called Maple Plaza, will have 155 one-to-three-bedroom units ranging from 650 to 1,040 square feet. The apartments will be sold for an average of $7,600 each because of an unusual financing structure that blends public subsidies with private money. 
 Eighty percent of the apartments will be offered to people with annual incomes from $32,000 to $70,000. The remaining 20 percent will be made available to people with incomes of as much as $118,000.
Maple Plaza will have 12,000 square feet of ground-level medical office space. The complex is eight stories high in the middle, with two six-story wings, and the building is set back from Madison Avenue and overlooks Marcus Garvey Park. Parking in a lot at the complex will be available for $85 a month. The apartment complex also has a laundry room and a landscaped courtyard in the rear.
Construction of Maple Plaza, which began in late 1996, will cost $20.9 million. Completion is expected in July, when residents are scheduled to be moving in.
Maple Plaza is the second project developed under a plan devised in the early 1990's by the city and North General Hospital to revive the six-block area along Madison Avenue around the hospital, which is the neighborhood's largest employer.
The first project, Maple Court, with 135 units, was completed in 1995, just north of the hospital on the block from 122d to 123d Streets. A third project, with 140 units, is tentatively planned two blocks south of the hospital from 119th to 120th Streets.
Sparrow Construction Corporation of the Bronx, which developed Maple Court, is also developing Maple Plaza. The complex was designed by Architecture for Health, Science and Commerce of Tarrytown, N.Y, which designed North General Hospital.
Eugene L. McCabe, president of the hospital, said, "Now with two projects, there is the impetus for rebuilding the neighborhood."
Barry Zelikson, director of development at Sparrow, said the success of Maple Court led his company to get involved with Maple Plaza. "What we found with the initial project is that potential buyers wanted to come back to the neighborhood, but we had to turn lots of them away because their incomes were too high," Mr. Zelikson said. "So we increased the income threshold for 30 units, providing for a healthy economic mix."
Joseph Pagan, vice president of Community Board 11, which helps guide growth in the area, would like to see marketing efforts that "reach a broader ethnic mix." Additional housing has helped build the neighborhood's tax base and change how people perceive East Harlem, Mr. Pagan said, but he added, "A community only prospers when the housing is offered to all its members."
The new apartments, like the earlier ones, are being sold through a lottery, and 40 percent of the units are reserved for neighborhood residents.
Maple Plaza, like Maple Court, is being built as a limited equity co-op, and any profits from resale of the units must be split evenly with the city, which provided most of the money to build the complex.
Buyers benefit from prices that have been kept low because of a novel financing plan. Maple Plaza is being financed partly by a $16.7 million mortgage provided by the city's Housing Development Corporation through the sale of tax-exempt bonds. In addition, the apartment complex has secured $2.72 million in city subsidies and a $15.6 million construction loan from Chase Bank.
Typically, a buyer of a share in co-op apartment building makes a down payment of about 20 percent and obtains a loan to pay off the rest. In addition to making payments on a personal mortgage, the shareholder pays a monthly maintenance fee, part of which is used to pay the co-op's underlying mortgage, which is secured by the entire building.
But at Maple Plaza, prices are set low -- ranging from $4,971 to $10,171 -- enabling many of the purchasers to buy the apartments without a loan. The co-op has a larger underlying mortgage, which buyers help pay through their monthly maintenance fees, which in turn are high, ranging from $729 to $1,240. On an apartment priced at $7,600, for example, the buyer's share of the building's underlying mortgage would be estimated at $105,000, and the buyer's monthly maintenance fee would be $925, 65 percent of which would be used to pay the building's debt.
The interest rate on Maple Plaza's mortgage is a relatively low 6.25 percent a year, helping to keep monthly fees comparable to what a high-end rental unit in the area would cost, said Mr. Zelikson of Sparrow. The rent from the office space, which North General Hospital plans to occupy, will also help, as will a 20-year property tax abatement from the city, he said.
Since sales began four months ago, contracts have been signed on 50 apartments and reservations taken on 13, Mr. Zelikson said.
Danny Bell, a city bus driver, and his wife, Maritza, a social worker, hope to close on a two-bedroom apartment in Maple Plaza by this summer. The monthly cost of their co-op will be slightly higher than the $780 in rent on their apartment in Flushing, Queens, Mr. Bell said, adding, "and now we own a home."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Maple Plaza, an apartment building under construction in East Harlem. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bernard Meltzer, Dispenser Of Advice on Radio, Dies at 81

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Bernard Meltzer, the folksy foggy-voiced radio personality who built a huge following in the 20 years that he dispensed advice over WOR-AM in New York on virtually every known problem and every conceivable subject, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 81 and widely regarded as the father of "expert talk radio."
His wife said the cause was complications from pneumonia. 
 "Remember," the announcer intoned, "Dr. Meltzer is not an attorney."
Come to think of it, his doctorate -- a mail-in degree in philosophy, economics and finance from the unaccredited Columbia Pacific University in California -- was not all that kosher, either.
Never mind. When Dr. Meltzer spoke, people listened, and with such rapt attention and in such numbers -- almost 600,000 listeners an hour at his peak in the mid-80's -- that he was on the air for 23 hours a week, from 3 to 6 on weekday afternoons and 10 to 2 on weekends until 1993.
What they heard when they tuned into his program, "What's Your Problem?" was an engaging grandfatherly presence who sometimes mispronounced words or garbled syntax but who addressed bereaved widows as "Mother," included a prayer on every program and instilled such confidence with his wide-ranging expertise and common-sense wisdom that at a time when WOR sold commercials for $350 a minute, the fee was $500 if Dr. Meltzer, himself, read them.
For all that, the personal touch could be quite a bargain, especially if Dr. Meltzer departed from the text, as he frequently did. When he got wound up, an ad-libbed 60-second ad could last for two and a half minutes.
An eclectic expert, Dr. Meltzer had a legitimate degree in civil engineering from City College and a master's in economics and city planning from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.
Dr. Meltzer, who was born in Manhattan, liked to say that he was born in the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge and that his immigrant father had delivered seltzer from a wagon on the Lower East Side. By the time he joined WOR in 1973, Dr. Meltzer had worked as an engineer, a real estate contractor, a property evaluator and an investment analyst. He had taught real estate, finance and economics as an adjunct professor at the University of Pennsylvania and was chairman of the Philadelphia Planning Commission.
He also made a surprising name for himself as a radio personality. In a story he loved to tell, Dr. Meltzer, who had been a frequent guest on a number of Philadelphia programs, was pressed into service in 1967 as an emergency replacement for a departing host on WCAU. On his first day, he mispronounced so many sponsors' names, mangled so much ad copy and generally gave such a dismal performance that the station manager fired him on the spot, only to rescind the dismissal after learning from his supervisors that listeners had flooded the station switchboard and his sponsors' telephone lines with adoring calls.
When he moved to New York almost six years later, Dr. Meltzer proved even more popular. Although only a handful of callers could get through on a program, hundreds of thousands of others hung on his every word as he advised on mortgages, leaky basements, Medicaid, feuding neighbors, retirement plans, recalcitrant children and philandering husbands, or, as Dr. Meltzer put it, "everything from affairs of the heart to affairs of the pocketbook."
It was not uncommon for a caller to begin by saying that he had been trying to get through for years, apparently realizing that whatever long-forgotten problem had prompted the effort another one would surely have popped up by the time the caller got through and could wheedle a signature T-shirts.
Except for personal appearances and a brief television stint that his friend Joe Franklin had him do on WOR-TV in the early 70's, Dr. Meltzer was largely unseen, which meant that he could move around unnoticed, at least until he opened his mouth.
His wife, Meredith, recalled yesterday that she and her husband, who loved Broadway musicals, opera and ballet, would be eating at a restaurant or on a cruise when someone at the next table hear his distinctive voice and say with startled delight, "Why, you're Bernard Meltzer."
In addition to his wife, who lives in Long Branch, N.J., he is survived by four children from a previous marriage, Melinda Jacobs of Milburn, N.J., Cynthia Weller of Philadelphia, Lesley Silverstein of Washington and Michael Meltzer of Westport, Conn.; two sisters, Rae Fieldman and Dora Glatter of Brooklyn, and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Crisis in Asia Contributes To Fall in Corporate Profits
The financial turmoil in Asia helped push American companies' after-tax profits down 2.3 percent in the fourth quarter, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $483.7 billion. 
 And the economy grew at a slower pace than previously estimated in last year's fourth quarter. The gross domestic product rose at a 3.7 percent annual rate, down from an earlier estimate of 3.9 percent because consumer spending on services was not as robust as first calculated. Page D3.
 
Senate Approves Funds for I.M.F.
The Senate approved $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund, setting up a fight with the House, which has attached an anti-abortion provision to its financing measure. A8.
 
Japanese Party Backs Fiscal Plan
Japan's Liberal Democratic Party has approved a package valued at $124 billion intended to spur that nation's foundering economy and to reduce the risk that Japan will set off a global economic slowdown. D2.
 
Tax Writers Endorse Limit on REIT's
Congressional tax writers have endorsed a version of President Clinton's proposal to limit the tax benefits from a certain type of real estate investment trust. D17.
 
Swiss Banks Agree to Negotiations
Switzerland's three major banks have changed their positions and agreed to negotiate a global settlement with victims of the Holocaust, pledging to set up a compensation fund in the United States. A1.
 
Morgan Stanley Income Rises 21%
The bull market continues to help Wall Street firms announce strong earnings; Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said it beat analysts' estimates, reporting net income of $691 million for the latest quarter. Earnings at Morgan Stanley's securities business rose 31 percent, while profits at its credit card business fell. D2.
 
McDonald's Kitchen Makeover
McDonald's is switching to a high-technology kitchen system that it said would eliminate warmed-over burgers and fries in all of its American restaurants by the end of next year. The leading fast-food operator also said it would probably dismiss some headquarters employees. D4.
 
Profits at Adobe Systems Plummet
Adobe Systems reported that first-quarter earnings fell 50 percent, a larger decline than analysts expected, because of weak sales in Asia and North America and decreasing sales of Macintosh products. D17.
 
Stock Market Ends Mixed
Demand for technology stocks and small-company stocks sent some indexes to records, but other stocks fell on disappointing earnings news, leaving the market mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average declined by 25.91 points, to 8,846.89. D6.
 
Treasury prices were lower, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 5.97 percent from 5.94. D6.
 
Big Payout for Radio Executives
Some executives of the nonprofit Minnesota Public Radio will profit handsomely from the sale of a for-profit sister company to Dayton Hudson. D3.
 
AT&T Chief Received a Stock Deal
C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman of AT&T, received stock and stock equivalents now valued at more than $22 million when he agreed to join the telecommunications giant. But to receive the full value he must remain with AT&T until 2003. D3.

HEADLINE: Plan Ratified for Mall at L.I.R.R. Terminal

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
After a last-minute dispute with City Hall was resolved, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved the renovation of Brooklyn's busiest rail terminal, the combined Long Island Rail Road and subway station at Atlantic Avenue and Flatbush Avenue, and the construction of a large shopping mall above it.
Long envisioned as a link in a chain of development that has revitalized parts of downtown Brooklyn since the late 1980's, the 450,000-square-foot mall would be built directly over the subterranean rail station by Forest City Ratner, the developer of the Metrotech office complex and a smaller mall next to the station. 
 Although the transportation authority's board had been expected to approve the project in January, it was forced to delay its vote after aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said they had not been provided with sufficient information. Yesterday, Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for economic development, said, "We think it is a very good project, and we are happy to cooperate."
Under plans previously approved by the transportation authority and budgeted at $180 million, the rail station, which serves 10 subway lines and the L.I.R.R., is to receive extensive alterations, including the widening of several platforms.
An authority spokesman, Tom Kelly, said yesterday that the project would also include construction of a new street-level entrance that would lead to the renovated platforms by escalator. Access for people in wheelchairs would also be added.
Fewer details of the shopping mall have been disclosed. But the Atlantic Center, Mr. Ratner's neighboring mall, is notable for its large stores, including Pathmark, Caldor, Old Navy, Circuit City and the Sports Authority. The businesses have brought oversized retail spaces and suburban-style selection to what had been a declining urban crossroads.
Oficials with both the M.T.A. and Forest City said yesterday that decisions about such things as the design of the new mall, its tenants and the size of stores had been put off pending the outcome of yesterday's vote.
"It means that we will now be able to move forward and negotiate how the rail station project can be coordinated with Forest City Ratner's work," Mr. Kelly said.
Although M.T.A. officials expect simultaneous construction of the rail terminal and the mall, Mr. Kelly declined to say when construction would begin. One city official involved in negotiations on the project, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he expected construction to begin by early next year.
The site, designated by the city for more than 30 years as the Atlantic Terminal Urban Renewal Area, provides many reminders of Brooklyn's decline since World War II. Sandwiched between the 19th century residential blocks of Park Slope, Boerum Hill and Fort Greene, it was proposed in the 1950's as the site for a new stadium for the Brooklyn Dodgers, to replace Ebbets Field. After the city refused to finance the stadium, the Dodgers moved to Los Angeles.
The remnants of meatpacking businesses that had thrived on the site earlier in the century were leveled by the city in the 1960's, and since then, a series of short-lived development proposals have come and gone, including a proposal in the 1980's for a corporate complex similar to Mr. Ratner's Metrotech in downtown Brooklyn.

GRAPHIC: Map of Brooklyn shows site of planned mall: A shopping mall is planned over Brooklyn's busiest rail station. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On Tour With Clinton: Business, Business, Business

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, March 26

 BODY:
President Clinton is the undisputed star of the American troupe touring Africa, but there are supporting acts, too.
In the company of 800, which fills two planes in addition to Air Force One, are the usual gaggle of advance people, security specialists, stenographers, telephone operators, pilots, diplomats, coordinators, facilitators, assistants to the President, deputy assistants to the President, special assistants to the President, reporters and technicians (about 250, including 58 from Fox News alone), spin doctors (10, if you count the assistants and their assistants), members of Congress (16, including 14 Democrats and 2 Republicans), Cabinet members (3), business executives, labor leaders, mayors, church leaders, Clinton pals and the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, who is working hard to learn how to play second banana. 
 A lot of them -- two of the three Cabinet members and 12 of the 16 members of Congress, for example -- are African-Americans, as Mr. Clinton has emphasized. He made apologetic remarks about slavery in Uganda on Tuesday, but in the next breath he remarked upon how much the descendants of slaves had contributed to the United States.
The President thus plays simultaneously to two constituencies, the mostly Democratic black voters at home and the black leaders with whom he is conferring.
It is a new twist on an old political technique, practiced in the past by American Presidents barnstorming in Poland, Italy or Ireland.
At a briefing here today, Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, discussed the makeup of the delegation, answering Republican criticism that many are Democratic contributors who stand to profit from White House policies on Africa.
"Obviously, some of them are political contributors," he said, adding, "Some of them contribute to the Republican Party in excess to what they contribute to the Democratic Party."
"This was not a delegation assembled by quota," he said. "This is, in part, a delegation assembled by interests. And there were very substantial interests, on the part of the Congressional Black Caucus, in this trip.
"The President, I think, feels we've got a balanced, representative delegation who's here. And we make no apologies for the fact that some of them are political supporters of the President. That's not unusual, and that's been a practice in past White Houses."
For many African-Americans on the trip, it is a moment to savor.
"I can hardly believe this is happening," said Representative Donald M. Payne, a Democrat from Newark. "I'm pinching myself. I've been in the wilderness for 20 years, me and a few others, trying and failing to get the United States interested in Africa."
Mr. Clinton's role is to buck up the leaders of countries that are privatizing their economies and liberalizing their political systems, while urging others to follow their lead, and to alert Americans to the changes here.
The Americans whose attention the President most wants to grab are business executives, in the hope they will invest in Africa.
"We have the leader of the free world here for 12 days," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, a Democrat who has attended many of the President's meetings. "That has to say to people back home, 'Africa ain't what you think it is.' It's gone gone beyond Sally Struthers on television, saying, 'Send money to this little baby.' It's time for business to take a second look."
One question hangs over the enterprise -- the fate of an Africa development bill that has passed the House. Representative Edward R. Royce, a California Republican who heads the House Subcommittee on Africa, said it would be taken up in the Senate soon. "If it passes," he added, "Africa will be open for business."
It will be up to William M. Daley, the Secretary of Commerce, who is traveling with the President, to clinch deals with individual business leaders later. He says it won't be easy.
"This isn't for everyone," he said. "We're going to have to target our opportunities carefully, matching companies and countries. I just hope this trip will get people to listen to our arguments, which is all you can ask. There are still serious problems in these countries. But the smart businessman will say, 'Where there's a problem, there's an opportunity.' "
Mr. Daley said the Administration's plan for more investment would succeed only if African governments maintain stability, make a commitment to legal norms and develop cadres of able officials and administrators.
There are other problems, different in each country. In Uganda, for example, access to the port of Mombasa, in Kenya, is vital. At the moment, the port is so corrupt and supply routes so inefficient that it costs 10 times as much to ship cargo from Mombasa to Kampala, the Ugandan capital, a distance of 750 miles, as it does to ship it from Los Angeles to Mombasa.
Some of Mr. Daley's targets are among his fellow voyagers, like Melvin Clark Jr., chief executive of the Metroplex Corporation, a Washington construction company; Carl Ware, who heads the Africa group at the Coca-Cola Company; Paul A. Allaire, chairman of the Xerox Corporation, which returned to South Africa in 1997, and Kase L. Lawal, the Nigerian-born owner of a Houston energy and real estate firm called Camac Holdings.
Others are along for other reasons. Lottie Shackleford is a former vice chairman of the Arkansas Democratic Party and a longtime Friend of Bill. Alma Brown, a senior vice president of the Chevy Chase Bank in the Washington suburbs, is the widow of Ronald H. Brown, who as Commerce Secretary began the work of encouraging American business to invest anew in Africa.
Kweisi Mfume, a former Representative, heads the N.A.A.C.P. Ilyasah Shabazz, an aide to Mayor Ernest Davis of Mount Vernon, N.Y., is the third child of the late Dr. Betty Shabazz and the late Malcolm X.
Maurice Tempelsman, best known as a longtime beau of the late Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, made his fortune as a diamond dealer and industrialist. He has longstanding connections with the DeBeers diamond syndicate, based in South Africa, and he made Democratic campaign contributions of more than $170,000 in 1995 and 1996 alone.
Also here is Ron Burkle, a Los Angeles supermarket executive, who contributed $125,000 and lent his Beverly Hills mansion to President Clinton for fund-raisers.
But none have generated the attention in African business circles that Robert Johnson has. A calm, quiet-spoken Washingtonian, he has built a network of companies around his Black Entertainment Television network. Its jazz programs are already beamed into southern Africa by satellite, and on this trip he hopes to put together enough countries in East and West Africa to justify spending the $8 million to $10 million a year it costs to rent a satellite transponder.
Mr. Johnson made it plain that he is willing to take considerable short-term risks to establish his brand names here, and he said he sensed that African business executives welcomed deals with African-Americans like himself, "maybe because they think they get a squarer shake."
"You have to take a long-term view here," Mr. Johnson said in Kampala the other day. "I don't think you can ignore Africa forever. If you think you have a product Africans want or are going to want, like entertainment, then you come in, maybe take some knocks, and stay the course as the place matures."

HEADLINE: Dreamers of Thoroughbred Glory Mine Florida

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: OCALA, Fla., March 26

 BODY:
Dennis G. Madonna, a 39-year-old general contractor from Pennsylvania, walked around horse stalls at the Ocala Breeders' Sales Company here this week with a trainer and two veterinarians in tow. Tired of losing money with four racehorses, he came to an auction of thoroughbreds determined to find a winner, if not of the Kentucky Derby, at least high-stakes races.
"It's more entertainment than it is a business, but it's also a business," Mr. Madonna said minutes after successfully bidding $37,000 for an unnamed brown filly and $27,000 for "Star One One," another filly. "I don't like to lose." 
 The two-day auction that ended on Wednesday was one of several held throughout the year in this central Florida city that is one of the world's largest horse-breeding areas and the heart of Florida's thoroughbred industry. Although Florida is better known for citrus than horses, its 600 farms breeding and training thoroughbreds employ 29,000 people, generate $1 billion for the state's annual economy and produce more than 3,300 horses a year, which puts Florida second to Kentucky in the production of registered thoroughbred foals in the nation. Kentucky produces more than 7,000 thoroughbreds a year.
The auction of selected 2-year-olds, thoroughbreds screened for both pedigree and physicality, attracts buyers from all over the world, young and retired, poor and rich, experienced and novices, all in search of "the dream." They took their places in an amphitheater where each horse was paraded on a crescent stage, bringing bids as high as $500,000 on Wednesday.
Mike H. Sherman, who is president of Farnsworth Farms in Ocala and who races his own horses, is one of the most successful breeders.
"We have the dream," Mr. Sherman said. "The Kentucky Derby, the Breeders' Cup, to have a horse like Cigar or Secretariat. To win fame, glory and money."
This week, $18.3 million was spent on 288 horses by buyers, some looking for that dream, others for simply getting a competitive horse that would at least earn more than it cost. The average sales price was $63,000, but dreams can also come cheap.
Silver Charm, winner of the 1997 Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes, sold here two years ago for $17,000 and so far has earned more than $2 million in prize money. Owners typically take 60 percent of the purse money, with most of the rest going to the jockey and the trainer. Millions more can be earned in breeding fees after the thoroughbred is retired from racing.
But the potential of such immense profit is set against enormous risk, with the worst being injury. Breeders like Bob Noble, manager of Ocala Stud Farms, one of the oldest farms in the area, says that for every story like Silver Charm "there are others where people just pay bills."
That was not the case of Rick Kaster, a home builder in Wisconsin who was picking horses here with the aid of a bloodstock consultant hoping to strike gold again. Mr. Kaster said he and three partners spent $85,000 on the mare that was pregnant with Countess Diana, the $1 million Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies Champion last November. Now, mare and brood are worth more than $6 million.
"Realistically, they're still going to be rare," Mr. Kaster said of such champions, "but if we work right we'll have another and then another. We'll find another one."
The auction also drew buyers like Mauro Porcelli, 29, a local firefighter and paramedic who said he realized barely an hour into the bidding that he would have to return next year with more than the $15,000 he had planned to spend. Mr. Porcelli said he wanted to invest $50,000 on both a horse and its first-year upkeep, looking for "a business adventure."
"You have the potential of making a lot of money and it looks like a lot of fun," Mr. Porcelli said. "I'd rather spend $50,000 on horses than in the stock market."
Mr. Porcelli said his wife, a bank vice president, "thinks I'm an idiot but she supports me."
Although Florida breeders acknowledge that Kentucky still offers the best blood stock in the industry, Mr. Noble and others say environmental advantages here -- a limestone-rich soil that nurtures strong bones and a warm climate that allows horses to spend more time outside exercising -- have helped develop an athletic horse that can outrun its pedigree.
Florida, where thoroughbred breeding and training began in the 1930's, produces about 10 percent of the country's thoroughbred foals, but they win 20 percent of the major races, said the Florida Thoroughbred Breeders' and Owners' Association. Kentucky produces about 25 percent and the rest come from about 30 states.
So buyers here look not just for bloodline, but things like muscularity, personality, even attitude, in a greatly subjective process that relies as much on intuition as expertise. A 2-year-old, the age when a horse can start racing, also allows buyers to see the horse work out. None of the horses have raced competitively before they are sold.
"After all the work," Mr. Kaster said, "you still have to get lucky."
Mr. Madonna, for whom owning racehorses was a sentimental incursion that goes back to the trips to the racetrack with his father, is determined to work at being lucky. He pays about $2,200 a month in boarding, training and veterinarian fees for each of his four thoroughbreds and is still far from recouping his investment. Recently, he decided on some changes that he hoped would help reverse his fortunes. Heswitched to a trainer with a solid winning record and started buying better-quality horses at this auction.
"I'm trying to do everything right," he said, "but you can still go wrong."
In addition to having the best trainers, blood stock and advice, buyers say they need a plan. Mr. Kaster said his strategy was to know what it took to buy a good horse and then "try to find them as young horses when they are still affordable."
Others note that even the best horse can be doomed in the wrong hands.
"If the person doesn't have the wherewithal to take it all the way he'll probably destroy that horse before it gets to a stakes," Max Hugel, a former Central Intelligence Agency official who owns the Rockingham Park racetrack in New Hampshire, said referring to the upper-tier races. "I can tell you that most owners have a hard time making money in this business, but they love it."
That is because nothing, owners say, compares to the thrill of victory.
"Watching your horse cross the finish line first you have to feel," Mr. Madonna said. "It's like your kid. When I win a race I take videos of it and I watch the race two months after."
Mr. Kaster, remembering Countess Diana's victory, said, "It's like having a football team and winning the Super Bowl."

HEADLINE: Bid-Rigging Case Engulfs an Elite Who Built the Interiors of Offices

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Addressing the elite of New York City's interior construction industry at an awards breakfast earlier this year, Dennis M. Cahill, the publisher of Interiors magazine, made a little joke that hit painfully close to home. He said he would understand if anyone had to leave early to talk with a lawyer about indictments or subpoenas.
A long-running investigation into allegations of bid-rigging and kickbacks in New York's huge but largely hidden office construction business has been the subject of dark humor, feverish rumors and legal maneuvering for much of the 1990's. But now it is drawing to a close, with the Manhattan District Attorney's office negotiating plea deals with officials from as many as six companies. 
 The plea arrangements could come within the next few weeks, said lawyers involved in the negotiations. And if those talks fall apart, the lawyers and industry executives say, prosecutors are expected to bring charges of tax evasion, money laundering and bid-rigging against more than a dozen executives. Eventually, the charges are expected to involve architects, real estate brokers and corporate managers, as well as lighting and furniture suppliers.
"This is going to be a steamroller over the industry, and it'll cause a major restructuring," said Thomas D. Thacher 2d, president of Thacher Associates, a corporate investigations firm, who has monitored the industry for 15 years. "Every single corporation that renovated its space or relocated in the past decade could well be affected by what will come out of this."
Investigators say they believe a group of construction executives rigged the bidding on almost all the major corporate renovation and relocation jobs in the 1990's in exchange for millions of dollars in payoffs and kickbacks from contractors. As a result, investigators say, major corporations were overcharged by as much as 20 percent for office construction.
The contractors have told the District Attorney's office that the payments were legitimate commissions for helping them obtain contracts, and not kickbacks. They also maintained that they did not raise their prices to offset the commissions.
 
Influential Executives At Center of Inquiry
While corruption investigations in the construction business are not new, most have involved union officials and organized-crime figures. This inquiry, by contrast, strikes at an elite segment of the industry, whose executives have vast wealth and influence.
The investigation began after the chairman of a construction company pleaded guilty to money laundering in 1995 and began to guide investigators through a maze of corporate relationships. The inquiry now encompasses much of the $5 billion-dollar-a-year industry, which is thriving in the city's building boom, just as it did during the recession, when businesses were forced to renovate rather than relocate.
Because of the pending plea bargaining, most of the people involved in the case, including prosecutors, either refused to comment or declined to be quoted. Six of the people involved agreed to be interviewed on the condition of anonymity.
Even without any charges filed, many large corporations have dismissed or avoided tainted contractors. For example, Christie's, the auction house, said that it ended its contract with a consulting firm, Bennis & Reissman, and would end its dealings with a construction company, A. J. Construction, because of the investigation, said Taggarty Patrick, a Christie's spokeswoman.
"It's a cloud over the entire industry," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the New York Building Congress, a trade association. "We'd like to see it resolved."
Central figures in the inquiry, company executives and lawyers said, are Howard Lazar, 55, and Robert Bennis, 52, childhood friends from Queens who went on to become two of the most powerful people in the industry.
After pleading guilty to charges of attempted bribery in the 1970's, Mr. Lazar, a diminutive, athletic man with a talent for sales, established one of the city's largest interior construction companies, NICO Inc. In the 1990's, Mr. Bennis became the most powerful owners' representative in the business.
A trim, white-haired man who drives a Bentley convertible, Mr. Bennis helped develop budgets and schedules for relocation and renovation work for his clients. He also coordinated the work of architects, real estate brokers and, because he was so highly regarded, often solicited and accepted the bids from contractors. His fees amounted to $1.50 to $4 a square foot, or about $2 million for a 1 million square-foot project. His firm, Bennis & Reissman, which once had as much as two-thirds of the business in New York, closed its doors in January.
 
'Pay to Play' Was Rule, Office Contractors Say
The contractors under investigation are suspected of having made $14 million in payments to JDL Holdings, a company with ties to Mr. Lazar. Executives with two of the contractors and a lawyer familiar with the investigation said that the money was provided to insure that the contractors obtained work. They also said Mr. Lazar split the proceeds with Mr. Bennis, who was in a position to direct companies to particular contractors.
Contractors who did not "pay to play" did not get work, said representatives of three of the contractors under investigation.
Mr. Bennis, Mr. Lazar and their lawyers did not return repeated phone calls requesting comment.
Bruce Fahey, president of E. S. McCann & Son, an interior construction company, acknowledged that the District Attorney had subpoenaed his records concerning a multimillion-dollar project at two Times Square office towers owned by Morgan Stanley.
McCann is one of the companies under investigation, said executives and lawyers involved in the case. The others, they said, are Lehr Construction Corporation, Structure Tone, AJ Contracting, Ambassador Construction and Bennis & Reissman.
Some executives said the District Attorney had asked six contractors for records of check requisitions for money paid to JDL Holdings. Although some of the requisitions indicated that the checks were for business development services, investigators suspect that JDL was essentially a mail drop and had no employees, said an executive who worked at one of the construction companies and a representative of another contractor.
Construction and design operations make up about a third of the $60 billion-a-year real estate industry, according to the New York Building Congress.
A cloud fell over the industry in 1995, with the indictment of Ted Kohl, chairman of Herbert Construction Company, on charges related to a $7 million kickback scheme. Mr. Kohl pleaded guilty last year to money laundering and tax evasion, and began providing prosecutors with information that led them to JDL, Mr. Bennis and Mr. Lazar, said industry executives and a defense lawyer.
Mr. Lazar and Mr. Bennis, who have known each other since kindergarten at Public School 86, started in the industry in the late 1960's, at H. L. Lazar, an interior construction company started by Mr. Lazar's father and uncle in 1954.
In 1975, Mr. Lazar was one of the most prosperous executives in the industry when he was indicted on bribery and corruption charges. He and other executives were accused of paying off building inspectors to speed up permits and obtain favorable treatment.
Mr. Lazar eventually pleaded guilty to attempted bribery and was sentenced to one weekend a month in jail for 12 months. In testimony in a related case, he admitted doling out money to Peter Roberto, an expediter for H. L. Lazar, who paid off about 100 building inspectors with theater tickets and cash before becoming an undercover agent for investigators.
Mr. Lazar's testimony came back to haunt him in a 1977 civil suit brought by one of his company's biggest clients, J. C. Penney. The department store chain said Mr. Lazar, his father and their company had paid $1.4 million in bribes to a J. C. Penney executive, Andrew Tsanas, to get $23 million in contracts for renovations at the J. C. Penney Building. The lawsuit also said the Lazars inflated the cost of their work and submitted fake invoices while doing renovation work at the homes of Penney executives.
According to a transcript of his testimony, Mr. Lazar said he and his father met with Mr. Tsanas, who told them if they paid $5,000 he would guarantee contracts from J. C. Penney. He then detailed how bids were rigged.
"After the bids were in," Mr. Lazar testified, "Mr. Tsanas came to our office and showed me what the other bids were and we went in at the lowest price."
Mr. Lazar testified that Mr. Tsanas told him to make up the cost of the payoffs by inflating his bills to J. C. Penney.
In the end, H. L. Lazar and its subcontractors paid Penney $2.5 million to settle the lawsuit. Mr. Tsanas was sentenced to three years in prison for tax evasion.
 
An Era of Prosperity For Two Old Friends
Mr. Lazar's legal problems did not prevent him from starting NICO Inc. in 1977, and it became one of the largest publicly traded interior-construction firms in the country. In 1984, NICO bought Mr. Bennis's consulting firm, A. R. Blyth. Reunited for the first time in more than a decade, the two old friends fell into a working rhythm: Mr. Lazar solicited work for the company, while Mr. Bennis worked out the budgets for the jobs.
In 1991, NICO closed after suffering major losses. Mr. Lazar then joined his brother Gerald's company, Lehr Construction. Mr. Bennis did independent consulting before forming Bennis & Reissman, with Maurice Reissman, the former chairman of the failed Crossland Savings Bank.
Bennis & Reissman quickly prospered, in part because many corporations had eliminated their own real estate executives during the recession in the early 1990's.
But in 1992, a woodworking subcontractor in the Bronx went to the police with a tale of graft, claiming that he was fed up with having to kick back millions of dollars to Mr. Kohl, according to court papers filed in Mr. Kohl's case. The allegations led to Mr. Kohl's indictment in 1995 and eventually to the top interior contractors in the city.
No matter what ultimately happens with the District Attorney's investigation, giant cracks have opened up in the interior construction industry. Smaller companies are gaining an increasing share of the business, while companies like Plaza Construction and HRH Construction, known for building skyscrapers, are now doing the interior work that seemed impossible to get only a few years ago.
"It was a cartel," said the chief executive of one large construction company, who insisted on anonymity. "If you didn't play the game, you couldn't get any work."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
White Rejects Criticism for Remarks

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
Reggie White did not back off yesterday from his remarks in the Wisconsin State Legislature on Wednesday that left some legislators cringing and some activists criticizing him.
"I didn't start a ministry to please everybody," White, the Green Bay Packers star, said in a telephone interview. "I'm getting tired of people patting me on the back, anyway." 
 White, an ordained fundamentalist Christian minister, admitted he was feeling the fallout from his comments, which included referring to homosexuality as "one of the biggest sins in the Bible."
An African-American, White also said that blacks "like to sing and dance" while whites "know how to tap into money" and he also used what he felt were positive stereotypes of Hispanics, Asians and Native Americans.
Yesterday, White said he had received calls from sponsors to his New Hope Ministry in Knoxville, Tenn., from which he tries to stimulate minority-owned business.
"People are saying they're going to have to re-evaluate me," White said. "I said: 'Don't re-evaluate me. Forget about me. I don't need your money.' "
Among those speaking out yesterday was David Smith, a spokesman for the Human Rights Campaign, a gay and lesbian activist group, who was quoted by The Associated Press as saying that White had showed "complete disrespect" for gay Americans.
Felmers Chaney, the president of the Milwaukee chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said: "Reggie is not one of those who speaks for all of us, and he shouldn't attempt to do that. I am not going to condemn him, and I am not going to stand up for him."
Mark Kanz, the director of tourism for the Green Bay Area Visitor and Convention Bureau, said: "Most people who I have spoken to are shaking their heads and saying, 'Reggie just kind of got loose a little bit and probably said some things he was thinking but probably shouldn't have been brought up in a public forum.' "
In fervent, unapologetic tones yesterday, White said: "What people missed was the message. I was discussing the gifts people have. It's just like a marriage. People bring different gifts to the marriage."
White said he had stressed the spiritual and musical and athletic side of African-Americans. He also said that people had made too much about his remarks about homosexuality, saying: "That's not the only sin in the Bible. There's fornication, lying, stealing, adultery, false idol worship."
Asked about his motivation for speaking of sin in a public place, White said: "When wicked people came into power, the Roman Empire fell. Yes, I was speaking to things today, if it's true about the White House. People say, 'The economy is good,' but it's not good for everybody. If our leaders are into this, we should expect more from them than just intelligence."
He added: "Look, I'm not saying I'm perfect. I made my mistakes in high school but then I straightened out. Today you've got television stars talking about passing out condoms. They should be talking about abstinence, instead."

HEADLINE: BLOODSHED IN A SCHOOLYARD: THE IMPACT;
Determined to Find Healing In a Good and Decent Place

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: JONESBORO, Ark., March 26

 BODY:
This is a place that has learned to cherish a slow day.
Most days, Dennis Woody and the other paramedics at Emerson Ambulance have a nice, long wait between calls, and sit talking on the soft, secondhand sofa, watching television, thinking about how they could throw darts at the dartboard, if they really wanted to. 
 On Tuesday, an afternoon that forever altered the lives of so many in this small city, Mr. Woody found himself on his knees in a blood-spattered schoolyard, trying in vain to make a young girl live again as her father stood over him and chanted, "Come on, come on, come on."
Most days, T. J. Kelley of radio station KFIN cracks jokes, reports on soybean futures and spins country music ballads for lovesick teen-agers, helping to heal broken hearts that are never really broken all that much. This week, he tries to help young listeners who feel guilty for just being alive while their classmates and friends are dead from a hail of bullets, and pours words out onto the airwaves that remind this place how good and decent it was before this, and will be again.
Most days, Mitchell Faught, who has run the flower shop for 34 years, and Grover Cooper, longtime superintendent of schools, join other older men in the McDonald's to drink coffee, read newspapers and joke about Mr. Cooper's impending retirement.
This morning, as four of his students and a teacher lay in funeral homes and two young schoolmates sat in jail, charged in the killings, the talk was kinder than usual.
"How you doing, Grover?" Mr. Faught asked.
"I'm going to be fine," Mr. Cooper said.
Most people here say that. They will be fine, only different.
Jonesboro, which is expected to pass 50,000 in population by the next census, will always be known, at least partly, as the Arkansas city where two boys, ages 13 and 11 and dressed in camouflage as if they were going deer hunting, shot to death four of their classmates and an English teacher in a rain of bullets that also wounded nine other children and another teacher.
Before that, it was a place to live and work and raise children, where the worst thing that ever happened was a 1983 bus accident that killed eight people: a tragedy, but a thing that they could understand.
It was a place where only one store carries Playboy magazine and you have to ask for it "under the counter." There are no blinking beer signs or hotel happy hours because there is no booze -- Craighead County is dry as old bones -- and faith in God is a given. In a town dominated by the Church of Christ and Baptists, the Methodists are about the most liberal people in town.
One of the two boys charged in the killings was given Bibles as they were locked away, after asking Sheriff Dale Haas whether he had "any Bible thoughts" that might help him through his ordeal.
John Deresbach, assistant minister of music at Central Baptist Church, said, "When you hear people say, 'It isn't supposed to happen here,' what they're saying is, 'This is not the atmosphere that breeds this sort of violence.' "
That is why people in this mostly white, largely blue-collar college town get angry when they hear psychiatrists talk on daytime television about how Southerners are just more prone to violence, or that a proliferation of guns -- deer hunting is a rite of passage here -- led to the slaughter at Westside Middle School.
What happened at Westside Middle School, these people say, was born in the disturbed minds of one of the two boys, perhaps both, and carried out in a freakish, unmentionable moment in time. It had nothing to do with them, people in Jonesboro say of themselves. They only have to dig the graves, and live with the memory of what happened here.
Mr. Deresbach has noticed one change in people.
"People are gentler," he said, in dealing with each other. They will help each other, feeding the need with food baskets prepared at churches and binding up their wounds with thousands of white ribbons, some on mailboxes, others on car antennas, all honoring the dead. Marquee signs that once advertised fried catfish promised prayer.
At Emerson Ambulance, the lobby was crowded with men who had worked to save the students who were shot down. They talked angrily about news accounts blaming breakdowns in society -- their society -- for what happened.
If that were true, these men wondered, why had they not seen this horror before now?
Most days at the ambulance service are "pretty much like recess," said Rickey Elder, a 42-year-old paramedic.
Charlie Ferguson, a 32-year-old paramedic, described a usual day: "We sit, we eat, we get fat."
Some days, they may answer two or three emergency calls. In 1996, there were two killings. In 1997, two again.
"This is a college town," Mr. Ferguson said, "and the wildest things that happen here are the parties. And, it's a dry county," so those parties are not often drunken brawls resulting in trauma.
The 911 calls changed all that.
They all scrambled to it, men like Mr. Woody, Mr. Ferguson and Toby Emerson, who is also the coroner. Mr. Woody, the first to arrive, described how he had knelt over the already dead child, at the feet of her frantic father, and could do nothing. Mr. Woody said he knew she was dead, but could not tell him.
But that was not the worst of it. "The thing I'm going to walk away with," Mr. Woody said, "is the memory of looking up and seeing another girl," in the arms of another rescuer, and how "her head fell back, and the blood coming out."
They did not question whether this would not have happened if guns were absent from the culture.
"You lay a gun on a table and a hundred years from now the gun will still be sitting there, unless someone touches it," reasoned Mr. Elder. Like the others, he wore a white ribbon across his badge.
At KFIN, T. J. Kelley is more accustomed to callers who want to hear the latest by Garth Brooks or dedicate a song to their boyfriends.
"It's not really small town," Mr. Kelley said of his city, which has an economy that mixes farming, factory work and teaching jobs at Arkansas State. "But it's hometown."
He used to be the late-night disk jockey, and he got to know a lot of 12-year-old boys and girls.
"You know when their boyfriends or girlfriends break up with them, know when they're acing a test or got special homework," he said. "They're good-natured Southern kids. You have some doing the nose ring thing, but they're good kids."
When he first heard the names of the dead and wounded, he said, he recognized some of them from those late-night calls. Now he reports on prayer vigils. He hears dedications to dead children.
But like the paramedics, Mr. Kelley cannot blame the world the children grew up in for this. If anything, he said, young people here know better than inner-city youths what a gun can do.
They do not carry guns in their waistbands, for the feel of it. They have seen bullets strike and kill animals, he said. If anything, he said, they have more respect for the gun.
What they are losing respect for, say many here, is the news media. The first mass invasion of news media here has been an ugly one for so many people. Two television camera people cursed each other outside the county jail because one had gotten in the way of the other's shot.
Today, Sheriff Haas told reporters, some from around the world, that his switchboard was flooded with complaints from people here. Television trucks block driveways and access roads. Some reporters have refused to leave doorsteps when people asked them to, or have been trespassing or offering money for stories.
"If it doesn't stop," he sheriff said, he will ask his deputies to start arresting people.
But mostly, people have gone about the necessary things in this bad time.
Mr. Faught, the florist, usually does about 75 arrangements a day. Today, he and his workers did more than 200. The orders for the funerals are still coming in.
People here say the city is still small enough so names and faces are familiar, and history seems to circle around itself. In the bus accident of 1983, one passenger, a man named Terry Woodward, was credited with saving the lives of several students.
Mr. Woodward is the stepfather of 13-year-old Mitchell Johnson, one of the two boys sitting in jail, blamed for the killing of his classmates.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 35; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk
