HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
A Cow Town That Acquired High Culture

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
This is the Mile High City, right? Right. Its National Football League champion Broncos play in Mile High Stadium, right? Right. So Denver must be cradled in the beautiful Rocky Mountains, right?
Wrong. 
 Denver is in fact 5,280 feet above sea level; there is a brass disk marking that exact altitude on the 18th step of the State Capitol's staircase. The city is not in the mountains, however, but at their base -- at the foot of the Front Range, on a high plateau at the western limit of the Great Plains.
Nor is this Blizzard Central, as so many Easterners seem to think. Most years, the sun shines for at least 310 days (the Chamber of Commerce swears it), the sky is often startlingly blue and the Rockies provide a backdrop to daily life so vivid that Albert Bierstadt himself might have painted it.
Denver came into being as a mining town, a put-up-your-dukes, shoot-first-and-ask-later kind of place. When The New York Herald's great editor, Horace Greeley, spent two weeks here in 1859, on an overland trip from the Atlantic to the Pacific, it was a log city of 150 dwellings -- not a third of them, he wrote, fit to be inhabited. No place of similar size anywhere on earth, Greeley concluded, had as many brawls, fights or "pistol shots with criminal intent."
Just after World War II, John Gunther judged this "the most self-sufficient, isolated, self-contained and complacent city in the world."
That was long ago. Now Denver is a haven of clean air, low crime rates and successful high-tech businesses, full of healthy people obsessed by the outdoors. They like their city and state, and many people who don't live here wish they did. When the Harris polling organization asked Americans not long ago where they would like to move, only the three top retirement states -- Florida, Arizona and California -- finished ahead of Colorado. Which worries Coloradans, who fear the place will be overrun; many would pull up the drawbridge if they could.
Japan is about to open a consulate here, and enough Koreans live here to support a Korean-language daily newspaper. A Japanese company owns one of the nearby ski areas, a Canadian company owns another, a Brazilian company owns a third. Denver-based companies mine gold in Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and the Russian Far East. And Mayor Wellington Webb travels the world, courting international business for his city.
Yet Denver doesn't feel like a city on the make. It is too laid back, too comfortable in its in-town neighborhoods full of unpretentious houses from the 1930's, 40's and 50's, plus smart suburbs farther out.
When not at work, all Denver, it seems, bikes, hikes, camps, climbs, hunts, fishes, jogs, skis and comes perilously close to mountain worship. Road warriors can join in if they like; weather permitting, you can make a day trip by car through Boulder, Rocky Mountain National Park, Granby and Winter Park, then back to Denver. The world-class ski resorts of Vail, Aspen and Crested Butte are only commuter flights away, and in summer the charming Victorian mining villages of Leadville (America's highest incorporated town at 10,152 feet) and Telluride (once the hideout of Butch Cassidy and other outlaws) beckon visitors.
No place has everything, not even Paris, and few would anoint Denver as a national cultural capital. Still, this is no philistine cow town, even if some men still wear cowboy boots, and the National Western Stock Show draws record crowds each January. It boasts a fine zoo, extensive botanical gardens and one of the nation's better natural history museums, and it is slowly developing into a regional arts center for Colorado and the other mountain states.
 
A Boom in the Arts
"The city I grew up in doesn't exist," said Robert B. Yegge, dean of the University of Denver law school, whose family has been here for four generations. "The oil boom attracted one group of new people, and the technology boom attracted another one. They're young and well educated, and many bring a taste for the arts with them."
Indeed, more people hereabouts bought tickets last year for arts events and scientific institutions like the zoo than for sports events, at a time when the Broncos were on their way to a championship, the baseball Rockies were bashing long balls by the bucketful in Denver's thin air, and the Avalanche was trying to win the Stanley Cup again.
Not many areas tax themselves to support scientific and cultural facilities, but the six counties of metropolitan Denver do; last year 250 organizations received about $27 million from the levy. And not many areas have a cultural center like the glistening, four-square-block Denver Center for the Performing Arts.
It includes the Helen Bonfils Theater by Kevin Roche and John Dinkeloo, named for the late owner of The Denver Post; the updated Auditorium Theater, opened for the 1908 Democratic National Convention that nominated William Jennings Bryan; the Boettcher Concert Hall by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer; a 1,700-car parking garage, and other structures. They are connected by a series of enormous steel and glass arches that form a kind of galleria to keep snow and rain at bay.
Together, the buildings house eight halls with more than 9,300 seats, second in capacity in this country only to Lincoln Center in New York. They are home to the Denver Center Theater Company, an ambitious repertory group, as well as Broadway touring productions, and to the Colorado Symphony Orchestra, Opera Colorado and the Colorado Ballet.
The city's performing arts gem is the Denver Center Theater Company, a resident group that presents a dozen plays a year on four stages, ranging from Shakespeare, Moliere and O'Neill to Strindberg, Athol Fugard and Derek Walcott. In a large building just across the street, it has what most regional theaters only dream of -- rehearsal halls, storage spaces and elaborate shops that fabricate sets, costumes and props.
A silver-haired, pink-cheeked North Carolinian named Donald Seawell made it happen. A longtime New York lawyer and Broadway producer (and present-day chairman of the American National Theater and Academy), Mr. Seawell collaborated on stage projects with Ms. Bonfils. Later she brought him here as publisher of The Post. Returning from lunch one day, he said, he decided the area around the auditorium would make a perfect site for the arts center the city needed.
With money from the city and from Ms. Bonfils, as well as other donors, the complex was built in the 1970's and 80's. Now 85, the courtly Mr. Seawell remains active as head of the $110 million Bonfils Foundation, which devotes most of its resources to sustaining the theater company's operations.
At least to date, the musical organizations have found no equally reliable stream of support.
Founded in 1981 by a pair of displaced New Yorkers, Nathaniel Merrill and his wife, Louise Sherman, the opera has hit a rough patch after the death of Ms. Sherman in February and the resignation of Mr. Merrill this month.
The orchestra plays "in the round," with the audience seated all around it, much like the Berlin Philharmonic in its home hall, the Philharmonie. Both the orchestra, under Marin Alsop, one of the nation's most prominent female conductors, and the ballet company, which won good notices on recent visits to New York, are still struggling to build lasting traditions.
 
Shakespeare, or Bust
Denver is a young city, dating only from the gold strike of 1858, but it grew fast; within 18 years it was the capital of the nation's 38th state, with a population of 35,000. Much of the wealth produced in its hinterland went to enrich other cities, like the smelting fortune of Meyer Guggenheim, a Swiss immigrant who struck it rich at Leadville in 1880, and the dry-goods fortune of David May, who started in business in a tent in Leadville on Harrison Avenue.
In those raucous early days, the performing arts were more than a little problematical. Oscar Wilde appeared onstage in Leadville in 1882 in a velvet suit, I learned in the applicable volume of the invaluable Smithsonian Guide to Historic America, and read to the miners from the autobiography of Benvenuto Cellini. Asked why he hadn't brought Cellini with him, Wilde replied that Cellini had been dead for quite a while, which elicited the question, "Who shot him?"
The year before, one of the mining kings, Horace A. W. Tabor, took offense when the opera house he had built in Denver, with a stage 70 feet long and 50 feet wide, opened for business. Noting a portrait in the lobby, he summoned his partner and asked who it was.
"That's Shakespeare," the partner is said to have replied.
"Who is Shakespeare?"
"Why, the greatest writer of plays who ever lived!"
"Well, what the hell has he ever done for Colorado?" demanded Tabor, incredulous. "Take his picture down and put mine up there!"
Tabor was also famous for having abandoned his wife for a blue-eyed waitress, Elizabeth (Baby) McCourt Doe, whom he married in Washington in 1883 with President Chester A. Arthur in attendance. His monument in modern Denver is the Tabor Center, a shopping mall that forms one anchor of the Lower Downtown or LoDo district. Also in that yeasty neighborhood are Larimer Square, where 17 buildings from the Victorian era have been converted to shops, and the 16th Street Mall, a pedestrian promenade packed with bistros and brew pubs. There is a branch of the Tattered Cover, one of the nation's great bookstores, at 1628 16th.
Nearby stands Coors Field, home of the Rockies, another of those faux-Fenway exercises in nostalgia, designed by the same firm that did Baltimore's and Cleveland's ballparks, but a little too pretty to carry off the illusion.
The Denver Art Museum, largest of its kind between Missouri and California, is housed in a fascinating if forbidding building designed, late in life, by the great Milanese architect Gio Ponti. It houses impressive collections of pre-Columbian and Spanish colonial art and 18,000 American-Indian objects, including pots, totem poles, jewelry and baskets dating back as far as the ninth century. It also holds the personal collection of Herbert Bayer, once a teacher at the Bauhaus, later a leading American designer who helped develop Aspen.
In facing the building with a million triangular pieces of gray glass, Ponti said, "I asked the sun and the sky and the light to help me."
At the moment, the local cultural lion is a burly, earthy mutual-fund tycoon named William M. B. Berger, who has assembled an immense collection of British art in a spending spree over the last few years. His holdings were to have formed the centerpiece of the grand reopening of the museum's European and American galleries in November, after a $7 million, seven-year, museumwide make-over.
But the collection, which includes works by Turner and Holbein, George Stubbs and Joshua Reynolds and Joseph Wright of Derby, as well as a 16th-century Nottingham alabaster of a splendor rare even in Britain, proved too large; it will now be shown starting in September, when part of the permanent collection will go into storage and Mr. Berger's trove will occupy the whole seventh floor.
Some experts are skeptical about the quality of some items in the collection, arguing that they cannot match those of the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven and the Huntington Library in San Marino, Calif. The museum's director, Lewis I. Sharp, strongly disagrees. Mr. Sharp, a former curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said that many of the Berger works, especially the earlier ones, "are of great beauty and rarity -- some of them unique in this country."
 
Modern Architecture
The new wing of the Denver Public Library, a post-modern extravaganza by Michael Graves just across the street, houses a collection of books, photographs and ephemera chronicling the development of the American West. It also displays works by the trinity of American Western art, Bierstadt, Frederic Remington and Charles Marion Russell.
Graves's building, where the leaders of the Western world met during their economic summit conference here last June, looks as if it had been made out of oversize children's building blocks -- pyramid, rectangle, cylinder, rectangle, rotunda, rectangle, piled together to surprisingly good effect -- then painted with watercolors.
Denver's most discussed building, without a doubt, is its new, $6 billion airport, and much of the discussion is ill-tempered. To start with, it is inconveniently located 26 miles northeast of downtown. Its supposedly advanced baggage-handling system, which chewed up luggage for three years, has been quietly set aside; now the only problem is that baggage takes forever and a day to arrive. The rental-car system is also subject to infuriating delays.
The building itself has a certain majesty, especially the main terminal hall, which is covered with a tent of Teflon-coated fabric. But from the outside, it looks like nothing so much as a high-tech encampment for a race of Bedouin giants, and I confess that I can't look at it without giggling.
 
If You Go to Denver (as Tourist or Cowboy)
 
Here is information about visiting Denver. Room rates are based on double occupancy.
 
Where to Stay
 
BROWN PALACE, 321 17th Street, (303) 297-3111. Completed in 1892 at the zenith of Colorado's silver boom, to a Richardsonian design by Frank Edbrooke, a talented local architect, the Brown Palace has reigned ever since as the empress of Denver hotels, and a $10 million renovation completed last year restored its Gilded Age luster. It has 237 rooms, centered on a sparkling nine-story atrium with a stained-glass skylight, surrounded by intricate bronze balconies. Every 20th-century President since Calvin Coolidge has stayed here. Daily room rates: $125 to $195.
WESTIN TABOR CENTER, 1672 Lawrence Street, (303) 572-9100. Location, location, location -- right on the 16th Street Mall, close to theaters, LoDo restaurants and downtown offices. The lobby, lean and blond, is enlivened by an angular stainless-steel fountain. A fourth-floor swimming pool offers a view of the mountains, and the amply proportioned rooms are subtly decorated, mostly in grays. A branch of the Palm, the Manhattan steak house, is in the building. Weekend daily room rates: $128, including breakfast and self-parking.
LOEWS GIORGIO, 4150 East Mississippi Avenue, (303) 782-9300. This 190-roomer is often overlooked. Although it is situated some distance from the downtown action, it's close to the University of Denver and the Cherry Creek shopping district. This is a handsome, well-kept hotel, full of fresh flowers and copious fruit baskets, with Italianate frescoes concealed beneath a steel-and-glass skin. Its restaurant, the Tuscany, serves the city's most sumptuous Sunday brunch. Weekend daily room rates: $89, with city view; $99, with mountain view.
OXFORD, 1600 17th Street, (303) 628-5400. Opened in October 1891, rescued and reopened in June 1983, this is Denver's oldest hotel. Reasonably priced, comfortable rather than luxurious, it has been skillfully restored. Its 85 guest rooms are furnished in turn-of-the century English, French and American antiques, including good Arts and Crafts pieces. The Cruise Room cocktail lounge, remodeled in purest Art Deco style in 1931, with hand-carved decorative panels and dramatic cherry-red lighting after dark, is so authentic that you expect Fred and Ginger to dance by at any moment. The dry martinis are no less genuine. Weekend daily room rates: $139.
 
Where to Eat
 
BAROLO GRILL, 3030 East Sixth Avenue, (303) 393-1040. It doesn't really look much like an Italian farmhouse, but Barolo delivers in other respects. The wine list, for instance, which would impress people in Turin with its 50-odd Piedmontese classics, from Angelo Gaja, Ceretto, Luigi Einaudi, et al; and the food: a superb wine-sauced duck, and a mixed fry of scallops, calamari and baby shrimp, served with a harissa mayonnaise, and perfect gnocchi. Such quality makes it easy to ignore buffoonery like presenting the check inside a Michelin guidebook to Italy.
PAPILLON CAFE, 250 Josephine Street, (303) 333-7166. Radek Cerny is a Czech who worked with Roger Verge in the south of France and pals around with the likes of Paul Bocuse. He mixes Italian, American regional and Asian influences in an appealing menu strong on seafood and pasta. A smoked salmon quesadilla with goat cheese is a brilliant starter, and gingered tuna and Thai beef salad are both worth trying. Service is more professional than at most Denver restaurants.
BRASSERIE Z, 815 17th Street, (303) 293-2322. This is the latest venture of Kevin Taylor, a pioneer of modern cooking in Denver. The setting is stunning: the Tuscan-columned main hall of an old bank, walls white, floors tiled, with four big palms and commedia dell'arte murals for color. My waitress was clueless, but I ate an excellent, properly chewy hanger steak with frites; at the next table, a tuna salad looked good. Every menu I saw in Denver featured tuna; I presume a school of bluefin swam up the South Platte River the day I arrived.
STRINGS, 1700 Humboldt Street, (303) 831-7310. A good-looking spot with bare maplewood floors and blocks of Mondrianesque color, even on the menus, Strings has been at it for a long time. On my last visit, the calf's liver and the pasta were hits, the egg roll and the waiter were misses. Noel Cunningham, the Dublin-born chef, is held in high regard by his peers around the country, and Denver's beautiful people flock there.
AUBERGINE, 225 East Seventh Avenue, (303) 832-4778. Only a decade ago, says a longtime resident, Denver thought good cooking meant "melting three cheeses on top of anything." This is the kind of place that helped change that, and at which Denver now excels: simple, welcoming, reasonably priced. There are only 15 tables, covered with brown paper. The Caesar salad is good, the desserts (like a rich panna cotta with coffee syrup) even better, and the Sunday-night roast chicken for two, cooked as it is at Zuni in San Francisco, a total delight.
 
Sights
 
DENVER CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS, 14th Avenue at Curtis Street. Information: (303) 893-4000. Tickets: (303) 986-8742. This weekend there will be performances of "Valley Songs," a coming-of-age story set in Africa, at the Source Theater; "Blues for an Alabama Sky," about the renaissance of jazz in 1930's Harlem, at the Space Theater; and Shakespeare's "Macbeth," at the Stage Theater. All shows are tonight at 8, and tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. and 8 P.M. Tickets range from $27 to $33. The Colorado Symphony Orchestra performs "A Night in Spain" this weekend at Boettcher Hall. Performances are tonight and tomorrow at 7:30 P.M., and Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Appearing with the orchestra is the Colorado Flamenco Society and the Ballet Espanol. Tickets: $10 to $40.
DENVER ART MUSEUM, 100 West 14th Avenue Parkway. Hours: Tuesdays, Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: adults, $4.50; students and the elderly, $2.50; children under 5, and everyone on Saturdays, free. Information: (303) 640-2793.
DENVER PUBLIC LIBRARY, 10 West 14th Avenue Parkway. Hours: Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. Free tours at 11 A.M., Mondays through Saturdays; Sundays at 2 P.M. Information: (303) 640-6206.
DENVER ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS, City Park between York and Colorado Boulevards at 23d Avenue. Hours: Daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: adults, $6; the elderly and children 4 to 12, $3; children 3 and under, free. Information: (303) 331-4100.
DENVER MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, 2001 Colorado Boulevard. Hours: Saturdays to Thursdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Fridays, 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. Admission: adults, $6; the elderly and children under 12, $4. Tickets include planetarium show. Information: (303) 322-7009.
BOTANICAL GARDENS, 1005 York Street. Hours: 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission: adults, $3; students and the elderly, $1.50; youths 6 to 16, $1; children under 6, free. Information: (303) 331-4000.
MILE HIGH STADIUM, 2755 West 17th Avenue. Information: (303) 458-4848. Home stadium of the Denver Broncos and the soccer team, the Colorado Rapids, who play their first game of the season at 7 P.M. on April 4 against the Los Angeles Galaxy. Tickets: $12 to $20. Call 1-800-844-7777 for ticket information. There are no tours, but the south end of the stadium is open, free, Mondays through Fridays from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M.
COORS FIELD, 2001 Blake at 20th Avenue. (303) 292-0200. The Colorado Rockies will play their first home game on April 7 against the St. Louis Cardinals at 1:30 P.M. Tickets: $4 to $30. Tours are available Mondays through Saturdays at 11 A.M., noon, 1 and 2 P.M. Tour fee: $5; for children and the elderly, $3.

PUB-DATE: March 28, 1998

SECTION: Section B; Page 11; Column 3; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 302 words

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Sees Hope Of Erasing Arts Losses

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
New York State may be about to restore aid to the arts to a level not seen in nearly a decade, State Senator Roy M. Goodman told cultural officials and artists yesterday at a gathering at Lincoln Center.
In what has become, in effect, an annual state of the arts luncheon, Mr. Goodman, a Republican and chairman of the Senate Special Committee on the Arts and Cultural Affairs, urged the Senate and Assembly to add $10 million to Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal of $41.7 million for arts grants in 1998-99. 
 That, he said, would bring the grants to be distributed to arts groups to nearly $52 million, close to the high in 1988-89 and 1989-90, when $54.3 million was given out each year, although inflation would make the difference greater.
Mr. Goodman said some members of his party had opposed national aid to the arts, but he said it was Governor Pataki, also a Republican, who reversed the decline in Albany. Under Mr. Pataki's Democratic predecessor, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, arts grants were cut, dropping to $23.3 million in 1992-93, according to a report by Senator Goodman.
Mr. Goodman said the prospects for a proposed state capital contribution to the arts had been thrown into disarray by efforts to spend much of the money on sports stadiums.
The prospect of more money for the arts was hailed by many at the luncheon, including Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center, who said: "We used to fight a rear guard action. Now the question is just how much the budget is going to be increased this year. It's a good feeling."
Still, the writer Kurt Vonnegut contrasted the $98 million budget of the National Endowment for the Arts this year with the billions spent by European governments overall. "Arts make the soul grow," he said. "The soul deprived of arts starves to death."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Major Indexes Close Lower For Third Consecutive Day

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Rising investor concern about corporate profits pushed major stock market indexes lower for the third day in a row.
An early morning rally bolstered by a stronger dollar, rising crude oil prices and Treasury bond increases fizzled by late morning. Then a broad array of stocks headed south and stayed there, in contrast to their recent resilience. 
 "I think there's a growing nervousness about the earnings reporting period," Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said. "As the days go by, the companies are telling you the earnings are not going to be as good as they had hoped."
Earnings warnings from Adobe Systems and Silicon Graphics were among the latest in a batch of disappointments announced this week. Many companies will begin reporting quarterly earnings in late April.
After Thursday's market close, Adobe Systems announced a larger than expected 50 percent decline in first-quarter earnings because of weaker software sales in the United States and Asia.
Silicon Graphics said yesterday that it would lose money this quarter because demand for its work stations and supercomputers was waning.
Such weakness among technology shares helped to push the Nasdaq composite index, a key technology stock indicator, lower for the first time this week. The Nasdaq fell 4.92 points, to 1,823.62. Despite those declines, the Nasdaq ended the week up 34.46 points.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 50.81 points, to 8,796.08, finishing the week down 110.35 points. The Standard & Poor's 500 company index slipped 5.36 points, to 1,095.44, off 3.72 points this week.
The modest declines could be short-lived, some forecasters say, if the Dow average surmounts the 9,000 peak and moves to 9,100 and 9,200 in the next two to three weeks, convincing more investors that the bull market's stamina remains strong.
"I think there is a psychological barrier there, but this is a normal little dip that's going to prepare us to break through the barrier," Robert Dickey, managing director of technical analysis at Dain Rauscher in Minneapolis, said.
"The momentum is still there," he said. "We're still likely to see money come into the market. Where else is it going to go?"
The continued flow of cash into mutual funds should also keep stocks from seeing steep declines, he said. "You can't argue with money and when money goes in, no type of analysis can fight that kind of trend," Mr. Dickey said.
But some analysts are not so sure prices will bounce back quickly.
"Momentum has been strong, but there's a natural hesitancy here," Mr. Acuff said. "The next thing is to take some profits and to sit back and see what happens. I'm not interested in market levels. I'm interested in whether companies are going to make their earnings."
Some investors have been extraordinarily cautious about making strong commitments to the market.
Despite the S.& P. 500's 12.9 percent gain this year, Richard Sichel, chief investment officer at Bryn Mawr Trust in Bryn Mawr, Pa., is still recommending that clients hold 10 percent to 20 percent cash in their portfolios.
Mr. Sichel said that if companies reported strong earnings, he might adjust his cash allocation to 5 percent to 10 percent.
 
Treasury Securities Rise
 (By Bloomberg News) -- The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday as the dollar rallied against the yen and investors snapped up the highest yields since March 6.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond climbed 5/32, to 102 11/32, pushing its yield down to 5.96 percent, from 5.97.
The dollar rallied against the yen on doubts that Japan will cut taxes to revive its economy, and after the credit ratings on four of the country's biggest banks were cut by Standard & Poor's. A stronger dollar increases returns from Treasuries for foreign investors who convert the proceeds into their home currencies.
Bonds had fallen this week as traders absorbed some $50 billion of new Treasury debt, including $25 billion of new two- and five-year notes.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA;
Two Presidents, Two Strong Commitments to Africa

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, March 27

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by President Clinton and President Nelson Mandela at their news conference today, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private company:
 
Mr. Mandela
During these last four years, we have received a record number of heads of states and heads of government. They have come from all continents and practically from every country. They have come from the industrial nations. They have come from the developing world. Some have advanced democratic institutions. In others, such institutions are just developing. . . . 
 I have visited one, which is a creditor nation, which has got one of the highest standards of living in the world, which is tax-free, which has got one of the best schemes of subsidy for housing, for medical services, and where education is free and compulsory, and yet the people in that country have no votes. They have no parliament, and yet they are looked after better than in so-called democratic countries. . . .
So we have received heads of states and heads of government from all those countries. But a visit to our country by President Clinton is the high watermark, and I hope that the response of our parliamentarians yesterday has indicated that, very clearly, our people have welcomed President Clinton with open arms. . . .
The fact that we have high respect for him does not mean that we have no differences. But I would like to declare that when we have differed on an issue, at the end of that, my respect for him is enhanced because I fully accept his integrity and his benevolence. But such differences are unavoidable. . . .
We had a Government which had slaughtered our people, massacred them like flies, and we had the black organization which we used for that purpose.
It was very repugnant to think that we could sit down and talk with those people, but we had to subject our plan to our brains and to say: without these enemies of ours, we can never bring about a peaceful transformation to this country. And that is what we did. The reason why the world has opened its arms to South Africans is because we are able to sit down with our enemies and to say, let us stop slaughtering one another. Let's talk peace.
We will comply with the provisions of the United Nations Charter. And the United States, as the leader of the world, should set an example to all of us to help eliminating tensions throughout the world.
And one of the best ways of doing so is to call upon its enemies to say, "Let's sit down and talk peace." I have no doubt that the role of the United States as the world leader will be tremendously enhanced. . . .
 
Mr. Clinton
. . . As I said yesterday in my address to the Parliament, I was very honored to be the first American President to visit South Africa on a mission to Africa to establish a new partnership between the United States and the nations of Africa and to show the people of America the new Africa that is emerging -- an Africa where the number of democratic governments has quadrupled since 1990, where economies are beginning to grow, where deep-seated problems, to be sure, continue to exist, but where hope for the future is stronger than it has been in a generation.
It is in our profound interest to support the positive changes in Africa's life.
Nowhere is this more evident than in the miracle you have wrought here in South Africa. The partnership between our nations is only four years old but already we are laying the foundation for a greater future. And I think everyone knows that the most important reason for our success is President Mandela. . . .
Today, we talked about how the United States and South Africa can move into the future together. We've reaffirmed our commitment to increasing our mutual trade and investment, to bringing the advantages of a global economy to all our people.
South Africa is already our largest trading partner in Africa, and as the President said, America is the largest foreign investor in South Africa. We want to do more. . . .
Questions and Answers
 Q. Mr. President, two days ago in Kigali, you met with survivors of the 1994 genocide in Rwanda and you said that the United States should have acted sooner to stop the killing. Do you think that American racism . . . played a role in its inaction?
MR. CLINTON. I do not believe that there was any racial element in our slow response. Keep in mind, I don't think anybody on the outside was prepared for somewhere between 800,000 and a million people to die in 90 days. . . .
What I believe we have got to do is to establish a system, hopefully through the United Nations, which gives us an early warning system, that gives us the means to go in and try to stop these things from happening before they start.
And then, if it looks like a lot of people are going to die in a hurry, that kicks in motion some sort of preventive decision, mechanism, before hundreds of thousands of people die. I mean, if you look at the sheer -- the military challenge presented by those who were engaging in the genocide, most of it was done with very elemental weapons.
If there had been some sort of multinational response available and sort of multinational force available to go in pretty quickly, most of those lives probably could have been saved.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Leader Snubs U.S. Envoy and Rejects Peace Offer

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, March 27

 BODY:
The Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, refused to see a top American envoy today and rejected a European offer to help end the crisis in the independence-minded Kosovo Province.
In Kosovo itself, some 5,000 ethnic Albanians buried two men, cousins aged 19 and 21, who were killed this week when Serbian police officers and ethnic Albanians fought an 11-hour gun battle. 
 Mr. Milosevic declined to see the United States special envoy, Robert Gelbard, who warned senior Milosevic aides on Thursday that time was running out on chances to avert tougher foreign sanctions -- or a war in Kosovo.
More than 80 ethnic Albanians have died in police crackdowns in the province this month, fanning fears of wider bloodshed.
After snubbing Mr. Gelbard, Mr. Milosevic received Poland's Foreign Minister, Bronislaw Geremek, the chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. Mr. Geremek said he brought a plan for ending the crisis, but after meeting Mr. Milosevic, he was clearly upset and said he was disappointed that there had been no change in the Yugoslav position. Mr. Milosevic insists that the Kosovo problem is an internal issue that should be solved without foreign mediation.
In Washington, the State Department said Mr. Milosevic was risking stiffer economic sanctions by rebuffing United States and European efforts to resolve the crisis.
Mr. Gelbard later visited Montenegro and met with President Mile Djukanovic, an advocate of Western-style reform. Far from the diplomacy, more than 5,000 ethnic Albanians came by car, horse cart or on foot to the village of Glodjane to bury Agron and Gazmen Mehmataj.
A cousin, Haki Mehmataj, 39, said no one knew how the men had died. He said the whole Mehmataj family was home when gunfire erupted on Tuesday morning. Serbian policemen said the gunfire came from an Albanian terrorist ambush that killed one policeman.
Later the family decided to flee and the two cousins went to collect children from school. "That is the last we saw of them," he said. Today the bodies lay in open coffins, draped in Albanian flags, on a makeshift stage in the village.

HEADLINE: Personal Income and Spending Were Up Strongly in February

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Personal income and spending grew robustly in February, an indication that American consumers will continue to spur economic growth.
The Commerce Department said today that incomes rose six-tenths of 1 percent in February, the same as in January. Spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent in February, while January's increase was revised to seven-tenths of 1 percent, the largest rise since a 1.7 percent gain in July, from the four-tenths of 1 percent reported initially. 
Low unemployment, income tax refunds and a surging stock market are expected to bolster consumer strength. "The consumer is king of the world," said Christopher Rupkey, an economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York.
Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's output of goods and services.
The data were issued a few days before the next meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee. That body, the Federal Open Market Committee, will meet Tuesday and is expected to keep interest rates unchanged.
At its meeting on Dec. 19, the most recent meeting for which minutes have been released, the committee dropped the presumption that its next move in interest rates would be upward. Its members cited uncertainty about the impact of the Asian turmoil on the American economy.
Today's Commerce Department report also showed that disposable income, the money left over after taxes, increased six-tenths of 1 percent in February after having risen eight-tenths of 1 percent in January. The savings rate rose to 4.3 percent, the highest since June 1997, from 4.2 percent in January. Interest payments to businesses, which are counted separately from the spending figures over all, were little changed from a month earlier, at $160.6 billion.
The increase in February spending was led by strength in spending on nondurable goods and services, which both showed gains of half a percent. Spending on big-ticket items was flat.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1546 words

HEADLINE: A Road Warrior of Innovators;
Tires a Slow-Growth Industry? Don't Tell Goodyear's Chief

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio

 BODY:
How is this for a corporate nightmare:
Your company is in a slow-growth industry. It spends a fortune on research, yet customers view its product as a ho-hum commodity. Now the topper: Every new product either lasts longer than the old, does double duty or otherwise reduces demand for your company's goods. 
 That scenario would keep most executives tossing and turning all night. But it doesn't ruffle Samir G. Gibara, chief executive of the $13 billion Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. "If you innovate enough, you can have a sustainable competitive edge," Mr. Gibara said.
In tires, though, unlike the cars or computers whose users crave the latest bells and whistles, innovation can also crimp sales. Producers introduced all-weather tires and killed the market for snow tires. Several now offer tires that can go without air for 50 miles, obviating the need for spares. And all tires, even the cheapest, last much longer today than they did a decade ago.
None of which seems to faze Mr. Gibara. He promises Wall Street that he will make Goodyear grow twice as fast as the industry, adding $10 billion to its top line within five years. With tire prices barely keeping pace with inflation, the only way to do that is to increase market share. Acquisitions will account for some of that, Mr. Gibara concedes. But most, he insists, will come from home-grown innovation.
Whatever the route, he vows that Goodyear, now trailing the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan and Michelin of France in global sales, will leapfrog over them to the No. 1 spot in the world before five years are out.
Last month, amid much hoopla, he began trotting out the products and processes that he expects will drive that growth. There was a passenger tire that unlike the old steel-belted radials replaces polyester with steel throughout the tire carcass, making it, Goodyear said, one of the most durable tires around. There was a run-flat tire that unlike most available models can be installed on old cars without special rims or wheels. And there was Impact -- the Integrated Manufacturing Precision Assembled Cellular Technology -- which Goodyear says will slash the cost of making tires without expensive new plants.
"Are people forgetting that 35 years ago, a tiny tire company called Michelin introduced a radial tire, grew 25 percent a year and became No. 1?" Mr. Gibara asked. "Well, we have the radials of the 1990's."
Still, none of Goodyear's new products look like slam dunks. People who pay $125 each for the run-flat tires, for example, also have to spring $300 for a sensing system to tell them if their tires have lost air.
"These days, you can drive 70,000 miles on the tires your car came with," said Marvin Bozarth, executive director of the International Tire and Rubber Association. "Who wants to pay $800 to put new tires on a car you're ready to trade in?"
Nor is Goodyear traveling a low-traffic road. It commands 29 percent of American sales but just 17 percent of the $70 billion world market. Bridgestone and Michelin are less than two percentage points ahead, but even analysts who recommend Goodyear doubt that it will siphon sales from the leaders.
"Most consumers don't believe there's much difference between, say, a Goodyear or a Michelin tire," said Stephen Girsky, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. Moreover, said Efraim Levy, an analyst with Standard & Poors Equity Group, "Whatever Goodyear comes up with, the competition will match."
To hear the competition tell it, they already have. Unlike Goodyear, they say, their new tires are rolling and their new plants are humming.
"We announce breakthroughs when they occur, rather than prematurely speculate in the media," said James C. Morton, a spokesman for Michelin, who notes that Michelin has already installed its new manufacturing process in many plants and has had run-flat tires for certain high-priced models for years.
John Lampe, president of Bridgestone's American subsidiary, is equally dismissive. "It is easy to say what you want to be five years out," he said. Bridgestone, he said, is building an ultramodern tire plant in Aiken, S.C., and is modernizing 17 other plants.
Nor is Continental A.G. of Germany, the No. 4 tire maker, standing still. Continental General Tire Inc., its American subsidiary, is investing more than $100 million to automate the plants that make its biggest-selling tires. "We're all automating and getting more flexible," said Bernd Frangenberg, the subsidiary's chief executive. "Frankly, I think Goodyear's claims are one big public relations story."
Mr. Gibara easily ticks off his rebuttal. He says he has armed Goodyear with a revved-up research department, a more nimble marketing operation and a number of alliances overseas, all aimed at getting products out quickly. "If you strike first, your sales grow, even if competitors are right behind," he said.
Investors seem to believe him. On Feb. 9, the day Goodyear announced its new products, its stock rose $3.632, more than 5 percent, to $68.88. Goodyear shares closed Friday at $74.1875, down 62.5 cents.
"When you introduce this many new products and technologies, your image as a leader serves as an umbrella for your entire product line," said Gertrude G. Michelson, a Goodyear director.
Goodyear once had that image down pat. Indeed, until a decade ago, it was on a roll, churning out new products and comfortably occupying the world's top tire spot.
But then, in 1986, the British financier Sir James Goldsmith made a hostile run at the company. Goodyear stayed independent, but it was a Pyrrhic victory. The company spent the next 10 years digging out from the $4 billion in debt it incurred in warding him off. "Research budgets were frozen, and we had to defend every project," recalled Chet Gasowski, an engineer who joined Goodyear in 1971.
"We were crippled," Mr. Gibara acknowledged. "Michelin and Bridgestone were buying up Uni royal and Goodrich and Firestone while we were paying down debt."
Things started changing in 1991, when Stanley Gault, freshly retired from Rubbermaid Inc., signed on as Goodyear's chief. In three years, Mr. Gault cleaned up the balance sheet, sold ancillary businesses and expanded distribution. Goodyear's research and marketing people had been working on a wet-traction tire for years; Mr. Gault lighted a fire under them, insisting that they push it out the door. Aquatred, the tire, was a hit, salvaging Goodyear's reputation as an innovator.
Mr. Gault also spurred Goodyear to spew forth incremental improvements, from the slightest change in tread or chemical composition. "He realized that a constant stream of new products is the only thing that will keep competition from grabbing market share," said Robert G. Purcell, owner of Purcell Tire and Rubber Company, a chain of 50 tire stores that is based in Potosi, Mo.
Mr. Gibara is trying hard to build on that momentum. While he continues to cut costs -- shrinking the headquarters staff in Akron to fewer than 500 from more than 3,000 two years ago, for example -- he is also beefing up the research staff. In the last year Goodyear has hired 100 engineers, and it is seeking 100 more.
And he is building outlets overseas, apart from the mature domestic market. "Stan Gault started the overseas push, but Sam Gibara has internationalism in his blood," said William J. Hudson Jr., a director.
An Egyptian by birth and an internationalist by career, Mr. Gibara spent 25 years working for Goodyear overseas and pushed the company into China, Eastern Europe and Latin America. He is not only chasing tire sales in those areas; he is also taking advantage of their low labor costs to make tires for export.
Mr. Gibara also masterminded a strategic alliance with Sumitomo of Japan, the world's fifth-largest tire maker, whose brands include Dunlop. Under the alliance, Goodyear and Sumitomo make, test and sell each other's tires in their home countries. Periodically, rumors crop up that the two companies will merge, but Mr. Gibara said that for now "we're happy with the relationship just as it is."
On the home front, Mr. Gibara has led Goodyear more heavily into the lucrative side business of retreading truck tires. "We want to manage tires cradle to grave," said Marco Molinari, Goodyear vice president of sales for North America.
Mr. Gibara has set his sights higher than that. He wants Goodyear to be a "transportation services" company.
He is offering, for example, to provide car companies with mounted wheels, not just tires that they must mount themselves. He is offering to handle fleet maintenance for trucking companies. He also wants Goodyear dealers to grab more of the auto service business -- changing oil, fixing brakes, everything but engine repairs.
"Too many people don't realize we can service their cars," said Craig Arch, who owns Bay Area Tire and Service Centers, a chain of seven Goodyear dealerships in Maryland.
Still, putting Goodyear in a fast-traffic lane will require a lot more than some extra brake jobs.
"Can anyone really grow at twice the industry rate these days?" asked Mr. Bozarth of the tire association.
His tone made it clear that he doubts it. How much time will investors give Mr. Gibara to prove him wrong?

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Fall for Third Day On Fears of Weaker Profits
Rising concern about weaker corporate profits pushed major stock market indexes lower for the third consecutive day. An early rally on a stronger dollar, rising oil prices and higher Treasury bond prices faded, and selling undermined a broad array of stocks. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been less than 100 points from the 9,000 level a week ago, finished at 8,796.08, down 50.81 for the day and 110.35 points for the week. But some forecasters called the retreat a temporary blip and said a renewed rally could push the Dow average past 9,000 in the next few weeks. Page D3.
 
Treasury securities prices ended higher. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell to 5.96 percent from 5.97. D3.
 
Income and Spending Rise
Personal income and spending grew robustly in February, an indication that consumers will continue to spur economic growth. The Commerce Department said that incomes rose six-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in January. Spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent, while January's increase was revised to seven-tenths of 1 percent, the largest rise since July 1997. D2.
 
Loss Forecast by Silicon Graphics
Silicon Graphics Inc. said it expected to report a significant quarterly loss and a 23 percent drop in revenues because of declining demand for the company's work stations and supercomputers. The news surprised securities analysts, who had lowered their expectations for the company only a few weeks ago. Silicon Graphics shares traded lower and are now worth less than half their value of six months ago. D2.
 
German Concern Over Euro Stability
The German central bank endorsed the country's participation in the euro, but it said it was concerned that big debts burdening Italy and Belgium could undermine the stability of the single European currency, which is to be introduced next year. D2.
 
Metromail Bidding Intensifies
The bidding war for Metromail, a direct marketing company, heated up, and Metromail's shares rose amid expectations that both suitors -- Great Universal Stores of Britain and American Business Information -- might offer even more. D3.
 
Higher Bid Possible
Decaux, a family-owned French outdoor advertising company, said it might make a bid for More Group of Britain at a higher price than an existing offer of about $750 million by the United States media company Clear Channel Communications. D3.
 
Costlier Cigarettes Foreseen in Law
After protracted negotiations on tobacco legislation, leading senators have agreed to drive up the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.10 over the next five years, almost double what the cigarette manufacturers accepted in a settlement they reached last June with state attorneys general. The price increase is not definite. A1.
 
REIT Shares Fall
Shares of several real estate investment trusts ended lower yesterday on news that influential members of Congress had thrown their weight behind a bill to end a tax break that has helped some REIT's expand. D3.
 
Pacific Lumber Still Faces Protests
A California environmental protest dating to 1925 is unlikely to disappear even with a recently announced $380 million deal to preserve the nation's largest stand of old-growth redwoods in private hands. Although the agreement would save 84 percent of the ancient redwoods owned by Pacific Lumber, environmental groups say the company remains free to cut substantial numbers of trees, covering an area bigger than New York's Central Park. A6.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN AFRICA: THE OVERVIEW;
From Mandela, a Gentle Admonishment

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN, March 27

 BODY:
President Nelson Mandela of South Africa praised President Clinton and some of his policies today as Mr. Clinton stood beside him in the midday sun, but he stoutly defended his right to remain friendly with nations the United States considers rogues, like Libya, Iran and Cuba.
He also suggested, fondly but firmly, that "the United States, as the leader of the world, should set an example to all of us" by reaching out to its enemies and saying, "Let's sit down and talk peace." The standing of the United States would be "tremendously enhanced," he said. A South African minister explained later that he had been referring to Cuba, among other countries. 
 Mr. Clinton listened intently, his face betraying no emotion. Excerpts from Mr. Mandela's and Mr. Clinton's comments, page A5.
It was an extraordinary moment. The rules of the diplomatic game do not permit the leader of one country to lecture the leader of another. But Mr. Mandela has such towering moral authority that the rules do not really apply to him, and American officials took no offense.
Mr. Clinton has made it clear at every stop on his 12-day tour of Africa that the United States wants full partnerships with the continent's young states, rather than the unequal relationships of the past. Today Mr. Mandela, at 79 years of age almost three decades Mr. Clinton's senior, acted every bit his equal.
After a 90-minute meeting with Mr. Clinton and a joint news conference, Mr. Mandela gave Mr. Clinton an emotion-drenched tour of Robben Island, where he spent 18 years as a political prisoner, confined to a tiny cell, forced to do backbreaking labor. From that confinement he emerged, as Mr. Clinton noted, "not in anger, but in hope, passion and determination to put things right," to become the first leader of newly democratic South Africa.
"When I come here," Mr. Mandela said after he and Mr. Clinton reached the island by helicopter, "I call back into memory that great saga in which the authorities, who were pitiless, insensitive and cruel, nevertheless failed in their evil intentions."
The two Presidents first visited a quarry where Mr. Mandela broke rocks, hour after hour, as his assigned duty. They were casually dressed, Mr. Clinton in a navy blue sport shirt, open at the neck, Mr. Mandela in a flowing gold and midnight-blue shirt whose collar was buttoned. Mrs. Clinton joined them.
Mr. Mandela put his right arm around Mr. Clinton's waist as he led him into the cellblock where he was jailed, and Mr. Clinton put his left arm over Mr. Mandela's shoulder.
"This was my home," Mr. Mandela said softly as the two men entered a 6-by-6 cell with a small window looking onto a barren courtyard. A slop bucket and a pile of gray felt blankets sat on the floor. For 14 years Mr. Mandela slept on the floor, until his bad back won him the privilege of a cot.
President Clinton praised President Mandela because he had survived "without having his heart turn to stone and without giving up his dream for South Africa."
Eight miles off Cape Town in the Atlantic Ocean, Robben Island was a place of banishment for centuries. Many of the leaders of the African National Congress, today the ruling party, were imprisoned on its 1,600 acres, and their lives were harsh. Like Gettysburg for Americans, it is sacred soil for South Africans. Patrick Lekota, now Chairman of the Council of Ministers, the upper house of Parliament, described it today as "the ground on which the peace, the stability and the future of our country was cultivated."
Tonight President Mandela was host at a state dinner at Vergelegen, a showpiece farm northeast of Cape Town. The guests ate in a marquee erected near the restored 18th-century homestead.
A bit shaky on his legs now, Mr. Mandela needs help going up and down stairs. But he was full of intellectual vigor as he answered questions at the news conference.
Mr. Mandela was asked about an African trade bill passed by the House of Representatives earlier this month. It has been widely criticized in South Africa as a harmful neocolonial plan because it would require African nations to privatize their economies and liberalize their political systems in order to attain free access to American markets.
"This is a matter over which we have serious reservations, this legislation," Mr. Mandela said. "To us, it is not acceptable. But nevertheless we accept each other's integrity and we are discussing the matter in that spirit."
A senior American official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said later that most of the African leaders had welcomed the bill, which Mr. Clinton supports. He conceded that the South Africans were highly dubious, but suggested that "when the intention of the act is better understood, that will erase some concerns here."
The bill's prospects in the Senate remain highly uncertain, and the continued opposition of South Africa, the continent's major economic power, would do little to improve them.
Noting that many foreign leaders had visited South Africa in recent months, Mr. Mandela said he had invited Fidel Castro of Cuba and Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, and had received Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former President of Iran. The United States has no diplomatic relations with those three countries, and has accused all of them of violating human rights and harboring terrorists.
"I do that because our moral authority dictates that we should not abandon those who helped us in the darkest hour of the history of this country," President Mandela said with animation. "Not only did they support us in rhetoric, they gave us the resources for us to conduct the struggle, and the will.
"Those South Africans who have berated me for being loyal to our friends -- literally, they can go and throw themselves in a pool. I'm not going to betray the trust of those who helped us."
But he stopped short of noting that for many of the years when Cuba, Iran, Libya and other countries were helping the cause of apartheid's foes, the United States and many of its allies maintained relations with the old white-controlled Government, largely because of strategic and economic considerations.
Mr. Clinton, who spoke after Mr. Mandela at the news conference, did not dilute his praise as a result of the South African's comments. Everyone in the world, he said, could learn from Mr. Mandela's example that "fundamental goodness and courage and largeness of spirit can prevail over power lust, division and obsessive smallness in politics."
To some in the President's party, that last phrase seemed to carry a hint of bitterness against those who have hounded him over his alleged financial and sexual transgressions. It was the first news conference at which the President was not questioned about those issues since the disclosure in late January of the testimony of Monica Lewinsky, the former White House intern.
Mr. Clinton also promised to press his partners in the Group of Eight industrial nations to cancel up to 80 percent of their debts for African countries that reformed their economies. He said that the subject of debt relief had been raised by every Africa leader he had met on this trip.
At the end of his remarks, President Clinton turned briefly to a domestic topic, expressing his determination to prevent a repetition of the shooting deaths of five people at a Jonesboro, Ark., school.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1678 words

HEADLINE: Hip-Hop Idol Is the Pride Of a People;
Young Haitian-Americans Get Help Against Stigma

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
Nelust Wyclef Jean, a member of the hip-hop group the Fugees, strolled onto the basketball court in the Springfield Gardens High School gymnasium in Queens, grabbed a microphone and delivered a few lines from "Gone Till November," a hit from his latest album.
The thousand or so teen-agers packed into the bleachers screamed and began to sing along. But just as quickly, Mr. Jean stopped and got to the main point of his visit. "I want everybody to know, first of all, that I'm a kid from Haiti who grew up in New York City," said the 27-year-old musician, to thunderous applause from a group of Haitian students, who were waving the blue and red colors of their country's flag. 
 Mr. Jean, who won two Grammy Awards last year and was nominated this year, was peppered with questions from students about how he got his break in the music business. But one Haitian girl wanted to know something else. "What do you do when people make fun of you because you're Haitian?" she asked with distinct pride.
Mr. Jean had a pointed answer: "The same people that are making fun of you, 10 years from now most of them will be on crack anyway. So get your education."
Being a Haitian teen-ager in America is not easy, many young immigrants and children of immigrants say. With black skin, French names and Creole accents, they stand out vividly at an age when fitting in is all important. The teen-agers say "Haitian" has become an all-purpose dirty word hurled by some of their classmates as an insult -- most often by African-American teen-agers who share their skin color but feel no bond with the newcomers.
Now Haitian youths in New York and across the country have latched on to Mr. Jean as a symbol not just of success but also of acceptance. His appeal across ethnic lines -- and especially his popularity among African-American youths -- is seen by young Haitians as proof that they too can fit in, be cool and win the respect of their non-Haitian peers.
"He's a hero for us," said Petit Frere, an 18-year-old senior at Springfield Gardens High School. "He makes us feel proud. He's not afraid to say that he's Haitian."
Mr. Jean, who has homes in Manhattan and New Jersey and has made frequent visits to schools in the area, says he wants to use his music to inspire young people and to bridge the gaps between ethnic groups, especially among blacks. But it is clear where his heart lies.
"They're the only ones I love," Mr. Jean said in an interview after the Queens appearance, referring to the Haitian youngsters. "If I can help them be proud of themselves, tomorrow they're going to go to school with a different self-esteem, and it's going to help them accomplish what I accomplished."
The music of Mr. Jean and the Fugees -- including Prakazrel Michel, who is Mr. Jean's cousin and also Haitian, and Lauryn Hill, who is African-American -- is a mix of hip-hop, reggae and rap, including raps in Creole, the language spoken by the majority of Haitians. That trend is even more pronounced on his solo album, "Carnival," on which the other Fugees appear as part of the Refugee All-Stars, his backup group.
Last year, Mr. Jean wrapped himself in the Haitian flag during a performance at the Grammys -- an image that was broadcast across the world and left a deep impression on many young Haitians in the United States.
The experience was a balm for lingering wounds. Edwidge Danticat, a Haitian-American writer whose novels depict her experience growing up in Brooklyn, recalls how some Haitian friends in junior high were beaten up almost every day after school, most often by black classmates. The situation got so bad that teachers had to escort groups of Haitian-American children home, and they were not taken along on class trips, said Ms. Danticat, whose short-story collection "Krik Krak!" was a finalist for the National Book Award two years ago.
A typical insult, she said, was "H.B.O." -- Haitian Body Odor. But Ms. Danticat, 29, said that Mr. Jean's ascension into American popular culture had presented another side of what it is like to be Haitian. "When we think of the Haitian identity, it will always be before Wyclef and after Wyclef," said Ms. Danticat, who has herself become a role model for many Haitian immigrants here.
To some extent, the rift between Haitian students and their peers, including African-Americans, simply reflects the typical cliquishness of teen-agers. And for generations, immigrant children from different parts of the world have found themselves confronting the taunts and fists of classmates who view the schoolyard as their native ground.
But Haitian schoolchildren have had to jump over more hurdles than many immigrants. Besides skin color and language, they find themselves confronting negative stereotypes associated with their deeply impoverished country and even the lingering stigma from the early days of the AIDS epidemic, when Haitians were inaccurately classified as a high-risk group.
Some American-born black students acknowledged that they were not on good terms with their Haitian peers, and they put the blame at least in part on the Haitians, describing them as standoffish. "They're different," said Kevin Peterson, a 17-year-old senior at Clara Barton High School in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. "You try to talk to them, and they turn away, so you just call them names."
At Erasmus Hall High School in Flatbush, Brooklyn, a group of African-American students hanging out on Church Avenue during their lunch break acknowledged that they had "beef" with Haitian students, and some described a continuing animosity.
But when asked about Mr. Jean and the Fugees, their tone was decidedly warmer. "Yeah, we know Wyclef is Haitian," said 17-year-old Yusef Taylor, adding the teen-age stamp of approval: "He's down."
Still, their admiration for the performer has not necessarily softened their overall attitudes toward their Haitian peers. "He's not like the others," Mr. Taylor said. "He's been here for a while."
Such tensions, of course, are not confined to young people. Relations between African-Americans and various immigrant groups in the city have often been strained, in part reflecting the economic stresses of communities that find themselves competing for limited jobs and other opportunities.
Some African-Americans feel that immigrant groups, including Haitians, unfairly reap economic benefits that are denied to American blacks. The immigrants, this argument goes, are given every opportunity to succeed while discrimination continues to confine many blacks to the bottom of the economic ladder.
And many Haitian immigrants are determined to distance themselves from African-Americans, fearing that their own progress will be slowed if they are lumped together with American blacks. Some parents even express concern that black American youths will be a bad influence on their children in school.
"African-Americans are as diverse as Haitians," said Dr. Carole Charles, a Haitian-born sociologist at Baruch College who has written extensively on the relations between Haitian immigrants and American-born blacks. "But Haitians identify them as being at the bottom. The animosity comes because African-Americans react to that."
The irony, Dr. Charles said, is that Haitians and American blacks should be bound together by their common skin complexion and concerns. "Both groups to some extent are victim of a racial system that they didn't invent," she said.
Percy Thorne, the principal of Springfield Gardens High School, said that more than 30 percent of the school's 1,900 students are Haitian, and that the number is growing. Citywide, school officials have identified about 7,000 students as Haitian, but that does not include those who were born here of Haitian parents.
The scorn of other students, particularly African-Americans, has a sharp sting for young Haitians brought up to take pride in their nation's status as the world's first black republic. Indeed, when Haitians first came to the United States in large numbers in the early 1960's, they were mostly well-educated French-speakers from the cities, who were often viewed here as exotic and sophisticated.
"If anything, they thought we were uppity," said Gosette Rimpel-Judkins, a 39-year-old executive who came to the United States in 1969. "I grew up in Bed-Stuy, and strangely enough, the only person who wanted to be my friend was a little white girl."
By the early 1980's, the image of Haitian immigrants in this country began to shift. Continued political repression and economic hardship forced an exodus of rural peasants who fled Haiti in rickety boats, their plight a staple of the nightly news. As AIDS began to take its toll, the Federal Government initially classified Haitians as a high-risk group, along with gay men, intravenous drug users and hemophiliacs. Haitians were removed from the list in 1991.
"You wanted to crawl under a rock and hide," said Herard Severe, a 31-year-old accountant who came here in 1966, referring to the AIDS fallout. "We caught hell."
But on the recent rainy afternoon when Mr. Jean, clad in baggy jeans,walked into Springfield Gardens High School, the Haitian students were not hiding. They came out in full force. "Where are my Haitians?" the musician asked in Creole, to wild cheers. "I want to hear from you."
"I see a lot of them cheering for Wyclef," Loudina Brice, an 18-year-old senior, said of her non-Haitian classmates. "I'm going to remind them of that when they call me 'Haitian.' "

HEADLINE: Senators Agree On Forcing Up Cigarette Price

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
After a week of day and night negotiations on tobacco legislation, leading senators have agreed to drive up the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.10 over the next five years, almost double what the cigarette manufacturers accepted in a settlement they reached last June with state attorneys general.
But senators cautioned today that many other elements of the legislation had not been completed and that the negotiations, including the agreement on the higher price, could still come apart. "We plug one hole up and then another one springs open," said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. 
 The Treasury Department estimated that the price increase and other contemplated steps, including limiting tobacco advertising and outlawing most cigarette vending machines, would result in a 40 percent reduction by 2003 in the number of teen-agers who smoke.
The biggest stumbling block today seemed to be how much authority to give the Food and Drug Administration to regulate tobacco products.
In a letter this week to the White House with copies sent to many senators, J. Phil Carlton, a top lawyer for the tobacco industry, declared that the cigarette manufacturers opposed the legislation now under consideration because "it would almost certainly result in industry bankruptcies."
In an odd way, the complaint may have improved prospects for the legislation, and the letter should be considered with that in mind. The tobacco companies are such pariahs in the public's eye that few lawmakers can afford to vote for a bill that the industry endorses.
But the companies are the largest corporate contributors to Republican politicians and are spending millions this year on lobbying, so their political influence remains substantial.
Staff members planned to work on the details of the legislation all weekend. Among those involved are senators from both parties and their staff assistants, officials from the White House and various agencies, public health authorities and representatives of state attorneys general. The tobacco companies do not have representatives in the negotiating room, but they are following developments closely from the outside.
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is directing the negotiations, said that he hoped to bring a bill before the Commerce Committee, of which he is chairman, next Wednesday.
No other legislation Congress is likely to vote on this year would lead to such fundamental changes in the society. President Clinton has called it the most important public health measure in years.
If the Commerce Committee approves a bill, it will be but the first step in the legislative process, and many obstacles will be ahead. If the committee cannot come to an agreement, then the prospects for tobacco legislation this year are slight.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, said this week that tobacco legislation must clear the Senate before the end of May if it is to stand much chance of enactment.
The House of Representatives is treading water on the issue, with House leaders waiting to see what the Senate does before they move.
The price of a pack of cigarettes varies considerably depending on state and local taxes. The average price nationwide is $1.94. The $1.10 per pack increase, when added to a Federal excise-tax increase already on the books and expected inflation, would push the average price to $3.58 in 2003, the Treasury calculates.
Politicians generally agree that raising the price of cigarettes is the best way to prevent young people from starting to smoke, but some have cautioned that the price cannot be pushed so high that an illegal market develops.
The Senate negotiators have estimated that the legislation would require the cigarette companies to pay about $500 billion into a trust fund over the next 25 years, significantly more than the $368.5 billion envisioned by last June's settlement with the state attorneys general. The payments would be financed by the price increase and would be passed on to smokers, but the companies would presumably lose revenue because fewer people would smoke.
In exchange for not challenging in court the advertising restrictions and other aspects of the legislation, the industry has insisted on protection from lawsuits based on smoking-related illnesses. One of the industry's main goals is to have a degree of certainty about how much money it will have to pay in legal claims.
The lawmakers seemed receptive to a ceiling on how much the industry would have to pay out in damages each year, with any excess payable in later years. But as of tonight, the matter of further protection -- especially a ban on class-action lawsuits seeking punitive damages for past industry conduct, a prohibition the cigarette companies urgently want -- was still undecided.
Senators said there was broad agreement that the legal protection awarded the companies should be contingent on a drop in youth smoking to specific levels and should be withdrawn if the goals are not met.
In addition, the companies would be assessed a stiff fine if the rate of teen-age smoking did not fall to the levels set in the legislation.
The sense among negotiators tonight seemed to be that those questions could be resolved if they could agree on the matter of regulation by the Food and Drug Administration.
The agency and leaders in the field of public health, like David A. Kessler, the agency's former commissioner who participated in the negotiations Thursday evening, and C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General, insist that the F.D.A. should be allowed to regulate nicotine as a drug and cigarettes as drug delivery devices. They want this authority to be codified in the new legislation.
The agency already claims such authority. But in a case now before a three-judge panel of the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, the tobacco companies maintain that it exceeds the agency's current statutory bounds. The case may have to be reargued, since one of the three judges died and another is ill.
The Food and Drug Administration is out of favor with many Republicans in Congress. Two influential Republican Senators, Orrin G. Hatch of Utah and James M. Jeffords of Vermont, prefer legislation that would restrict somewhat the agency's capacity to regulate tobacco.

Tobacco Documents Ordered
 ST. PAUL, March 27 (AP) -- Tobacco companies must comply with lower court orders to turn over 39,000 secret documents because a request for individual review of the papers is a "practical impossibility," the Minnesota Supreme Court said today.
The court stayed its order until 5 P.M. Wednesday, giving defendants in Minnesota's tobacco lawsuit time to appeal to the United States Supreme Court. David Bernick, a lawyer for Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, said the defendants would ask the Court for a stay and a further review of the state ruling.
Attorney General Hubert Humphrey 3d of Minnesota said the documents would "expose the full depth of the tobacco industry's law-breaking."
