HEADLINE: I Shop, Ergo I Am: The Mall As Society's Mirror;
Scholars Say Where, What and How People Buy Is Changing, and Not for the Better

BYLINE: By SARAH BOXER 

 BODY:
In certain academic circles, "shop till you drop" is considered a civic act. If you follow cultural studies -- the academic scrutiny of ordinary activities like eating fast food, buying a house in the suburbs, watching television and taking vacations at Disneyland -- you will know that shopping is not just a matter of going to a store and paying for your purchase.
How you shop is who you are. Shopping is a statement about your place in society and your part in world cultural history. There is a close relationship, even an equation, between citizenship and consumption. The store is the modern city-state, the place where people act as free citizens, making choices, rendering opinions and socializing with others. 
 If this sounds like a stretch, you're way behind the times. The field of cultural studies, which took off in England in the 1970's, has been popular in this country for more than a decade.
The intellectual fascination with stores goes back even further. When the philosopher Walter Benjamin died in 1940, he was working on a long study of the Paris arcades, the covered retail passageways, then almost extinct, which he called the "original temples of commodity capitalism." Six decades later, the study of shopping is well trampled. Some academics have moved on from early classical work on the birth of the department store and the shopping arcade to the shopping malls of the 1950's and even the new wide aisles of today's factory outlets and superstores -- places like Best Buy, Toys "R" Us and Ikea.
Historically, the age of shopping and browsing begins at the very end of the 18th century. In a paper titled "Counter Publics: Shopping and Women's Sociability," delivered at the Modern Language Association's annual meeting, Deidre Lynch, an associate professor of English at the State University of New York in Buffalo, said the word "shopping" started to appear frequently in print around 1780. That was when stores in London started turning into public attractions.
By 1800, Ms. Lynch said, "a policy of obligation-free browsing seems to have been introduced into London emporia." At that point, "the usual morning employment of English ladies," the 18th-century writer Robert Southey said, was to "go a-shopping." Stores became places to socialize, to see and be seen. Browsing was born.
The pastime of browsing has been fully documented. Benjamin wrote that the Paris arcades, which went up in the early 1800's, created a new kind of person, a professional loiterer, or flaneur, who could easily turn into a dangerous political gadfly. The philosopher Jurgen Habermas, some of his interpreters say, has equated consumer capitalism with the feminization of culture. And now some feminists, putting a new spin on this idea, are claiming the store as the place where women first became "public women."
By imagining that they owned the wares, women were "transported into new identities," Ms. Lynch said. By meeting with their friends, they created what feminist critics like Nancy Fraser and Miriam Hansen call "counter publics," groups of disenfranchised people.
 
Putting Merchants In Their Place
Some feminists point out that as shoppers, women had the power to alter other people's lives. Women who spent "a summer's day cheapening a pair of gloves" without buying anything, as Southey put it, were "fortifying the boundaries of social class," Ms. Lynch said. They were "teaching haberdashers and milliners their place," taunting them with the prospect of a purchase and never delivering. It may not have been nice, but it was a sort of political power.
Women could also use their power for good. In 1815, Ms. Lynch points out, Mary Lamb wrote an essay called "On Needlework," urging upper-class ladies who liked to do needlework as a hobby to give compensatory pay to women who did it to make a living. Lamb's biographer recently noted that this was how "bourgeois women busily distributed the fruits of their husbands' capitalist gains in the name of female solidarity."
The idea that shopping is a form of civil action naturally has its critics. In one of the essays in a book titled "Buy This Book," Don Slater, a sociologist at the University of London, criticized the tendency of many academics to celebrate "the productivity, creativity, autonomy, rebelliousness and even . . . the 'authority' of the consumer." The trouble with this kind of post-modern populism is that it mirrors "the logic of the consumer society it seeks to analyze," he said. Such theories, without distinguishing between real needs and false ones, he suggested, assume that shoppers are rational and autonomous creatures who acquire what they want and want what they acquire.
Another critic, Meaghan Morris, author of an essay called "Banality in Cultural Studies," has faulted academics for idealizing the pleasure and power of shopping and underestimating the "anger, frustration, sorrow, irritation, hatred, boredom and fatigue" that go with it.
The field of shopping studies, whatever you think of it, is now at a pivotal point. In the 19th century, emporiums in London and arcades in Paris turned shopping into social occasions; in the 20th century, academics turned shopping into civic action; and in the 21st century, it seems that megastores will bring us into a new, darker era.
Shoppers' freedoms are changing. According to Robert Bocock, writing in "Consumption," the mall walkers of today do not have the rights that the flaneurs of the 19th century had. "In the United States, 'policing' of who is allowed entry to the malls has become stricter in the last two or three decades of the 20th century."
In superstores, the role of shoppers has changed even more radically. Superstores are warehouses that stock an astounding number of goods picked out at a national corporate level, said Marianne Conroy, a scholar of comparative literature at the University of Maryland. Shoppers educate themselves about the goods and serve themselves. Thus, the superstore effectively "strips shopping of its aura of sociality," Ms. Conroy said. There is no meaningful interaction between the salespeople and the shoppers or among the shoppers. The shoppers' relationship is not with other people but with boxes and shelves.
Does the concept of the shopper as citizen still hold? The real test is to see how the citizen-shopper fares at the superstore. In a paper she delivered to the Modern Language Association, titled "You've Gotta Fight for Your Right to Shop: Superstores, Citizenship and the Restructuring of Consumption," Ms. Conroy analyzed one event in the history of a superstore that tested the equation between shopping and citizenship.
In 1996 Ronald Kahlow, a software engineer, decided to do some comparison shopping at a Best Buy outlet store in Reston, Va., by punching the prices and model numbers of some televisions into his laptop computer. When store employees asked him to stop, he refused and was arrested for trespassing. The next day, Mr. Kahlow returned with a pen and paper. Again, he was charged with trespassing and handcuffed.
When he stood trial in Fairfax County Court, he was found not guilty. And, as Ms. Conroy observed, the presiding judge in the case, Donald McDonough, grandly equated Mr. Kahlow's comparison shopping to civil disobedience in the 1960's. Mr. Kahlow then recited Robert F. Kennedy's poem "A Ripple of Hope," and the judge said, "Never has the cause of comparison shopping been so eloquently advanced."
 
Like Canaries In the Mines
At first, Ms. Conroy suggested they both might have gone overboard in reading "public meaning into private acts," but then she reconsidered. Maybe, she said, it's just time to refine the model.
Ms. Conroy suggested that consumerism should be seen no longer as the way citizens exercise their rights and freedoms but rather as "an activity that makes the impact of economic institutions on everyday life critically intelligible." In other words, shoppers in superstores are like canaries in the mines. Their experience inside tells us something about the dangers lurking in society at large.
What does one man's shopping experience at Best Buy tell us about the dangers of modern life in America? The fact that Mr. Kahlow was arrested when he tried to comparison shop shows that even the minimal rights of citizen-shoppers are endangered, said Ms. Conroy. Not only have they lost a venue for socializing, but they are also beginning to lose their right to move about freely and make reasoned choices.
Without the trappings of sociability, it's easier to see what's what. Stores used to be places that made people want to come out and buy things they didn't know they wanted. And they were so seductive that by the end of the 20th century they became one of the few sites left for public life. But in the superstores, the flaneurs and the consumer-citizens are fish out of water. They have nowhere pleasant to wander, no glittering distractions, no socializing to look forward to and no escape from the watchful eyes of the security guards. If this is citizenship, maybe it's time to move to another country.

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
Remaindering Baghdad

BYLINE: By Shashi Tharoor; Shashi Tharoor is the author of "The Great Indian Novel" and other works of fiction, and most recently of "India: From Midnight to the Millennium."

 BODY:
I traveled to Baghdad in mid-February, not as an Indian writer but in the course of my "other life" as a United Nations official. The world was largely focused on two dramas at the time, both involving (in very different ways) issues of access to presidential sites -- the Monica Lewinsky investigation in Washington and the crisis over United Nations weapons inspections in Iraq. I had nothing whatsoever to do with America's internal affairs (if the dreadful pun can be forgiven), but the other crisis took me to the Iraqi capital, at very short notice, with an advance team to prepare the visit of the Secretary General of the United Nations. The necessary groundwork completed, there was just enough time away from United Nations business to catch a few glimpses of Baghdad before the political negotiations began.
Where does a non-Arabic speaker go in quest of literary pleasures in Baghdad? The answer, I was told by a senior United Nations colleague resident there, was to what visitors call the "book souk." This is actually a street market on both sides of a long block, rather than, as the word "souk" implies, a full-fledged bazaar. Along Almutanabi Street, old (and some new) publications are laid out for sale on the sidewalks -- magazines and volumes arrayed on sheets, racks and in cartons from a busy intersection at one end to a cul-de-sac at the other. This was not, for a visitor familiar with the third world, extraordinary in itself; it reminded me of the pavement bookstores of Calcutta's College Street. But what was different was the added pathos that many of the books and journals on sale were from the personal libraries of families devastated by life in post-sanctions Iraq, who now had to sell them to buy food. 
 And what a cornucopia there was for the indiscriminate reader! Books and periodicals overflowed the dusty sidewalks. Some were leather-bound, some tattered; first editions of rare books rubbed spines with paperbacks from forgotten best-seller lists; technical textbooks sat alongside primly covered Arabic girlie magazines from a more modest era. The volumes were mainly in Arabic, but the makeshift stalls also featured a multiplicity of foreign publications, especially in English (though German, French and -- according to a Scandinavian colleague -- even Swedish popped up too). Here I spotted a lovingly thumbed reference book, there a set of brittle 1950's Time magazines; 1970's Lebanese reprints of 19th-century British classics sat side by side with out-of-date almanacs and even, bizarrely, an old telephone directory. Many of the English titles seemed incongruous on an Arab street -- a paperback of Leon Uris's "Exodus," for instance, or even more startling, Grace Metalious's "Peyton Place." Though Iraq had long enjoyed a reputation as one of the most secular and cosmopolitan of Arab societies, adversity has begun to breed piety (among those who were buying, if not those who were selling): many of the newer volumes were Korans, some handsomely bound, and they were selling more briskly than the pulp fiction -- or the men's magazines.
I had heard from foreigners of the bargains to be had at the book souk: stories, perhaps apocryphal, were told at the United Nations cafeteria of op-
portunist colleagues like the one who had picked up a first edition of T. E. Lawrence's "Seven Pillars of Wisdom" for the equivalent of 7 cents in Iraq's dramatically depreciated currency (at a penny a pillar, the buyer clearly had little need of additional wisdom). What I had not heard about, however, was the avid interest of the local population in the offerings of the book souk. Even at an early hour on a weekend (I went by on a Friday, the Islamic Sabbath), there was a crowd of Iraqis on the pavement, browsing, chatting, laying out more books in remarkably orderly fashion, eager to share their wares with a visitor. Iraqis are a famously literate people; an old saw about the Middle East has it that "the Egyptians write, the Lebanese publish and the Iraqis read." Here was proof of this, in these apparently often perused, carefully preserved books bought decades ago, many with ownership proudly inscribed on the flyleaf, some lovingly annotated in the margins. It was easy to imagine them on the shelves of middle-class living rooms in educated homes, now brought out by their owners to help fill stomachs where in the past they had only salved souls.
The threat of bombs had been in the air for weeks, and Baghdad was full of journalists looking for news that would be obsolete in minutes. But here in the book souk there was a sense that there is a world beyond the news, that life must go on and that what sustains it is the timeless pleasure that the printed page -- read, re-read, passed on from hand to hand -- will continue to provide.
Perhaps I was being unduly romantic. By my rough calculation, the literary works and the potboilers were both outnumbered by the textbooks, many dauntingly technical and in European languages, some seemingly too old to be authoritative sources of the scientific knowledge they sought to impart. One vendor assured me that they sold well, no doubt because new books were either unavailable or unaffordable or both. And in disciplines where the opportunities for experiment, for practical work and for international exchange are dwindling or have disappeared altogether, textbooks, however old, are all that a student can fall back upon.
Many in the street, however, were just looking. I spotted a man in his early 20's picking up a book at which he had been gazing intently for some time. He held it, opened the cover, put it down again, then stood there looking at it, unable to walk away. Racked by hesitation, he picked it up once more, studying its contents as if weighing them against alternatives in his mind. Then he asked the vendor the price. When he heard the answer he had a hand in his pocket, perhaps fingering banknotes within; but I saw him shake his head sadly, put the book gently down and walk slowly away. I asked an Arabic-speaking colleague what the book cost. "Five hundred dinars," he replied. Thirty-three American cents at the prevailing black market rate of exchange, but a week's rations, perhaps, in a country where the typical middle-class wage is 4,000 dinars a month.
"For every student like that, you'll also find a fat cat buying books by the armload to cash in on the bargains," a diplomat who knows Iraq well later told me. "The book souk isn't kept alive by foreigners. There aren't enough of us here to do that. Iraqis are still doing most of the buying. But what's sad is that those who love books are mainly doing the selling."
With the book souk still on my mind, I took a trip to see the riverside statue of Scheherazade, the storyteller of the 1,001 Arabian nights. Only in Baghdad, said friends who know the Arab world, would there be such a statue at all -- not only of a woman but of a woman renowned for decidedly un-Islamic reasons.
Scheherazade stood 20 feet high in black stone, hands extended, weaving her spell to an equally immense sculpture of her husband, the Sultan Shahryar, reclining entranced at a safe distance. Her eyes were large, her gown flowing, her expression modest; but there was no doubt that she dominated the scene, a woman harnessing the power of fiction to her own salvation.
I walked slowly around the plinth on which the pair had been erected and failed to find a plaque or even a date. Nor was there any other visitor or attendant to ask. The site was deserted, and the park in which the statuary stood was overgrown and ill tended. The city of the fabled Caliph Harun ar-Rashid, patron of the arts, now neglects its own stories -- as if, with harsh reality pressing down upon it, even literary Baghdad can no longer seek solace in the magic of myth.

HEADLINE: A Life on Art's Barricades

BYLINE: By Lee Siegel; Lee Siegel is a contributing editor for Art News.

 BODY:

Clement Greenberg
 A Life.
 By Florence Rubenfeld.
 Illustrated. 336 pp. New York:
 Scribner. $32. 
 CEZANNE said that Monet was just an eye, but what an eye. The so-called New York intellectuals were all opinions, but what opinions, and how fiercely held! Writing about Hamlet, T. S. Eliot famously coined the term "objective correlative" to express the idea of an external dramatic situation that justified a character's inner state. The external drama of exhausting debate was the name of the New York intellectuals' desire.
The biographer who chooses a life among that ardent throng has to liberate it from the sentimental caricature that frequently accompanies the burst of nostalgia the New York intellectuals now enjoy, if enjoy is the word. As a clutch of memoirs attest, their lives were often as involuted as some of their arguments. And just as often, their generalizing, overbearing manner and their frantic competition were the underside to their impassioned, beautifully complex and independent minds.
Clement Greenberg, America's most potent and consequential art critic, is invulnerable to sentimental treatment. In this respect, he makes a good subject for a biography. Born in the Bronx in 1909 to Polish Jews of Lithuanian extraction, he attended Syracuse University and not City College, the fabled stamping ground of many other New York intellectuals. According to Florence Rubenfeld's evidence in "Clement Greenberg: A Life," his father was "rarely sympathetic or compassionate," but he also seems to have encouraged his son's intellectual ambitions. Greenberg's mother, who died when he was 16, arranged life-drawing lessons for him. And Greenberg senior built himself up, even through the Depression, from modest merchant to large manufacturer, becoming a millionaire. Unlike many others in his circle who grew up during those hardscrabble years, Greenberg seems never to have worried about money. In the ideologically troubled and troubling 1930's, he regally rode horses in a Brooklyn park.
Yet Greenberg pined for higher social status. All his life, he courted socially elevated women. In his early 20's, he married Edwina (Toady) Ewing in San Francisco after a three-week affair. They had a son, and then he returned to his father's spacious Brooklyn apartment. Though he sent Edwina money from time to time, he never lived with either her or their son again and later obtained a divorce. In 1956, he married Janice Van Horne, and the two of them soon embarked upon an emotionally bumpy open marriage. Greenberg spent most of his life lurching between solitude and the social swirl, dwelling by himself in a small walk-up in a building owned by his father in Greenwich Village, just a few blocks from where his father lived.
In his 30's, he made his mark simultaneously in intellectual precincts and the art world by means of a single idea. It was all the more effective for its Procrustean simplicity. He laid down its premises in a 1939 essay in Partisan Review called "Avant-Garde and Kitsch." Adopting what would become a trademark air of emergency, Greenberg argued that modern mass society had created two separate cultures: "One and the same civilization produces simultaneously two such different things as a poem by T. S. Eliot and a Tin Pan Alley song." Tin Pan Alley, however, was winning. Low art had appropriated the interest -- and the economic support -- of educated taste. Worse, the sharp idiocies of popular culture were slouching toward democracy's jugular vein. Kitsch, Greenberg wrote, was "vicarious experience and faked sensations . . . the epitome of all that is spurious in the life of our times." It could be "dangerous to the naive seeker of true light." Kitsch posed the fascistic menace of groupthink.
In response, Greenberg argued, high art in the modern period develops an idiosyncratic language it can once again share with an educated segment of the public. It does so by striving to attain an "absolute" value far above modern society's confused content. Avant-garde art, in fact, abandons content altogether, each medium seeking the purest reduction to its formal components. Advanced art therefore becomes synonymous with abstraction. Like beautiful and well-born women, formalist esthetics seemed to beckon to Greenberg from a higher realm of freedom.
Though its originality lay mostly in its dazzling extremism -- the essay was historically inaccurate and conceptually overwrought -- "Avant-Garde and Kitsch" established Greenberg as a figure to be reckoned with. In short order, he obtained an editorial position at Partisan Review, got hired as The Nation's art critic and later became an editor of Commentary. Polished and assured, Greenberg's judgments were gravely weighted with his earlier Marxist faith in historical inevitability. As a critic, Greenberg offered the impression of having just conferred with God on, say, the subject of vigorously gestural brushwork (too tactile and thus "literary") versus pools of paint soaked into the canvas (cool and ineffable and historically correct).
Like many other New York intellectuals, Greenberg was in the process of recasting his politics in esthetic terms. The Trotskyist stance against Stalin became the avant-garde stance against kitsch. From the 40's through the 60's, Greenberg generously championed, and sometimes coldly abandoned, one artist after another as the historical agent who practiced his theory: Jackson Pollock, David Smith, Barnett Newman and Mark Rothko, Helen Frankenthaler (a longtime Greenberg amour), Kenneth Noland, Morris Louis and Jules Olitski.
Unswerving in his vision of art history, Greenberg possessed a signature intellectual style. It made a perfect accompaniment to the signature style Abstract Expressionist painters needed in order to prevail. And like those drinking, brawling, turbulently fornicating figures, Greenberg also played the tough guy, until intense carousing seems to have taken a heavy physical and psychological toll. Artists who didn't fit into his grand scheme he either ignored or scorned. People who disagreed with him he cut off, and if he felt insulted, he occasionally decked them, including women.
The swaggering could have long-term consequences. For years artists have been telling stories, which Rubenfeld cites, about resisting Greenberg's suggestions for radically modifying their work along his esthetic lines. As a result, they claim, Greenberg refused to grant them his imprimatur, thereby extinguishing their careers. Made an executor for the estate of the sculptor David Smith, Greenberg scraped the paint off some of Smith's outdoor pieces, convinced that painted sculpture had no place in the formalist utopia. Later in life, Greenberg, who died in 1994, threw himself into an authoritarian cult called Newtonian therapy, colluding with its therapists, according to Rubenfeld, to control the emotional and sexual lives of the friends and students he intimidated into joining.
Greenberg's financial relationships in the art world were also vexing, especially his business dealings with Morris Louis's widow. After Louis's death, Greenberg "stretched" Louis's remaining several hundred canvases himself -- that is, he decided how much white border there should be between the canvas and the frame, a crucial matter in abstract painting. Then he helped Louis's widow sell the art off at increasingly high prices, making sure after each exhibition to keep one high-yield work for himself. Still, as Rubenfeld observes, Louis had allowed Greenberg literally to direct his esthetic choices. The alternative was to let the posthumous paintings lie in oblivion.
Greenberg's numerous enemies turn such ultimately ambiguous episodes into war crimes, playing down their own worldliness to play up what they insist was Greenberg's venality. Such hostility is not surprising. By the 60's, Greenberg had influenced so many artists, curators and critics that he had become the art world's maker of taste and anointer of kings. Confronted by minimalism and Pop Art, he grew ever more doctrinaire and punitive. His foes, therefore, cherish the evidence of his manipulativeness, shady dealings and dictatorial invasiveness. And indeed, by all accounts, including this one, Greenberg was a supercilious and even sadistic man.
Rubenfeld, a former East Coast editor for New Art Examiner magazine, has ventured a life of Greenberg that is a defense of sorts. It is bound to kick up a stir. Her strategy is to present damning evidence against her subject selectively. (One would think that his notorious put-down, "stupid as a painter," would have been a stumbling block to her sympathy.) Methodically, she adduces counterevidence and then concludes with vindicating explanations. Greenberg, the agile dialectician, would have been pleased.
Unfortunately, Rubenfeld's method, though often colorful, makes Greenberg's ideas, and their cultural context, take a back seat to the admittedly juicier question of his character. The emphasis feels misplaced: Rubenfeld defends the seemingly indefensible man and breezes over the formidable critic. One wants to like her book simply because of the impressive amount of research she obviously has done. Yet for anyone who doesn't know much about the concerns that drove Greenberg, and about the milieus he traversed, this biography will be a big disappointment. For readers who do know about Greenberg and his various contexts, it will be an even bigger disappointment. For one thing, Rubenfeld's language stumbles across the page: The art market "took off so quickly and unexpectedly that neither laws nor longstanding tradition existed to regulate it." People are so careful that they "walked on eggs." And her thinking is juvenile. To take one example, she explains the ambitions of the editors of Commentary magazine, founded at the end of World War II and supported by the American Jewish Committee, in this way: "To the image of the Jew as shyster, shylock or victim, they wanted to add that of the Jew as writer, thinker, scholar, scientist."
She does not handle ideas more reliably. The antecedents to Greenberg's formalism, the arguments of his opponents, other trends operating at the same time as the ones he promoted, are merely glanced at. Aside from superficially discussing several seminal essays, Rubenfeld does not sufficiently analyze or quote from Greenberg's voluminous writings. She rightly notes that T. S. Eliot's critical writing profoundly influenced Greenberg, then proceeds to caricature Eliot's ideas. Alas, her psychological insight also lets the reader down: "Clem had," she notes, "what psychologists call authority problems."
This is not nit-picking. As Rubenfeld gratifyingly insists, Greenberg's ideas make up an important part of American cultural history. He was a valuable, if disturbing, figure, whose eye could be as stunning as his contempt for flatulent thinking was unbridled. His elitism, arrogance and unabashedly tendentious standards kept the art world in a democratic stew of outrage, opposition and fecund creation. His championship of Pollock, as against his archrival Harold Rosenberg's advocacy of gestural "action painters" like Willem de Kooning, fueled one of the most thrilling antagonisms in modern American intellectual life.
William Inge, the acerbic English cleric, once said that a man could build a throne with bayonets, but that he couldn't sit on it. Greenberg lived at a time that allowed him to build a throne with pointed arguments as well as with bayonets. And he sat on it -- cruelly, brilliantly, myopically, belligerently, tenaciously -- for as long as he could. He deserves from his biographer at least as good as he gave.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2561 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
A Dreamy Sojourn in Helsinki

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
IN the Helsinki Airport, at the start of a long winter weekend in the Finnish capital, I got an interesting piece of advice from the immigration agent who stamped my passport: "You don't get much vacation in America. You should strike."
I could see his point. Who goes to Europe in February, much less to Finland (at the same latitude as Siberia), for just three days? 
 I do, when the price is right -- in this case, $550, from a tour company called Norvista. The package included a round-trip ticket on Finnair from New York (leaving at 6 P.M. on Thursday and arriving at 9 A.M. on Friday, then departing Helsinki on Sunday at 2 P.M. and returning to New York in the late afternoon), two nights at the Hotel Inter-Continental Helsinki, buffet breakfasts, a $100 charge for single occupancy, and $52 tax.
I'd have done Norvista's five-day St. Petersburg package ($802 in February with tax and a single supplement) or an eight-day tour of Lapland ($1,695 in February with tax and a single supplement) had I the money and time. I did five nights in Venice in the winter of 1994 (on Alitalia for $799), two nights in Brussels in December 1994 (on Sabena for $599) and four nights in Madrid in February 1996 (Iberia Airlines for $735). Such winter deals are a great way to see the world cheaply -- provided you're not too jet-lagged to see at all.
When Greg Louganis hit his head on a diving platform at a meet in the Soviet Union in 1979, he blamed it on jet lag -- which takes a toll, as all travelers know. According to a book called "Jet Smart," by Diana Fairechild, a former flight attendant, a full day of recuperation is required for every time zone crossed in the air.
I'd be flying through seven, meaning I needed to confront the jet-lag problem head on. It has two main ill effects, I've found: a zombielike state on the day of arrival, and terrible wakeful 2 A.M.'s thereafter.
I took all my usual precautions, like setting my watch to Helsinki time the minute I boarded the half-empty jet; keeping a mask, earplugs and the sleeping pill Ambien (which I try to take as seldom as possible) at hand, so that once the tasty beef Bourguignon dinner was cleared away, I could curl up and sleep; stretching in the aisle; drinking lots of water, and swearing off alcohol -- a particularly painful step, because fine wine and Finlandia vodka flow freely on Finnair flights.
But this time I went further still, mixing up a vial of energizing essences that I bought in a health store (geranium, eucalyptus and rose) to drop in my morning baths; buying a homeopathic remedy called No-Jet-Lag (made in New Zealand, of leopard's bane, daisy, wild chamomile, ipecac and club moss) to take during the flight; and following the rather less-natural advice of a friend, a music producer who jets around the world scouting bands.
The key to enduring overnight flights is to consume no caffeine before and during the trip, he says. Regardless of how little shut-eye you get en route, you can make it through the next day if you drink about three cups of espresso on arrival.
I'd slept about five hours, so when we landed I felt decent, though as if still in the hold of a dream set in a strange, clean, quiet place vaguely like a sanitarium, with polished wood floors and windows revealing a piney world vanishing under a shower of big wet snowflakes. But this was the very real Helsinki airport, where I had my first hit of caffeine in the deserted shopping concourse.
It was a good thing that little was required of me. There was no line at immigration, and I didn't have to retrieve luggage because I'd carried on my one small bag. In the arrival area, there was a currency exchange booth, where I got all the Finnish cash I intended to spend (812 marks for $150, a rate of 5.4 to the dollar, with a 15-mark commission). Steps away, I found the Hotel Inter-Continental's reception desk, manned by a nice clerk who checked me in and directed me to the Finnair bus that takes passengers to the back door of the hotel in 30 minutes (about $5).
The 552-room Inter-Continental, in a residential neighborhood about a half-mile northwest of downtown, is a blockish nine-story edifice. It is hardly as distinctive as other buildings in Helsinki -- like the head-turning, white-tiled National Opera, which opened in 1993 just across wide, tram-plied Mannerheimintie. Still, the hotel's interior seemed plenty luxurious to me, with pillow-strewn couches in the lobby, two restaurants, the Opera Cafe and the Baltic Bar.
My room on the fifth floor (regularly about $225 a night) overlooked the courtyard and had two single beds covered in soft chestnut-patterned spreads, a comfortable sitting area with lots of pictures and lamps, and a deep tub in the bath. The maid gave me a terry robe for the pool and sauna on the top floor.
I can't think of a better way to shake off jet lag than by swimming laps and taking a sauna ($7.75 before 2 P.M., $17.50 thereafter) -- a health practice the Finnish have perfected, of course. In the wood-lined women's sauna chamber, which looked brand new, with blond wood, squeaky-clean tiled floors, and green mats and chairs, my head cleared and my skin tautened. Then, a gull flew by while I showered by the big picture window high above Toolo Bay, the almost landlocked body of water at the center of the peninsula where Helsinki was established by one of Finland's many Swedish rulers, King Gustav Vasa, in 1550.
Later that morning, a front-desk clerk sold me a two-day Helsinki Card (about $25), which turned out to be a veritable key to the city, entitling me to (among other things) use of the efficient mass transit system, a guided coach tour of the city and entrance to 47 museums. The card began to pay off right away, at the National Opera box office, where I got a $43 orchestra ticket to the Saturday night performance of "The Barber of Seville" for half price.
From there, I could have hurried off to join the bus tour or caught a tram downtown. But though the sky was gray, it had stopped snowing and the temperature was an unusually warm 45 degrees. So I wandered down a path in the sliver of a park that lines the west side of Toolo Bay, noting that the full-sized ice castle on the bank to the south was melting. (Every winter, the city raises a public ice work, like last year's frozen cathedral in Senate Square, where couples were married and babies baptized.)
The city center was my goal, but before reaching it, I stopped at the Carrara marble home of the Helsinki Philharmonic, Finlandia Hall, built in 1975 by Alvar Aalto, the revered Finnish architect. This year, the country is celebrating the centenary of his birth with restoration projects and exhibitions, including the one I saw in the lobby of Finlandia Hall on Aalto's unrealized plan for a total redesign of Helsinki (about $5.75).
Then, I joined a tour (free with my card) led by a guide who kept apologizing for his perfectly understandable but slightly fractured English -- which is how I got to see the exquisite, amorphously shaped auditorium and the upstairs lobby with sveltely minimalistic furnishings by Aalto. "I hope I turned out well," the guide said, patting my shoulder as we finished.
Back on Mannerheimintie, there were almost no people around at midday, as if the 900,000 Finns who live in the city had gone away for the weekend. I felt like a character in an old Alfred Hitchcock film -- "The 39 Steps," maybe. A tram clattered by. So I caught it, landing at the Art Deco entrance of Finland's oldest and largest department store, Stockmann, where I collected the "little gift" promised in my Helsinki Card brochure (a packet of five souvenir postcards), and had a chicken sandwich and cappuccino ($9) at the stylish street-level Cafe Strindberg.
Still feeling fine, if slightly addled, I saw the Academic Book Store next door to Stockmann, another bold Aalto building completed in 1969, with huge, show-stopping skylights; the Esplanadi, a park that evokes fin de siecle Paris and is bounded by two rows of handsome Beaux-Arts buildings housing Helsinki's finest shops, like Artek and Marimekko; Market Square at the east end of the Esplanadi, where a tongue of the ice-crusted Baltic Sea licks into the city, and the gloriously neo-classical Senate Square, pinnacled by Helsinki's imposing Lutheran Cathedral.
This is the historic center, built in the 19th century by Finland's new ruler, Czar Alexander I of Russia, and the German architect C. L. Engel. Cafe Engel, with swagged curtains and framed architectural designs, is on the south side of the square -- a nice place to stop for more caffeine and a slice of sour lingonberry pie (about $7.80).
It was about 5 and getting dark (not much different than New York), though I didn't worry about being out late, because Helsinki is safe, if empty, at night -- but for its sad, weaving drunks, a reminder of the severe recession that hit Finland in the early 90's, when the unemployment rate rose to 20 percent, from 3. I wasn't hungry, and thought a cocktail unwise. So I went to the eight-theater cineplex in the Forum Shopping Center downtown, where it seemed that everyone left in Helsinki had tickets to see "Titanic." I opted for "Anastasia," dubbed in Finnish but still beguiling -- even though I couldn't imagine what thinking Finns made of the Russian Revolution, Disney-style.
Life is strange, and travel more so -- which is why seeing that movie will remain a Helsinki highlight for me. On Saturday, I woke with a chest cold, then almost drowned when I fell asleep during my energizing bath.
The Inter-Continental's vast breakfast buffet (croissants, eggs, porridge and herring en croute), and visits to more architectural landmarks -- like Steven Holl's striking new Museum of Contemporary Art (to open May 1), Eliel Saarinen's mighty Art Deco railway station and the graceful Art Nouveau Hotel Torni downtown -- reinvigorated me. But a free noon classical piano concert at the Sibelius Academy, just east of Mannerheimintie and an hourlong ride on the 3-T tram, which makes a scenic crazy eight around Helsinki, made me sleepy again.
After lunch at the pretty Russian Galleria Hariton, just south of the Esplanadi, where I had blini with sour cream and salmon slivers ($12), I felt revived. Streaks of pale sunlight were filtering into the city, so I caught a ferry at Market Square (free with the card) to the island fortress of Suomenlinna, about a 20-minute ride away.
This great stone fort, begun by the Swedish in 1748, sprawls over four interconnected islets in the Gulf of Finland. In 1808, the Russians took it over, and Suomenlinna faced bombardment by the English during the Crimean War. Today, Helsinkians walk their dogs there, regardless of the weather -- which turned dismal again. Indeed, in the chill wind and rain, I never saw a place so grim.
I thought dinner at the Cafe Carelia, in a narrow, sprucely renovated apothecary shop across from the opera might cheer me up. And because the glass of white Italian wine, salad with pignoli, and fish canneloni I ordered (for $25) were delicious, it did -- together with Rossini's romping overture to "The Barber of Seville."
But I had to resort to a half tablet of Ambien to sleep that night. Shortly after breakfast the next morning, I learned that my flight home had been delayed three hours. So I attended the 10 A.M. service at Temppeliaukio Lutheran Church, an unusual domed structure sunk into a rocky knoll about a 20-minute walk south of the hotel. And though it was utterly sodden outside, I detoured north on my way back to the Inter-Continental to see the modernistic Sibelius Monument in Sibelius Park.
Just a taste of Helsinki, really -- but enough to make me want to return, perhaps on the way to Russia or Estonia. I can't claim that my anti-jet-lag efforts had been successful, but I'd survived and spent relatively little money. In fact, I had just enough marks left over to buy a little vase designed by Alvar Aalto at the Stockmann shop in the airport ($26.50).
On the flight home, I sedated myself with a tot of vodka, put on my earphones and cranked Sibelius up high.
 
A few days of Sibelius, herring and saunas
Getting There
Norvista, 228 East 45th Street, New York, N.Y. 10017, offers a wide range of trips to many destinations reached by Finnair, like Lapland, St. Petersburg and Stockholm. In February, the weekend package to Helsinki cost $399 a person, double occupancy, not including tax. But from Wednesday to May 14, the price is much higher -- $780, plus tax. Phone (800) 526-4927 or (212) 818-1198.
Finnair flies nonstop between New York and Helsinki daily. Fares can fluctuate widely: in late February, the lowest available round-trip fare for April was $951 with a seven-day minimum advance purchase, and in mid-March, it was $419 plus tax, when leaving on a weekday; (800) 950-5000 or (212) 499-9026; fax (212) 499-9037.
For stays of three months or less in Finland, United States citizens need only a valid passport. The Finnish Tourist Board, is at 655 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 885-9700 or, for brochures only, (800) 346-4636; fax (212) 983-5260.
In Helsinki, there's an excellent City Tourist Office, (358-9) 169-3757, on the north side of the Esplanadi, at 19 Pohjoisesplanadi. You can buy Helsinki Cards there, as well as at most hotels, the Stockmann Department Store (37 Pohjoisesplanadi), and the Hotel Booking Center in the railway station. At the exchange rate of 5.1 marks to the dollar, the card costs $21.50 for 24 hours, $27.45 for 48 hours and $33.30 for 72 hours.
"Jet Smart" by Diana Fairechild (Celestial Arts Publishing, $12.95) and No-Jet-Lag, a homeopathic remedy ($9.85 for 30 tablets, good for 40 hours' flying) are available from Magellan's, a mail-order house specializing in travel supplies; (800) 962-4943.

 Where to Stay
Hotel Inter-Continental Helsinki, 46 Mannerheimintie, has 555 rooms, an indoor swimming pool, saunas and two restaurants. Rates for doubles range from $264 to $313. Contact Inter-Continental Global Reservations, (800) 327-0200.
The beautiful Art Nouveau Sokos Hotel Torni, , is downtown at 26 Yrjonkatu. It has 152 rooms, with doubles for $109 Friday and Saturday, and $255 Sunday to Thursday. There is a chic restaurant and a pocket bar on the roof; (358-9) 131-131; fax (358-9) 131-1361.
Hotel Anna, 1 Annankatu, is a good choice for budget travelers. It has 60 small but neatly-kept rooms with doubles priced at $94 Friday and Saturday and $121 Sunday to Thursday; (358-9) 616-621; fax (358-9) 602-664.
 
 Where to Eat
Cafe Strindberg, on the ground floor of the Stockmann store, is an elegant spot for coffee and pastry ($5 to $8); (358-9) 270-60124.
Cafe Engel is a traditional favorite where you can sit as long as you like over a Lapland Golden beer ($4.70) or cappuccino ($3) on Senate Square at 26 Aleksi; (358-9) 652-776.
Galleria Hariton is an intimate, pretty restaurant at 44 Kasarmikatu, a block south of the Esplanadi. Entrees are pricey, with a dish of blini with sour cream and salmon slivers costing about $12, (358-9) 622-1717.
Cafe Carelia, a block north of the Inter-Continental, at 56 Mannerheimintie, has sleek furnishings, tile floors, polished service and Continental entrees for about $11 to $24; (358-9) 2709-0976.

PUB-DATE: March 29, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 996 words

HEADLINE: Word & Image;
Lies to Live By

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
"Save social security first," Bill Clinton exclaimed with the thundering-herd scandal hunters at his heels. And thus, the polls record, he first saved himself.
It was a more elegant lie than those that preoccupy the herd. If only the media could spare a few columns to scrutinize all the fraudulent accounting by both parties -- accounting that concerns not sex and perjury or even campaign finances but budget "balances" and "surpluses." 
 Here's an image that pierces those deceptions:
Imagine that you head a family with three kids who will start passing through college about 10 years from now. Even if each were to need only a static $10,000 a year, their education would cost a total of $120,000. But you are clever and affluent, so you begin now to set aside $5,000 a year. You expect your bank and broker to invest that accumulating College Fund so that it eventually yields at least $100,000 to cover your future obligation.
You now feel virtuous as well as prudent. Indeed, having met your most worrisome family responsibility, you proceed to enjoy the good life. You buy a house you can barely afford and move in circles whose parties, fashions, cars and vacations balloon your credit-card debts. Nonetheless, being clever and affluent, you move to avert the absurd interest rates charged by your overdrawn Visa account. You borrow $3,000 against the first $5,000 you've banked in the College Fund. After all, you figure, you're only borrowing your own money!
Presto: At the end of the year, you proudly announce that your family budget is fully balanced. Not a dime has been added to the large debts of the past; all expenses have been covered with available cash! And, you predict, your shrewd bookkeeping will achieve the same happy result every year from now on.
Your oldest kid dares to wonder what will happen to the shrinking College Fund. Not to worry, you reply; your reliable money management -- and a windfall bonus from a pending damage suit -- will keep future budgets in balance. What's more, your boss has promised annual raises of at least $500, maybe even $1,000, and these will yield an annual surplus! You warn the kids that you will not let them squander those raises. Every request for new spending will find you intoning, "Save the College Fund first!"
The college-fund metaphor perfectly explains the Social Security accounting of our leaders. They invoke the most sacred family values -- embedded in words like security, trust, balance, surplus -- to conceal a continuing Federal budget imbalance. In fact, the imabalance will grow under the weight of the Social Security benefits that have been promised to the baby-boomer generation.
Like my mythical College Fund, what is amusingly called the Social Security "Trust Fund" has long been "borrowed from" every year to pay for weapons, highways, prisons and other normal Federal expenses beyond the old-age pensions to which it is pledged. If the fund were really held in reserve to meet future obligations, the Federal budget would continue to show a woeful deficit. (And that's not even counting the promise to cover the next generation's old-age medical expenses.)
Even after all this legerdemain, President Clinton can claim a current balance only by counting the still unhatched chickens of a proposed deal with leading tobacco companies -- a much-resisted deal that would let the cigarette industry buy Federal protection against future damage claims.
For more than 30 years, Presidents and Congresses have pretended that the Social Security Ponzi scheming between the generations will never explode in their lifetimes. By claiming that they have now achieved budget balance and surplus, they only pretend to be fiscally responsible. Worse, they are also discussing new spending or tax cuts. At the President's urging, the Democrats propose to use the tobacco windfall to subsidize more child care and other instantly gratifying social benefits. The Republicans want to just give every family a little more spending money. But the cheers for Clinton's artful bookkeeping are bipartisan. Although in six or eight years the Social Security Trust Fund will run out of money to lend the rest of the Federal Government, both parties take false comfort from assurances that it won't be "fully exhausted" until the middle of the next century.
So the majority of voters have been misled into thinking of the complex Federal economy as if it were the family budget, once out of balance and now in. Thus it was that in the darkest hours of his latest sex scandal, President Clinton could rally the public to his side by celebrating an imminent "surplus" in his State of the Union address and vowing to use it to "save Social Security first."
He was greeted by cheers on both sides of the aisle. Republicans grudgingly applauded the brilliance of the President's ploy and took credit for forcing him to "eliminate" the deficit. The scandal-scarred Democrats cheered because they suddenly saw that they could escape the moral stench around the White House by running for re-election on a platform of economic virtue.
But where are all the truth hunters of the media? The true condition of the budget and the illusory Social Security "Trust Fund" is not so difficult to explain. Yet in The New York Times alone in recent weeks, more than two dozen articles have referred to the Federal Government's budget balance and future surplus, with only an occasional attempt to render a corrective accounting. Most news stories on television and in the press have given the politicians' arithmetic an almost total pass.
Economists have delved into the subject on a few op-ed pages. And some have also properly asked whether budget imbalance is not sometimes desirable at some stages of the business cycle. But the public has been effectively lulled by slogans that would never wash at the family dinner table. Ask any high-school senior worrying about his College Fund.

HEADLINE: Lust at the Top: the Prequel

BYLINE: By Gail Collins; Gail Collins writes editorials for The New York Times. This article is adapted from her book "Scorpion Tongues: Gossip, Celebrity and American Politics," to be published in April by William Morrow.

 BODY:
By the time the Monica Lewinsky drama has run its course, there will probably be more people who can identify Warren Harding's mistresses than the causes of World War I. Americans generally have little interest in history, but whenever the nation's moral bearings seem particularly shaky, we turn hopefully to the past, looking for evidence that the present social disarray is merely part of an old pattern rather than evidence of some long, irrevocable slide into spiritual decay. It's nothing, we yearn to tell ourselves. This has happened before, and we got over it.
Fortunately for our peace of mind, history seldom travels in a straight line. It's more like a kaleidoscope, in which new pictures are created with every turn. The current epoch is unusually colorful, but most of the pieces are still familiar. Previous generations have been exposed to gossip about philandering in the White House, some of which was probably true (Nan Britton's memoirs about having sex in the Oval Office closet with Warren Harding are pretty convincing) and some of which wasn't. Woodrow Wilson, who was not guilty of any White House affair more shocking than premarital sex with his fiancee, was rumored to be paying off an old girlfriend, and rewarding the go-between with a Supreme Court appointment. During his re-election campaign, gossips also said he and the second Mrs. Wilson had murdered his first wife, or at least broken her heart. (Wilson may appear to be a cold fish in the history books, but he had his moments.) 
 There are plenty of other parallels between the present and the venerable past. Politicians in previous eras also had to put up with a yappy media making all sorts of allegations about their private lives. (A late-19th-century copy of The Chicago Tribune compared two potential Presidential candidates, Thomas Hendricks and Oliver Morton, under the headline: "The Former's Name Untrammeled by Lust, the Latter's Reeking With Filth and Slime. A Few of the Hellish Liaisons of, and Attempted Seductions by, Indiana's Favorite Stud Horse.") There were sensational sex trials involving prominent officials and allegations of every sort of forbidden behavior, from sleeping with the housekeeper to cannibalism. Look back far enough, and you'll discover that Daniel Webster, a perennial near-President, was once accused of what we would now call sexual harassment in the workplace.
One aspect of the current scandal that surprised even the cognoscenti, however, was polls indicating a national shrug over the possibility that the President might have been having sex with a White House intern. Public opinion samplings have the shelf life of an open jar of mayonnaise, but it did appear that the American public was saying -- though with many hedges and respectful bows to the seriousness of perjury -- that character didn't really count. "I thought there would be more of a tendency to rush to judgment," said the historian Michael Beschloss, who is still sure voters will turn on Clinton if they find "incontrovertible evidence that the President behaved badly."
He may be right. But the popular response, although surprising, is pretty much in tune with our past performance. The American electorate doesn't have much of a record of punishing politicians for sinning in private. The saga of great men undone by private lust belongs to the sophisticated Europeans. We have no Parnells here. Jefferson, Jackson, Cleveland, Wilson and Clinton were all elected despite an enormous amount of gossip about their private lives. Some of it may have been false, but the public had good reason to think it was true. Somebody at Monticello was fathering young slaves who startled visitors with their resemblances to Thomas Jefferson.
Andrew Jackson had, in his dim past, lived with his future wife while she was married to somebody else, and his campaign's explanation about how it was all an innocent mistake was about as convincing as Rose Mary Woods's demonstration of how she accidentally erased 18 minutes of the Nixon tapes. Grant had a history of drinking problems, and if he did not drink during his White House years, he certainly ran the Government like a man who was half in the bag. Grover Cleveland had taken financial responsibility for an illegitimate child whose mother named it Oscar Folsom Cleveland, and although there was reason to think the candidate was protecting his dead law partner Oscar Folsom, Cleveland never spoke in his own defense. (As President, he married Folsom's beautiful young daughter. Somebody is going to make this story into a movie as soon as the market improves for romances about pompous 300-pound politicians with beady eyes.) The rumors about Cleveland escalated into charges of compulsive philandering, drunken brawling and the mass despoilation of New York virgins. ("Moral Monster," headlined The Cincinnati Penny Post. "A Boon Companion to Buffalo Harlots. A Drunken, Fighting, Roistering Roue.") The public was far from unconcerned -- people had all the familiar debates about how to explain it all to the children, and the need for the Commander in Chief to set a good example. But they were voting, as usual, for what was going to be the lesser of two evils. Taking everything into account, they elected Cleveland by a narrow margin. Despite further gossip about wife-beating and alcoholism, they gave him the most votes in the next two elections as well. (In 1888, the electoral college went to Benjamin Harrison.)
Those same impulses to overlook private behavior for the big picture are very much alive today. The ex-Clinton adviser George Stephanopoulos once asked Ralph Reed, the former head of the Christian Coalition, why the coalition had preferred Ronald Reagan, a divorced man with a record as an indifferent father who was not a churchgoer, to Jimmy Carter, a staunch family man and born-again Christian who spoke openly and earnestly about the importance of faith in his life. Reed said that those things were important to conservative Christians, but that Reagan shared their views on other, more overriding matters, like taxes. When the Clinton-campaign-strategist James Carville said, "It's the economy, stupid," he was not only coining a slogan; he was encapsulating 200 years of American history.
Beyond all that, it's still important to acknowledge that this year's White House sex scandal is more than just a replay of a very old scenario. In one important way, the Lewinsky matter really does take us where no electorate has gone before. We have never had a publicly litigated sex scandal involving a sitting President. To look for previous patterns of public response, we have to set our sights lower, in Congress. There have been plenty of politicians tarred by scandal, but few of them were driven out of office by the voters as a result. Arkansas re-elected Wilbur Mills to Congress in 1974 despite his alcohol-fueled high jinks with the stripper Fanne Foxe, the Argentine Firecracker (a k a the Tidal Basin Bombshell). The Mills scandal was part of a wave of unpleasant revelations during the 1970's about the private deportment of members of Congress, ranging from mistresses on the payroll to soliciting sex from under-age boys. Virtually every one of the men who were exposed, however, was re-elected -- including Representative Robert Leggett of California, whose relationships with wife, second family by a former secretary and lobbyist-mistress were summarized in a Washington Post article titled "Life of Immense Complications." The major exceptions were politicians whose misdeeds went totally counter to the public image they presented to the voters. (Several Congressmen have been re-elected after scandals involving homosexual solicitation, but not Robert Bauman of Maryland, who had run on a conservative, anti-gay platform.)
But it is important to point out that there is a second stage to many of these stories. Politicians emerge from the heat of scandal to win re-election but then frequently resign from office. It is easier to keep your job after being caught in some well-publicized private sin than it is to keep power. Some veterans of the exposes of the 70's, like Mills and Representative Wayne Hays of Ohio, quit after being stripped of their committee chairmanships. Others were indicted, or simply pressured into retiring by their peers. The most spectacular modern example of a politician brought down by a wandering libido, Gary Hart, dropped out of the 1988 Presidential race before a single ballot was cast. Later, when Hart tried to re-enter the field just before the New Hampshire primary, the first polls showed him well ahead of all the competition. But Hart had lost his credibility with the political insiders. He had no money, no staff and, after a few days of notoriety, no media coverage. He quickly faded from voters' screens.
Even politicians who retain power after a public scandal are permanently marked by the experience. Andrew Jackson became so obsessed with the evil of gossip that he spent much of his first term trying to clear the name of Peggy Eaton, a Cabinet member's wife who was being shunned as a slut. When Jackson sent one moralistic minister a handwritten defense of Eaton's reputation, people noted with awe that the 3,000-word letter was longer than his inaugural address.
Bill Clinton has always been blessed by voters' low expectations and an ability to weather humiliating public scrutiny that would send most politicians racing to the shelter of private life. But if the past is any guide, his challenge now has less to do with opinion polls than with the confidence of the nation's power elite. If it appears that the President is no longer able to govern, nothing else will matter. The people's tolerance is certainly being tested on an almost daily basis. But the past suggests that their focus will be less on his private behavior than on his ability to do his public job.

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Urban and Rural, Rise and Fall

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
YOU can't keep a good museum down. The Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is undergoing renovation, and consequently will have no exhibitions during 1998. Until last year, however, the center's director, Patrick McCaughey, was the director of the Wadsworth Atheneum. Largely due to this link, 43 paintings from the 18th and 19th centuries were taken to Hartford to form an absorbing exhibition, "Canaletto to Constable, Paintings of Town and Country From the Yale Center for British Art." 
Although the show might sound genteel, it is full of substantial issues. The countryside, with its economy was on the wane, and the city, which was on a tumultuous rise during the 18th and early 19th centuries, had a tense co-existence, and the paintings reflect this. But the social issues don't affect the sensation that each picture is its own world. And, to lend the catalogue a wider import, Cynthia E. Roman, assistant curator of European art at the Atheneum, who organized the show, engaged Carrie Roider, a specialist in British hunting poetry, to choose a contemporary selection from English literature to accompany each painting.
The obvious town and country opposition puts a viewer in mind of some other major dualities, such as that of classical and romantic. This opposition is reflected in the outlook of the two headliners.
Canaletto is the name by which Antonio Canal (1697-1768) is known. A Venetian, he went to England for a nine-year stay beginning in 1746, enticed by the prospect of painting metropolitan London for eager patrons. The exhibition has three of his meticulous, perpetually sunny, nearly topographical, views of the brash capital, along with a detailed rendering of St. Paul's Cathedral looming over minutely rendered citizens.
When John Constable (1776-1837) looked upward, it wasn't at the towering architectural marvels going up on the banks of the Thames, but at the cloud-filled sky, mostly over his native Sussex.
A bracing surprise near the end of the show is Constable's "Cloud Study," punctuated only by a few birds. The sky is prominent in other paintings such as "Malverne Hall, Warwickshire," which, though seemingly benign, reveals potential discord between nature and civilization. Ms. Roman asserts that in this painting the balance is weighted in favor of nature, noting the way the trees seem to be encroaching on the mansion. In Constable's attempt at a commemorative painting, "The Opening of Waterloo Bridge," the particulars of the pomp are obscured by energetic brush work.
Canaletto had several British followers, among them William Marlow and Samuel Scott, but in terms of depicting a vibrant London, Canaletto was preceded by Pieter Angillis of Flanders. His 1726 work called "Covent Garden" is loaded with lively vignettes of the mercantile life. At the painting's center is a heap of large vegetables -- the country come triumphantly to the city.
A view of London from long after Canaletto's departure, "Westminster Abbey and Bridge," by Joseph Farrington, painted in 1794, is noteworthy for the sense of calm it projects; boats glide serenely down the Thames, as if the growth of the city is taking time out.
Around the time of Canaletto's arrival there was a vogue for painting ruined buildings in rural settings. John Wootton is represented by two paintings featuring the vestiges of former abbeys, one with farmers, the other with fox hunters. Thomas Gainsborough figures prominently in the exhibition in four paintings that display his determination to preserve the idealism that, since Virgil, had been associated with country life.
Shepherds and peasants are Gainsborough's major heroes, in the middle of bucolic surroundings as far as the eye can see, as if the city weren't on the same planet. The late 18th century witnessed a vogue for picturesque views that included major topographical landforms. Richard Wilson's "View Near Wynnstay" is infused with the kind of poetic golden light that was popularized by Claude Lorraine, the inventor of the picturesque painting in the 17th century.
The dynamic structure of the exhibition means that it never reaches a point of rest. The calm world of Gainsborough is not an end, for the potential for upheaval is always there.
In a painting from 1733, "Boxhill, Surrey, With Dorking in the Distance," George Lambert evokes, in Ms. Roman's words, "a scene of arcadian harmony that recalls pastoral myths of a golden age." But the country prospect has a couple of prominent, disfiguring holes in which a peasant is digging for chalk. This signals the presence of industry.
Joseph Wright of Derby is best known as a chronicler of the Industrial Revolution. The dramatic "Cottage on Fire at Night" (1795-93), features one of Wright's triumphs of Rembrandt-like chiaroscuro. Even though it is not about industry per se, its major theme is immense and unsparing change.
This omen is also present in George Stubbs's "Horse Attacked by a Lion" (1770). Stubbs was a closely observant painter of animals, but this violent scene has social meaning, especially in the context of this show, for there were no lions roaming the English countryside. The horse symbolizes rural life, and the lion is the unknown terror that will savage it.
A more subtly disturbing work is the Alsatian Philip James de Loutherberg's "The Rainbow" (1784), which nevertheless packs a devastating message. A perfect rainbow arches over the landscape, but de Loutherberg's slovenly tourists, who probably were enticed on the trip by the prospect of the picturesque, have their backs to it.
"Canaletto to Constable" is at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford through April 26.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Upper left: John Constable's "Malvern Hall, Warwickshire." Left: Thomas Gainsborough's "Wooded Landscape With a Cottage, Sheep and a Reclining Shepherd." Above: Canaletto's "St. Paul's Cathedral."

HEADLINE: FILM;
The Movie That First Noticed TV's Grip on Politics

BYLINE: By J. HOBERMAN; J. Hoberman is senior film critic for The Village Voice.

 BODY:
HEGEL saw the ritual reading of the daily newspaper as the secular equivalent of morning prayer. If so, the great televised media events that periodically transfix Americans must be something akin to religious festivals.
Less exalted than the form of collective expression developed in ancient Athens, media events -- watched and parsed simultaneously by millions -- are equally dramatic. Whether the subject is a Presidential cover-up or a trial for double murder, these spectacular narratives are alike in certain key elements: powerful stars crash and burn while supporting players (even members of the chorus) become new-minted celebrities; phrases are turned and buzzwords introduced. Afterward, the images will be recycled and refracted through ancillary deals until the debris-littered national landscape suggests a New Orleans street on the day after Mardi Gras. 
 Such ghosts of media events past haunt "Point of Order," the 1964 documentary assembled by Daniel Talbot and Emile de Antonio from television footage of the 1954 Army-McCarthy hearings. Opening Friday for a two-week revival at Film Forum in Manhattan, "Point of Order" is the first documentary feature to treat American politics as spectacle, as well as a portrait of the first American politician to achieve full media symbiosis. Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, the flamboyant hunter of Communists, real and imaginary, built a career on events created to be reported. McCarthy's means were less photo ops and sound bites than tabloid headlines and wire-service bulletins, but long before the term "news cycle" existed, he knew how to manage it. As Richard Rovere wrote in his book "Senator Joe McCarthy," McCarthy "invented the morning press conference called for the purpose of announcing an afternoon press conference."
While televised hearings had made a national figure of Senator Estes Kefauver in 1951, the same format destroyed McCarthy. His problems began with the 1953 inauguration of President Dwight D. Eisenhower and the installation of the Republican Administration the Wisconsin Senator had helped elect. Having rocketed to fame by denouncing Democratic "treason," McCarthy was disinclined to abandon the issue. He used his chairmanship of the new Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations to probe Communist infiltration of the Voice of America, the International Information Administration and, finally, in a direct challenge to the former general now President, the Army itself.
BUT the military was not without its own resources. On March 11, 1954 (two days after CBS fired a shot across the Senator's bow with Edward R. Murrow's critical report on the program "See It Now"), the Department of the Army released documents chronicling the attempts made by a McCarthy aide, Roy Cohn, to obtain special treatment for the newly drafted Private G. David Schine, the subcommittee's erstwhile "chief consultant." McCarthy responded with charges that the Army had tried to forestall further investigation by taking Schine hostage. The Senate authorized televised hearings to begin on April 22.
Media interest was not a given. CBS passed on the telecast; NBC dropped out after two days. The full hearings were carried by ABC, a network then so weak that it had no daytime schedule to pre-empt. This gamble proved to be a brilliant coup. Public response was enormous. As the hearings built to a climax in June, CBS and NBC affiliates dumped their afternoon soaps to pick up the ABC feed while the Gallup Poll reported that an astounding 89 percent of adult Americans were following the show.
On some afternoons, the audience was estimated at 20 million. Among them was Mr. Talbot, then an unemployed writer living in Queens. "I was hooked," he recalls. "I watched every second. I was totally apolitical but this was a fascinating piece of Americana. I read McCarthy as a kind of W. C. Fields character selling snake oil."
Six years later, when he had become the owner of the New Yorker theater, a revival house on the West Side of Manhattan, Mr. Talbot wondered whether it would be possible to present excerpts from the Army-McCarthy kinescopes, perhaps charging viewers a dollar an hour. He joined forces with De Antonio, then an artists' agent, raising $100,000 to secure the rights to all 188 hours of televised footage. Although, according to Mr. Talbot, "neither of us had ever seen a moviola before," the partners spent three years distilling the material to 97 strictly chronological minutes.
"Point of Order," named for McCarthy's frequently employed interjection, remains a remarkable chamber drama. As in "A Midsummer Night's Dream," the narrative motor is the abduction of a princeling; Schine was the scion of a wealthy hotel family. Here too, confusion is rife. As The New Republic's Michael Straight wrote in his 1954 account of the hearings, "Trial by Television," McCarthy "understood that the investigation was not a court proceeding, where order would reign and rules of evidence would prevail, but a vast, disorderly drama whose plot would be shaped and whose end would be written by the actors possessing enough power to take command of the stage."
Who is investigating whom? Generals, Cabinet officers, senators, even lawyers are placed under oath. Senator Karl Mundt of South Dakota becomes the subcommittee's temporary chairman. The chaos produces a series of one-on-one confrontations, predicated less on rational discourse than on volume, quips and personality. The inquiry meanders from Schine to alleged Communist (and homosexual) infiltration of the armed forces, the question of McCarthy's sources and, finally, in a stunning non sequitur, the political associations of a young lawyer who is not part of the hearings but a junior partner in the firm of the Army counsel Joseph N. Welch.
McCarthy is playing to something larger than the committee or even the Senate. The television audience, he says more than once, is "the jury in this case." That the spectacle is being produced for the camera is underscored by the various debates on the quality of color-coded charts and photographic evidence. The crudeness of the television image only serves to render the antagonists more iconic. But although appreciated by his fans as a sort roughneck Mr. Smith gone to Washington to purge the Communists, McCarthy had a sepulchral urgency and a mirthless laugh that proved perversely untelegenic. (So too his 5 o'clock shadow, despite the "cream-colored makeup" noted by Mr. Straight.)
It was the prim and puckish Welch, a skilled trial lawyer (as well as a lifelong Republican), who blossomed under the lights. The Army counsel also badgered witnesses -- alluding even to Cohn's rumored homosexuality -- but where McCarthy specialized in menace, Welch proved a master of deflationary humor. Although the frustrated Senator attacked his nemesis as "an actor" who "plays for laughs," the Army counsel could also take the high moral ground.
The hearings and "Point of Order" reach their climax when, exasperated by Welch's cross-examination of Cohn (and over Cohn's silently mouthed objections), McCarthy exposes Welch's partner Fred Fisher as a former member of the left-wing Lawyer's Guild. This gratuitous guilt by association exposed McCarthy himself to Welch's withering scorn. "Have you no sense of decency, sir? At long last, have you left no sense of decency?" Welch exclaims to a round of spontaneous applause. Variety subsequently hailed him as "one of the great performers ever to appear on the small screen," and Otto Preminger cast him as the presiding judge in his 1959 movie "Anatomy of a Murder."
After seeing "Point of Order" in the 60's, the critic Dwight Macdonald suggested a revisionist view of Welch's cri de coeur: "It seemed to be a spontaneous cry of moral indignation -- 'seemed' because on this viewing, at least, I thought I detected a calculated artistry in Welch's performance."
In fact, according to Nicholas von Hoffman's book "Citizen Cohn," McCarthy had recklessly violated a "back door" -- or should we say "backstage" -- agreement not to mention Fisher if Welch avoided bringing up the subject of Cohn's draft record. Performance defeats character: McCarthy's psychology dictated his divergence from the script. He could not help himself. Nor, perhaps, could Cohn, whose irrational devotion to Schine had dragged the McCarthy juggernaut onto the rocks.
(For a contemporary audience, Cohn -- having already figured as a character in Tony Kushner's "Angels in America" and in Ron Vawter's one-man show "Roy Cohn/Jack Smith" -- may well be the secret star of "Point of Order." Mark Rappaport, maker of the innovative experimental documentaries "Rock Hudson's Home Movies" and "Jean Seberg's Diary," is currently preparing "Roy Cohn, or How I Learned to Hate the Commies." Cohn, Mr. Rappaport explains, is "a key to unlocking repression and denial in the 50's.")
Even before the hearings ended, a week after Welch's outburst, McCarthy was the butt of television comedians like Steve Allen and Milton Berle, who mimicked his constant interruptions and shouted points of order. Although the subsequent subcommittee report was ambiguous, the Wisconsin Senator's hold was broken. On Dec. 2, the Senate voted, 67-22, to censure him. Still, perhaps because McCarthy was America's pre-eminent media politician before John F. Kennedy, his fictional doppelgangers populate the Washington thrillers that characterized the Kennedy era.
McCarthy is reconfigured as a liberal appeaser in "Advise and Consent" and, even more outrageously, as a Communist invention in "The Manchurian Candidate." "Point of Order" is the documentary correlative. The movie had its premiere two weeks into 1964, still the disorienting aftermath of the Kennedy assassination, at the posh Beekman theater in Manhattan. There it played through the end of February -- a run overlapping the Beatles on Ed Sullivan's show, the opening of Barry Goldwater's Presidential campaign and the release of two more political fantasies predicated on the sedition of right-wing generals, "Seven Days in May" and "Dr. Strangelove."
Reviewing the latter for Partisan Review, Susan Sontag called "Point of Order" "the real comedie noire of the season." Indeed, in successfully repackaging "live" political theater as a sort of filmed political cabaret, the movie began new careers for its creators. Mr. Talbot branched out into distribution the following year while De Antonio established himself as a leading political documentary filmmaker. ("Milhouse: A White Comedy," which De Antonio directed and Mr. Talbot released in 1970, landed both men on the Nixon enemy list.)
McCarthy is as far from us today as the red-hunting Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer was from "Point of Order's" original audience. What remains startlingly immediate is the televisual. Treating the Army-McCarthy hearings as a form of found Pop Art, "Point of Order" is a movie about television -- literally. The kinescopes from which it was fashioned were filmed off the television screen. The public drama was already mediated for maximum human interest; its spectacle anticipates C-Span and Court TV as well as Watergate and Iran-Contra.
The most powerful demagogue is not McCarthy at all. Nor is Welch the real hero. An electronic cave painting from the dawn of the media-saturated age, "Point of Order" demonstrates the way that television inevitably recasts news as entertainment, subsumes politics in personality, elevates anecdote to history and, in the final analysis, substitutes its own flickering image for collective memory.

McCarthy, right, with his aide Roy Cohn during the 1954 hearings, which were broadcast by ABC (Photographs from Film Forum/Photofest) (pg. 30).
