SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 2; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1502 words

HEADLINE: Q&A: Bill Ayres;
In Forefront of Fighting World Hunger

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG 

 BODY:
BOTH body and soul need nourishment in order for man to survive." So says Bill Ayres, and he's taken to these tasks quite diligently. As co-founder and executive director of World Hunger Year in Manhattan, Mr. Ayres is working to eliminate world hunger. As a former priest and host of "The Bill Ayres Show," a call in radio program that airs Sundays at midnight on WPLJ (95.5 FM), he also dishes up plenty of food for thought.
World Hunger Year (WHY) is a nonprofit organization that supports innovative programs to create livelihood, self-reliance, food and economic security through research and education. In this country alone, some four million children live in homes without sufficient food, and 60 percent of them have at least one working parent, the organization reports. 
 Mr. Ayres grew up on Long Island. He earned a degree in philosophy from St. John's University and went on to pursue seminary studies. In 1966, he became a Catholic priest. He spent 10 years at St. Joseph's Church in Babylon before resigning in 1979.
In 1975, Mr. Ayres co-founded WHY with Harry Chapin, the singer-songwriter. In 1983, two years after Mr. Chapin's death, Mr. Ayres became the executive director. He is also on the board of Long Island Cares, a food bank he began with Mr. Chapin, and the Huntington Enrichment Center. Mr. Ayres and his wife, Jeannine, are co-founders of "At the Water's Edge," a series of self-help workshops given across Long Island. He has also written a book called "All You Need is Love" with Pete Fornatele, a WPLJ disk jockey and show host. It will be published in November by Simon & Schuster.
Mr. Ayres lives in Huntington Station with his wife and two teen-aged daughters.
Q. How did leaving the priesthood affect your professional life?
A. I had to resign from the priesthood when I decided to get married but, if given the choice, I wouldn't have left. I loved it. I loved the work, the education and the media. I was on TV and radio all over the country for the church. I was involved in the civil rights movement, hunger and poverty. I counseled people and became very aware of this need we all have to heal. I didn't want to change anything. So, I continue to do what I've always done, just not as a priest. There are three strands which have always made up my life: healing and spirituality, social justice, and media and communications.
Q. You blend spirituality with broadcasting?
A. Yes. I started doing a radio show on WGSM radio on Long Island back in 1968, when I was still a priest. I was working with Pete Fornatele, and he and I have been friends and partners ever since. In 1973, I hosted a show for WABC Radio called "On This Rock," where I would ask rock music performers to discuss the meaning behind their music and not just how many albums they had sold. Then came "The Bill Ayres Show" on WPLJ, a call-in show which is still on. It deals with emotion, healing and spirituality.
Q. How did you get involved in the fight against world hunger?
A. In the 70s, aside from my radio shows, I'd been working on a series of TV shows for Channel 9 about the third world. I came into contact with a missionary order which went all over the world. They had a film library and, one day, I sat and watched four hours of what I call "horror films" -- films of people starving all over the world. I knew about this kind of thing, but I had no idea the extent to which it was going on. It was one of those days that changes your life. I remember sitting in my car afterwards and my head felt like it was just going to explode. I knew I had to get involved, to try and help in some way.
Q. When did WHY begin?
A. Shortly after that occurrence, Harry Chapin was a guest on my radio show. He invited me to his house for dinner, and we became great friends. I suggested that we work on the problem of world hunger together, and he immediately agreed. Harry was a very quick study and had a tremendous amount of energy and intelligence. We formed WHY in 1975, but it was a very unequal partnership because Harry was able to raise a great deal of money, he had boundless energy and he just put his heart and soul into this project.
When he died in a car accident in 1981, I wasn't running WHY; I was on the board. About a year and a half later, the organization was in serious trouble, so I agreed to take it over for a couple of years. Now, 15 years later, I'm still here.
Q. What, exactly, does the organization do?
A. We do a lot of things; educating people and raising money are certainly among them. But much of what we do involves going around the country, listening to grassroots groups that have seen great successes in eliminating hunger and trying to bring them together and duplicate their efforts on a larger scale. For years, people thought there were two ways to deal with hunger. The "conservatives" believed that people needed to take care of themselves and that help should come from private charity, rather than the government. "Liberals" saw hunger and homelessness as community problems wherein we needed to help one another.
We think the answer is in a melding of the two. Self-reliance is an important thing. Harry Chapin loved the saying, "Give a man a fish and he'll eat for a day; teach him to fish and he'll eat for a lifetime." That's very important. But, we're trying to take that a step further. A man not only needs to know how to fish, he needs to have the freedom to do it and a place to do it. That's where community comes in. We have to help each other, and we feel government has a very important role therein.
We're trying to create a triangle -- a very powerful triangle -- where grassroots groups, government and business all work together to obliterate hunger. When groups of people listen to one another, they come up with some very innovative solutions. Over the last three or four years, we've helped raise more than $5 million to help feed the hungry.
Q. You say your work with WHY and your radio show on WPLJ were born of the same thing -- a realization that people need to tell their "stories" and begin to heal. Can you explain?
A. In my work with WHY, we listen to success stories that you don't read or hear about in the news; you usually hear about the disasters. But we want to take people's success stories and re-write the "story" of hunger. There are things that have been working, and things we know can work. It may once have seemed like a hopeless story, but we're changing it to a hopeful one. This is healing on a social level.
On my radio call-in show, I listen to individual stories and try and heal people on a personal level. There are specific themes that we deal with: self-identity, relationships, spirituality and social issues. We all have a story inside us and, if we don't tell it, part of us gets sick and may even die. Ultimately, the person may die. We all need a place to tell our story; someone who will truly listen to us -- not try and solve our problems but just hear us. When someone feels they've been heard, it makes an enormous difference in their life. It gives them a sense of confidence. And, often, when you tell your story, you work things out in the telling.
Q. You say society is undergoing a renaissance of spirituality, and that scientists and others who formerly rejected or even ridiculed it are now seeking and accepting it. Can you explain?
A. I think people are genuinely seeking spirituality. There's a simple reason for this. In the midst of the daily grind of life, it's easy to forget we have a spirit, and we can get depressed, even sick. We are spirits as well as bodies, and spirits need nourishment. Many people aren't finding this in their churches and temples; attendance there is down. I think that's tragic, because there is wonderful tradition in all the major religions.
Q. Why do you feel attendance is down?
A. I think it's because the services don't relate to people very well. There are so many competing elements in life now -- people are so busy -- that they really have to make a commitment to their religion and, to do that, you have to see it as something very valuable for you. Unfortunately, I think a lot of people got turned off as kids. They got a dose of fear-based religion, sheer boredom, or both. That's incredibly unfortunate, because the truth is that the traditions religions are trying to convey are anything but boring -- they're very exciting -- and the basic instinct is love, not fear.
Q. You try to help them do this with your radio show?
A. What I do is listen. I don't think you can counsel over the radio, and I'm not a professional counselor. My job is to listen, give some good advice if I can and to make suggestions so that people can get plugged into long-term help. I try to get them connected, whether it's with a good friend, family member, counselor or clergy person. The whole notion of people being connected, rather than isolated, is incredibly important.

HEADLINE: ART;
Collage of Memories and More On Civilians in World War II

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
I HAVE forgotten the name of the movie but not William Holden's performance in it. He is cast as the captain of a merchant ship who, while shaving, learns that the United States has entered World War II and, without missing a stroke, says, "Which side are we on?"
At the Hudson River Museum here is an account of the civilian response to the same situation. "On the Home Front," as it is called, adjoins "Say Ahh!" the quasi-history of American medicine, like its neighbor, long on information and very short on art. But the similarity ends there, for the medical show is large, flashy and tantamount to propaganda while that about the war is more like a collage of memories. 
 The memories come from eyewitnesses, as imagined by the organizers of the show, who are Yvonne Borelli, Mary Kocy and Laura Vookles. Education coordinator, museum educator and curator of collections, respectively, they were assisted by some students from the Museum Junior High School nearby, and their purpose is to make the war something more than an obscure event recorded in history books and sometimes dramatized on television. Humorously enough, the show is watched over by students who, of course, know only what they have been taught but are happy to share it with visitors, even those old enough to remember the war.
To emphasize the hardship experienced by civilians, the show begins with photographs of objects and materials that were hard to get -- a rubber doll, a toy car made of metal . It also includes statistics that make the current recycling campaign seem like an intellectual exercise. In those days, a label says, 12,000 razor blades were the equivalent of a 2,000-pound bomb and one shovel equaled four hand grenades. Among the more significant relics is a cartoon of a Japanese soldier with the caption, "Honorable Spies Say 'Thanks for the can you throw away.' "
Survivors of the Stalingrad siege would be amused to learn that American civilians "had money in their pockets but nothing to spend it on" -- no refrigerators, no toasters, a precious little toilet paper. On some tables, margarine replaced butter and organ meat and steak and, to insure a supply of fresh vegetables, many citizens raised them in victory gardens. A wall label mentions that soldiers needed candy to get them through "obstacle course training and battles" but says nothing of the Hershey bars that sweetened the American occupation of Europe.
"On the Home Front" is made up of installations, one of which represents the living room, complete with overstuffed armchairs protected by lacy white doilies, another a kitchen with ration books on the table and a third a sewing room. Objects like the wood-burning stove in the kitchen and the women's clothes in the sewing room give the impression that the show is less about the rigors of war than the deprivation caused by economic depression. The outfit displayed in the sewing room consists of a navy blue dress and a bright green cape, both very limp, together with net gloves and a rakish toque covered with pink flowers. Can these really have been made in the country which invented the band box look?
Items calculated to arouse nostalgia in the older generation range from zinc pennies to instructions on what to in an air raid, one of them to park cars "at the curb" before taking shelter. One more engaging demonstration of loyalty is a war bond decorated with Disney animals, which proclaims its owner to be "an investor in the country."
When it comes to bringing home reality, this investigation of inconveniences caused by war may succeed where Goya's etchings of war itself failed, if only because it reaches out to everyone. Thus, restrictions on clothing are symbolized by a label that asks, "What's worse than a mother who doesn't let you choose your own clothes?" and answers, "An Uncle Sam who won't let you buy them."
Rosie the Riveter gets a mention in the pictures of women in factories and there are pictures of women in factories. The star of the female section is a black worker in an aircraft plant who, quoting her sister, says, "Hitler was the one that got us out of the white folks' kitchen." The statement almost makes up for the sparse representation of black people -- two photographs by my count. But in a show that confines itself to the American experience such a lapse is hard to understand (and forgive), but I can only suppose that the support rendered by the National Endowment for the Arts was too modest to permit a wider focus. Still, parochial as it is, "On the Home Front" covers a lot of ground, and together with a slide presentation of war posters drawn from the collection of Seymour Chwast, it will continue to remind, inform and entertain its viewers through June 14. The information number is 963-4550.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Trophy Properties Top the Recovery in Chicago

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
THE recovery of the downtown commercial real estate market in major urban centers in the mid-90's has led in Chicago to new ownership at some of the city's choicest office properties.
According to LaSalle Partners, a major downtown brokerage and leasing concern, the number of major transactions, defined as sales of over $10 million, more than doubled last year to 13. LaSalle also estimates that investors spent $2.2 billion for downtown real estate, up from $500 million in 1996. 
 Included in these sales were some of the city's premier office buildings, beginning with the 110-story Sears Tower, until recently the world's tallest building. (It is now, at 1,450 feet, the second tallest, after the 1,483-foot twin Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.)
Several other notable properties have also changed hands, including the Merchandise Mart, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Leo Burnett Building. Earlier this month, the Amoco Corporation, owner of the 80-story Amoco Building, the city's second-tallest structure, announced that it was putting its building up for sale.
"We saw what happened with the sales of the Sears Tower and the Merchandise Mart," said Howard Miller, an Amoco spokesman. "And it is clear that the commercial real estate market is the strongest that it has been in a very long time."
Investors say there are two main factors driving the recovery -- the booming local economy and the influx of money from real estate investment trusts, or REITs.
"There are four great 24-hour cities in the United States -- New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Boston -- where investors know the downtown business district is assured of remaining a vibrant workplace and cultural center," said Michael Reschke, chairman and chief executive of Prime Group Inc., a REIT that has invested more than $240 million in downtown Chicago real estate in recent months. "We see a lot of upside here over the next two or three years."
"There's no question that REITs are a major part of the activity," said Camille Julmy, vice chairwoman of U.S. Equities, a downtown real estate company that leases, develops and manages property. "But at the same time, there is a broad base of investors looking at Chicago."
The largest sale in the last 12 months, the $804 million deal for the Sears Tower, did not involve a REIT. The Sears Tower has been something of a debacle for its owner, AEW Partners of Boston, in the last decade.
AEW Partners had acquired the building in 1989 for $800 million, just as Sears announced it was moving to a new headquarters in the suburbs. The move left about 50 percent, or more than a million square feet, of the tower's rentable space vacant. In the last nine years, AEW increased the occupancy rate to more than 90 percent but has never made money on the building, partly because it was obliged to offer rents that were 30 to 40 percent below market rates.
LATE last year, AEW sold out to the TrizecHahn Corporation, a publicly owned real estate concern in Toronto. "We didn't get the return we wanted," said Thomas Nolan, AEW's managing director. "We're not in business to break even."
The new owner, TrizecHahn, is betting that the downtown recovery will continue for at least four or five more years, allowing it to raise rents to market level. That alone, said Gregory Wilkins, president of TrizecHahn, would increase the value of the building to more than $1 billion. He also said his company would probably sell the naming rights to the building. "I think they would be worth a fair amount of money," he said.
The tower sold for $241 per square foot, top dollar in Chicago at the moment though still below the $300 per square foot that some buildings went for at the peak of the last real estate boom in the late 80's.
Of the 10 largest commercial property sales last year, seven were purchased by REITs and five involved Equity Office Properties, the REIT controlled by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier. Equity's largest purchase was the twin office towers of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on Wacker Drive, which it acquired for $462 million. Equity has also announced that it would bid on the Amoco Building, which is expected to sell for more than $500 million.
The competition for so-called trophy buildings, many with dramatic architecture and marble-clad lobbies, is easy to understand, Mr. Zell said. "Given a choice, and if rents are the same or only slightly more, tenants always go for the marble over steel and glass."
But trophy buildings are not the only buildings being snapped up.
Mr. Reschke's Prime Group Realty Trust specializes in acquiring what he calls "B buildings in A locations" and then renovating facades and lobbies to bring the buildings up to A status.
In the last four months, Prime has acquired four such buildings in and around the Loop, including two on LaSalle Street, the traditional heart of Chicago's financial community.
Mr. Reschke said that it was getting harder to find the right property "because there are so many people looking for deals right now."
"Every deal takes a little more work than the last one," he added.
Unquestionably, REITs offer a lucrative opportunity for many owners looking to cash out.
The main advantage is that sellers who accept payment in the form of REIT stock do not have to pay any taxes until they sell the shares. "It's a very attractive capital gains situation right now for a lot of folks," said Christopher Kennedy, whose family recently sold the Merchandise Mart and its across-the-street neighbor, the Chicago Apparel Center, to the Vornado Realty Trust, based in Saddle Brook, N.J., for $575 million in stock.
THE Kennedy family has been a major presence in Chicago since Joseph P. Kennedy, his grandfather and the father of the late President John F. Kennedy, bought the 4.2-million-square-foot Merchandise Mart from Marshall Field's department store in 1945.
Regarding the recent sale, Christopher Kennedy said: "We're not sure that we got top dollar, but that's not what we were looking for. We wanted the best currency." He added that because of the tax situation, stock provided the best return.
The big question mark in downtown real estate today is who will be first with new construction. With vacancy rates in some parts of the Loop at less than 8 percent, the lowest in a decade, and rents approaching what many see as the magic figure of $25 per square foot, most developers say it is only a matter of time before ground is broken for one or more speculative buildings.
"The big issue today in Chicago is large blocks of space," said Thomas Boland, national director of real estate for the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick, which recently signed a lease for 229,000 square feet of space at 303 East Wacker Drive, which is part of the Illinois Center complex. "If you need 150,000 to 200,000 square feet, you can count the choices on one hand and not use all your fingers."
"There's definitely a shortage of contiguous Class A space," said Earl Webb, managing director of LaSalle Partners. "And that probably isn't going to change until there's some significant consolidation or new construction."
No one, however, is predicting a return to the 80's and early 90's, when more than a dozen large buildings were built in a short time. "The presence of REITs should moderate the boom-and-bust real estate cycles," Mr. Zell said. "Because the companies are public, everybody knows what everybody else is doing. That's the kind of information that has never existed in the real estate market."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
When There's No More Space for the Overflow

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FROM the outside, the three-story structure on Van Brunt Avenue in Englewood, not far from Route 4, looks like any other office building. But inside, instead of office space, there is a vast collection of cubicles used by families as second attics and by businesses as extra supply closets.
The 41,400-square-foot structure opened last week as part of the three-acre Lackland Self Storage complex, with 1,200 individual storage units in five buildings. It is one of a spate of recently completed, under construction or planned facilities across New Jersey as developers respond to what they say is a demand for storage space with the latest available technology for climate control and security. 
 Among those responding are long-term players who continue to expand in the state, including Lackland Self Storage, a private firm based in Middlesex, and the Glendale, Calif.-based Public Storage, among the nation's larger self-storage real estate investment trusts, or REITs. They are being joined by newcomers that want to increase their market presence, like Shurgard Storage Centers, based in Seattle, which is also a REIT.
Last year there were 26,272 self-storage centers in the country, up from 19,438 in 1993, according to MiniCo Publishing in Phoenix, a company that tracks data for the self-storage industry. In New Jersey, there were 287, up from 239 four years ago.
The current number could double in the next two years if all the projects in various stages of development are realized, said David Haver, president of the New Jersey Self Storage Association, the state chapter of the national trade group based in Cincinnati.
Many of them are planned for the northern part of the state where incomes and populations tend to be higher and developers "feel they can get more bang for the buck," added Mr. Haver. He is also president of Keepers Self Storage, which is based in Manhattan and owns and operates over 1 million square feet of storage space in New Jersey and New York.
The self-storage industry, which is said to have begun on the West Coast in a row of empty garages, developed largely in the late 70's as people moved from from large homes in cold regions to smaller ones in warm regions.
But today, when job transfers and life changes, including marriage and divorce, entail more frequent moves, storage is the answer for families between houses or moving to smaller homes. And for families, as well as businesses in need of more space it is a less costly alternative to buying a bigger house or renting additional office space, industry experts and developers said.
They also said that the new storage structures, unlike the boxy metal buildings of the past, are more likely to resemble office and retail centers to blend in with their surroundings.
The activity in New Jersey started heating up last summer, said Daniel F. Spector, senior managing director at the Schultz Organization, a commercial brokerage in Woodbridge that is working with Shurgard Storage Centers. Several factors, he said, are stoking the push to develop, including the availability of money and the fact that the vacancy rate for storage space in New Jersey is about 7 percent.
In addition, MiniCo reported that the state had only .94 square feet of storage space per person in 1997, making it among the most underserved metropolitan areas in the country. By comparison, the Las Vegas metropolitan area, which is the best served, had 8.87 square feet per person.
ANOTHER factor is the overall improvement of the economy in the state, which is riding "the momentum of five and one half years of steady economic advances," said James W. Hughes, Dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University.
That in turn has helped increase the state's housing supply and fill office buildings. Indeed, the number of housing permits issued in the state last year was 27,454, up from 21,521 in 1995, state figures show.
The sale of existing homes also rose, to 157,247 from 138,300 in 1995, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors in Edison. And at the end of last year the 11-county northern and central New Jersey Office market registered an overall vacancy rate of 12 percent, the lowest in 25 years, reported the Sitar Company/Oncor International, a real estate services firm based in Woodbridge.
But land prices are rising as self-storage operators compete for prime sites, said Jerry Putterman, a senior vice president at the West Orange office of Grubb & Ellis, the national brokerage, which works with Lackland Self Storage. And rents for storage units, added Mr. Haver, are "stagnant." Moreover, some developers and industry analysts fear oversaturation.
Lackland has 17 self-storage centers in the state, of which four were built in the last two years. This year it expects to start construction on four more projects, each with 100,000 square feet and 750 units, said Michael Lackland, who manages the family-owned 21-year-old company.
In terms of production pace and style "we've moved along with the demand in the state," said Mr. Lackland, adding that the demand today was for "humidity-controlled space" and buildings with elevators.
A case in point is Lackland's newest building in Englewood, which has elevators and a front office with a central monitoring station linked to a security system. Of the 350 storage units at the newest building, 200 have heating and cooling, as do half of all 1,200 in the entire complex. The units range in size from 25 square feet to 300 square feet and rent for $61 to $360 a month.
The other four future projects, one each in Fair Lawn, Upper Saddle River, East Hanover and Clifton, will be similarly designed and comparably priced, said Mr. Lackland.
A window of opportunity now exists, said Mr. Lackland. But, he added, "it's scary" how crowded the playing field has become. "My biggest concern," he said, "is that the market will be oversaturated in 12 months."
Public Storage still sees New Jersey as a good market, "because of the supply and demand imbalance," said Harvey Lenkin, its president. Of the company's 1,100 self-storage centers 31 are in New Jersey, most of them clustered in the southern half near Philadelphia and the northern half near Manhattan.
"The market is competitive, but New Jersey's economy is good" said Mr. Lenkin, "And given our past success we will continue to add to our presence in the state as long as the demographics are there."
PUBLIC STORAGE'S latest project is a six-story building that opened last May on the northbound side of Route 17 in Rochelle Park. The project, which Mr. Lenkin said is prototypical for the company, features an extensive security system and contains 62,000 square feet and 628 storage units. The 25- to 300-square-foot climate-controlled units rent for $61 to $360 a month.
Mr. Lenkin said his company had two more sites under contract in North Jersey, which he expects to close on by this summer.
Shurgard, which has 300 self-storage centers in the nation, entered the state at the start of the year. "We see New Jersey, as the rest of the New York metropolitan region, as having great viability," said James Goonan, the company's regional development manager for the Northeast. "It's a hot market."
Typically, Shurgard builds 65,000- to 80,000-square-foot structures with 400 to 600 storage units protected by a buildingwide security system, Mr. Goonan said. All also bear the company's logo -- a 35-foot lighthouse. The company looks for development sites or existing commercial buildings "in the thick of things -- along Main Streets and close to shopping and residences," he said, noting that contract negotiations were under way on six sites, many in North Jersey.
"At some point the market will reach saturation," Mr. Goonan said. "But right now no one seems to be holding back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Lackland, manager of Lackland Self Storage in Englewood, N.J., at the family-owned complex. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q&A/Stuart Kessler;
From a Tax Man, Thoughts on Old Image

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
ON various levels the Federal tax code and the Internal Revenue Service have been under attack. Last year, Congress held hearings on reported I.R.S. abuse. Earlier this month, Vice President Al Gore called for a friendlier I.R.S. There is talk of eliminating the income tax entirely and replacing it with a national sales tax, and seemingly everyone decries how complicated the tax code is.
Stuart Kessler of Ardsley, a certified public accountant, lawyer and senior tax partner at the Manhattan firm of Goldstein Golub Kessler & Company, recently became chairman of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. He said he hopes to change the image of accountants -- he is not, he wants people to know, a bean counter -- and begin outreach programs to encourage minorities to enter accounting. 
 The association recently started approving sale sites on the Internet, assuring the public that the sites provide the services they claim and that credit cards are being protected. Mr. Kessler, a C.P.A. for about 40 years, was named one of the country's leading tax practitioners by Money magazine in 1997 and was listed among the 100 most influential people in accounting by Accounting Today in 1995. Here are excerpts of a recent conversation:
Q. You make a point that you want to change the image of the C.P.A. What is that image and why is it the wrong one?
A. It is really our grandparents' image that was handed down to our parents and down to us -- that of somebody who is basically a number cruncher, who is conservative with a green eye shade and rolled-up sleeves. I've been trying for over 20 years to bring to the public's attention the fact that we're a different breed now. We are now computer literate. We're broad thinking. We look to do things for business and individuals that are far beyond what our grandparents thought we did.
In fact, the students today don't learn to add in any college; they use computers. They used to use adding machines. But today, even on the C.P.A. exam you can use a calculator. When I took the exam, we'd spend half our time adding and subtracting and multiplying. That's no longer. We're business consultants. We bring a lot to the table for individuals and businesses: estate planning, financial planning, systems and health care. We're all over the place. I've long felt a great TV show is in the waiting dealing with C.P.A.'s. I think it could be compelling TV drama dealing with technology and human relations.
Q. Congress recently had hearings on I.R.S. abuse. Were the horror stories just anecdotal, or are problems of abuse widespread?
A. I'm a modest I.R.S. defender. They have a duty to perform, and they get their marching orders from the Congress. Many Congress people pound on the I.R.S. and blame the tax code. But what they do is based on what Congress promulgates. Congress puts in a myriad of crazy laws, which they did last year -- 804 pages of complications. And then they say, Boy, you guys in the I.R.S., you should simplify it. The Congress people are the ones that create the mess.
I say all the time that a Congressman or Senator should not be permitted to vote on a tax bill until they've prepared their own tax returns. In around 1989, for example, they did this terrible thing putting on a 15 percent excise tax on retirement funds, in addition to the state tax and income tax. I said at the time this will not fly when Congress people start to retire. And that's exactly what happened. When they started to retire they saw this heinous tax could in effect bring people over the 100 percent tax point. It was repealed last year. As for the I.R.S., there are abuses; there are aggressive agents; there are aggressive managers. By and large they're like any of us. We try to do our best.
Q. You say that people who make these laws often don't know the ramifications of what they're adopting? How do we get around that?
A. I'll tell you a really far out way of doing it. I think somewhere along the line, in the year 2050 when none of us will be opining on this, there probably will have to be a domestic president and a foreign policy president; a domestic Congress and a foreign Congress. The breadth of knowledge to run the country is so incredibly vast that we can't expect an ordinary man or woman to go up to Capitol Hill and learn all about commerce, industry, agriculture, taxes, foreign affairs -- all of those things. We're in a era of specialization. Just to know the tax code itself -- we have to go back to Wilbur Mills, the famous Wilbur Mills that got caught in the fountain in Washington with Fanny Fox, to find someone in Congress that knew the tax laws inside out.
Q. Can flat-tax proposals for the income tax really simplify things?
A. There are a couple of issues. They figure that those who do simple forms can use a postcard for filing. The postcard doesn't leave room for the listing of dependents. Before listing dependents by name and with Social Security number was required, people were writing in all sorts of dependents. I had an experience about 14 years ago of a woman who when I asked who her dependents were, said "Only Tommy." And I said, "Is that your child?" She said, "My cat." She had been claiming the cat as a dependent. If you eliminate the requirement that dependents be identified, the fraud will just go exponentially where it was.
Let me tell you another scenario to show how ludicrous the flat tax would be. You use a car for business. Let's say the flat tax comes in the year 2000. You buy a $40,000 small Mercedes, let's say. And you use it that year for business. That's legitimate and under the flat tax you'd be able to deduct the full $40,000 in that year. The following year, you decide you don't need to use the car any more for business, so you convert the car to personal use. There is no recapture of the deduction. In the third year, you decide to sell the car and you sell it for $40,000. It has kept its value. There is no capital gain that you would have to pay under the flat tax proposal. That's just one example. What they should be doing is simplifying the tax code itself -- get rid of 19 different depreciation rates. Get rid of the 35 or 40 effective dates. Make life easier for everyone. Make it simple for people whose income is $50,000 or less.
Q. What do you think of the idea of a national sales tax, which would replace the income tax?
A. We already have a New York State sales tax and we know how badly most people feel about it. When they took the sales tax off of clothing, people literally flocked to the stores to buy. If you had a national sales tax, if you're selling a sweater for $50 and now you pay, let's say, a 7 percent sales tax, that's $3.50 and people don't mind it too much. We're sort of used to it. If you add a Federal sales, tax, which is estimated at the beginning to be 27 percent, that's 34 total sales tax. That's a tremendous change. Stu Kessler is not going to buy that sweater.
That's just one little part of it. Look at what it does to the state. New York State has an income tax, which is based on the Federal. If there is no Federal income tax, we're going to have to change our whole method of collecting that. And state tax administrators tell us that it's much more difficult to collect sales tax fairly than income tax. We'll have to have somebody to collect it, and it's much more difficult than an income tax.
Q. Difficult in the sense that there are more ways to evade it, like buying things off the books?
A. Exactly. By the way, anyone who is talking about national sales taxes is not saying, Do away with the payroll tax -- the Social Security, Medicaid, unemployment taxes. Some people pay more in these taxes than they do in income taxes. Something has to be done about Social Security. We're balancing the budget with Social Security funds. The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants is doing a study about what should be done.
Q. What is the current law on mail order and sales tax?
A. If you have any presence in another state -- and a presence can be an office or a person -- you generally have to collect sales tax in that state. They're getting to a situation where in the foreseeable future there will be a tying together of all the states where you will not be able to evade the sales tax by catalogues. I would guess within the next five years or so.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stuart Kessler of Ardsley, certified public accountant and senior tax partner of a Manhattan law firm, in his office. (Barbara Alper for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I. Sound Benefiting From Rise In Support

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
STANDING along the wind-whipped shores of Long Island Sound earlier this month, Gov. George E. Pataki waxed poetic about the once foul estuary, describing it as potentially one of the major environmental comeback stories of the decade. Other New York politicians, too, took bows that stormy morning as millions of dollars from the state's Clean Water, Clean Air Bond Act came to their constituencies for projects in the Sound.
While a downpour pummeled the great waterway behind him and washed up around his shoes, the Governor, standing under the cover of a tent, happily announced that $14 million would be allocated for 18 cleanup projects along the Sound in Westchester County, on Long Island and in New York City. 
 "Protecting and restoring New York's waters to health is the heart and soul of the Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act, which devotes more than $1 billion to water-quality protection and improvement," Governor Pataki said on March 19 at Harbor Island Park in Mamaroneck.
After years of neglect, much loved but also much polluted Long Island Sound is showing signs of recovery, thanks in part to the fact that being green is politically correct these days. "I'm passionate about the environment," the Governor said last week, "and that's a passion shared by many."
With the climate more receptive to environmental causes, the ranks of those rallying on behalf of Long Island Sound has swelled -- now including not just advocacy groups but also representatives of state government, elected officials, lawyers, fishermen and many of the more than 8 million people who live within 50 miles of the coast.
As the Governor observed on his visit to Mamaroneck, the story of the Sound's revival is one that gladdens many sectors of society, including labor, a group once pigeonholed as anti-environment.
"This funding will allow work to begin on badly needed environmental projects, bringing new life to our natural resources and putting New Yorkers to work building a cleaner, healthier and more productive future," Mr. Pataki said.
Like Mr. Pataki, County Executive Andrew J. Spano is an ardent campaigner for the environment. "I'm a guy who has done a lot of clamming and oystering on the Sound," Mr. Spano said recently, pleased that the county received $3.8 million from the bond act for a demonstration project at the Mamaroneck Sewer District to remove nitrogen and other pollutants entering the Sound.
"The waterway is a priority for all of us," he said.
This year's allocation for the Sound also includes $34,500 from the bond act to restore the native vegetation in a marsh area in Mamaroneck. For New Rochelle, there is $50,000 for aquatic plantings to reduce runoff and sediment in one area and $141,000 to reduce the amount of sediment washing into the city's harbor.
David J. Miller, executive director of the National Audubon Society of New York State, observed that the time was right in many respects to call attention to pressing environmental issues. "It's not only the politically correct thing, but economically and environmentally right," said Mr. Miller, who is co-chairman of the Citizen Advisory Committee for the Long Island Sound Study, a Federal interstate and intergovernmental project.
While politicians, environmentalists, labor and other organized groups have gone to the mat for the Sound, its continuing comeback can also be attributed to the efforts of individuals like Peter Studwell, a tough-talking sports fisherman who grew up along its shores in Port Chester.
Two years ago Mr. Studwell declared war on the commercial boats that dredged bait fish in the Sound and left the waters barren of blues and striped bass. Mr. Studwell said that all that was left once the large vessels departed was a watery desert where his anchor sank into emptiness.
Just days before large commercial fishing vessels were due in the Sound last spring, Governor Pataki signed a law banning the boats from plying the western waters of the Sound. Connecticut followed suit with a two-year moratorium on commercial menhaden fishing. Menhaden are the small fish that make up part of the diet of the sport fish, and they are used commercially in pet food and as fertilizer, among other things. If Connecticut does not impose a permanent ban on commercial fishing before the end of the two-year moratorium, commercial fishing vessels might return to the Sound.
"It has been a long and hard fight," Mr. Studwell said, "but people are finally speaking up."
Friends of the Sound Alliance, an organization formed in 1996 by Mr. Studwell, received a conservation award in January from the International Game Fish Association, a 60-year-old organization based in Pompano Beach, Fla., which names Ernest Hemingway among its founding members.
John W. Atkin, president of Save the Sound, an advocacy group in Stamford and Glen Cove, said it was "unusual for someone with an idea to be able to get legislators' ears in two states and have them adopt laws the first year the problem came before them."
"This was a real success story," he said of Mr. Studwell's efforts.
In other developments, there was more good news announced for the Sound in March when Federal and state environmental officials at a meeting of the Long Island Sound Policy Committee in Bayville unanimously adopted a 15-year, $650 million plan to upgrade sewage treatment plants along the New York and Connecticut shoreline.
The plan seeks to reduce nitrogen discharges, linked to reduced levels of dissolved oxygen in the Sound. Nitrogen acts as a fertilizer for algae blooms, which eventually sink to the floor of the Sound, decompose and consume oxygen in the water, severely stressing marine life.
The officials also adopted a plan to reclaim and restore at least 2,000 acres of habitat along the shores of the Sound over the next 10 years.
"We're at a turning point," said Mark A. Tedesco, technical director of the Federally run Long Island Sound Study office, which involves the cooperative efforts of the Government, two states, interstate and local agencies, universities, environmental groups, industry and the public.
The initiatives adopted on Feb. 5 are part of the Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan for Long Island Sound, which was first approved by state and Federal agencies in 1994. The management plan followed a $15 million Federal study of ways to clean up the estuary, which was initiated in 1987 amid fears that the Sound might be dying.
Terry Backer, the Long Island Soundkeeper and director of the nonprofit Soundkeeper Fund, which has offices in Oyster Bay and Norwalk, has described the Sound as a fragile body of water "with a microsystem that reacts like a game of dominoes." A report several years ago by the American Oceans Campaign, a nonprofit public policy group, said that the Sound and other estuaries -- bodies of water where freshwater from rivers and streams mingles with ocean saltwater -- are being overwhelmed by unchecked development and population growth.
Written in conjunction with Save the Sound and the Long Island Soundkeeper Fund, the report said fewer than half of the shellfish beds of Long Island Sound can be harvested because of pollution.
The Soundkeeper Fund filed a lawsuit this month in Federal District Court in Brooklyn accusing New York City of illegally polluting the Sound. The suit seeks enforcement of a permit issued in 1994 under the Clean Water Act, which required the city to reduce its discharge of nitrogen from its four East River treatment plants.
On Monday, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut announced that his state would join that lawsuit. And the state's Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, accused New York City of using the Sound as a cesspool.
New York City is also named in a suit filed on March 9 in Supreme Court in Manhattan by Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of New York State. In that suit, the State Department of Environmental Conservation charges that the city exceeded the limits of its state discharge permit at eight of its sewage plants.
"We're obviously telling the city it has to do more," said John P. Cahill, Commissioner for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. "The Bond Act helps, but we want to make sure that all the municipalities are doing their share."
"Westchester also has to do more," Commissioner Cahill said. "We'll be pressuring them as well." The county is under a consent order from the state to reduce storm water infiltration and inflow from municipal and county sewers.
As Mr. Spano conceded last week, "We still have a long way to go." He agreed that the sewer and storm water problem was a No. 1 priority for the Sound and his administration.
Looking toward the future, Mr. Atkin at Save the Sound said, "We're getting there, but no one can afford to sit on their hands."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Studwell, who has led a fight against commercial fishing in Long Island Sound, at Port Chester Yacht Club. (Susan B. Markisz for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: March 29, 1998

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 2; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2125 words

HEADLINE: Appetite for Talent, Fed With Flexibility

BYLINE: By DIANE SIERPINA 

 BODY:
WHEN Lisa Benne left her job as a seller of medical diagnostic equipment two years ago to join the Essential Data Corporation, a Stamford consulting firm, little did she expect to get breakfast at the office every morning, not to mention massages and other eclectic thank-you's, courtesy of her boss.
And when Suzanne Haas needs to get her creative juices flowing at the Atlantic Group, a Norwalk-based printing and marketing firm, she takes a midday break to shoot some pool. The boss thinks it's great. 
 The evidence is everywhere. Connecticut's business environment may not be as relaxed as Silicon Valley's, but it's certainly moving in that direction. With a national reputation as a center of culture and brainpower, it's a no-brainer that companies around the state, large and small, are discovering that being as creative as possible with benefits and workspace is the key to attracting the skilled employees they need.
"Connecticut tends generally to be behind the trend," says Cathy Woolley, senior vice president of administration for the Hutensky Group, commercial real estate developers based in Hartford. "It is the land of conservative habits. But I think we're going to see companies bend a great deal."
At Hutensky, she said, "The one thing we are doing more of is paying attention. We are listening to our employees as to what works for them and trying to figure out how to make the work work around that."
Human resource professionals around the state agree that, no matter the size or type of company, the biggest problem facing Connecticut companies is recruiting -- and, even more importantly, retaining -- employees with scientific and technical skills.
"An ounce of retention is worth a pound of recruiting," warns Bruce Tulgan, president of Rainmaker Inc., a New Haven consulting firm that teaches corporations how to attract and retain skilled Generation X employees. Those who go unchallenged or whose needs go unattended, he says, go out job hunting.
Companies are listening -- through surveys, employee committees or direct contact --to learn what their staff members need to get the job done and still have a life outside the office. Yes, there are increased salaries and benefits, but there are also child care and health and fitness centers, casual dress, allowing staff to rearrange their workspace or listen to music, and giving a day off for winning the company's baby picture contest. In between, companies are offering flexible hours, telecommuting, job sharing and additional training.
"I tell my clients that they've got to create opportunities for people to reinvent themselves over and over again," says Mr. Tulgan.
And what do the companies get in return? Increased productivity, experts agree. "It's really about recognizing that workers are people, too," Mr. Tulgan says.
Large and small companies may approach the problem in different ways, but, at a minimum, they're looking for guidance.
"The tight labor market has upped the ante. Companies have to do more," says Robert D. Noonan, vice president and counsel for management services for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association.
The association will offer a special session at its annual two-day conference on Employment, Law and Human Resources Management in June to focus on recruiting and retention strategies. "And I expect it will be very well attended," says Mr. Noonan.
An association survey on personnel policies of 200 Connecticut companies last year indicated that up to half are paying rewards to existing employees for referrals, 90 percent provide training and development opportunities for salaried employees and one-third offer 100 percent tuition reimbursement for undergraduate courses. (The number goes up to one-half for graduate courses.)
Many are shortening or eliminating waiting periods for health benefits, providing medical coverage for domestic partners, accelerating raises, expanding leave policies and subsidizing child care and adoptions. "Flexibility varies with the industry," says Mr. Noonan.
The more progressive companies also find visibility and community service powerful tools for attracting new employees and invigorating current staff.
Small, private firms like Essential Data, a $12 million company that provides technical writers and documentation trainers to businesses, and the Atlantic Group, with 50 marketing, creative and print production employees, can offer even the quirkiest policies and benefits.
"I try to make my associates feel appreciated," says Antoinette Allocca, president of Essential Data. "And that can't just be in the pocketbook." When she notices a staff member is under particular pressure, Ms. Allocca says, she may prescribe a massage or a round of golf. Birthday parties are celebrated and breakfast is available daily.
Stephanie Primm, president of the Atlantic Group, says her philosophy has always been to keep the office atmosphere loose, creative and full of team spirit -- especially when looming deadlines add to the stress level.
"People need to be allowed to be themselves," says Ms. Primm. "They need to have a little down time. I think playtime fosters greater creativity."
At Atlantic Group, an antique electric train on the lobby ceiling can be set in motion by a switch at the receptionist's desk. The billiard table in a space off the lobby and another on the second floor are in use most lunch hours and often after work.
A nearby bar is a hangout after work hours and the center of happy hour style get-togethers with staff and clients. Ms. Primm's two dogs, a beagle and a golden retriever, often roam the offices and sometimes have animal visitors.
Suzanne Haas, associate creative director, and Heidi Adair, senior account executive, agree that the Atlantic Group's unstructured environment makes for great camaraderie and job cooperation, but it may not work for those who aren't self-motivated, they warn. "We grew up with this place," says Ms. Adair. "That's why there's such a comfort level here. The wackier GenX'ers -- maybe they went to the city because they felt they needed to be there."
At the Hutensky Group in Hartford, which employs 55 people in four states (45 in Connecticut), the staff likes half-day Fridays in the summer. Desks are cleared off by 1 P.M. Friday, says Ms. Woolley, the senior vice president of administration.
Staff members make up one half hour each day from Monday through Thursday, either at the beginning or end of the work day. Clients appreciate the extended office hours, says Ms. Woolley. "It's not a benefit; it's a productivity tool," she explains.
The Bushnell, which operates the performing arts center in Hartford, also uses contests, gift certificates, days off and complimentary show tickets to reward its 45-member staff, says Diane Bruno, director of human resources. And any suggestions made by its employee committee are definitely considered.
"Some of the things we asked for when we entered the work force were unusual, too," she remembers.
Large companies too are trying to be more innovative and they have more resources to back up their changes.
The Xerox Corporation in Stamford, a regular on Fortune and Working Mother magazines' lists as one the top 100 United States employers. is getting calls on how to do it. In recent months, five to 10 companies a week -- most of them large -- call Marilyn Timbers, Xerox's life cycle program manager, to get details about the company's practices. "Never before have I gotten these kind of calls," says Ms. Timbers of the volume.
Xerox, among many other things, provides each employee with a bank account of $10,000 that can be used over his or her work career for child care, extended health care coverage or first-time mortgage assistance. Other applications, including elder care and college tuition assistance, are being considered. The company also offers free referral services for child care, elder care, parenting skills and education.
"When all is said and done," says Ms. Timbers, "what employees really want is flexibility and empowerment. Everybody doesn't have the same needs. One-size benefits don't fit all."
Last fall, Xerox rewrote the employee motivation and satisfaction survey it distributes annually to reflect more life/work balance issues. Managers are evaluated based on the anonymous results, says Ms. Timbers.
BankBoston, meanwhile, in addition to its regular benefits package, offers a minimum 100 shares of stock options annually to each full-time employee.
In October, the end of the first year of the program, the value had risen by $42 a share, meaning a minimum gain of $4,200, says Karen Schwartzman, BankBoston's spokesperson.
"BankBoston is doing exceedingly well," she explains, "and we wanted to share the wealth and to give employees a stake in the performance of the company." BankBoston has 1,150 employees in Connecticut.
Next, in response to staff requests, BankBoston will extend family medical benefits beginning in July to domestic partners or one other dependent residing with the employee.
"It's important to have progressive benefits programs because people have choices," says Ms. Schwartzman, "It's a tight labor market. We have found time and time again, if our employees are happy and appreciated and valued, they do better for the company and the company does better for its shareholders."
And at the Bayer Corporation's pharmaceutical division in West Haven, the company recently opened a child care center and created a lactation program for breastfeeding mothers as a result of a survey of the needs of its 2,000 employees.
The lactation program, which provides pre- and post-natal counseling as well, has allowed mothers to return to work sooner and will be offered at Bayer's other sites around the country, says Laura Malis, a Bayer spokeswoman. Fifty-five women have taken part in the West Haven program.
"At Bayer, we spend a lot of time talking about what it means to be an employer of choice," says Kim Carpenter, vice president of human resources. "We like to think we're open to good ideas."
Perhaps the closest Connecticut workplace to Silicon Valley is Hyperion, the Stamford-based software company that had only 200 employees six years ago and now has 1,300.
"Our challenge," says Bill Hewitt, vice president of marketing, "is to maintain the culture of a smaller company."
In a large, still expanding fitness center, television sets provide programming from around the world by satellite hookup. Workspace has been rearranged to provide common meeting areas. And a billiard room and game room supplied with pinball machines, Nintendo and other games are almost always in use. The company encourages it as a means for hard working staff to clear their heads, says Mr. Hewitt.
"It's a good way for people in different departments to get together," he says. "People work out ideas; they work out problems there. Especially in a company growing as quickly as ours, communications is key."
With developers who work odd hours, Hyperion makes sure it keeps the pantries around the company well stocked with sodas, water, juice and coffee. "To keep people fed and happy -- and supplied with lots of caffeine," says Mr. Hewitt.
Connecticut's technology companies must compete with high-tech centers around the nation for the skilled workers they need to grow. But the state's reputation as a defense and insurance headquarters has hurt its image, says Tom Bradley, spokesperson for the Connecticut Economic Resource Center, a nonprofit agency whose mission is to attract new companies to the state and help existing ones grow.
Last December, the center began a print and radio campaign in technology trade publications and major newspapers touting Connecticut as a hotbed of technology activity. After all, 17 percent of the work force is employed in technology, the largest ratio in the nation according to Federal Labor Department statistics, says Mr. Bradley.
"The campaign is a lot funkier and geared to a younger audience," he says. "We're reaching the skilled worker."
So what if Silicon Valley companies allow animals in the workplace, stock refrigerators with beer, and let employees walk around barefoot? Do these things increase job satisfaction, motivate workers and add balance to their lives?
"These lavish perks seem sort of frivolous" says Brent Laymon, a spokesman for Xerox. "I'm not sure the people looking for them are, in the long run, the ones who are going to make you competitive."
But it doesn't hurt to be more worker friendly. Says Mr. Hewitt of Hyperion, "people want to come to work and be productive. And anything we do to make that happen is to our benefit -- obviously!"

HEADLINE: School Aid: State Has Promises To Keep

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
MAYOR NANCY VALENTINE of Ansonia says the state has put her city in a bind. Rising school enrollment and state mandates are increasing the cost of public education but the state won't pay what it promised. Instead, the money comes out of Ansonia's property tax revenue.
Ansonia is not alone. There seems to be little disagreement between state and municipal officials that the state is short-changing many cities and towns on financial assistance for public education. The amount of the shortage, and what to do about it, are, however, in dispute. Last year, the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities estimated the shortfall to be $868 million a year. Legislative leaders say it is far less. The co-chairman of the legislature's Education Committee, Senator Thomas P. Gaffey, a Democrat of Meriden, wants to use the anticipated state budget surplus to make up the difference, while Gov. John G. Rowland has proposed establishing a task force to study what an appropriate amount should be. 
 But Ansonia and 11 other municipalities have filed a lawsuit asking the courts to order the state to pay the full amount they claim it has promised. They charged that the state is violating the State Supreme Court's Horton v. Meskill decisions of the 1970's and 1980's that found that Connecticut's over-reliance on local property taxes to support education was unconstitutional.
The suit, filed in Hartford on March 18, names seven children from six communities as plaintiffs. In addition to Ansonia, the municipalities suing include Bridgeport, Coventry, East Hartford, East Windsor, Manchester, Meriden, New Britain, New Haven, Seymour, West Haven and Windham.
Robert DeCrescenzo, a former Mayor of East Hartford who is representing the plaintiffs, said the two Horton decisions cited a provision in the Connecticut constitution that makes the state responsible for public education. In its Horton decisions, the Supreme Court ordered the legislature to develop a school aid formula that eliminates the advantages that wealthy communities have over poor ones.
The legislature took that step in 1988 when it established the Equalized Cost Sharing grant program, with the goal of providing half the money for public education across the state. It uses a complicated formula that channels more of the money to poorer cities and towns based on their needs and their ability to raise revenue.
Around the same time, the legislature enacted the Minimum Education Requirement, setting a minimum sum per pupil that school districts must spend, and another mandate for for special education. To offset the special education spending mandate, grants were established that, like the Equalized Cost Sharing grants, also gave larger sums to poorer towns.
At the outset, the Equalized Cost Sharing grants provided 45 percent of the total spending for public education in the state, well on the way to the legislature's goal of 50 percent. Then Connecticut slid into recession, an enormous deficit appeared in the state budget, and the legislature began to move in the other direction, providing a smaller and smaller percentage each year.
In 1989, 1990 and 1992, the legislature revised downward a part of the Equalized Cost Sharing formula that determines the level of property wealth of a community that is considered sufficient to support the local share of public education spending. In effect, poorer towns were redefined as wealthier, and their education aid grants were reduced.
Since salaries and other educational costs usually rise each year, an original assumption of the Equalized Cost Sharing program was that the foundation level of per pupil spending in its formula would have to be raised periodically. But the last time the legislature authorized an increase was 1992, and since then it has not kept up with inflation. It is now nearly $600 per pupil less than it would have been under the original formula.
Furthermore, in 1992 and 1995, the legislature imposed caps on the amount any municipality's Equalized Cost Sharing grant could rise, further preventing them from keeping pace with inflation.
Also in 1995, the grant programs for general and for special education were combined. This act produced revisions in the formula that further limited growth in state aid to local school districts. That last revision opened the shortfall the most between the actual grants and the 50 percent reimbursement goal, said Ben Barnes, an expert on the education funding issue for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities.
"It's been ongoing," he said, "but it's been particularly acute since 1995, and I expect it's grown this year, though I haven't figured it out." But based on the grants for the 1996-97 fiscal year, he said, the shortfall was $868 million a year, and the state's reimbursement level had gone down below 40 percent.
Ten years after the legislature acted to equalize spending, the highest-spending towns in the state spend about twice as much per child as those who spend the least. The largest cut to a municipality was borne by Bridgeport. "Bridgeport received $57 million less than if the state had followed the court-ordered funding schedule," said Mayor Joseph Ganim. If he had that money, he says he believes his city's schools would have smaller class sizes, more computers and more children getting pre-school education, among other things.
Mr. Ganim says he doesn't believe the legislature has the political will to restore the original Equalized Cost Sharing formula and its goal of providing 50 percent of public education costs, which necessitates the lawsuit.
"We're only going to court as a last resort," Mr. Ganim said. "We'd rather this be settled in the state house than in the courthouse."
Mayor Ganim and Mayor Valentine of Ansonia are facing municipal budget difficulties. Bridgeport's teachers were recently awarded a 4.9 percent pay raise in binding arbitration that Mr. Ganim says his city cannot afford.
Ansonia's Board of Aldermen last month cut $200,000 from the school budget proposal, which, if allowed to stand, will lower that city's per pupil school spending to below the level mandated by state law.
Ms. Valentine said Ansonia would have received $13 million under the original Equalized Cost Sharing formula, but under the current formula will receive only $9 million. "We're short $4 million," she said.
Although she is a Republican, Ms. Valentine criticized Mr. Rowland's proposal to use $120 million from a state budget surplus by mailing income tax rebates to all state taxpayers next October. "If we have such a large surplus, why aren't we funding education?" she asked.
Dean Pagani, Mr. Rowland's spokesman, defended the Governor's education plan, noting that it includes $93 million to hire 300 more elementary school reading teachers, help build more classrooms and schools, offer grants for educational innovations and improve the vocational/technical school system. Also, since the state is now in the middle of a two-year budget cycle, it isn't possible to increase spending on the magnitude that the lawsuit demands, he said.
But, Mr. Pagani said, Mr. Rowland would propose a task force study the formula and determine if it should be revised during the 1999 session of the legislature.
To which Senator Thomas Gaffey, co-chairman of the Education Committee, replied: "I don't think we need a task force to remedy this problem. This is not a complex issue."
Mr. Gaffey said only $150 million is needed to remove the caps limiting Equalized Cost Sharing grant increases, and he believes that sum can be found. It would mean sacrificing Mr. Rowland's tax rebates.
State Senator Judith Freedman, the ranking Republican on the Education Committee, noted, however, that there are constitutional restrictions on the use of budget surpluses that may impede Mr. Gaffey's simple solution.
Ms. Freedman also said she felt it is, indeed, a complex issue. There are 46 different elements in the Equalized Cost Sharing formula, and she said that every time one is changed it creates a ripple somewhere else in the formula. She said she thought convening a task force was a good idea.
Ms. Freedman also criticized the lawsuit for excluding wealthier towns, thus making its case stronger. Towns in lower Fairfield County in particular were discouraged from participating, even though they receive lower equalization grants every year.
Mayor Valentine, said, however, that no community should worry about the lawsuit, because it will help all of the state's cities and towns if it's successful. She said she doubted whether Mr. Rowland's task force would make much of a difference.
"What is a task force going to tell us?" Ms. Valentine said. "Uncap the formula." "If it's a mandate, then the state's got to pay it,"
She added, "I've got taxpayers to answer to, and education to provide to the children."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Hawthorne Motel Owner Razing It to Build Anew

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: HAWTHORNE

 BODY:
DIRECTLY opposite the exit to this hamlet off the Saw Mill River Parkway, a 50's-style motel sits unobtrusively on a hill overlooking heavily trafficked Route 9A. For 42 years, it's been a part of the landscape, often the first thing motorists see when they come into Hawthorne.
But faced with the threat of losing his Quality Inn franchise unless he embarked on a substantial upgrade, Jeffrey H. Zelekowitz has proposed razing what was originally the Hawthorne Circle Motor Inn and replacing the three-structure complex with a three-story modern motel. 
 His proposal, now before the Town of Mount Pleasant's Planning Board, calls for a 40,000-square-foot commercial building and a free-standing restaurant in addition to the new motel, at a total cost of $10 million.
Mr. Zelekowitz said that he was currently seeking "institutional financing" for his project."
"This kind of project is representative of the kind of investment owners are making in hotel properties all over the county today," said John D. Williams, president of the Westchester Hotel Association. "It's just one of several multimillion-dollar projects either being discussed or under construction."
Mr. Williams attributes the activity to the fact that "business is good as a result of a stable local economy," he said. "We get good weekday business from I.B.M., Texaco, MasterCard and Pepsi and other local corporations. And business has also been good on the weekends, with bar and bat mitzvahs, graduations or just weekend getaways from the city."
According to the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau, based in White Plains, taxable hotel sales in Westchester were up 25.7 percent in 1997 over the previous year.
Of the 62 counties in New York State, Westchester was second only to New York City in taxable hotel sales and first in growth in 1997, compared with the previous year.
The Renaissance Westchester Hotel in Harrison has just completed an $8 million renovation of its 350 rooms. "We added several conference rooms and installed two phone lines in every room as well as speaker phones and data ports," said Mr. Williams, who is also manager of the hotel.
Similarly the Tarrytown Hilton is in the second phase of a $5 million renovation, which will eventually include a complete redesign of its 250 guest rooms, according to Jeff Voorhees, the manager. "The rooms, which are now typical hotel style, will have a more country type decor, with sleigh beds and granite-top dressers."
The renovation will also include the building of an Irish pub, which will have a "modified Victorian design, almost like the kind of pubs you see in Ireland, the ones that look like a country store," Mr. Voorhees explained.
As testament to the health of Westchester's hotel market, the Quality Inn in Hawthorne continued to be busy despite its vintage design, according to Emily Kirwin, the manager.
Built in 1956 by her father, it is the style of motel where every room has its own exterior entrance and a guest pulls his car right up to the door.
"We've always catered primarily to a business guest," Ms. Kirwin said, "and business has been steady over the years." Room rates are considered reasonable, between $85 and $95 a night for a single. But they are expected to go up once the new motel is built, said Ms. Kirwin, who is staying on as manager. She declined to say, however, what the new rates would be.
"I was kind of hoping they'd be able to renovate it instead of replacing it," said Ms. Kirwin. "It has great curb appeal. I'm going to miss it."
MR. ZELEKOWITZ noted that the existing 69-room motel, which has an outdoor pool, takes up all of his nine-acre property. "Renovation just didn't make economic sense so we decided to start from scratch," he said. "By building a taller motel, we can add 16 rooms and still have room for a commercial building and a restaurant. It makes much better use of the land and adds value to it."
The property has already been rezoned to allow for the mixed-use project, according to Robert F. Meehan, Supervisor for the Town of Mount Pleasant. "The old zoning, which was adopted in the 50's, required exterior entrances to all the rooms with parking in front of the units, which is how the existing motel was designed," Mr. Meehan said. "The rezoning was necessary in order to build a new modern motel with one single entrance."
A public hearing on the site plan is scheduled for Thursday, but Mr. Meehan does not anticipate any major opposition.
"It's really a welcome proposal," he said. "It will modernize a highly visible and important intersection in town."
Mr. Zelekowitz has agreed to make some road improvements at the intersection of the motel property and Route 9A, which parallels the Saw Mill River Parkway. An internal road will connect the hotel with an existing office building and a 24-hour diner on Route 9A.
"It will bring all traffic out to a turning signal on Route 9A, which is a definite improvement over the present situation," explained Nat Parish, a planning and environmental consultant who is working on the project.
"Right now people exiting the diner and office building have to make a very dangerous turn onto Route 9A with no light," he added.
The motel's design will be "post modern with a porte-cochere focus with an articulated roof and Palladian design," according to Gary Warshauer, principal with Warshauer Mellusi Warshauer Architects of Hawthorne, which is designing the project.
The stucco facade will be done in earth tones and beiges, he added, "to blend in with the woodsy surroundings."
The two-story commercial building, which will have 20,000 square feet of retail on the ground floor and 20,000 square feet of office space above, will be designed in red brick and stucco, Mr. Warshauer said. "This will tie in with the restaurant, which is expected to be developed by Appleby's," Mr. Warshauer said, adding that it would be done in red brick with green awnings.
The exterior detailing of the buildings will be carried into the inside of the hotel, which will have stonework and a two-story lobby with a peaked roof.
"The backdrop to this project is a woodsy area so we want to use natural materials and have the project sit in the property as unobtrusively as possible," Mr. Warshauer said.
Scott Benson, of Benson Commercial Realty in White Plains, is marketing the retail portion of the project and hopes to attract a discount retailer for the lower level and a medical complex for the office space upstairs.
"We see it as a stand-alone retail property, rather than as a complementary space to the hotel," Mr. Benson said. "It's a very visible location and would be ideal for a destination-type retailer."
