HEADLINE: The Computer Age Began in a Barn

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
IN 1948, 20-year-old William B. Wenning of Stamford, fresh out of a two-year technical college in New York City, was looking for a job. An acquaintance suggested he try Remington Rand.
"I had never even heard of Remington Rand," Mr. Wenning says today. But in post-World War II America, with an economy adjusting to peacetime and millions of ex-G.I.'s also out looking for jobs, any suggestion was appreciated. Just before Christmas he showed up at Remington Rand's research center in Norwalk and, in a manner of speaking, walked into a new frontier: the computer. 
 The man who hired young Mr. Wenning was Loring P. Crosman, whom he admired then and still, not only for his business vision but also because he was a good guy, quiet-spoken, and appreciative of his workers.
"He hired me and had me come in right away so I could get holiday pay," Mr. Wenning says. You don't forget a gesture like that, even after close to 50 years.
In the middle of World War II, Mr. Crosman had interested James Rand, the chairman of Remington Rand, in a new venture. The company, then situated in Brooklyn, N.Y., was a major manufacturer of office furniture, machines and systems and Mr. Crosman saw the future in an electronic machine that could add, subtract, multiply and perform other functions much faster than digital calculators. Such a marvel didn't even have a name -- but computer, or computer machine, would do.
Remington Rand had to wait until the end of the war to get into such a new venture. It also had to wait until Mr. Rand, who lived in Darien, got around to establishing a new corporate headquarters in Connecticut.
He had become enamoured of an splendid property in the Rowayton section of Norwalk. It was the James A. Farrell estate, known as Rockledge, a huge fieldstone mansion set well back on one side of Highland Avenue with an equally impressive Tudor building on the other side of Highland. The latter was a stable.
Mr. Farrell, who went to work in a factory at 15, had risen in Horatio Alger fashion to become president of U.S. Steel, and of his own steamship line. As such, he had enough money in the pre-World War I era to build a home, and stable, to rival the showy mansions, and stables, in Newport, or anywhere else. He needed a staff of eight to keep the place comfortable.
Both Mr. Farrell and his wife died in the early 1940's and Mr. Rand purchased Rockledge, the mansion to become corporate headquarters, the stable to be used for research. And with the end of the war, the company could settle down for some research into new prospects.
When Bill Wenning arrived in late 1948, he reported to Mr. Crosman in the old Rockledge stables, joining eight other men, all older than he, who had dubbed their workplace "the barn."
Life in the barn had a certain air about it, Mr. Wenning reflects today. "One guy said he could still smell manure there but I never did." Rather, the air was one of a certain excitement, a feeling that something new was happening. It was an adventure. At the same time, he said, nobody in the group was really aware of the ramifications of what they were doing.
Indeed Remington Rand itself might not have been fully attuned to the potential. There was no security at the barn in the early years. "When we got through for the day we just shut the door," Mr. Wenning says. Sometimes, he adds, when the group opened up on Monday mornings, it was obvious that the caretaker's kids had been playing in the barn.
The workers at the barn did just that, work, Mr. Wenning says, and improvised, and enjoyed it all. "In 1950 to 1951 we worked 12-hour shifts and we didn't get paid for that. We did it because we wanted to."
While the work was going on, changes were piling on changes in the postwar business world as companies scrambled for shares of the new peacetime market, at home and abroad. At Remington Rand, even the name changed. It became Sperry-Rand after a merger with the Sperry Corporation. And James Rand had added some important men to the top echelon of the corporation -- Gen. Leslie R. Groves, who had headed the Manhattan Project that developed the atomic bomb; Gen. Douglas MacArthur, famed for leadership in the Pacific during World War II and then for being fired by President Harry Truman in the Korean Conflict.
Mr. Wenning says he guesses that General MacArthur was hired as a figurehead but he did create a few more legends there. One was about corporate officers reporting to work early. "He would stand at the front door across the street at 8 in the morning and wait for the vice presidents to check in," Mr. Wenning says. "They would drift in at 9 or so at first but eventually they got the message."
General MacArthur also enjoyed having his picture taken, with everyone. When it came to Mr. Wenning's turn, he stood on the floor, he says, and a little platform was provided for the General to stand on. Mr. Wenning is a fairly tall man. General MacArthur was not. But the General looked up to no one.
In 1951, the first prototype of a working business computer, known as the 409, was unveiled to potential customers and the second prototype was installed at the Internal Revenue Center in Baltimore.
To compare the 409 with any computer today, personal or business,would be ludicrous. The 409, Mr. Wenning says, was more than 7 feet long, 2 feet deep and 5 feet tall, "and generated lots of heat." In addition, it was accompanied by a punch card unit, to feed it information, and that itself was as big as a refrigerator.
Today, he adds, any home computer "is a million times faster and better, and a thousand times cheaper."
But the 409 was first. What the group in the barn had done, Mr. Wenning says, was to take a concept, that of a computer just for business, and bring it to reality. "There was no precedent for it. We went from an idea to a finished product," he says.
There was no question of demand. "There were so many customer orders that in late 1949, the company stopped taking orders," he says.
In the competitive that followed, International Business Machines became the major player, while Sperry-Rand started to turn out business computers under the name of Univac, another company it had absorbed.
In 1961, Mr. Wenning was picked as program manager on a project to bring a much more sophisticated business computer, the Univac 1004, to market. amid so many doubts that it would fly, that it was code-named Bumblebee. Aerodynamically, it should be impossible for a bumblebee to fly, Mr. Wenning explains. But fly it did, becoming the most successful punch-card computer in the company's history.
By then, dozens of other companies -- soon to be hundreds, then thousands -- had jumped into research and production of computers. And security had become so tight at the barn, crowded with 185 people at one time, that many people at the mansion had no idea of what was going on across the street.
Mr. Wenning left Sperry-Rand in 1962 and went to work for Pitney Bowes of Stamford, became a corporate vice president, and retired from there in 1986. He now lives in a hilltop home in Old Lyme, with a fine view of the Connecticut River where it meets Long Island Sound.
And Sperry-Rand eventually left the state, absorbed into the Unisys Corporation of Pennsylvania. The old Farrell mansion became a private school for young women, then was owned by the Continental Can Corporation and is now headquarters for Hewitt Associates. The barn became the Rowayton Library on one side, the Rowayton Community Center on the other.
The computer industry has also changed more than a bit. From a few dozen companies in the early 1960's, the industry has grown to more than 10,000 companies around the world today. By the turn of the century it is expected to be the second-largest industry in the world, exceeded only by agriculture.
Last year, Erik H. Rambusch, a management consultant to the information industry and also president of the Rowayton Historical Society, discovered something that dismayed him: there is virtually no written history about the infancy of the computer in Rowayton.
He arranged for a meeting of eight of the men who had worked in the barn in the late 1940's and early 1950's. They sat around for hours, talking about that time and being tape-recorded. Another session has been planned for next Sunday, to observe the 50th anniversary of the first working model of a business computer, and to reminisce a bit more about being on the threshold of a massive change in technology. "One guy last year said it was the best time of our lives," Bill Wenning says.
People wishing technical information or to contribute more information about Rowayton's part in computer development may contact the web site: www.rowayton.org.

PUB-DATE: March 29, 1998

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2544 words

HEADLINE: Our Medicine Chest

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
SAY Michigan and the automobile business comes to mind. To think of Texas is to think of the oil industry. And North Carolina still means big tobacco.
But say New Jersey, and the word "pharmaceuticals" hardly leaps to the tongue. The Rodney Dangerfield-ing of the state has extended to its mightiest manufacturing industry, which can't get no respect. 
 "People know that our companies are here, but they have no idea what an important industry we are," said Raymond V. Gilmartin, the chief executive of Merck & Company. "We haven't gotten the focus or attention that we might have deserved."
And yet the state's 186 pharmaceutical companies, with their 60,000 jobs, have spawned an influential corporate culture and an exploding, highly skilled talent pool. The drug makers have transformed nearly every aspect of New Jersey, ranging from the consumption of pizza in Nutley and the proliferation of rural executive subdivisions to making key early contributions to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.
Thanks to an accident of geography and history, the industry is the state's largest manufacturing sector, according to the New Jersey Department of Commerce. The giant, research-based pharmaceutical companies' global war is increasingly being waged from New Jersey turf. And the state's role is growing: In December, for example, Pharmacia & Upjohn, of Kalamazoo, Mich., the maker of Rogaine hair restorer and Nicotrol nicotine patches, announced that it would move its worldwide headquarters and 700 jobs to Bridgewater Township this year.
Fred Hassan, the company's chief executive, said the move would place the company's headquarters "within the global center of gravity of the pharmaceutical industry." Yes, New Jersey.
Certainly the industry's vocal critics in environmental groups and labor unions, who have bitterly fought the pharmaceutical companies for decades, charge that the drug purveyors have all too much power in the statehouse and in the Legislature. They call for more regulatory focus on the dark side of the business.
But the industry is gearing up to foster an image-building campaign that would make "New Jersey" and "pharmaceuticals" synonymous. Last year the state's largest companies, including Merck & Company, Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corporation, Johnson & Johnson and Hoffmann-La Roche, each paid dues of $50,000 to set up a trade association, the 16-member Health Care Institute of New Jersey.
Drawing on statistical and financial information never before released by the implacably competitive and often secretive companies, Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting and consulting company, was hired by the institute to compile a statewide portrait of the business. It conclusively supports the notion that New Jersey is the "Medicine Chest of the Nation," as the institute perkily puts it:
* New Jersey has the nation's largest concentration of businesses that produce prescription pharmaceuticals, over-the-counter medications, generic prescription drugs, vitamins, diagnostic drugs and medical devices.
* These companies inject more than $8 billion into the state's economy, including $3.2 billion in wages.
* The state's drug makers are currently targeting 60 major ailments, including cancer, Alzheimer's disease, heart disease and AIDS. A third of all new drugs approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration during the last five years have come from New Jersey-based pharmaceutical companies (Pennsylvania and California came next).
* New Jersey companies produce at least 43 percent of the pharmaceuticals sold in the United States. Last year, 17 of the 48 most significant new drugs approved by the F.D.A. originated from New Jersey companies.
Nary a nook or cranny in the state is untouched by the industry. The pharmaceutical companies channel $1.4 billion to New Jersey vendors ranging from temporary-employment agencies to security guards. They include not only computer suppliers but also the Park Pub in Nutley -- a cozy, barn-beamed watering hole directly across from the main gate of Hoffman-La Roche on Kingsland Avenue -- and the Crocco Brothers New York Pizza and Restaurant, just around the corner.
"We recently sent over 150 pies for an office party," said John Crocco, the restaurant's co-owner. "They account for 80 percent of our business during the day," he said. "Sometimes the scientists will even order in pies at midnight."
For knowledge workers, at least, the life style can be thoroughly rewarding. The average salary of full-time workers at the top 15 companies is $58,380, and senior researchers make $150,000 and up.
The New Jersey talent pool "is like something out of the Middle Ages, where all the shoemakers worked on the same street," said Dr. Daniel O. Hauser, who heads pre-clinical research for Novartis in Summit. "New Jersey is the equivalent of the Pharmaceutical Guild, the place where you find the talent."
In attracting top scientists to the region, "the access to academic institutions, museums and fine restaurants is important," said Dr. Alan J. Main, director of pharmaceutical research at Novartis.
For the drug makers, the problem with everyone-into-the-talent-pool is that close proximity fosters headhunting, and recruiters draw employees into a human-resources merry-go-round. "The job market is very tight, very competitive," said Jim Bishop of Burke, O'Brien & Bishop Associates, of Princeton, an executive search firm. "Companies are looking for executives with science and marketing backgrounds, and they aren't that easy to find."
To remain competitive, the major pharmaceuticals offer a robust array of flex-time, job-sharing, child-care and elder-care options. "We are model employers in terms of compensation and benefits," said Wayne P. Yetter, chief executive of the American subsidiary of Novartis.
And for the past few months the pharmaceuticals have been racing to sign up new Ph.D.'s in a competition "like the N.B.A. draft," said Dr. Thomas N. Salzmann, head of chemistry research at Merck's Rahway center. The rookies' starting salary? About $70,000.
 
Meetings in the Car Pool, Married Competitors
While some workers live near their offices, most employees are dotted about the state like beads in a time-release capsule.
"Amazingly, there are three of us within five houses of each other," said Jeffrey A. Soper, a public-affairs manager for Roche who lives in bucolic Sparta in Sussex County, 43 miles from Nutley. Next door is a manager from Knoll Pharmaceutical Company and down the street is a research scientist for Merck.
There are so many Roche co-workers in Sparta that they head to the office by car-pool, dubbed the Sparta Express. "We work on the same product," said Mr. Soper of his colleagues Al Masucci and Phillip Villavicenzio, "so we've made our drive into an extended office meeting."
At times, the serendipities of the labor pool are positively weird. Once Dr. Salzmann was engaged in an intense scientific discussion with a colleague at a seafood restaurant in Westfield. "H. C. Brown has a brilliant way of doing this," he was saying of a Nobel Prize-winning chemist's research procedure. Someone tapped Dr. Salzmann on the shoulder.
"Thank you," said a stranger who introduced himself as the laureate, Dr. Brown.
"We've all gone to conferences together, or worked together, or gone to school together," said Dr. Victoria Rusiecki-Lombardo, a chemist at Merck who works on diabetes.
This is true of her husband, Lou -- they met while getting their Ph.D.'s in chemistry at Yale -- and they form a not unusual industry pairing: a dual-career couple working for fierce pharmaceutical rivals.
"Luckily we're both working in different areas," said Mr. Lombardo, a group leader in anti-cancer chemistry at Bristol-Myers in Lawrenceville.
"It's sort of a James Carville, Mary Matalin thing," said Mrs. Rusiecki-Lombardo. "For us, we find that there are a lot of topics off-limits."
Secrecy is a never-ending concern. "You will notice a significant phenomenon on the 7 A.M., 8 A.M. and 9 A.M. Continental shuttles from Newark to Washington," said Ronald Califre, head of clinical development and regulatory affairs at Novartis. "I'd bet 80 percent of the people on those flights work for pharmaceutical companies. But none of them is talking shop."
As scientific, technical and financial jobs have been added in the industry, blue-collar jobs have been lost.
"Now, probably no more than 20 percent of pharmaceutical jobs in New Jersey are unionized," said Mark Dudzic, president of the Distict Eight Council of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International, which represents the largest number of pharmaceutical workers in the state. "The companies have moved more and more toward outsourcing, and have moved a lot of jobs offshore to Puerto Rico."
He estimated that about 5,000 New Jersey jobs were lost from the 1970's to the 1990's because of a tax loophole, which has now been closed, permitting Puerto Rican tax writeoffs for the companies.
Currently the disintegrating State House dome in Trenton is being refurbished by a consortium of companies led by the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company. The drug makers' critics see that as a symbol of the industry's domination in Trenton.
The companies "always hold out the continual threat that 'we'll pull out if we don't get this tax break or this grant,' " said Anthony Wright, program director for New Jersey Citizen Action, a consumer group.
State Assemblyman Bob Smith, Democrat of Piscataway, often an opponent of the industry, said the companies "are very powerful, but they don't own the Legislature." He added, "They don't have the same influence as oil does in Texas, but the pharmaceutical companies contribute hugely to legislators in both parties."
"I only wish we were so powerful," said Patrick J. Zenner, president and chief executive of Hoffmann-La Roche. Indeed, the companies have suffered legislative losses on environmental regulation and on restrictions governing generic drug makers.
"We haven't really leveraged the power of the industry," said William H. Tremayne, president of the companies' Healthcare Institute. "The reality is that there hasn't been much of a public presence of the industry as a whole in the state."
At the local level, the companies' influence has always been significant. The impact of the industry's varied philanthropy is profound, amounting to more than $300 million, according to Corporate Giving Watch, an independent nonprofit newsletter.
"And it's hard to get away from the word 'Johnson' in New Brunswick," said Curtis Fisher, executive director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group.
Bob Wilson, the vice chairman of the Johnson & Johnson board of directors, speaks proudly of the company's role in its community. "We made a commitment to New Brunswick 20 years ago, and have tried to improve education and health and amenities there," he said, adding: "We've tried to be very responsive and not make it a company city."
 
Environmental Issues Draw Foes' Criticism
 It is the environmental issue that draws the most fire from the industry's foes. "They've fought every health and safety measure kicking and screaming, and if they're good citizens in the state it's because they have to be," said Bill Kane, president of the New Jersey State Industrial Union Council, an umbrella organization for 40 unions representing 260,000 workers.
One of the state's most notorious Superfund toxic-waste sites is in Toms River at a plant formerly run by Ciba-Geigy; the company was assessed a $3.5 million fine. The Oil, Chemical and Atomic union charged management with covering up a higher incidence of cancer among workers, which the company (now Novartis) strongly denied.
The industry "has had environmental problems, but earlier in the century our knowledge base was not as great, and we didn't have an understanding of what these things did," Mr. Zenner said of toxic substances. "We have an exemplary record now."
The pharmaceuticals "have cleaned up their act to an extent," said Mr. Fisher of the Public Interest group, but he contended that the companies "are still putting large amounts of chemical carcinogens and reproductive toxins into their products, and releasing them into the environment."
New Jersey's pharmaceutical pre-eminence is an accident of history. "Pennsylvania and Missouri could have been the nation's pharmaceutical centers, but ultimately they couldn't offer the market concentration and talent pool of New Jersey," said Louis Galambos, a professor of business and economic history at Johns Hopkins University.
In the 19th century, German and Swiss pharmaceutical companies established East Coast operations to sell to the American market. When they began to produce chemicals, they looked to the nearby, low-cost farmland of New Jersey.
The most famous early pharmaceutical migration was that of the Johnson brothers, who left New York to search for a suitable factory in New Jersey. One day in 1886, one of the brothers, James, was riding a Pennsylvania Railroad train, which slowed to cross the Raritan River at New Brunswick. "He looked out the window and spied a To Let sign on a four-story red brick building," according to a corporate history. "This would soon become the first home of Johnson & Johnson."
By World War I, many companies were forced to sever their ties to German corporate parents or have their assets seized as alien property. "By the 1940's, New Jersey was solidly established as the nation's leader," said Professor Galambos.
It is likely to remain so, for now. Currently the pharmaceuticals "are going through a new product cycle, unit volume is up 4 percent and dollar sales are up 10 percent" over the same quarter last year, said Hemant K. Shah, an independent pharmaceutical industry analyst.
A frenzy of high-tech research-facility construction is going on now in New Jersey, and more than 5,000 new scientific, managerial and financial jobs are expected to be added in the coming years.
The cost of research is increasingly prohibitive. It takes an average of 14 years and more than $200 million before a drug is approved by the F.D.A.; the failure rate of new compounds is 90 percent. Such extreme expense has driven ever new mergers of companies that affect operations within the state.
"More mergers are inevitable," said Jack Lamberton, an independent pharmaceutical analyst, "and workers at companies in New Jersey should expect that layoffs will be involved."
Over the next decade, the patents will expire on more than 150 big drug brands, opening them to knockoff competition from generic drug manufacturers -- some of them in New Jersey -- peddling low-cost copycat prescriptions. If this is cheering news for consumers, it gives the giant research-based companies perpetual agita.
As bright as the short-term picture looks here, "no industry is forever," said Professor Galambos, adding: "The New England textile factories were built with 18-inch granite walls because they thought they'd be there forever. Now only the walls remain. Industries always move where they feel it is in their best interests to go."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Manhattan Strength Lifts All Boroughs

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
DONALD PIERRE could not find the home he wanted for the price he could pay in his old neighborhood, Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- the one that would work for his growing family and bring in a bit of rental income.
But three miles east, in once-notorious East New York, Brooklyn, he found a three-family building on a 40- by 100-foot lot. And, in October, Mr. Pierre closed on the $165,000 deal and moved in with his wife and two small children. 
 "I got what I wanted: a driveway, a yard, two rentable apartments," said Mr. Pierre, a 33-year-old native of Trinidad.
"It's all changing," Mr. Pierre said of East New York, a community that, during the crack wars of only five years ago, had been dubbed by some the "murder capital" of New York City. "East New York is coming around."
Indeed, say real estate observers and brokers who serve neighborhoods like East New York, Bushwick and the South Bronx, they are all coming around -- a bit. The high tide churned by the Manhattan residential sales market -- with its bidding wars, price leaps and the squeeze of too many bonus-bearing buyers seeking too few properties -- has rippled through the other boroughs, with price increases trickling even into poorer neighborhoods.
According to a comprehensive survey conducted by Case Shiller Weiss, a real estate statistics firm in Cambridge, Mass., house prices rose last year in all but 14 of the 130 ZIP-code areas in the boroughs outside of Manhattan. In 1996, when the city's recovery from the real estate recession of the early 90's was already under way, more than twice as many (29) ZIP-code areas in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island experienced price depreciation.
One of them was East New York. Last year, however, the community rebounded with prices appreciating by up to 2 percent.
To be sure, it is not as though East New York is suddenly paradise found. There remain rubble-strewn lots and the hollow-stare windows of abandoned buildings. Fifty thousand people live in the neighborhood's 23 towering housing projects. R.I.P. murals still dot brick walls.
But in a community that, despite its blighted image, boasts long blocks of primly kept homes, there is a sense that, just maybe, a corner has been turned.
Crime is down. There were 35 homicides in the 75th Precinct last year, a 72 percent drop from the 126 that set a city record for a single precinct in 1993. "The streets are cleaner," Mr. Pierre said. "A multiplex, stadium-seating theater is being built 10 blocks away. It's getting better."
The Bronx, too, is getting better, said Harry Baksh, president of ERA Besmatch, a brokerage with offices in the Castle Hill and Wakefield sections. "There's so much happening," he said. "I see opportunities to sell in the Bronx now that I didn't see 10 years ago.
"Even in the South Bronx, there's been improvement," Mr. Baksh said. "If you drive through the area, you'd see that many of the properties that were abandoned have been refurbished or are in the process of being refurbished. It's not just a few blocks. It's not just some showpiece development."
Across the city, boards of realtors reported a range of price increases in 1997, from 15.4 percent for a two-bedroom apartment below 96th Street in Manhattan to 6 percent for a single-family home in Queens and 4.1 percent on Staten Island.
A broadbrush profile of sales volume for the city, another indicator of market strength, was less calculable, primarily because statistics gathered by realty boards in the Bronx and Brooklyn were unreliable.
Still, as a measure of the pressure cooker that the Manhattan market has become, total sales of condominiums and co-ops selling for $75,000 or more in Manhattan below West 116th Street and East 96th Street increased to 7,114 in 1997, according to the Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report, an 18 percent jump from 6,037 transactions in 1996.
In the Bronx, where Mr. Baksh conducted his own survey, based on transfers of deeds recorded at the Bronx County Courthouse, there were 1,797 transfers in 1997, a 12.1 percent increase over the 1,603 in 1996.
And on Staten Island, where development of remaining expanses of open land provides powerful allure for newcomers, there were 2,565 sales last year, according to the Staten Island Board of Realtors, an 11.8 percent increase over the 2,205 in 1996.
Only in Queens did the numbers indicate a slackening of sales volume -- a 6.7 percent drop to 3,804 from the 4,080 sales in 1996. But that slippage indicated a leveling off from the 2.4 percent increase the year before, and from the 84.8 percent climb since 2,058 sales were reported in 1991.
Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, which primarily represents Manhattan, believes the rebound of the Manhattan market over the last three years has rippled through the other boroughs. "We have surpassed the late 80's in terms of value and the competition for apartments in Manhattan," he said. "It has spread to the other boroughs. We're actually seeing developers look at the possibility of building in the boroughs.
"Soon somebody is going to use the word gentrification as a dirty word again."
For 13 years, Headley Barrett, president of HB Realty in East New York, has been juggling and struggling with supply and demand in his community. "You've got to remember that most of the people that we service are low-income." Mr. Barrett said. "When they don't have money, we suffer like hell. But the way things have been shaping for this session, it looks good.
"Now, we are seeing people who are hunting houses like crazy. Now, we are more affordable than most areas and people understand that, so they come. You get people from Flatbush over here to buy."
IF Manhattan is at the core of concentric circles, so, too, is it and the rest of the city riding a far larger wave.
A national record for sales of existing single-family homes was set in 1997, according to the National Association of Realtors. The 4.2 million homes sold last year represented a 3.1 percent increase over the 4.08 million sold in 1996 -- the previous record.
National sales of new homes hit 803,000 last year, according to Census Bureau data, a 6 percent increase over the 757,000 sold in 1996. And last year's numbers were the third highest ever.
The nation's home-ownership rate set a record in 1997, the Census Bureau reported, when 66 percent of the households in the country owned their own homes.
All of that, of course, has been powered by a robust national economy, the nation's lowest rate of unemployment in a quarter of a century and that real estate ignition fuel: low mortgage rates.
In January, said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage data company in Butler, N.J., interest on a standard 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage was 7.05 percent -- not much above the nation's 28-year low of 6.83 in October 1993.
The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 4.7 percent in December, a 25-year low. And while the unemployment rate for New York City remained considerably higher at 8.5 percent, said John L. Weiting, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, it, too, was improving. It had been 9.6 percent in 1996.
"The national expansion is 84 months long," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Rutgers University School of Planning and Public Policy. Pointing to those and other indicators of a stellar economy -- including the lowest inflation rate in 32 years, 2.2 percent -- Dr. Hughes said, "The home-buying stars are in full alignment."
Paul Hergenroeder's reading of the real estate constellation indicated that it was time to sell his one-bedroom Upper West Side co-op and buy somewhere else in Manhattan. It didn't quite work that way.
"There was a sense of wanting to cash in on increased value," said Dr. Hergenroeder, a physician who works at a long-term care facility for AIDS patients. Three brokers gave him varying price appraisals -- $130,000 to $210,000. "I went with the higher one, a little reluctantly because I thought they were high-balling to get the listing," Dr. Hergenroeder said. "Lo and behold, I got two offers for the maximum price.
"The only trouble with selling is you then have to buy."
Along with his companion, who then lived separately, Dr. Hergenroeder "looked at lofts in SoHo," intending to spend $300,000 to $400,000. "For a spacious two-bedroom or a loft, the prices were closer to $500,000, $650,000," he said. "For less than that we were able to get a brownstone in a promising neighborhood" -- Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. They paid $570,000.
"Brooklyn Heights was unaffordable," the doctor said. "The same brownstone there would have cost a million."
So goes the Manhattan squeeze.
According to the Douglas Elliman Market Report, prepared by the appraisal firm of Miller Samuel, the average price for Manhattan condominiums soared 30 percent last year, from $376,251 in 1996 to $489,228.
CO-OP price changes were more complex. While the overall average for Manhattan co-ops dipped by 7.6 percent, to $424,365 from $459,569 in 1996, there was wide fluctuation according to apartment size.
The average price for a one-bedroom dropped 15 percent, from $205,292 in 1996 to $174,499 last year, the Elliman report said. But studios increased 10.3 percent, from $99,301 to $109,544. Two-bedrooms rose 7.2 percent, from $427,990 to $458,705. Three-bedrooms increased 7.8 percent, from $1,116,000 to $1,202,646. And apartments with four bedrooms or more increased a whopping 33 percent, from $2,360,625 in 1996 to $3,139,585.
The reason for the drop in overall prices for co-ops, said Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, was a virtual doubling of the number of less expensive studio apartments sold in Manhattan last year -- from 305 in '96 to 602 in '97.
Divining real estate trends by the numbers is, at best, a murky exercise. To begin with, co-op sales are not officially recorded because, technically, they are securities transactions involving the selling of shares, and not transfers of title. Condominium sales, however, are officially recorded. As a result, studies of co-op data compiled by brokerage houses and appraisal concerns do not claim to include all transactions in the market.
Single-family home sales are reported by local realty boards. But not all real estate agents are members of the boards, and not all sales in a given area are recorded. At the same time, one board may use median prices -- meaning half the sales are above that figure and half below -- while others calculate an average. Still, the numbers, along with anecdotal impressions, can offer indications of market patterns.
Clark Halstead, founder of the Halstead Property Company, has a novel market barometer. "We've had our web site for three years and it seemed like a sinkhole into which we were pouring funds," he said. "Suddenly, traffic has increased radically, up to 22,000 hits in one week."
Barbara Corcoran, founder of the Corcoran Group, said demand has been so great that "the unwanted children of Manhattan" are being scooped up: "the cookie-cutter one-bedrooms, sponsor sales, fringe neighborhoods like the East Village -- where the response used to be, 'Live there?' "
Pressure from the Manhattan squeeze has been felt in the co-op market in the other boroughs, said Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives. "They are reporting many sales, whereas two years ago there was no activity at all."
Mr. Saft pointed to a co-op on Pelham Parkway in the Bronx where an apartment bought for $20,000 two years ago recently sold for $60,000.
Beginning three years ago, said Christopher Thomas, the William B. May Company's vice president for Brooklyn, "Prices in Brooklyn Heights started rising in response to Manhattan prices. And through last year, the rise in Brooklyn Heights prices prompted a rise for neighborhoods further into Brooklyn -- Cobble Hill, Carroll Gardens, Boerum Hill and Park Slope."
Comprehensive numbers for Brooklyn sales were not available because the borough has no central realty board. But, by another measure, the Case Shiller Weiss survey, the trend was apparent.
Case Shiller Weiss has devised an index to track price fluctuations. The survey is based on a table showing the average price of all single-family homes sold in ZIP-code areas, year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 1997, for example, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each ZIP-code area during the year just ended, compared it to the price that the house brought when it was last sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the earlier purchase price to what it likely would have been had it sold in 1996.
OF the 36 ZIP code areas in Brooklyn, only one experienced price depreciation last year; 10 showed appreciation up to 2 percent, 24 appreciated 2 to 4 percent and one appreciated by 6 percent or more.
A year ago, Mr. Thomas said, sales in Brooklyn Heights and the prime areas of Cobble Hill ranged from $1.3 million to $1.7 million. "By the end of '97, we had marquis listings -- the best properties in the best locations -- listed as high as $5 million. The resulting impact in Park Slope is that houses that were trading in the $750,000 to $900,000 range are now listed from $900,000 to $1.3 million."
Jacob Shayovitz, president of the Brooklyn Board of Realtors, said that "in a lot of areas, younger buyers are squeezed out by higher prices." By Mr. Shayovitz's estimate, prices "in Mill Basin would be $225,000 to $300,000; in Flatbush, $200,000 to $275,000 for the same 40- by 100 lot, and in Bed-Stuy, Bushwick, $150 to $235."
For some buyers, the Brooklyn crunch has exacted an extra toll -- on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.
Donna Connelly, a commercial printer, couldn't afford a condominium in Bay Ridge, where she had been renting. "Under $100,000, you're lucky to get a studio," she said.
Ms. Connelly said she looked "for a good year," in Park Slope, Windsor Terrace, Bay Ridge. "So I crossed the bridge. Did not want to do it, because I drive to work.
"But once I went out there," she said, "for $70,000 in the Bullshead section, I got a two-bedroom, central air, full attic in a town house" -- the Staten Island term for a row house -- "a front yard and an assigned parking space."
Ms. Connelly's mortgage is $451 a month; her maintenance is $130 a month -- for a total less than her $721 rent in Bay Ridge. "The best thing is," she said, "I haven't gotten a ticket for alternate-side parking since I moved here in January."
In Bay Ridge, Ms. Connelly said, "I got, on average, two tickets a month, which comes to $110. I'm saving a fortune."
According to the Staten Island Board of Realtors, 2,465 homes were sold on the island last year, up 11.8 percent from 2,205 in 1996. The median sales price was $158,200, 4.1 percent more than the $151,940 price in '96. All 12 ZIP-code areas on Staten Island experienced price appreciation last year.
"It's very frustrating," said Gerry McClean, president of the Staten Island Board of Realtors. "We don't have enough inventory."
Ms. McClean estimated that a one-family detached house "in one of our affluent areas like Todt Hill" would sell for between $500,000 and $1.3 million, while the average single-family home might cost $186,000, "about $11,000 more than last year."
In Queens, according to the Long Island Board of Realtors (which covers the borough, as well as Nassau and Suffolk Counties), the average single-family home price was $172,393 last year, a 6 percent increase over the $162,686 price in 1996. That trend was supported by the Case Shiller Weiss findings that all but 11 of the 57 ZIP-code areas in Queens experienced price appreciation last year.
Ed Gitlin, a broker at Benjamin Realty in Forest Hills, said that in his community "lower-end houses" that sold for $200,000 a year ago now bring about $230,000. "Fancier homes in areas like Cord Meyer, along the Grand Central, average $500,000," he said.
Even the Queens co-op market, long depressed after a spate of sponsor defaults in the early 90's, is showing signs of revival. Mr. Saft of the Council of New York Cooperatives cited a building in Sunnyside where three-bedroom apartments sold for $42,000 in 1996. "Today they're going for $53,000." And at a complex in Flushing, a two-bedroom "went for $30,000 in 1996, and a year later it's at $40,000."
Mr. Gitlin pointed to a luxury condominium in Forest Hills, the Pinnacle, "that was bankrupt a few years ago, and now a three-bedroom goes for over $400,000."
"These are folks from Manhattan coming in," Mr. Gitlin said, "or older people who have sold their homes on Long Island."
Prices for single-family homes in the Bronx, according to Mr. Baksh, who conducted his own survey, "remained in the same range last year compared to 1996" -- between $145,000 and $180,000. In fact, according to Case Shiller Weiss, there was slight appreciation of up to 2 percent in 20 of the 25 Bronx ZIP-code areas.
Mr. Baksh has noticed, in particular, that "there are a lot of investors in the market -- purchasing properties, mostly ones that need work, rehabbing them and reselling. In the South Bronx, two-family houses have been selling for $200,000, believe it or not. They can receive a city subsidy, so they end up paying about $40,000 less."
Much of the upward pressure on prices throughout the city, said Michael Schill, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law, is attributable to the dearth of new housing construction.
IN recent years, Professor Schill pointed out, an average of 12,000 housing units a year have been lost due to demolition, abandonment or the merging one apartment with another, according to data from the city's 1996 Housing and Vacancy Survey. And in each of the last two years, the Department of City Planning has issued building permits for about 9,000 units.
"So, we are experiencing a net loss of 3,000 units a year, despite the fact that our population has been growing," Professor Schill said. "It's wonderful for the people who are getting increased prices when they sell, but the flip side is that it's not so wonderful for middle- and lower-income New Yorkers who, if they are lucky enough to find housing, must pay extremely high prices."
To beat the squeeze, Marc Levitt and his fiancee, Danielle Bedell, came up with a simple solution -- stay put.
The couple had been subletting a one-bedroom co-op near N.Y.U. for $1,650. "Due to rising rents, it winds up being less expensive to buy," said Mr. Levitt, who works in video conferencing for the MCI Communications Corporation.
"Frustrating would be the word," he said of viewing about 50 apartments. "For over $200,000, we saw one-bedroom apartments where the bedroom was barely big enough to hold a queen-size bed -- I'm not kidding."
Ms. Bedell, a human resources worker at J.P. Morgan, complained of brokers who hyped apartments "that would be nothing that we could live with."
"We walked into one place that was a duplex and they told us it was a bath and a half," she said. "There was a full bathroom downstairs, but upstairs, where the bedroom was, it was a sink on the wall."
In the end, Mr. Levitt and Ms. Bedell decided to buy -- for $170,000 -- the apartment they were renting. "We don't think we're settling," Mr. Levitt said, "but we were looking for our dream apartment and realized that it was not within our means.
"You've heard the stories, but until you go through it you don't realize."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL;
Go West: New Sport Brutes Square Off on the Utah Buttes

BYLINE: By JIM McCRAW 

DATELINE: BLANDING, Utah

 BODY:
MONUMENT VALLEY, that collection of impossibly beautiful buttes, mesas, canyons and valleys in southeast Utah and northeast Arizona, is an excellent place to test the mettle of sport utility vehicles. There are great roads, good roads, bad roads, rocky roads, dirt roads and no roads, with natural wonders waiting no matter which route you take.
Three couples, including four automotive writers, gathered in Southern California in late January with a mission: We would take the pulse of five newborn sport utility vehicles on a 2,200-mile trip through the desert Southwest, seeing how they compared in the kind of environment for which they are designed (but all too rarely see). 
 Once assembled, we headed north and east from Los Angeles on Interstates 10 and 15 to Las Vegas, then on to Gouldings, a complex of motel, museum, store, restaurant and gas station off Highway 163 in Monument Valley near the Navajo reservation.
The director John Ford made his headquarters here, starting in 1939, while making films like "Stagecoach," "My Darling Clementine," "Fort Apache," "She Wore A Yellow Ribbon," "The Searchers," and "Cheyenne Autumn," his last in Monument Valley, in 1964.
We went there to see where the stars worked and to give these trucks a thorough workout. This included a trip to Four Corners, where Utah, Colorado, Arizona and New Mexico come together; through the Valley of the Gods, a huge, red sand gulch; up and down the treacherous Mokee Dugway road, with its switchbacks, silt-and-gravel surface and lack of guardrails. We looked over the Muley Point precipice; took a guided tour of the Navajo Recreation Park, a nature preserve laced by trails, and rode on the road where Forrest Gump stopped running.
At the end of a week in the wilderness, we drove to Flagstaff, Ariz., and began the long return trip to Los Angeles on interstate highways. Our trip included urban congestion, long stretches of interstate travel and extensive off-road driving. We went from sea level to an elevation of 7,400 feet and back down again, and had plenty of time to sort out our opinions of these vehicles:

DODGE DURANGO The largest truck in the group, the Durango is built on the Dodge Dakota pickup chassis. The test model had an optional third-row seat, expanding seating capacity to seven; a raised roof, and the most storage room. The second and third seats fold flat into the floor for cargo.
The Durango comes with a choice of engines: a 3.9-liter, 175-horsepower V6; a 5.2-liter, 230-horse V8, or a 5.9-liter, 245-horse V8. Either part-time or optional full-time four-wheel-drive systems are available. Thus, the Durango can be matched to a family's towing and hauling needs in ways the four others cannot.
The silver Durango SLT test vehicle went down the road like a determined freight train. It is as easy to drive on broken pavement and dirt as on the straight and narrow. It did not ride as comfortably as some of the others, but the steering was direct and accurate. It was also the longest truck with the longest wheelbase, making it a bit of handful in tight places, both on and off the road.
The Durango is a big, honest truck, but it showed inattention to detail. The quality of the plastics and the way they fit together trailed the other domestic vehicles, and especially the import brands. After a sunset photo session, one of my companions reported on the radio that when he pulled the headlamp switch, it came out of the dashboard.

GMC ENVOY The Envoy is a new version of the GMC Jimmy, loaded with luxury and convenience touches and, at $35,000, priced accordingly. The Envoy is thoroughly American and plenty big -- though not as large as the Durango -- and is powered by a 4.3-liter overhead-valve V6 and heavy-duty four-speed automatic transmission. The Envoy's part-time four-wheel-drive system is G.M.'s sophisticated electronic unit. A dashboard switch lets you select two-wheel-high, four-high or four-low range.
The plush Envoy also had Onstar, a dealer-installed global positioning system and cellular telephone that links you to a travel center. The operators there can tell you where you are and where you are headed, make hotel and restaurant reservations, unlock your car if you've locked the keys inside, send emergency or medical help and do a host of other tasks, for an installation charge of $995 and a fee of $22.95 a month.
Amenities included high-intensity-discharge headlamps; an optional dash-mounted CD changer; load-leveling suspension with on-board air compressor to inflate recreation equipment, and three 12-volt outlets to run power gadgets simultaneously.
Although the Envoy shares its clean, practical interior layout with several Chevrolet and GMC models, it has more and better wood trim and wonderfully comfortable leather-trimmed seats. Its on-road manners were exemplary -- the vehicle is quiet, smooth and good-handling. But it was a bit unwieldy off the road, bouncing far too much and refusing to track straight ahead over rough spots.
 
HONDA PASSPORT The Passport is a clone of the Isuzu Rodeo, made in Japan by Isuzu and finished to Honda's specifications, and both versions have been redesigned for 1998. One of the world's largest and most successful makers of medium-duty trucks, Isuzu builds its lighter trucks with guts and gusto.
While the Passport/Rodeo twins do not offer V8 engines, they have capable, civilized powertrains. A 3.2-liter, overhead-cam V6 turns out 205 horsepower; a dash-mounted selector switch turns on the part-time four-wheel-drive system and selects high or low range. The Passport can be had in either two- or four-wheel-drive versions, with a manual or automatic transmission, in either LX or fancy EX trim; the EX is also available with a leather interior package.
The Passport suspension combines torsion bars in the front with leaf springs at the rear. It is smooth on the highway and surprisingly comfortable off road, even on the desolate, bumpy Valley of the Gods Road.
I didn't care for the Passport's outside spare tire, mounted to a bar that must be swung away for access to the rear; the conservative Honda front-end styling (the Isuzu version looks much more aggressive and adventurous), and the fact that the rear seats will not fold all the way down to make a flat cargo floor. These quibbles aside, I found the Passport a solid performer.

LEXUS RX 300 This new sport utility is built on a modified platform from the front-drive ES 300 sedan, and it has a unit, or one-piece, body like a car -- not a body on a separate frame, like most trucks and sport utilities. The RX 300 comes in front- or all-wheel-drive versions, but unlike the other vehicles in this group, it has no low range for serious off-road work.
Hence, the Lexus was the least truck-like vehicle in this group. Designed to appeal particularly to women, it is more of a high-riding station wagon, for occasional off-road use, than a true sport utility. It has a very luxurious interior; a good, quiet ride on pavement, and a long list of appointments including side air bags, an air-filtration system and an optional six-disk CD changer.
The 3-liter, 220-horsepower V6 was smooth and quiet, like all Lexus engines; the rest of the powertrain was exemplary.
The RX 300 was comfortable and cozy, and the instruments were well done with the exception of a tan-on-blue information screen at the top of the dash. The screen's displays were ugly and clashed with the gauges. Their information -- like distance to empty and average mileage -- was skimpy, given the screen's size. An electronic compass would have served better.
The shifter console, which sticks out of the bottom of the dash instead of taking space between the seats, was a nice idea, except we collided with it every time we climbed in.
My biggest problem with the RX 300 was its appearance. The dinosaur-like grille -- complete with slanted bars as teeth -- and the overwrought multi-element headlamps and taillamps were just too much for me.

MERCEDES-BENZ ML320 Built in Tuscaloosa, Ala., the ML320 uses a 3.2-liter single-overhead-cam V6 with twin spark plugs, dual-channel fuel injection and a host of other high-technology ideas to meet strict emissions standards. It is the only compact sport utility with an independent rear suspension, which provides a pleasant, car-like ride on the road and enables either or both sides of the suspension to climb over rocks, trees and other obstacles off the road.
It has the only five-speed overdrive automatic transmission available on a sport utility, and its four-wheel-drive system is distinctive. Instead of using locking or viscous differentials, which are expensive, heavy and complex, the Mercedes has a lighter, cheaper open differential that sends torque in equal measure to all the wheels. It controls wheel slippage with the anti-lock brake system, which acts as a four-wheel traction control. The setup is simple, it keeps the price down, and it works wonderfully in most terrains and weather conditions.
Inside, the ML320 looks like every other Mercedes, with many of the same switches and controls; the same simple, sane instrument cluster, extremely comfortable heated leather seats, and some important safety equipment including standard side air bags in the front. The Mercedes decor was interrupted here and there by some cheap-looking trim items. (Then again, the ML320 starts at $34,000, so corners had to be cut somewhere.) A V8 version, the ML430, will be along later this year, but I found the V6 was adequate in all conditions.
In ranking these vehicles, I placed the Lexus RX 300 at the bottom. Aside from the styling, I found it too small and wimpy for rugged use. The Honda Passport came next, held down by a lack of power, despite its ideal size, great comfort, fine instruments and a reasonable price under $30,000. In the middle of the pack was the GMC Envoy, a truck I really enjoyed driving on the highway. But it seems expensive for what it offers, and it felt clumsy off the road.
I ranked the Durango second, for its looks, the way it covers distances and its ability to swallow cargo. And my overall favorite was the Mercedes. It has the most advanced technology; an economical, low-emission engine with guts; an interior that makes you feel you're riding in a tall E-class sedan, and plenty of usable room at a nice price.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Cincinnati Fund Looks No Farther Than Its Backyard

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
CINCINNATI'S dated nickname -- Queen of the West -- says a lot: it has been a long time since the city that invented air mail (by balloon), professional baseball and Ivory soap made waves as a driver of innovation and growth. In fact, Mark Twain remarked, "If the world would end, I would come to Cincinnati for everything happens here 10 years later."
So, if someone said, "I've got a great idea: give me some money, and I'll put it all in stocks of Cincinnati companies," few people would probably leap at the chance. And investment advisers say such a fund is probably not a good idea because the universe of potential investments is too limited. 
 Don't tell that to Cincinnati. Since Gateway Group, a fund manager based in the city, set up its Cincinnati fund in late 1994, investors who subscribed have done quite well even though J. Patrick Rogers, the fund's manager, is restricted to just more than 100 public companies that are based in or near Cincinnati or have significant operations there.
Mr. Rogers's neighborhood consists mostly of midcap companies, but it does include a few giants like Procter & Gamble. For the three years ended March 20, the Cincinnati fund's annualized rate of return was 29.3 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago.
That trailed the 32.7 percent return of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the same period. But it fairly trounced the 25.7 percent return of the average fund in Morningstar's midcap blend category, which consists of funds that invest in medium capitalization stocks but are neither growth nor value oriented.
The Cincinnati fund earned five stars from Morningstar at the end of 1997, the highest such rating, but has lost a star since then because it gained just 9.8 percent during this year's strong rally, below its peers.
"We haven't really been tested by a major bear market, but our risk profile is surprisingly low for a fully invested fund," said Mr. Rogers, who has seen the fund's assets jump to $25 million from $4 million. "Cincinnati's history has left it with a very diversified economy."
The Cincinnati fund is part of a small but growing group of mutual funds that focus on different parts of the country, individual states and, in a few cases, metropolitan areas. At first glance, it seems to be the most narrowly targeted fund yet -- the only other metropolitan area boasting such a fund is Washington -- but direct comparisons are tricky.
"The key in looking at a regional fund is what kind of out have they given themselves," said William Rocco, who follows both international and regional funds for Morningstar. "Most, like Cincinnati, allow themselves to buy companies that have a significant presence even if they aren't headquartered there."
Thus, while the Cincinnati fund's biggest bets at the moment are all local -- including a grocer (Kroger), consumer products giant (P.& G.), phone company (Cincinnati Bell), electric utility (Cinergy), commuter airline (Comair) and publisher (E. W. Scripps) -- the portfolio also includes General Electric, which has an aircraft engine plant in the area, and Delta Air Lines, which uses the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky Airport as a traffic hub.
The argument for regional funds is that their managers can get to know companies in their neighborhood more thoroughly and see values that outsiders overlook. "It might hold somewhat in areas like California, where there is so much high technology, but there can't really be that much of an edge these days with so many funds out there looking for opportunities," Mr. Rocco said. "Generally these things are long on marketing and short on raison d'etre. The problem is they are likely to attract the same people who already have a lot riding on the local economy in their jobs and homes."
Gateway, which manages about $700 million in all, does no marketing of the fund outside its hometown and very little in it, Mr. Rogers said. The fund grew out of local interest in the strong performance over several years of an index of local stocks Gateway published for its clients.
"We started this as a service to existing fund clients and have no plan to create a family of city funds," Mr. Rogers said. "It's a very narrow niche. We are not trying to be cute."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 10; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 494 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLATBUSH;
Food Co-op Ate Its Spinach, and Now Is Bursting Its Seams

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN 

 BODY:
Barry Smith, a founder of the Flatbush Food Co-op and its general manager for 21 years, remembers a time in the 1970's when New York had 20 food cooperatives. Some were small home-based buying clubs. Others operated in storefronts.
Then in the 80's, conventional grocery stores entered the health food arena, and most of the co-ops fell victim to their own distaste for competition. But the Flatbush Food Co-op used hardball business tactics -- reducing employees' pay and benefits, as well as benefits to members -- to stay afloat. 
 "It was a nightmare," Mr. Smith said, "but if we hadn't done that, we wouldn't be here."
Not only is the Flatbush Food Co-op still standing; it is bursting out of its 1,500 square feet of retail space on 1318 Cortelyou Road.
"We have no room to receive, to work, to sit," Mr. Smith said.
At the annual members' meeting, scheduled for next Sunday, the co-op's directors plan to broach the idea of expansion: either buying a larger store or opening an additional site.
From the outside, the co-op, which is open to the public, looks like a standard health food store. Nonmembers pay full price for its products, while its 1,400 dues-paying members get discounts ranging from 3 percent to 16 percent, depending on whether they contribute labor.
For the last five years, gross sales have grown about 12 percent annually, to a total of $2 million in 1997, Mr. Smith said. The number of shoppers, between 2,600 and 3,000 a week, has also increased, as has the average purchase, which is now between $18 and $20.
Yet Mr. Smith doubted that there would be a vote this year on whether to expand the co-op, though a special meeting could be called for that purpose. First, he said, members must be informed about the space crunch. And though he thinks that the co-op's growth will suffer if it fails to expand in the next few years, he supports the time-consuming process.
"Cooperative means you have to get the members on board," said Mr. Smith, who is 48 and a veteran of the war in Vietnam.
Mr. Smith and 10 other people founded the co-op in 1976 in the basement of a house he then shared in Midwood. By 1978, with 100 members, it operated out of a tiny storefront on East 16th Street. It opened to the public in 1980 and moved to its current location five years later.
Each move was controversial, Mr. Smith said, as he predicted opposition to any suggestions about leaving the economically and racially diverse neighborhood that is home to more than 80 percent of the co-op's shoppers. "We'd like to stay if we can expand," he said, but that might not be an option. The present space is rented, and the building is not for sale.
But he seemed confident that a decision would eventually be reached. Though many supermarkets sell organically grown food, he said, they have not drawn away co-op customers.
"If anything, it legitimizes what we've been doing for the last 20 years," he said. MARCIA BIEDERMAN

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1214 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Students Who Make the Grade and Make Money

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
FOR most college students, the chance to manage real money is as rare as a professor who never assigns homework. But then there is the University of Northern Colorado.
Each semester 12 seniors in a popular investment class there are given responsibility for managing more than $500,000 of the university's $37 million endowment. Letting students oversee endowment money is not a new idea; graduate business students sometimes do so. But the University of Northern Colorado, a 10,600-student state school in Greeley, is one of a few colleges that give undergraduates such authority. 
 And the students seem to have a grown-up awareness of the stakes. "We feel the responsibility 24 hours a day," said Adam Saenger, a senior.
Indeed, the students have done well. They started in 1992 with $200,000 from the University of Northern Colorado Foundation, which manages the endowment. The foundation gave $100,000 more in 1994, after the students' returns beat those of professional money managers with similar assets. From 1995 through 1997, the portfolio, which has stocks, bonds and cash, gained an average of 20 percent annually. And as of March 20, with no more infusions of foundation money and no expenditures, and with dividends reinvested, it was worth $546,700.
"The students have done consistently well," said Zona Felderman, vice president at the foundation.
Of course, the students have benefited from the long-kicking bull market. And they do not have completely free rein. The foundation sets a variety of conservative investment restrictions that apply to them and to its other money managers. The managers must avoid foreign stocks, high-yield bonds and bonds with less than a single-A rating, for example, and no holding can constitute more than 5 percent of assets.
The students also must keep much of their money in bonds, so they can learn about both fixed-income investments and portfolio diversification. As of March 20, stocks were 62 percent of the fund, cash was 6 percent and bonds were 32 percent.
"I won't let them get under 30 percent," chuckled John Clinebell, head of the university's finance department, about this relatively boring asset category.
For the first several weeks of the semester, the students develop a series of economic forecasts to guide them in allocating assets, apportioning their equity holdings among growth, value and income stocks and choosing industries to explore. Then they can, and do, invest, and along the way they learn to use tools like Reuters Instanet, Compustat and the Internet.
If the students who were interviewed are any indication, the class seems born to the business. For example, John Edwards, a senior, watched the defunct Financial News Network when he was in the eighth and ninth grades. And when the students met with U S West's pension managers in Denver recently -- they often travel -- they pined for the professionals' analytical tools, like access to real-time trading information.
"The grass is always greener on the other side," sighed Mr. Saenger, much as another student might hanker after a snazzy car. He hopes to work in mergers and acquisitions.
Other students spend weekends scrutinizing investments. "You have to push it away for a while because it becomes all-consuming," said Lori Barta, a senior who wants to go into corporate financial analysis.
This semester's crop of students have already made some moves with their stock holdings, which include Coca-Cola, I.B.M. and Staples.
In February, they sold half their 400 shares in Sun Microsystems to further diversify their computer holdings. (Along with health care, technology is heavily represented in the portfolio.) They used the money to buy 100 shares of Dell Computer, which has since risen 13.4 percent, to a split-adjusted $67.50.
The decision wasn't easy. The students wrestled with how they could invest in Dell, then trading at about 43 times its earnings per share, when Sun, a company they still liked, was trading at only 17 times earnings. But Sun's Unix operating system is facing a tough battle against Microsoft's NT, they reasoned, and Dell, in turning over its inventory in just seven days, should be able to continue to offer the latest technology and to be shielded from the price discounting common in computers.
In February, the students also sold 150 shares of Union Pacific. They had grown concerned that the retooling of the railroad in light of its 1996 merger with Southern Pacific would take longer than expected. The tip-off was a similar merger, in 1995, of the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe.
"It took Burlington two years to incorporate their acquisition, sort out their rail lines and get their logistics in order," said Mr. Edwards, who initiated the sale. "So, from a short-term perspective, we felt strongly that Union Pacific wasn't going to meet its projections."
The students may have acted just in time. On Friday, Union Pacific's stock, which they sold at $62 a share, closed at $55.25.
One of the students' riskiest moves was their recent purchase of 500 shares of Boston Chicken, at $8.125 each. Many analysts aren't optimistic about the company; indeed, its stock plummeted 82 percent last year. But the students, who have put less than 1 percent of their assets into the stock, thought the company's current revamping efforts made its stock an attractively priced turnaround play. They also noted that the company's insiders haven't flown the coop. On Friday, the stock closed at $5.5938.
Some of the students' choices have not panned out. Last fall, for example, they predicted that interest rates would rise. They then rejiggered their bond holdings to have more short-term debt, which earns less interest than longer-term investments but is also less subject to price drops when rates climb.
The theory was sound, but the facts did not cooperate: rates stayed low.
The students also face a temptation commonly seen among professional money managers -- seeking quick results.
"The hardest thing is to not focus on timing the market," said another senior, Jeff Hybiak. "We all want to look good when we go before the foundation's board at the end of the semester, but that can be hard when you're expected to follow a three-to- five-year investment time frame." (Students can spend more than one semester in the class, in which the grading is pass-fail and is determined by quality of analysis and class participation, not returns.)
The students are weighing other moves, including increasing their holdings of value stocks. Now, 60 percent of their equities are in growth, 20 percent in value and 20 percent in high-dividend securities.
And they are honing their investment skills. For example, they began setting target sale prices for their stocks after Bruce Wilson, their faculty adviser this semester, noticed they were unloading securities only after the price had declined.
"We've talked about improving the students' sell discipline," Mr. Wilson said. "Once a stock meets expectation, they need to see if the value is still there."
Still, for Mr. Wilson, a former assistant treasurer at U S West who is now retired, the class has been an eye-opener. "Frankly," he said, "I didn't expect the investment maturity that I ended up finding."
