HEADLINE: Puzzling Over Productivity

 BODY:
"America's Treadmill Economy" (March 8), Louis Uchitelle's article about productivity and the pressure on companies to increase quality as they fight to hang onto customers, drew a large response from readers. All the letters discuss -- and illustrate -- the divergence over what is or should be measured, and how.
 
To the Editor: 
 When politically convenient, economic commentary has been all in a sweat lately about age bulges in demographics and about Consumer Price Index faults. But both have been critical to almost all measures of economic change for decades. They are of such particular importance to productivity indexes that it is remarkable to see them ignored in most discussions of productivity.
The flood of inexperienced young baby boomers into the work force, which reached a peak in the late 1970's, was a major brake on productivity gains. To this must be added increasing participation of women. When relatively recent entrants predominated among working women, productivity indexes were depressed. Subsequently, there were upward pressures on the measures from the increasing levels of experience of the female work force component.
And the faults of the current C.P.I., significant as they are, are extremely modest compared with the false exaggerations of inflation in the 1970's or inattention to effects on the changes in the index -- including measures of housing costs and consumer expenditures -- in the 1980's.
 
ALBERT BIDERMAN
McLean, Va., March 9
 
The writer is research professor of justice, law and society at American University.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON LINE;
Is Your Rent Controlled?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In more than 12 years of studying housing in New York, Douglas P. Hillstrom, the executive director of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board, has decided at least one thing. "Real estate in New York is totally insane," he said. But a Web site, he reasoned, might introduce some sanity.
Every year, the board sets the percentage that New York landlords can raise rents for the nearly 71,000 rent-controlled and nearly 1.1 million rent-stabilized apartments in the five boroughs.
(Rent control typically applies to apartments built before 1947, and rent stabilization to units built between 1947 and 1968, as well as others built under certain tax incentives. Landlords can raise rents of rent-controlled apartments up to 7.5 percent per year but often don't raise the rents at all.) 
 In May 1996, Mr. Hillstrom set up the board's Web site, Housing NYC, mainly to showcase the seven-member staff's housing research. But Mr. Hillstrom quickly found that a growing number of tenants seemed to be hungry for information, especially in the currently hot real estate market. He soon added features like a landlord-tenant guide and a search engine to sift through thousands of pages of reports. The site gets about 24,000 visits a week.
 
WHAT YOU SEE -- The average citywide monthly rent in 1996 was about $600, a surprise to anyone in the current market trying to find an apartment for less than $1,200. But holding down the average are large numbers of apartments that are government-subsidized and thus hard to qualify for, like Section 8 housing.
Surveys have found that only 40 percent of tenants in rent-stabilized units know that their apartments are rent-stabilized. So the Web site includes a handy list of every rent-stabilized building in New York, organized by ZIP code. One caution: an individual apartment may not be rent-stabilized even though most of the units in the building are.
Whether the rent is illegally high is another common question. To help answer it, the site offers a relatively easy-to-use tool called a "vacancy lease calculator." (It works best with the latest versions of Netscape and Internet Explorer browsers; earlier versions are slow or may crash.)
The rent calculator is especially useful because one consequence of last year's bruising fight in Albany to renew the city's rent laws is a relaxation of the point when regulation ceases. For example, if a $1,500-a-month one-bedroom apartment is vacated after eight years, and if the landlord installs a new $10,000 kitchen, and a few other factors apply, the rent could legally leap past $2,000, in which case stabilization would no longer apply.
Visitors to the site can also E-mail the staff. Mr. Hillstrom recalls a "particularly sad" message from a roommate who said he forgot to sign the lease. When the other roommate decided to move, the remaining roommate had no rights to the apartment. "In this hot market, if you're a roommate and you don't watch out, you could find yourself on the sidewalk," Mr. Hillstrom said.
 
LINKS -- Two, to Tenant Net, an advocacy group (http://tenant.net/), and to the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which administers rent rules (http://www.dhcr.state.ny.us/)
 
WHAT YOU GET -- A richly informative, if text-heavy, Web site on the labyrinthine New York City rental market. ANTHONY RAMIREZ
 
HOUSING NYC ONLINE
(http://www.nycrgb.com)

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Corporate Profits Falter
Corporate profits fell 2.3 percent in the last quarter of 1997, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $483.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported, while the gross domestic product rose at a 3.7 percent annual rate -- less than the 3.9 percent reported earlier -- because consumer spending for services was less robust than first calculated. But numbers for February were far stronger. Sales of existing single-family homes rose 8.7 percent to a record annual rate of 4.75 million, and, excluding aircraft, orders for durable goods were up half a percentage point; over all, orders for big-ticket items fell 1.7 percent in February. 

MARKETS
Stocks Stumble; Rates Rise
The stock market, recently red-hot, chilled out, just as some in the media were gearing up to report on a 9,000 Dow. By late in the week, that milestone looked elusive, as the average ended at 8,796.08, down 110.35 from last week. One reason was earnings disappointments. Another was an upturn in the price of oil, which depressed airline and other transportion stocks. A third was a rise in interest rates and fear that the Fed would eventually push up rates to avert inflation. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond ended the week at 5.96 percent, up eight basis points.
 
WALL STREET
Heady Days for Big Firms
Enjoying some of the most favorable financial market conditions in years, Goldman, Sachs & Company, the last big investment banking partnership on Wall Street, reported a 13 percent gain in quarterly pretax earnings to a record $1.02 billion. Lehman Brothers Holdings reported an unexpectedly strong 30 percent rise in net income to $187 million, led by fees from advising on corporate mergers and other investment banking services. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company reported a 21 percent gain in net income to $691 million, or $1.10 a fully diluted share, 4 cents above analysts' estimates. But earnings on its Discover credit card business were down 21 percent, to $99 million.
 
PEOPLE
A New Chief at Intel
Andrew S. Grove, 61, left, will pass the chief executive's mantle at Intel to a well-groomed successor, Craig R. Barrett, the 58-year-old president, but will continue working full-time as chairman. Intel's microprocessors are the "brain" in more than 80 percent of the world's personal computers. . . . Roger A. Enrico, Pepsico's chairman and chief executive, is giving up his salary -- $900,000 last year -- to pay for scholarships for employees' children. . . . Time Warner granted its chairman, Gerald M. Levin, stock options that would allow him to collect $25.2 million in 2003. . . . Kim B. Edwards resigned as president and chief executive of Iomega, maker of the Zip disk drive, less than two weeks after the company warned that it expected a loss.
 
DEALS
U.S. Sues Lockheed
The Justice Department sued to block Lockheed Martin's purchase of Northrop Grumman, contending that merging the two military contractors could hurt innovation and undermine national security. Lockheed said it would fight the suit. . . . Arch Coal agreed to buy ARCO's domestic coal operations for about $1.14 billion. An ARCO deal with Beacon Group, a New York investment firm, collapsed recently . . . . Cendant agreed to buy National Parking of Britain for $1.34 billion, and, as expected, American Bankers Insurance Group for $3.1 billion. . . . Hilton Hotels and Circus Circus Enterprises called off merger talks that would have created the world's largest casino company. . . . Connecticut legislators defeated a bill that would have helped Echlin Inc., an auto parts maker based in the state, repel a hostile $3 billion bid from a smaller rival, the SPX Corporation.
 
PUBLISHING
Achtung! Lesen Sie Gut*
The largest English-language publisher of trade books would be neither English nor American, but German, if a blockbuster deal is completed. Bertelsmann A.G. agreed to buy Random House for an estimated $1.4 billion. Combining Random House with its Bantam Doubleday Dell division, Bertelsmann would have some 10 percent of the $21 billion American book market. The Newhouse family, which has owned Random House since 1980, appeared to be getting its businesses in order for the next generation. Some authors and agents were dismayed, fearing there would be less competition for books and less demand for literary works that lack best-seller potential, but Peter W. Olson, standing, chairman of Bertelsmann's North American book group, and Thomas Middelhoff, seated, the company's chief executive, were all smiles.
*Attention! Read Well
 
BANKING
A Blow to a Banking Bill
Investment banking and commercial banking have been separated in the United States since 1933, when the Glass-Steagall Act was passed as part of Depression-era measures aimed at eliminating abuses thought to be responsible for the nation's financial collapse. And if the powerful American Bankers Association has its way, they will stay separated. Although its member banks differ on the bill, the group announced its official opposition to the Republican-sponsored Financial Services Act of 1998, which would allow securities firms, insurance companies and commercial banks to merge and would expand the Federal Reserve's regulatory authority. The bill will go to the House floor for a vote on Tuesday.
 
TAXES
Overhauling the I.R.S.
The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, unveiled his long-awaited bill to rein in the I.R.S. and grant oversight authority to an independent board. His proposal goes further than a version passed by the House last year to prevent what critics say is widespread abuse of taxpayers by overzealous I.R.S. agents. Although the goal of overhauling the I.R.S. has wide support in Congress and the Administration, the bill faces a number of obstacles. For example, Senator Roth sees foregone revenue of $9.5 billion over 5 years and more than $20 billion over 10 years.
 
SPORTS
Investors Cry Foul
H. Wayne Huizenga, left, who owns three of South Florida's four professional sports teams -- the football Miami Dolphins, the baseball Florida Marlins and the hockey Florida Panthers -- insists that his baseball and hockey franchises are losing money. Still, he has found ways to profit. There is a cable television station, and he owns Pro Player Stadium, where the Marlins and the Dolphins play. And, in an original turn, he took the Panthers public and used the team's stock as currency to begin building another diversified enterprise. As a result, his original investment in Florida Panthers Holdings has nearly tripled in value, to $150 million. But investors -- unless they got in early -- have not done nearly so well, and shareholders have filed three class-action lawsuits.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 524 words

HEADLINE: Dangerous Inertia in Japan

 BODY:
Japan is sinking ever deeper into economic stagnation and confusion of purpose. Every day brings fresh news of another anemic financial rescue effort or an embarrassing disclosure of corruption or suicide in elite circles, including the Finance Ministry. Yet Japan is not just another Asian country in trouble. With an economy twice as large as the rest of Asia's, Japan's health is crucial to recovery in the region and stability throughout the world. It cannot afford to muddle along.
At the core of Japan's problems is the Government's failure to cope with the staggering weight of more than $600 billion in what are euphemistically called "problem loans." Some experts believe the number to be higher, since Japanese financial institutions often hide liabilities off the books. In the "bubble economy" of a decade ago, when the value of real estate in Tokyo was greater than the wealth of many countries, too few experts realized that lending was based on endlessly rising land values, rather than on potential return. 
 When the economic downturn hit in the early 1990's, Japanese authorities did not force banks to insure that their loan portfolios reflected the real value of their assets. Instead, Japan cut interest rates nearly to zero to stimulate the economy, which led to even more lending. Much of the lending flowed to Asia, and to companies with corporate links to the lending banks. Reality caught up in the form of currency swings a few years ago, which made it hard for the Asian loans to be repaid.
A similar crisis of non-performing loans paralyzed the American savings and loan industry in the 1980's. In a model of what Japan needs to do, the American Government stepped in to force ailing thrifts to write off their bad loans. Many institutions were shut down or merged.
Japanese officials have begun moving in the same direction, but their efforts are ineffectual. The Government's $238 billion bank bailout, for example, is designed to use taxpayer money to raise the banks' capital strength, restore the confidence of depositors and ease the Japanese credit crunch. But the Government has been reluctant to demand more disclosure, mergers and shutdowns. Instead, it is doling money out as if its primary interest was to protect weak banks from embarrassment.
As for stimulating the economy, pump priming has a bad reputation in Japan. A spending spree a few years ago was widely discredited because of corruption. After hundreds of billions of dollars in deficit spending, the economy is still idling.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is now reportedly preparing a new $124 billion spending program to stimulate the economy, though its timing and ingredients remain unclear. He needs to act quickly to get Japan back on its feet so that it does not try to export its way to prosperity, which would aggravate tensions with the United States. In fact, Japan needs to import more from Asian countries so they can solve their problems. Coming under outside pressure and criticism is uncomfortable for Japan. Yet if it is to live up to the world's expectations, it has no choice but to act more decisively.

HEADLINE: In Philadelphia Transit Talks, Uncertainty Rules

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, March 26

 BODY:
Despite its cherished reputation as the City of Brotherly Love, Philadelphia is accustomed to nasty labor disputes, and the latest one has been irritating people here for nearly two weeks.
The three-year contract between the city transit workers union and the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority expired on March 15, touching off threats of yet another citywide strike and fears of widespread inconvenience throughout the region. The union workers, who drive and maintain city buses and subways, have walked off the job eight times in the last 23 years before reaching settlements. 
 With little progress after months of halting negotiations, union leaders say their 5,000 members are ready to strike again, even if it means the usual consequences of gridlock, scarce parking and irate commuters. The union is, perhaps, emboldened by history: as pressures mounted in previous disputes, the transit authority conceded on many vital issues, leaving union members feeling strong and victorious.
But this time, that could change.
Negotiators for the transit authority, which is known as Septa, have staked out a rigid bargaining position, a tactic that has become increasingly common among companies and governments around the country as rising costs are forcing them to do more with less.
Management negotiators here say they need fundamental changes in workplace rules to keep the nation's fifth-largest transit system, and one of the country's oldest, operating at peak efficiency. They cite decreasing Federal transportation subsidies and declining ridership -- down 5 percent since the last strike, 14 days in 1995 -- as major reasons to rewrite rules that, in some cases, have been on the books for more than 50 years.
David L. Cohen, the authority's chief labor strategist, offered an actual case as an example. A cashier booth at a subway station on the north side of the tracks was unusable one morning because of construction, and the cashier for the booth on the south side was absent.
"The logical thing for the supervisor to do was assign the north-side cashier to work in the booth on the south side," Mr. Cohen said. "But under terms of the contract, the north-side cashier was sent to a cashiers' lounge until the problem with the booth was fixed, and the empty booth was filled by calling in someone we had to pay overtime."
The management position reflects, in effect, the same tough stand that city labor negotiators, led by Mr. Cohen, took in 1992 when Philadelphia teetered on insolvency. By holding firm, the city won major concessions from its four municipal employees unions, initiating a new era of labor relations in a city where unions in government and private industry have historically been strong.
But officials of the transit union, Transport Workers Local 234, are not buying management's assertion that Septa is in financial trouble, with a projected accumulated deficit of $180 million by 2000.
Union officials argue that incidents like the one Mr. Cohen described rarely happen, and management is only using them to deflect attention from what they believe is the core issue of the dispute, Septa's desire to squeeze $15 million in savings out of workers' wages, pensions and benefits.
"They want to cut their operating costs at our expense," said Bruce Bodner, a union spokesman, hastening to add that the union would never accept such a demand, and management's failure to recognize that makes a strike "highly probable."
Or does it? Another sign of the changing dynamic in the workplace -- certainly here, if not across America -- is a growing perception that the union's willingness to keep working even during acrimonious, unproductive negotiations reflects the union's weak bargaining position and expectations that a strike would cost the system even more riders and, eventually, jobs.
As previous transit contracts expired here with no agreement, strikes began immediately, four times lasting more than a month. Now, union leaders have gone so far as to promise the riding public that members would not walk off the job once a workday began. Also, union officials say a strike is not likely before Septa's two contracts with suburban transit workers of local 234, about 320 people in all, expire early next month.
"To me, that indicates a softness in the union," said Clyde Summers, a professor of labor law at the University of Pennsylvania Law School. "It also indicates that the union really doesn't want a strike."
In addition to negotiating a contract, representatives of Septa and the union are waging an aggressive public relations campaign. For weeks, each side has run advertisements and issued position papers.
Union leaders and outside labor experts cite Mr. Cohen's role in negotiations as the surest sign that management does not intend to bow to union demands. As chief of staff to Mayor Edward G. Rendell until last year, Mr. Cohen became the city's labor negotiator at a time when serious budget deficits were forcing city officials to cut back everywhere.
Mr. Rendell, who was re-elected to a second term in 1995, plays no formal role in the transit negotiations because Septa is a regional authority. He has told the union publicly, however, to "take the offer that's on the table," according to his spokesman, Kevin Feeley.
"For the union," said Arthur Shostak, a professor of industrial sociology at Drexel University, "Cohen is the dark shadow over these negotiations. He made his mark in the municipal strike, and to the transit union he is young, brash, arrogant and unyielding."
At a rousing, hourlong rally today in front of Septa's downtown offices, one of a half-dozen the union has held recently, Mr. Cohen was roundly criticized as a union-busting hired gun. With about 400 unionists from Local 234 and other industries cheering him on, Steve Brookens, the 234 president, attacked Mr. Cohen's bargaining position. He also said that the logical time to strike would be after the suburban contracts expired, but ever vigilant to public sentiment, he stopped short of saying when, or even if.
That kind of uncertainty has left many commuters uneasy and scrambling to line up alternative ways to get to work, like car pools, van services and regional light rail trains, which would not be affected by a transit strike.
In any case, with the regional economy improving and unemployment falling, few among the area's 425,000 daily bus and subway commuters have much sympathy for workers who earn as much as $40,000 a year.
Gilbert Sweinman Jr., a cab driver for 30 years, said he did not want a strike. "You know what that means? It means 100 million cars on the streets. Rush hour gets extended to 10:30, 11 o'clock. Besides, these people are making $20 an hour now. Is that chopped liver?"

HEADLINE: Dole, Still at Watergate, Plays Offense

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
After Republicans burglarized the Watergate in 1972, a hometown reporter sheepishly asked Senator Bob Dole whether he had hidden the break-in tools in his one-bedroom apartment in the complex. (He said he had not.)
Twenty-six years later, from the same first-floor apartment, Mr. Dole again finds himself a footnote in a scandal that has overtaken the White House. From Apartment 112, his new role is as a trader of gossip about sightings of the next-door neighbor in Apartment 114, Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern who is alleged to have had a sexual relationship with President Clinton. 
 "I did see Monica, got a glimpse of her Saturday night," Mr. Dole reported, sparing no detail, including her forays to the pool. Speaking admiringly of her newly cultivated skills of dodging the press, he added, "She had some groceries and she found a way of getting to the Safeway and back without the press."
Mr. Dole's current platform is a far cry from that of two years ago when, as the Republican Presidential nominee, he tried to persuade Americans that Mr. Clinton did not have the moral fiber to deserve re-election.
"Where's the outrage?" he bellowed again and again in 1996.
These days, from his law offices in downtown Washington, his miniature schnauzer, Leader, a bit frail and suffering from vertigo but still yapping, the former Senate leader from Kansas says the answer has finally sunk in: there is no outrage.
"There was a survey after the election that over half the people that voted for Clinton didn't trust him," said Mr. Dole, who is 74. "Which didn't say much about me. That's the part I've never understood."
But this week, in his first interview since the Lewinsky scandal erupted two months ago, Mr. Dole, who as Republican Party chairman was one of President Richard M. Nixon's most outspoken defenders in the Watergate crisis, recalled the early days of that scandal and said it might be a matter of time before the accusations catch up to Mr. Clinton. He said the President's claim of executive privilege and reluctance to release documents could haunt Mr. Clinton, just as they did Mr. Nixon.
"It's not the sex," Mr. Dole said. "It's the pattern of all these different things: the stonewalling and all this stuff about not furnishing documents. It's a pattern that will eventually disturb people. It wasn't the burglary in the Watergate. That was our spin -- a 'third-rate burglary.' "
Mr. Dole recalled that Mr. Nixon carried 49 states in the 1972 election, five months after the break-in at the Democratic Party's headquarters in the Watergate office and apartment complex, and that "his numbers were pretty high" until the political tide began to turn by early 1973.
Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton have mended relations since the election; Mr. Clinton even awarded his former rival the Presidential Medal of Freedom and dispatched him to Bosnia.
"Do you sit around and say, 'I'm going to get that guy?' " Mr. Dole asked. "Spend my next four years going after Clinton? I wasn't defeated to be America's No. 1 critic of Bill Clinton."
But several times in the 90-minute interview, Mr. Dole could not stop himself from speaking out about a scandal that he said "feeds the cynicism that is out there -- not just about the White House but about politics."
Although Mr. Dole stopped short of calling Mr. Clinton a liar, he raised questions, through quips and barbs, about the President's veracity.
"I thought Willey was credible," Mr. Dole said of the interview of Kathleen E. Willey, one of the President's accusers, on the CBS News program "60 Minutes."
Mr. Dole also castigated women's groups that attacked Clarence Thomas at his confirmation hearings for the Supreme Court and Senator Bob Packwood as sexual predators but have remained relatively quiet about Mr. Clinton.
"Maybe Packwood should be reinstated," he said of the Oregon Republican who quit in 1995 after the Senate Ethics Committee voted unanimously to recommend that he be expelled over accusations that he had forced himself on women.
But Mr. Dole said he had no regrets that he did not delve even deeper into character questions in the 1996 Presidential campaign.
"That's a pretty dangerous line you walk there," he said. "It generally backfires when you go out and attack somebody personally."
Of Mr. Clinton, he said, "People said, 'He's married to the same woman -- that's more than Bob Dole can say.' "
Mr. Dole has run the circuit of late-night talk shows, and seems to be cultivating, with some success, an image as a wisecracking elder statesman who is not depressed about his loss. In fact, he still seems to be more bitter about his upset by George Bush in the New Hampshire primary in 1988 after defeating Mr. Bush in the Iowa caucuses.
"I must say, I still think more about 1988 and what happened in New Hampshire," Mr. Dole said. "I thought '88 was sort of my year, anyway."
As for what went wrong in 1996, Mr. Dole said, "You can sit down all day long and figure out what happened." He obviously has. He still complains about how Steve Forbes pounded him with commercials in the primaries, how "every ad showed me and Newt joined at the hip," and how Mr. Clinton outspent him in the general election.
So far, Mr. Dole said, Mr. Clinton has not been hindered by the scandal because "everything's rolling along" with the economy and there seems to be a feeling of "leave the guy alone -- he's not going to run again."
"He's been a photo-op President in the last several months, surrounded by children and some environmental scene," he said. "And that's all people need."
The former Republican standard-bearer did not restrict his criticism to Democrats. Trying, perhaps, to soften his reputation after his appeals to the right wing in his run for President, Mr. Dole spoke angrily of religious conservatives.
"What do these guys want?" he asked. Speaking of abortion, he said: "We keep getting caught in these one-issue things. They keep raising the bar. If you've got a 99 percent rating, well, then, somehow, you're flawed. I don't understand it."
Asked who might get the Republican Presidential nomination in 2000, Mr. Dole surprisingly mentioned two supporters of abortion rights: Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania and Gov. George E. Pataki of New York. He said he did not know what his running mate, Jack F. Kemp, had in mind. And he has stopped pushing his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole.
"I can't say we've had any real serious discussions about it," Mr. Dole said. "I think she probably thinks about it -- she gets a lot of encouragement."
Though chipper, Mr. Dole seems to long for his old job on Capitol Hill. "I just miss being there," he said. "I like the back and forth and being in the eye of the storm."
But often these days, the eye of the storm seems to be back at the Watergate. He is thinking of expanding his own apartment by buying the apartment that Ms. Lewinsky and her mother are renting. "Haven't heard from my real estate guy," he said.
(For the record, Yah Lin Trie, Mr. Clinton's friend who is a central figure in the fund-raising scandal, is down the hall from the Doles, as is Justice Ruth Bader Ginsberg of the Supreme Court.)
"I feel a bit sorry for her, trapped in that apartment," Mr. Dole said of Ms. Lewinsky. He said her lawyer, William H. Ginsburg, "had a TV addiction that didn't seem to be in her interest," unless "he has some strategy that normal lawyers hadn't thought of."
For all his interest, Mr. Dole said he did not linger every time he saw his famous neighbor. "I walk by fast," he said. "I don't want to be subpoenaed!"

HEADLINE: Allure of 'Titanic,' Minus Ice, Is Packing Cruise Ship Cabins

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
After they marry in September, Colleen Murphy of New York and John Brady of Parlin, N.J., had planned to fly to Fiji or Paris on their honeymoon. But about six weeks ago the young couple -- she is 27, he 32 -- saw "Titanic." They quickly changed their plans and booked their first cruise, a 12-day Mediterranean trip aboard the Norwegian Cruise Line's venerable Norway.
"It was such a romantic movie," Ms. Murphy said. "It made the idea of a cruise irresistible." 
 Romantic? Well, yes. But at a certain point, movie fans might recall, formal dinners and ballroom dancing gave way to a cinematic Armageddon of crashing chandeliers, flooded cabins and passengers plunging into the freezing water. And of the 2,200 passengers having that grand romantic time, more than 1,500 died.
No matter. For potential cruise passengers, the fictional love story is outshining the factual 1912 tragedy. Most big cruise lines report stronger-than-usual bookings this year, and while other factors are at play -- such as the strong economy and eight new cruise ships scheduled to ply the seas this year -- "Titanic" has clearly given the industry a lift. Holland America said its bookings were running 15 percent ahead of last year, and the Cruise Lines International Association, the marketing arm for most North American cruise lines, is projecting a 7 percent increase for 1998.
"Friends and neighbors who never, ever asked me how the industry was doing now want to know all about cruising," said Arthur Sbarsky, executive vice president of Norwegian Cruise Line.
The average age of cruise passengers has been falling steadily -- it is now 44, down from 56 a decade ago -- but because of the movie, there is a surge of interest from travelers in their 20's.
Heather Costa, 25, a student at Johnson & Wales University in Providence, R.I., was undecided about where to spend spring break this year until she saw "Titanic" -- then took a five-day Caribbean tour from Miami aboard the Carnival Ecstasy.
"About six of us," she said, "wanted to get to the front of the ship so we could 'fly' " -- mimicking the actors Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet. But "we never could get to it," a disappointed Ms. Costa said. Passengers are not permitted at the bow on most cruise ships, an area laden with ropes, winches and cranes.
Not that cruise fans are oblivious to safety. The question most often asked, said Diane Hockensmith of the Cruise Shop in Fort Wayne, Ind., is, "Are there enough lifeboats?" Gerry O'Brien of Cherry Hill, N.J., who with her husband, Mike, will be making her maiden voyage this summer, to Alaska on the Princess Cruises' Sun Princess, made no bones about it. "The first thing I'm going to do when I get aboard," she said, "is count the lifeboats." But she also saw and enjoyed the movie.
Not everybody enjoyed the movie. Jessica Miller, 27, of Philadelphia, who works for a travel management company, said: "As I was sitting in the theater watching the Titanic go down, I was thinking, I will never, ever take a cruise as long as I live." In fact, she and her fiance, John Cassady, plan to fly to Hawaii on their honeymoon in September.
While many bookings inspired by "Titanic" are to warm-weather climes, passengers seem to have no apprehension about crossing the North Atlantic, where the supposedly unsinkable Titanic had its fateful encounter with the iceberg. On the contrary, the QE2's first three crossings of the North Atlantic this year, beginning April 15, are sold out, and bookings are strong for the other 16. Peter Bates, a spokesman for Cunard, which bought the White Star Line, the Titanic's owner, in 1934, said the movie had undoubtedly enhanced the popularity of the QE2's crossings.
In addition, the Cunard Web site, which was averaging 110,000 hits a month, recorded 963,000 hits in December, when the "Titanic" hype began in force, and a half-million more over the next two months. "To spike that way," said JoNell Modys of Cunard, "something unusual had to have been happening."
It was. Still, the new popularity of cruises caught some people off guard. "The cruise industry was very concerned about the movie at first," said Capt. James Garrett, a Coast Guard safety official. "But they found it very effective P.R."
It clearly worked on Carole Jaquis. "What a movie," she said. "That love story and all those priceless artifacts on the ship." She and her husband, Tom, who own a moving company in St. Petersburg, Fla., had planned to spend their vacation with relatives in Lake Placid, N.Y. -- until they saw the movie. Now they are booked for their first cruise, 14 nights from Barcelona to Miami aboard the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line's Splendour of the Seas.
Today's cruise ships, of course, cannot match the opulence of the Titanic, making some industry officials worry that newcomers might be disappointed. New, ultramodern ships do have soaring atriums, deluxe spas and theaters bigger than some on Broadway -- but not the extensive rich wood, crystal, fine china and well-appointed drawing rooms of Hollywood's version.
That opulence was costly: a first-class ticket on the Titanic cost $4,350, or $87,000 in today's dollars, according to the American Society of Travel Agents. Third-class passengers, the ones who found gates between them and the lifeboats, paid $30, or about $600 in current dollars.
The eight new ships scheduled to join the industry fleet this year include the first two Disney ships and the 2,600-passenger Grand Princess of Princess Cruises, whose 17 decks will rise 28 feet higher than Niagara Falls -- and whose $450 million price tag is 60 times the $7.5 million cost of the original Titanic. (Even adjusted for inflation, it is three times the cost.)
But the surprise factor is cruising's unexpected lift from a movie that ends with a veritable sea of floating bodies and the "unsinkable" pride of the White Star Line at the bottom of the ocean, broken in two.
"I don't think anybody in the industry anticipated the movie would be this great for the cruise business," said Tom Jackson, owner of the World Travel Bureau in Santa Ana, Calif. "In fact, a lot of people were holding their breath, expecting the worst. But because it romanticized cruising, people are not hung up on the tragedy."
Mr. Jackson is one of almost two dozen travel agents in more than a dozen states who said "Titanic" had helped increase their bookings.
"We're having the best year in our history," said Vicky Cannavale, owner of Cruise Shops Travel in Albuquerque, N.M. "In the first three months of this year, with that big help from the movie, we've sold as many cruises as we sold in six months last year."
"Crazy as it sounds, we're getting bookings for cruises all over," said Dottie Baum, a travel agent at Ahoy Cruise and Travel in Egg Harbor Township, N.J. "People like all the elegance in the movie, and they figure the tragedy was years ago and couldn't happen again."
Captain Garrett of the Coast Guard would not go quite that far. "But I'm impressed with the advances in safety of cruise ships," he said, ticking off a half-dozen safety features that did not exist 86 years ago. They include radar, fire alarms and sprinklers, better-trained crews and land-based computers that can detect water leaks aboard ships at sea.
And icebergs are of scant concern -- not because those mountains of ice have been rendered harmless, but because they are detectable by radar, and the few cruise ships that venture anywhere near them give them wide berth.
Fourteen percent of agents surveyed by the American Society of Travel Agents said the movie resulted in greater consumer interest in cruises, while only 1 percent said the movie made clients less interested.
Only after the Titanic disaster were cruise ships required to carry enough lifeboats and inflatable life rafts for every passenger on board. The Sun Princess, for example, which can carry 3,196 passengers and crew, carries lifeboats and life rafts for 3,996 people. Life rafts aboard cruise ships, incidentally, can hold up to 100 people. They also carry provisions and a radio, and are supposedly impervious to tipping over in high seas.
Some things, however, have not changed since 1912. In keeping with the "women and children first" tradition, some cruise lines -- including Royal Caribbean and Norwegian Cruise Line -- request that men stand behind the women and children during the evacuation drill.
But tradition is apparently all that keeps that custom alive. "We've looked to see where it says women and children first," Captain Garrett said, "and we can't find it anywhere in maritime law."

Former Premier to Run For Yeltsin's Job in 2000
Russia's dismissed Prime Minister said he would run for President in 2000. Viktor Chernomyrdin, who was ousted as premier on Monday, quickly announced his plans and tried to undo any perception that he was dead politically. But he has powerful rivals and low support in polls. 9 

Clinton Honors African Martyr
On his visit to South Africa, President Clinton planted a tree to honor Hector Peterson, a child killed while protesting the white regime then in power. His death, in 1976, led to national riots and galvanized the opposition to apartheid. 12
 
French Protest the Far Right
Tens of thousands of people took to the streets of Paris and other French cities to protest power-sharing deals in regional parliaments with the far-right National Front. 11

The Pope's Jewish Friend
A childhood playmate of Pope John Paul in Poland, a Jewish boy named Jerzy Kluger, has served as an informal intermediary between Israeli and Vatican officials. The Pope is a friend of the Jews because he knows Jews, Mr. Kruger said. 1
 
Turkey's Other Dilemma
As Turkey struggles to define the role of religion in society, it faces an equally hard question about the role of the military. 15
 
India's Reviled Widows
Centuries of social activism and legislation have only partly erased the plight of India's widows. "If we say we are suffering, who is going to bother?" asked one. 1
 
NATIONAL 16-30
 
Students in Quiet Town Discounted Boys' Threats
Jonesboro, Ark., is a conservative, pious, family-oriented town. But the two boys accused of fatally shooting five people and injuring 10 others at a school there last week seemed not to fit in at school. One of the boys appeared to have recently become aggressive and both were overheard by students on their school bus making plans to kill someone. 1
 
Incumbents Keep the Edge
As Republicans struggle to retain the narrowest House majority held by any party in the last half-century, they may benefit in this year's midterm elections from incumbents' high popularity ratings, the sturdy economy and a dearth of contentious issues, leaving many challengers with no foothold. 1
 
Drop in Crime is Puzzling
Crime has declined dramatically for six years, but new studies prepared for a national conference of academic experts on crime suggest that criminologists are no closer now to understanding the reasons than when the downturn was first detected. "The closer we look at the drop in crime, the more complex it gets," said Eric Monkkonen, a professor of history at the University of California at Los Angeles. 16
 
Philadelphia Labor Dispute
Despite its cherished reputation as the City of Brotherly Love, Philadelphia is accustomed to nasty labor disputes, and the latest one has been irritating people here for nearly two weeks. The three-year contract between the city transit workers union and the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority expired on March 15, touching off threats of yet another citywide strike. 16

Ignoring Miranda Rules
It is an open secret in law enforcement: some officers deliberately ignore the ground rule of Miranda warnings, which require officers to inform persons in police custody of their rights, by continuing to question suspects after they ask for a lawyer. 1

United States Customs agents recounted the manhunt that led to the arrest of Stephen Jenks, a Florida drug smuggler who eluded the authorities for more than a dozen years and, as a condition of his guilty plea, turned over 33 colored diamonds that will soon be auctioned off by the Federal agency. 35

Desperate to return to his native Russia, Michael Kurchak showed up at the offices of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in lower Manhattan on March 2 apparently seeking to be deported. He ended up throwing himself through a plate glass window from a ninth-floor office and fell to his death. 33

The school district in Perth Amboy, N.J. has been on a spending spree since last May, when the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered the state to provide enough money for the state's poorest districts to bring their spending up to par with the wealthiest districts. 33

HEADLINE: Ray Scott, 78, Voice of Packers During Glory Seasons in the 60's

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, March 24

 BODY:
Ray Scott, the voice of the Green Bay Packers during their dynasty years of the 1960's, died on Monday at a Minneapolis hospital after a long illness. He was 78.
Scott's resonating voice became synonymous with the National Football League as its television popularity exploded in the 60's. He was the voice of the Packers from 1956 to 1967. 
 He was paired with a young Pat Summerall as CBS's No. 1 announcing team after the N.F.L. merged with the American Football League, and he broadcast four Super Bowls, including the first A.F.L.-N.F.L. title game in 1967.
After being dismissed by CBS in 1974, Scott did play-by-play for numerous teams, including the Minnesota Twins and Vikings, Penn State, the Kansas City Chiefs and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
He also anchored coverage of major bowl games, golf tournaments, National Collegiate Athletic Association and National Invitation Tournament basketball, and baseball's World Series.
He was host of a nationally syndicated radio show until illness forced his retirement in 1997.
Scott, a western Pennsylvania native, was known for his economy of words.
"There was a highly respected high school coach there by the name of Pop Wenreich," Scott said in a 1996 interview with The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.
"He said: 'Ray, don't insult my intelligence when you broadcast a game. Tell me something I can't see.' I've never forgotten that.
"My philosophy has always been let the action speak for itself. It doesn't need me getting in the way."
He was voted by his peers as the national sportscaster of the year in 1968 and 1971. Scott was elected to the National Sportswriters and Sportscasters Hall of Fame in 1982, and named sportscaster of the year 12 times in Minnesota, Florida, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.
In the last seven years, Scott had a triple bypass, a kidney transplant, knee surgery, two hip replacements and prostate cancer, said Sarah Janacek, his daughter-in-law.
Scott, who lived in Edina, Minn., is survived by his wife, Bonnie, and four sons and a daughter from a previous marriage.

HEADLINE: Report Points to Next Battle at CUNY

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
In yet another attack on the embattled City University of New York, a new study charges that most of CUNY's senior colleges are denying their students a proper academic grounding by not requiring core courses in basic areas like mathematics, science, history and literature.
The report by two conservative interest groups, the Empire Foundation for Policy Research and the American Council of Trustees and Alumni, seems likely to turn curriculum into one more battleground at the university, as it grapples with criticisms that its standards are too low in other areas like remedial education, grade inflation and graduation rates. 
 While Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Herman Badillo, the vice chairman of the board of the university, embraced the report, CUNY officials and some educators outside the university immediately denounced it, calling it a polemical document whose conclusions about the necessity of core curriculums were baseless.
Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Badillo said the report was valuable and that it offered one more illustration of the university's failure to set appropriate standards.
"This creates a new credibility gap for CUNY that requires our attention," Mr. Badillo said. "If and when we deal with remediation and grade inflation, then we will have to cover curriculum next."
And Mayor Giuliani, in a statement accompanying the report, said that "to become a first-class university system," CUNY must make sure that all students learn about math, science, history and many other core subjects before granting them diplomas. Other necessary steps, he said, include ending remedial education and taking attendance every day.
But in a memorandum to CUNY presidents on Friday, Louise Mirrer, CUNY's vice chancellor for academic affairs, said the report contained "inaccuracies and misrepresentations, both in the presentation of data and in the general discussion, that lead to erroneous conclusions about the core curricula of CUNY's colleges."
Matthew Goldstein, the president of Baruch College, considered one of CUNY's strongest colleges, also dismissed the report's criticisms. "To say a university doesn't have standards because it doesn't require every student to take economics or philosophy is ludicrous," he said in an interview. "That's a big jump to make, to say that not requiring certain courses shows a lack of quality."
Some educators outside the university also challenged the report, calling it a political document based on a model of education that only 10 percent or fewer of American colleges employ.
Arthur Levine, president of Columbia Teachers College, a strong proponent of a required core, called the report a "political polemic" that was entirely arbitrary in the courses it held out as standards. Besides calling for mathematics, history, literature, composition and two courses in basic science, the report also said all students should take economics, philosophy, art and three years of a foreign language.
"Why is economics more important than politics or sociology or psychology, and why is there no technology on their list?" he asked. "Moreover, not having looked at the content of the courses, how could they evaluate the quality?"
Mr. Levine also said that by the standards of the authors, CUNY should have been applauded, since two out of the nine colleges, or 22 percent, had clearly established core curriculums, putting it well above the national average of about 10 percent.
The study gave high marks to only two colleges, Brooklyn and City, saying that they required students to take classes in most of the areas it deemed important. It said two others, York and Medgar Evers, had appropriate requirements in about half of the areas it considered important.
The study criticized the remaining colleges (Baruch, Hunter, Lehman, Queens and Staten Island) for giving their students such latitude that they could avoid courses in important areas like math or science or take courses that did not provide a broad, basic grounding in areas like history or literature.
"Allowing students to graduate with gaping holes in their preparation does a particular disservice to those students for whom a college education is a route to upward mobility," the authors said.
The idea that colleges should have a clearly defined core of learning that all students share is one that falls in and out of favor, Mr. Levine said, adding that while 3 percent of colleges impose no requirements at all, most of the rest have a menu approach in which they designate broad curricular areas, like the sciences or the arts, and let students choose what courses to take within those areas.
English composition was the only area where all nine colleges met the report's approval. The only areas where all nine colleges were deemed to fall short were economics -- none require it -- and foreign languages.
Other fields were more mixed. In mathematics, the report said that all of the colleges but City, Hunter and Queens had appropriate requirements. In philosophy, only Brooklyn and City met its standard for a required survey course. In the arts, Brooklyn, City and Medgar Evers were the only ones requiring a broad survey course. And in literature, the report approved of the requirements at Brooklyn, City, Medgar Evers and York.
In the sciences, Lehman, Queens and Staten Island all fell short. And in history, the report said that only Brooklyn, City, Medgar Evers and Staten Island had appropriately broad survey requirements.

HEADLINE: Candidate Scores an Upset In Straw Poll for Governor

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y., March 28

 BODY:
A vote today by upstate Democratic leaders further muddied the race for the Democratic nomination for governor as Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, the front-runner in the polls, did poorly, and a little-known former state official, James L. Larocca, ran away with the contest.
At a convention here of the Democratic Rural Conference, the balloting in the United States Senate race produced a mild surprise, with Mark J. Green, the Public Advocate for New York City, besting former United States Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, by far the best-known candidate. Representative Charles E. Schumer had pulled out of the straw poll, anticipating a poor showing. 
 Mr. Larocca, who has worked for more than a year courting upstate Democrats, and Ms. McCaughey Ross, the best-known Democrat running for governor, were widely expected to fare best in the straw poll of county leaders and state party committee members from 41 counties. But Mr. Larocca gained more than twice as many votes as the Lieutenant Governor, leaving her a distant second, barely ahead of the Speaker for the New York City Council, Peter F. Vallone, who has barely begun to campaign upstate.
Mr. Larocca, a former state energy and transportation commissioner, got 56 votes, to 27 for Ms. McCaughey Ross, 24 for Mr. Vallone, 17 for Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, and 3 for Richard A. Kahan, former chairman of the state's Urban Development Corporation.
The results bode well for Mr. Larocca's chances of clearing the first significant hurdle of the campaign: winning an automatic place on the primary ballot by getting 25 percent of the delegates' votes at the state party convention in May. Many of the people casting ballots here today will be among those delegates. Candidates who fail to reach the 25 percent threshold have to collect tens of thousands of signatures to get on the ballot, and this process is expensive and difficult.
Although the counties represented here today, in an area stretching from the Hudson Valley to Lake Erie, account for just one-sixth of the statewide vote, candidates saw the poll as an important test of strength. All the Democratic contenders for governor, United States Senate and state attorney general attended and made speeches, and most spoke about the weak upstate economy.
Democrats are acutely aware that Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, won in 1994 by outpolling Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, upstate nearly three to one. "In order to win statewide, we have to do better in these counties," said Michael Schell, the Jefferson County Democratic chairman, an organizer of the event.
Ms. McCaughey Ross, a Republican until last September, leads in the public opinion polls related to the primary, and her campaign has more than $2 million, most of it provided by her husband, Wilbur Ross, a financier. But she has little support from the party leaders who can help her at the convention and provide the foot soldiers for a campaign.
Mr. Vallone, second in the polls, has raised $2 million. With strong party backing in New York City and the surrounding counties, where the bulk of the primary vote lies, he is the only candidate all but guaranteed 25 percent support at the convention. Yet he was unable to win the consensus support of party leaders from downstate counties, and he remains little-known upstate. Mr. Hynes is third in the polls, but he has raised little money.
Today's results gave a boost to Mr. Larocca, who has campaigned longer and harder than anyone else in the field, but has raised little money and has not broken out of the single digits in the polls. A Long Islander who headed that region's largest business group, the Long Island Association, for several years, he has support from party leaders on the Island, as well as upstate.
"This is the first real test of sentiment among people who will make the decision in the party," Mr. Larocca said. "I see it as a very big step forward."
Ms. McCaughey Ross said she was not concerned about her showing. For her, failure to get 25 percent at the convention would not be a fatal setback. She has enough money to go the petition route -- estimated to cost $500,000 or more -- and she could use it to her advantage, casting herself as the outsider.
But the Lieutenant Governor has virtually no support from party leaders in New York City and the counties around it, and has been counting heavily on backing from counties north of Westchester.
Today's results were less significant in the Senate race, where Mr. Green, Ms. Ferraro and Mr. Schumer, who are looking to unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, are all virtually assured of winning automatic places on the ballot at the state convention.
But the outcome could not have pleased Ms. Ferraro, the former CNN commentator and 1984 vice presidential nominee, who came here confident, noting that in the 1992 Senate primary that she lost, she carried 36 of the 41 counties represented here today. She may have been hampered by her late entry into the race, in January, while Mr. Green has been running for a year.
Mr. Green won 70 votes, Ms. Ferraro 51, and Mr. Schumer 4.
In the race for attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, a wealthy former prosecutor who ran unsuccessfully for the office in 1994, got 54 votes, while State Senator Catherine M. Abate of Manhattan got 49. G. Oliver Koppell, who was Attorney General in 1993 and 1994, but lost the Democratic primary four years ago, won 19 votes, while Evan A. Davis, former counsel to Mr. Cuomo, got 4.

LENGTH: 1646 words

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS HOLD AN EDGE IN KEEPING CONTROL OF HOUSE

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WICHITA, Kan., March 27

 BODY:
As Republicans struggle to retain the narrowest House majority held by any party in the last half century, they may benefit in this year's midterm elections from something of a political security blanket: Incumbents around the nation are savoring high popularity ratings, and the sturdy economy and dearth of contentious issues has left many challengers with no foothold.
Although the two parties are also wrangling over 36 governorships and a third of the Senate, the early signs point to one of the most serene midterm election seasons in years, even in districts like Representative Todd Tiahrt's here, which have seen pitched battles in each of the last two elections. 
 Democrats concede that they have no chance to regain the majority in the Senate this year, while Republicans do not count on reaching the 60-vote margin needed to cut off a filibuster. Democrats also expect that Republicans will hold on to most of the big-state governorships. That leaves most of the attention on about 75 of the most competitive House seats.
Most political analysts agree that Republicans are well positioned to maintain their House margin, but their 11-seat edge is so slim that no one can speak with confidence about the outcome. Even if the House does not change hands, the result will be important in determining the extent of President Clinton's negotiating room over the next two years.
The quiet campaign environment may be deceptive. The wild card looming over the electorate is how -- or even whether -- the White House sex scandal will play. It could bring out angry Republicans in November. Or if the House Republicans conduct impeachment hearings, that could embolden Democrats who could view it as excessively partisan. Another possibility is that the issue will not sway voters one way or another.
Though incumbents are mindful of the possibility of a dramatic event that could alter the political forces, they are enjoying what many of them said in interviews is the most stress-free pre-election period in years. Here in Wichita at this time two years ago, Mr. Tiahrt (pronounced TEE-heart) was in a tight re-election battle as unions were bombarding the district with television commercials portraying him as eager to slash Medicare. His campaign headquarters was in full swing in downtown offices, and Mr. Tiahrt was furiously calling supporters for donations.
This year, Democrats have yet to find an opponent for Mr. Tiahrt -- and they might not do so. The only semblance of a campaign in Mr. Tiahrt's Fourth Congressional District is in the basement of Linda Arensdorf's modest clapboard house in west Wichita. She is the campaign's only paid staff member thus far. Instead of frenetic volunteers, the only background noise is Rush Limbaugh on the radio.
"This is it," Mrs. Arensdorf said as she surveyed the quarters from which she responds to letters from the Federal Election Commission and sends mailings to supporters. "Pretty impressive, huh?"
Reminding her visitor from the East that "we have tornadoes in this part of the county," she fretted that the basement was so cramped that "we'd have no place to go." Still, Mrs. Arensdorf said it was a welcome change from two years ago, when "the feeling I had was that we were trying to repair a car while we were going 60 or 70 miles an hour down the highway."
No one seems more appreciative or, more accurately, relieved, than Mr. Tiahrt, a conservative who in 1994 upset Representative Dan Glickman, a Democrat who had held the seat for 18 years and is now Secretary of Agriculture. "Last time I was fighting for my life," said Mr. Tiahrt, who won with only 50 percent of the vote in 1996. "Now, I'm enjoying the products of hard labor. Instead of fighting negative ads, I'm basking in the satisfaction of being able to do something for my district."
Mr. Tiahrt is not alone. While Kansas is a largely Republican state, local officials in both parties said they could not remember so little competition against the Republican incumbents. Gov. Bill Graves, who was in a hard-fought race four years ago, has no opponent. Nor does Senator Sam Brownback, who was elected in a bitter battle two years ago to fill the seat vacated by Senator Bob Dole. Of the four members of Congress from the state, only one, Representative Vince Snowbarger, appears to have a serious challenge.
The lack of competition extends far beyond the plains of Kansas. In Pennsylvania, six years ago, Senator Arlen Specter found himself in an intense struggle after his role in the confirmation hearings of Clarence Thomas as a Supreme Court Justice. And four years ago, Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania was in a costly, high-profile race. This year, those two Republicans face only token opposition.
In Texas, the race for Governor is the least competitive in years. Gov. George W. Bush has an enormous lead in early polls over Garry Mauro, the State Land Commissioner. Former Gov. Ann Richards was also popular, but that did not stop Mr. Bush from taking her on four years ago.
"It's going to be a huge incumbent's year," said Representative Joe Scarborough, a Florida Republican. "It's going to be monstrous. I think 98 percent will return" to office.
Since most incumbents are Republicans, that would be encouraging news for the party. But Democrats can also take solace in that, thus far, there are no signs that the party will suffer huge losses, as often occurs for a President's party at the midpoint of his second term.
Contributing to the lack of apparent volatility is that there are fewer open seats for the House and Senate. Only two incumbent Senators are widely considered to face spirited challenges: Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois.
But in two states where incumbent Democrats are retiring, Arkansas and Kentucky, the contests are expected to be particularly competitive.
Officials in both parties said one reason they could not convince more prospects to take on incumbents was the perception that there were no great ideological divisions between the parties this year. That may leave candidates waging very locally oriented campaigns.
"Nobody seems to have any traction," John J. Pitney, a professor of government at Claremont-McKenna College in California, said of challengers this year. "In order to bring about change, you have to have traction. And this is a campaign being fought on an oil slick."
Martin P. Wattenberg, a political science professor at the University of California at Irvine, put it this way, "If I were thinking about running for Congress or advising anybody, I would say, 'This is not a good time to be running -- unless you want to make a four-year commitment, knowing that you'll lose the first time.' "
Another striking development is that while Republicans have to defend 24 of 36 gubernatorial seats, few Democrats were willing to take them on, in part because they are so popular. In Arizona, for example, Gov. Jane Dee Hull did not take office until August, but a recent poll put her job-approval rating at a comfortable 71 percent.
The only incumbent Governors who appear to have competitive races are Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, a Democrat, and three Republicans: Argeo Paul Cellucci of Massachusetts, who is filling out the term of William F. Weld; Fob James Jr. of Alabama, and John G. Rowland of Connecticut. But the Democratic challengers in big states like New York, Texas, Pennsylvania and Michigan are far behind in early surveys.
Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, vice chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said he and Mr. Clinton had tried mightily to recruit three Governors to run for Senate this year: James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina, Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire and Zell Miller of Georgia. "I did not have one success," Mr. Torricelli said. "The Democratic Governors in each of those states could have almost walked in to the United States Senate. Not one would make the race." His explanation? "The atmosphere in Washington."
All signs suggest that despite the years of vilification of incumbents, incumbency may be in vogue. With no burning issues to draw challengers, incumbents can still scare them off by amassing large campaign war chests and boasting of their experience helping the state or district.
In Wichita, for instance, Mr. Tiahrt takes credit for helping channel $35 million in Federal money to the district for railroad overpasses to relieve streets clogged with traffic. And Mr. Tiahrt has not let his lack of a challenge daunt his fund-raising efforts.
Dave Hanna, Mr. Tiahrt's district coordinator, said the campaign could easily match the nearly $1 million it raised in 1996. But until there is an opponent, he said, the campaign can preserve its resources. Snapping his fingers, Mr. Hanna said of the prospect that a rival could materialize, "If they want to run, we can click this thing into gear tomorrow."
For all the confidence, the one certainty in the midterm elections this year is that nothing is certain yet, and the scandal surrounding the President or some unforeseen national crisis could intervene in the blink of an eye.
"This White House scandal puts an element of uncertainty into it for every incumbent," said Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who appears in such good shape that he was practically making excuses for having to stage a two-day formal beginning next week for his re-election campaign. "Now you're not sure what mood the country is in. Before this thing happened the approval of Congress was high. People were satisfied with their lives."
The scandal "could generate a high anti-incumbency attitude on the part of voters because when they think we're crooked or they get angry," Mr. McCain said, "People have a hard time distinguishing between Democrats and Republicans."

HEADLINE: Retail Center Is Proposed In East Harlem

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Amid intense government efforts to lure commercial development to the blighted manufacturing areas of Harlem and the South Bronx, city and state officials will announce a plan today to replace an abandoned East Harlem wire factory with a three-block-long shopping complex.
The project, to be announced jointly by Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, is to include two large retailers -- Home Depot and Costco -- several other stores, parking for 1,100 cars and a separate building dedicated to small entrepreneurial companies at the site of the former Washburn Wire plant. It will cover six acres on the west side of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, from 116th Street to 119th Street. 
 Officials said construction of the shopping complex, budgeted at $87 million, could begin next year and be completed by 2001.
If built as planned, they said, it would create 2,000 jobs, a large retail outlet in an area where residents frequently drive to the suburbs to shop, and fresh impetus for other commercial ventures in Harlem, Washington Heights and the South Bronx.
The Washburn Wire site, which city and state officials have repeatedly cited as a top development priority, is within two overlapping economic development zones -- one state, one Federal -- providing an array of benefits like tax credits and low interest loans for whoever builds there.
The proposed shopping complex "will be the anchor of the economic renaissance of Harlem," Governor Pataki said. Mayor Giuliani, describing the Washburn Wire site as "a symbol of our city's decline," said the project would be "another example of our city's resurgence, and more importantly, a sign of East Harlem's rebirth."
The complex, to be called East River Plaza, is to be built by the Blumenfeld Development Group, a Syosset, N.Y., company that bought the site at a foreclosure auction in 1996 for $3.1 million.
That followed a checkered history that in many ways mirrored the decline of manufacturing in East Harlem. The 100-year-old plant, a hulking red-brick structure that has been abandoned since the early 1980's, was once one of New York City's largest, employing 600 workers. But after closing in 1982, it had been the focus of a succession of failed development schemes, including plans for a movie production studio.
Under the plan to be announced today, Home Depot, the home improvement chain, and Costco, a chain of discount "club" style department stores, are to be the largest tenants in the complex, taking up a combined total of 240,000 square feet. An equal amount of space would be available to other tenants.
Randy Daniels, senior vice president of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's development agency, said executives of Blumenfeld Development were in discussions with several other national retail chains, including the Old Navy clothing chain, about taking space in the complex.
He said a separate four-story, 40,000-square-foot building to be built by Blumenfeld but controlled by some form of community advisory board that has not yet been appointed, would be designated as an incubator for small businesses, providing commercial space at low rent.
Despite the support of the Mayor and the Governor, the project could face roadblocks. Since the site is now zoned exclusively for manufacturing, it would have to be rezoned by the city for commercial use.
Such a change may meet resistance from East Harlem residents, because of the traffic the complex would generate. "The project is a home run," said one senior adviser to the Mayor, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But it may have to be scaled down."
Another senior city official who has been involved in the negotiations said that the developer would have to pay to rebuild the southbound exit off the F.D.R. Drive at 116th Street, which is too narrow to accommodate a fresh infusion of traffic. Northbound exits would not require reconstruction, he said.
Other difficulties could arise because the site will provide only about 75 percent of the land sought by the developer. State officials plan to use the state's power to condemn property to acquire adjacent lots for the project.
But even though Blumenfeld Development has agreed to pay for those lots, officials said, recent cases in which the state has used its condemnation rights -- particularly in Times Square -- have shown that lawsuits can raise the price of condemned property far above developers' expectations.
About 50 homes and 150 tenants in the neighboring lots could be affected, said Eddie Baca, an East Harlem resident who is president of the Local Development Corporation del Barrio and the former chairman of Community Board 11 there. He said there is uncertainty about how the project would affect lives and existing businesses.
The project would be welcome, he said, "provided that it protects the homeowners who are there now."
Mr. Baca also said he was concerned because there have been no guarantees that jobs created by the project would go to local residents. Without such assurances, he said, there is uncertainty. "They've made no effort to outline plans for the residents and people are frightened," he said.
Still, the project has attracted powerful government backing, particularly because of the wire factory's central location in two economic development zones.
If the shopping complex is built, it would be the largest project in the large Empowerment Zone created by Congress in 1996 and administered jointly by city, state and Federal officials, in parts of Harlem, Washington Heights and the South Bronx.
That zone provides developers with several financial incentives, including tax breaks for hiring people who live within the zone or in another depressed neighborhood.
The other economic development zone, created by the state in 1988, provides developers with such things as investment tax credits to defray some construction costs, and discounts on their electrical bills.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
State Comptroller Faults Development Agency

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
A state comptroller's audit has criticized the Department of Economic Development for failing to measure whether its economic development zones are succeeding, but a spokeswoman for the agency says a system to do so is nearly complete.
The spokeswoman, Caroline Quartararo, said the review has been time-consuming because it covers 92,000 workers in 40 economic development zones. 
 The audit, released last week by the office of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, criticized the department for failing to fully implement several suggestions Mr. McCall made in 1996 to gauge the success of the zones. The department, he said, does not have a system to track whether businesses that get tax breaks in economic development zones are creating new jobs.
Ms. Quartararo said that the program's achievements are clear. "This program is a major success," she said. "We've seen 800 new companies create 8,500 new jobs and invest $1.6 billion in 1995 and 1996."

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
$271 Billion Roads Bill Draws Clinton's Wrath

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
The six-year, $271 billion highway bill pending in the House is drawing fire from President Clinton, who calls it a threat to "both our fiscal discipline and our commitment to education and other critical investments in our future."
The bill has the backing of the House leadership, and the majority whip, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, predicted on Friday that it would pass easily when it comes before the full House in a few days, The Washington Post reported today. 
 A group of Democrats and conservative Republicans plans to offer amendments on the floor to trim the bill by $18 billion, the paper also said. But Mr. DeLay said he expected that effort to have little effect.
Mr. Clinton made his remarks in an undated letter to the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, calling a well-constructed highway and transit system "an important domestic priority and critical to our economic success" but citing a need to "strike a balance."
The Senate passed its version of the highway bill nearly three weeks ago. It calls for $214 billion in spending over the next six fiscal years.
