HEADLINE: When Life After Death Is the Company's Lot

BYLINE: By ERIC HUBLER

 BODY:
THERE'S no good time to get bad news, but some times are worse than others. Nicole Maxwell was the humand resources director for Barrington International Hospitality Inc., an upstart hotel-management company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., eight months pregnant - and had moved the previous day to a new house in a new neighborhood - when the word came: The plane carrying her boss and father, Barry L. Conrad, on a United States trade mission to the former Yugoslavia was missing.
 
 While the nation focused on the loss of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown in the April 3, 1996, crash near Dubrovnik, Croatia, Ms. Maxwell faced a double burden of grief: to comfort and be comforted by her family, but also to respect the unsentimental, unrelenting demands of profit-making and get back behind her desk.
 For her, as for all the employees, aides, customers and shareholders of the 12 companies with executives on the flight, the days and months after the crash yielded unwanted but unavoidable lessons in how to keep a company alive in the face of a sudden death at or near the top. Two years later, a look at two of the companies that lost their chief executives reveals many of those lessons, which executives and board members at other companies would do well to heed.
 Apart from their interest in helping to rebuild the former Yugoslavia, the companies could not have been more different.
 The privately held Barrington, an eight-employee company only 14 months old, was so tightly identified with Mr. Conrad, 55 at his death, that it had not had time to create, let alone fill, several key positions, and had no crisis plan; it could well have followed its founder into oblivion.
 By contrast, ABB Inc., a $5 billion, 22,000-person United States subsidiary of ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., the Swiss-Swedish engineering conglomerate, had a many-tendriled hierarchy that it could tap to compensate for the loss of Robert E. Donovan, its 54-year-old chairman, president and chief executive.
 And while their approaches to recovery differed greatly, too, there were some striking similarities. At both companies, the death has been looked on not just as a loss to be mourned but as a business challenge to be overcome. At both, there is an openly acknowledged conflict between the desire to be faithful to the fallen leader's wishes and the need to innovate. And at both, there is a sense of being poorer for the loss but richer for having undergone the trial.

Barrington International
No Dreamer,
No Dream
 The words "dream" and "vision" recur too often in conversations with people close to Barrington not to be taken seriously.
 Although the leisure industry had been hospitable enough to Barry Conrad - he had risen to leading positions at Trusthouse Forte, the British hotel company, and Burger King - he had grown disgusted with the lack of personal loyalty in the corporate world, and especially disgusted with himself when he had to lay people off.
 Barrington was supposed to be different. People would be valued. There would be no sinecures, but the company would be Mr. Conrad's moral and financial legacy to his children. Bot his daughters went to work for him, as did Nicole's husband, Todd Maxwell, the senior vice president for finance and accounting. Mr. Conrad's youngest child, Brent, studied hotel management at college in hopes of doing likewise. Even the name Barrington, a play on Barry, was a form of immortalization.
 The company started as a 50-50 joint venture between Mr. Conrad, who had the knowledge and skill, and Paulo de Brito, a Brazilian rancher and investor, who had the money. Mr. Conrad knew he wanted to do something in the emerging economies of South America - operate Burger King franchises, he thought, but McDonald's turned out to be too well entrenched. He turned instead to hotels, securing the master franchise in Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay for Choice Hotels International's Clarion, Comfort, Sleep Inn and Quality brands. Such a franchise would give Barrington equity in or outright ownership of the hotels.
 But the company needed a source of short-term income to finance its long-term investment in Latin America. And that's where Croatia came in.
 The hotels along the magnificent Adriatic coast had, after a half-dozen years as little more than refugee centers, pretty well forgotten how to be hotels. Croatian Hotels and Resorts, a joint venture of Barrington and partners from Croatia and Austria, supplied management services - mainly Mr. Conrad's expertise. Contracts covering 68 hotels were in place by the time of the Brown mission.
 Mr. Conrad's widow, Patricia, recalls their final conversation, on the eve of the crash, in which 35 people died: "He called me the night before saying, 'Can you believe it? We're actually going to be able to save a country.' "
 With Mr. Conrad's death, the Broatian revenue source was in peril. The first and most pivotal meeting of Barrington's leaders after the crash was a soul-searching discussion in a cafe at the Marriott Hotel in Miami several weeks later. The topic, according to Mr. Maxwell, who served as secretary to the board, was, "How do we carry on a develop this thing, or do we let the dream die where it was?"
 Mrs. Conrad had no formal experience in the hotel business. But as the heir to Mr. Conrad's 50 percent stake and his seat on the four-member board, she felt so strongly about keeping about keeping the company running that within weeks of his funeral on April 15, 1996, she went to Hungary, seeking to save a nascent management deal that ended up falling apart.
 In some cases, the Barrington team tried to appease a nervous client by pledging more time or money to a project; in others, Mrs. Conrad said, "we just decided simply to let go because there seemed to be too strong an identity with Barry rather than the company, and we were not comfortable with their level of expectation."
 If anyone had a motive to bail out it was Mr. Brito, the investor, who had never intended to play an active role in the company. Instead, he assumed Mr. Conrad's position as chairman. "We had a very good understanding that the company had to proceed so we didn't lose all the effort that culminated in the loss of his life," Mr. Brito explained.
 Two months after Mr.Conrad's death, Barrington recruited a new chief executive - Paul J. Sistare, a hotel industry longtimer, who was nominated by Mr. Conrad because he had worked with her husband off and on for 20 years and considered him a mentor.
 The two had been out of touch. But in a bit of company lore that varies somewhat with each telling, a note was found after the crash in Mr. Conrad's Zagreb hotel room in which he reminded himself to call Mr. Sistare to sound him out about joining Barrington. The note, discovered after Mr. Sistare had already begun interviewing for the job, amounted to Mr. Conrad's succession plan.
 Mr. Sistare's first task was to closet himself in his late friend's office for several weeks, reading Mr. Conrad's notes in an almost seance-like effort to gain guidance from beyond. "Who knows what plans were floating around in Barry's head?" Mr. Sistare said. "The guy was a visionary. But fortunately, he was also a very careful note taker."
 Personnel decisions were fairly easy: Mr. Sistare quickly brought in experienced marketing and technical executives, for example. But what to do about Croatia - a time-intensive operation that generated $70,000 in monthly revenues but created no lasting assets for Barrington - was another matter, and here began a series of decision that changed the nature of the company. Barrington stopped seeking new business in Europe and is now in the final stages of selling its take in Croatian Hotels and Resorts. The company will reap "a very significant profit," Mr. Sistare says, but it means the end of the venture that cost Mr. Conrad his life.
 With Croatian Hotels and Resorts out of the picture, where would the money to build and operate hotels in South America come from? Again it was Mr. Brito who came up with the answer - in the middle of the night, as one Barrington executive tells the story, so Mr. Brito had to ask his wife to remind him of his brainstorm in the morning.
 The angel was Gregory J. Ryan, a fellow Brazilian who had already unwittingly shaped Barrington: He was the McDonald's franchiser whose success in South America had kept Burger King at bay. Mr. Ryan bought 40 percent of the company and became chairman; Mr. Conrad and Mr. Brito now own 20 percent each, and Mr. Sistare remains president and chief executive; the remaining 20 percent is spread among various corporate officers.
 Mr. Ryan endorses and tries to emulate Mr. Conrad's style of running the company, with, as he says, "the formality that's required by law and the informality that leads to good conversation" among the shareholders. But he acknoledged that his investment in Barrington is "a pure business move," and that he has no personal connection to the Conrads and no responsibility to provide for them as a father would. The company, which has grown to 28 employees, will continue to sell bits of itself to outside investors he said.
 Mrs. Conrad says her decision to water down her stake in the company was correct, but adds that she did not depart from her husband's vision without regret. "We as a family had to accept the idea that this would no longer be able to proceed according to his plan," she said.
 "As a legacy, it's pretty much gone," said her daughter Nicole, who remained with Barrington for more than a year but now stays home caring for her two sons. Nicole's sister also has left the company.
 Mr. Conrad knew he needed a succession plan, his widow said, but the company had grown so quickly that there simply had not been time.
 "I think you have to have a recovery plan for not just having lost an individual, but also the emotional impact on the company and the people they do business with," Mrs. Conrad said. A succession plan, she added, is "not something you ever complete."

ABB Inc.
From a Tragedy
Comes Cohesion
 On the floor and a half of a quiet Norwich, Conn. office complex that serve as ABB's American headquarters, the question was never whether to carry on, only how.
 Fortunately, ABB people are engineers, so "how" is the question they feel best qualified to answer. When Bob Donovan's lieutenants heard that his plane was missing, they leaped quickly from watching-the-news mode to devising a plan of action. There was no crisis document to guide them, but the executives instinctively turned themselves into a task force, as if mentally executing a schematic.
 "We're project people, and we're used to taking very complex logistical situations and managing them, so that really played right into the things we do and the things we are," said John Sullivan, a staff vice president who handled the daunting details of Mr. Donovan's funeral for the company.
 The task force included one man who, technically, did not work for the company. Richard J. Slember had retired the previous week as head of ABB's worldwide nuclear business and was in the office just to finish his packing. He was dispatched to the Donovans' home in Fairfield to hold vigil with the family and talk to reporters. He also agreed to go to Manhattan the next morning for a interview with CBS News.
 In the car on the way to the city, Dr. Slember's role took a sudden turn from peripheral to central. Percy Barnevik, ABB's chairman, called from Zurich, asking Dr. Slember to come out of his three-day retirement and take Mr. Donovan's job. "It was such a natural thing, with my back-ground and availability - it just felt like the right thing to do," Dr. Slember recalled. "Later, I thought, 'Well, what am I going to tell my wife?' "
 But guiding ABB, even without a crisis at hand, would not have been easy. Created as a by product of the 1988 merger of Sweden's Asea and Switzerland's BBC Brown Boveri, the American operation promptly had gone on a buying spree of its own, acquiring two venerable but aging companies: Westinghouse Transmission and Distribution, which provided services and equipment to local utilities, and Combustion Engineering. Neither was doing terrifically, and it didn't help, Dr. Slember said, that as a result of the recession and utility deregulation, "the market went south."
 In short, the American operation "required major, major restructuring," he said, a restructuring that was just nearing completion when Mr. Donovan died after only two years as chief executive.
 Part of the problem was the difficulty, common to merged companies, of meshing systems and corporate cultures. "When I came to ABB in 1990 I had, I think, eight electronic-mail systems, none of which communicated with any of the others," Dr. Slember said. "Same with financial software, word processing, communications, spreadsheets - everybody had their own."
 ABB executives say Mr. Donovan's death hastened a process that could have taken years even for the most talented executive: bringing the company together. The corporate communications department, by then able to get messages to the entire company, made its heaviest use ever of Lotus Notes to keep ABB locations across the country up to date. As soon as Mr. Donovan's death was confirmed, Mr. Sullivan was deluged with requests to attend the funeral, at St. Luke's Church in Westport, Conn., and the interment at Mr. Donovan's alma mater, West Point.
 "There was just a grass-roots up-rising of, 'Could we get into this?' 'Could we see?' and 'Where's the church?' " Mr. Sullivan said. "It became apparent that if everyone comes, we're just not going to able to fit everyone." His solution was satellite hookup to five locations, allowing as many employees as possible to grieve together.
 That was not the end of Mr. Sullivan's chores, however. The entire ABB executive committee, including Mr. Barnevik, planned to attend, so there were flights and airport pickups to arrange, as well as transportation from the funeral to the interment. Making sure that such seemingly minor details went smoothly was, in retrospect, one of the most important things that could have been done.
 "The fact that this tradegy brought in everbody was a tribute to how people saw this guy," Mr. Sullivan said. "And then seeing them here was some solace. It was viewed very positively by all of the people that were going through the trauma that had known Bob for an extended period of time."
 The emergence of a sense of cohesion, until then missing at ABB, was tangible. "This was bonding experience," said Karin Quinland, who has served as senior executive assistant to four chief executives of the American unit in the last six years. "All senior management came to the funeral and everyone is kind of unmasked, and it really created a bond that needed to be created at the time. A tragedy brought us all closer together, and I think we understand each other a lot more as a result of what happened."
 By the time Zurich headquarters announced Mr. Donovan's permanent replacements, the company had a better sense of itself and was more ready to be led than it had been when Mr. Donovan had taken over in 1994.
 Succeeding Dr. Slember in September 1996 were Howard Pierce, head of ABB China, as chairman, chief executive and group executive vice president for the Americas, and Peter S. Janson, formerly one of Mr. Donovan's executive vice presidents who would report to Mr. Pierce as president, with responsibility for the United States.
 Splitting the position in two "was a very good move, as the position as it was before was a man-killer," said the re-retired Dr. Slember.
 "You were moving constantly, you can imagine, with the area that needed coverage," he said.
 If Dr. Slember, and then Mr. Pierce, kept ABB together, it was Ms. Quinlan who kept the two men in one piece. Among the American chief executive's responsibilities is attending executive committee meetings in Zurich every three weeks, a massive briefing book in tow. The chief executive's assistant, unappreciated in many companies, wasn't unappreciated at ABB. "Mr. Pierce came here to this office and did not know anyone here," Ms. Quilan said. "He did not know his own staff very well. So he would ask me about who does that project, who does this, how is this relationship - you know, relying on my knowledge."
 Mr. Sullivan represented ABB in a follow-up mission three months after the crash, retrieving a few fragments of the plane to give to Mt. Donovan's widow and resuming the pursuit of several power projects on which ABB was bidding. "We were not successful," Mr. Janson said. "We are participating, but not to the extent that we would rather be. But that's part of the competitive nature of our business."
 Thought ABB executives decline to say how extensive a succession plan was in place for Mr. Donovan, the experience clearly pushed the matter up a notch on the priority list. "We've been active in the last couple of years doing succession plans," Mr. Janson said. "It's a management responsibility to discuss succession planning for each individuals."
 Like most companies, ABB always had a policy letting key executives travel together. Today, Mr. Janson said, it is applied "a little more strictly."

PUB-DATE: March 29, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 44; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 7520 words

HEADLINE: Kofi Annan's Next Test

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub has written for The New York Times Magazine about Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Webster Hubbell, Floyd Flake and others.

 BODY:
A few minutes before noon on sunday, Feb. 22, three black Mercedes sedans pulled into the U-shaped driveway of the Baghdad villa in which the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, and his staff had been quartered since their arrival in Iraq two days earlier. These were not the same drivers who had taken Annan to his repeated negotiating sessions at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; these were Saddam Hussein's personal drivers, among the very few people permitted to know the Iraqi President's whereabouts. They had come to take the Secretary General to his climactic negotiating session with Saddam. Annan was told that he could take no more than three aides and his bodyguard. He was not told where he was going. He didn't seem fazed;
Annan never seems fazed. Ahmad Fawzi, the spokesman for Annan's delegation, asked one of the Iraqis where the Secretary General was being taken. "He looked at me like I was a cockroach," Fawzi said later. "I think he wanted to take me out back and have me shot." 
 Here was a moment scripted by Hollywood. Whatever moral romance is associated with Annan's job stems from its essential powerlessness. The Secretary General steps into a situation bristling with menace, armed only with his mandate and his moral authority. He has something of the Pope's spiritual status, but of course he has no church -- no army of believers. He is a small, solitary figure
silhouetted against a vast backdrop. And here, in Baghdad, Kofi Annan -- "the soft-spoken, gentle lamb," as I heard him once mockingly call himself -- had been whisked off to meet the most evil tyrant on earth.
In reality, of course, the Secretary General is seldom truly unarmed. In this case, Saddam Hussein knew that the United States stood prepared to bomb his country to kingdom come if he did not open his eight "presidential sites" to U.N. weapons inspectors. But Saddam had not submitted so far; no one knew which way the seesaw would tip. The atmosphere at the villa as the Annan caravan sped away was a crackling mixture of helplessness, hope and sleep deprivation. Elisabeth Lindenmayer, who has worked with Annan for many years, paced back and forth for hours, waiting for the Mercedes to pull back into the driveway.
As it turned out, Annan was only a few minutes away, over at the Republican Presidential Palace, where he met with Saddam for three hours and, while the two men smoked cigars, persuaded him to accept what the Iraqis had said they could not accept -- unlimited access to the eight sites previously designated completely off-limits. At least for a time, Annan had averted the war that only a week earlier seemed almost inevitable. And he had done so without offering anything more than a few symbolic concessions. It might well have been the most dramatic achievement by a Secretary General since the era of Dag Hammarskjold.
Annan left Baghdad believing that he had achieved not only personal but also institutional vindication -- vividly demonstrating the merits of diplomacy and multilateralism. Then he arrived back in the United States and heard himself denounced as a latter-day Neville Chamberlain by the Senate Majority Leader, Trent Lott. The Clinton Administration, which he had arguably saved from itself, issued not so much as a thank-you. The atmosphere improved in the weeks that followed, as the Iraqis complied with the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding. But Annan's hope that he could cash in the settlement, and his modest reputation as a reformer, for an American promise to finally repay the $1 billion it owes the U.N. in back dues began to look ill founded. The U.N. desperately needs the U.S., but the feeling is scarcely mutual. On a flight to Washington, where he went earlier this month to plead his case, he said of Congress, with an air of impatience quite unusual in him, "We have delivered; I want to know when they will deliver." The answer appears to be: Not in the foreseeable future. Just now, as Annan has discovered, Washington may be less amenable to reason than Baghdad.
The Secretary Generalship is one of the world's oddest jobs, half moral witness and half C.E.O. Actually, the division is more like 10 percent and 90 percent. The Secretary General is the chief administrator of an international parliamentary system and the boss of 10,000 international civil servants; he is expected to coordinate, though he does not control, the activities of affiliated groups like Unesco and the World Health Organization. But Article 99 of the U.N. charter also gives the Secretary General the right and obligation to bring to the attention of the Security Council any issue that threatens international peace and security. The drama of the position, and the possibilities for heroism and humiliation that go with it, lie entirely in the peacemaking role.
The job has produced, by common consent, only one great man: Dag Hammarskjold, the Swedish statesman who served as the second Secretary General for eight years beginning in 1953. It's instructive that Hammarskjold was chosen because, as a former Dutch representative to the U.N. later wrote, he was mistakenly believed to be a "careful and colorless official" who would tend to administrative business without inserting himself into issues of war and peace. Traditionally, the smaller states want an activist Secretary General willing to speak for their interests and take on the great powers. The great powers themselves, who control the U.N. through their permanent membership in the Security Council and the veto power that comes with it, want a man who is, as the saying goes, more secretary than general. It was Hammarskjold who fostered the atmosphere of moral charisma that surrounds, or used to surround, the office of Secretary General. It wasn't only that he put himself in harm's way all over the world -- and died a martyr's death when his plane crashed during a peace mission to the Congo in the fall of 1961 -- but also that he understood and expressed his role in transcendent terms. When he traveled to China in 1955 to win the release of 15 captured American airmen, he explained that his authority lay not simply with the member states that he represented but with the U.N. charter itself, a novel interpretation that came to be known as the Peking Formula.
The shadow of Hammarskjold has hung over the U.N. ever since. It's clear, in retrospect, that it was the cold war, and the fear of another world war, that made his achievements possible; the superpowers, no matter what they said, needed him to put out at least some of the fires they had started. But it's also true that the Secretary General's peacekeeping role is so vague and improvisatory that the characteristics of the incumbent matter enormously. And Hammarskjold's successors have not measured up. As Rosemary Righter, the British author of a history of the U.N. called "Utopia Lost," tartly puts it: "U Thant was invisible; Waldheim was a liar; Perez de Cuellar was a man of whom Vernon Walters once said, 'He couldn't make waves if he fell out of a boat,' and Boutros-Ghali was completely impatient with the job." Boutros-Ghali became the first Secretary General to be denied a second term when the Clinton Administration vowed in 1996 to veto his candidacy. It was a display of sheer muscle on America's part. Boutros-Ghali, after a promising start, had shown little appetite for reducing the U.N.'s legendary bureaucracy, and he could never quite put a lid on his anticolonial rhetoric, famously accusing the West of being preoccupied with "a rich man's war" in Bosnia rather than with the genocide in Rwanda. He may not have recognized the passing of an era when the West, and particularly the Americans, were willing to tolerate the rhetoric of the third world.
At the time Boutros-Ghali's fate was being settled, Kofi Annan was serving as a special U.N. representative in the former Yugoslavia. Annan, who is from Ghana, had started at the U.N. 30 years earlier as a P1, the lowest professional designation. He first ran the personnel department, then the budget department before serving as comptroller, and he distinguished himself in every job for his efficiency, his exquisite tact and his slightly mysterious powers of persuasion. If any single person embodied the institution, it was he. Jean-Pierre Halbwachs, who has worked with Annan off and on for 20 years and now serves as the U.N.'s comptroller, says, "He has this uncanny ability to get people to shift their position without feeling threatened or without any tension." He is, in this and many other regards, the living opposite of Boutros-Ghali. In fact, it was widely believed inside the U.N. that Boutros-Ghali had sent Annan to Yugoslavia in 1995 in the hope of removing a potential competitor as he sought renomination. He wound up giving his rival a new stage. The NATO countries, and especially the Americans, were impressed by how coolly and efficiently Annan handled the transition from U.N. to NATO troops. As one American involved in the Bosnia issue told me, "The discussions were just more sensible when he was involved than with some others."
At the same time, a question hung over Annan: Was he too nice a guy? As one veteran diplomat from an American ally says: "Kofi is conflict-averse in all his personal relationships and perhaps more broadly. There's a danger of allowing things to slide because they may involve conflict." Annan's association with one of the greatest debacles in the history of the United Nations inevitably raises the question of his toughness. He spent much of the period from 1992 to 1996 working on Bosnia, first as deputy for peacekeeping, then as head of peacekeeping, then as Boutros-Ghali's special representative. Sir Marrack Goulding, who was the head of peacekeeping when Annan served as deputy, says that Annan didn't express his doubts about policy "nearly as vociferously" as he himself did, since "it wouldn't come naturally to him to express strongly dissenting views about what the Security Council wanted to do." But Annan says that whenever he met with the representatives of the countries that contributed soldiers to the U.N. peacekeeping force, he pressed them to rethink the troops' limited mandate. As for the ruinous "safe havens" policy, which he was forced to administer, Annan said that the U.N. had asked for 34,000 troops and got 7,600. In any case, he says, "Screaming and getting bitter and being angry is negative energy, and takes a lot out of you, and doesn't help any."
Annan became Secretary General in January 1997, when he was 58. He was chosen because he was, like the spurned Boutros-Ghali, an African; because the Americans, and specifically Madeleine K. Albright, who was then the United States representative to the U.N., wanted him and because practically everyone else liked and respected him. And it didn't hurt that he seemed like the kind of inoffensive figure who would be more secretary than general.
An obvious way of stating the central predicament that Annan faced in his role as Secretary General is that he stood for multilateral solutions in a world dominated by one country with a strong unilateralist bent. But it was more complicated than that. Both Perez de Cuellar and Boutros-Ghali served in the era of American hegemony, but they benefited from the interval of comity that came with the sudden demise of Communism. As Fareed Zakaria, the managing editor of Foreign Affairs magazine, says: "There were two golden ages of the U.N. -- right after the end of World War II and right at the end of the cold war. What you had in both cases was a great power consensus in the shadow of victory. In both cases, the U.S. foreign policy was ratified out of fear and awe. That consensus frayed very rapidly after World War II owing to the emergence of a single rival. It's fraying in a much more haphazard and jerky way now, as you have three or four rival power centers emerging."
Annan's problem was to accommodate American demands for U.N. reform and the American ambition to serve as the world's policeman without losing everyone else. And it was this delicate position that made the Iraqi crisis an exercise in multidimensional diplomacy. From the outset, it was plain that only the Americans were enthusiastic about a bombing campaign; the British supported the use of force loyally but uneasily, while France, Russia and China -- the other permanent members of the Security Council -- were strongly opposed.
I first talked with Annan in mid-February, two days after he had convened a meeting of the representatives of the permanent five in the conference room adjacent to his office. "I think what is important," he said, "is that the permanent five are talking among themselves. Until Wednesday, they were talking past each other." Annan is so soft-spoken that though we were sitting next to each other on a couch in his wood-paneled office, I later found that I could barely hear his voice on my tape recorder. He has an elegance that comes less from dress than from equipoise; he barely moves when he speaks, and he never hurries either a gesture or a word. Very few people have ever seen Annan lose his temper, and I found him virtually unprovokable. When I said that I heard that the U.S. representative to the U.N., Bill Richardson, had been very skeptical about the prospects of a peace initiative, Annan said, "That was the first meeting." Annan pronounced the word "meetin' "; he has a soft and slowly unfurling way with English that almost sounds more Caribbean than African. "When you start these things," he added, "you don't expect miracles and a rapid result."
It appeared, at this point, that the Clinton Administration still wanted war. At the same time, one Administration official told me, there was a real fear that a war Washington prosecuted virtually on its own could destroy the coalition that had supported sanctions, which was the core of U.S. policy to contain Iraq. As it became clear how little support there was for bombing -- even in this country -- Annan's diplomatic initiative began to look like a way off the limb the Administration had climbed onto, which is precisely the service that a Secretary General alone can perform. But Annan had also, in a subtle way, forced the Americans' hand. The Administration official said that "there was a strong chance Kofi would go anyway" -- even if the Americans asked him not to. "So we concluded that the wisest course was to shape the trip to serve the purposes of our policy." Annan confirmed for me that he would have gone even if the Americans opposed. "I had a constitutional duty to avert this kind of tragedy if I can," he said, in an echo of Hammarskjold's Peking Formula. When I asked him if it was an accident that he had created a dynamic that the Clinton Administration found irresistible, he laughed and said, "To some extent, no, it wasn't."
Still, by mid-February, with U.S. forces massing in the Gulf, the process had not yet produced a solution that Annan could bring to Baghdad. The sticking point involved the weapons inspectors in Iraq from the U.N. Special Commission, known as Unscom. The French had proposed that the Secretary General choose a separate team of inspectors for the presidential sites and that they be accompanied by foreign diplomats stationed in Baghdad. But both the Americans and the British had vowed to reject any proposal that compromised the integrity of Unscom. After a third meeting of the permanent five on Feb.16, Annan met in his office with his staff. He sat behind his desk with his arms crossed and mostly listened. The British and the Americans were still holding out, and Iqbal Riza, the chief of staff, suggested that Annan put forward proposals from the draft they themselves had devised. Annan said: "I don't think so. It would muddy the waters at this point. We need to have a good night's sleep and see what comes out of the capitals. At this time, the elements are not in our hands." Someone asked what would happen if the Americans didn't budge. Annan said, "Then we have 'Mission Impossible.' " There was a nervous laugh, and everyone repeated the phrase "Mission Impossible."
And then, the following afternoon, the logjam broke. An American diplomat now says that the Administration concluded that it could live with the idea of a team appointed by the Secretary General, so long as it was not seen as undermining Richard Butler, the chairman of Unscom. The Americans had also wanted Annan to leave with written instructions -- and Annan had vowed to go to Baghdad with unified backing -- but it proved impossible to produce a document that the Russians, Iraq's strongest supporter among the five, could sign. Instead, he received what Britain's U.N. representative John Weston called agreed advice. This was not altogether bad; Annan did not have a "mandate," but neither did he fly to Baghdad merely as a messenger. Saddam Hussein could see Annan as an independent actor; he could comply with Annan's terms without appearing to knuckle under to the Americans. Annan had managed, somehow, to come out from under the American shadow without losing the appearance of collective will that he needed to force Saddam's hand. And he had emerged with just enough flexibility to afford the Iraqis a face-saving solution.
On his way to Iraq, Annan told reporters, "I have all that is necessary to negotiate." This was greeted with widespread skepticism. One diplomat was quoted as giving Annan's mission a 20 percent chance of success. It appeared that the Americans still wanted to bomb, and perhaps Saddam, for his own reasons, preferred to be bombed. Annan, however, has an almost mystical faith in positive outcomes. Elisabeth Lindenmayer recalls flying with him to Baghdad in 1990, on the eve of the gulf war, to negotiate the release of foreigners held hostage. "I said to him in the plane: 'What if it doesn't work? What kind of contingency planning can we do?' And I remember him saying: 'Don't ever speak to me negatively when I'm about to negotiate. We'll make it -- and I don't want to hear that we may not make it.' " This is, Lindenmayer points out, a highly useful motivational strategy: "It's a bit like parents who say to a child, 'I know you can do it.' "
It is also, of course, a matter of temperament. Annan is a modern and thoroughly worldly man with an essentially archaic personality. He is descended from tribal chiefs on both sides of his family; three years ago, tribal elders asked if he would be willing to be considered for the position of Paramount Chief of the Akwamu region. (He politely declined.) Annan's father, though not a chief, was a hereditary noble who served as commissioner of the Ashanti region. Annan describes his father as forceful but reserved. He was an educated man who worked for a subsidiary of Unilever, and, Annan says, "My family moved in and out all the time from a traditional to a modern urban setting." Annan grew up, as he says, "atribal in a tribal world." When I asked him how his character was shaped by this world, he said, "I've always tried to lead a simple life, which in fact gives you more freedom and room to maneuver in adjusting to any setting in which you find yourself."
As a child, Annan was sent to Ghana's leading boarding school, and he later enrolled in the College of Science and Technology at Kumasi, a provincial capital. He wasn't active in Ghana's independence struggle; he wasn't even a member of a political party. He was a bright young man who would help lead Ghana into the modern world. At 20, he won a Ford Foundation scholarship that allowed him to complete his college education at Macalester College in St. Paul, an internationally minded school that, Annan recalls, flew the U.N. flag at all times. Annan was very happy there. Though he recalls one frightening incident, in which he narrowly escaped being assaulted for walking with a white girl, he also recalls that the Mayor of Minneapolis sent him a personal apology on official stationery. Annan always speaks fondly of America, though it is true that he speaks fondly of practically everything.
As a young man, he assumed that he would return to Ghana, but he says that a job he had been offered at a Pillsbury flour mill there fell through at the last moment; he may have also felt unwelcome in Ghana's increasingly undemocratic atmosphere. Instead, he took a job at the United Nations and moved to New York. In 1972 he got a degree in management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Annan has worked in Geneva, Addis Ababa and Cairo, but he has always returned to New York. He has two children, who are now in their 20's, from his first marriage to a Nigerian. In 1985 he married Nane Lagergren, a tall, beautiful Swede who, by some sort of cosmic configuration, is the niece of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat famous for saving thousands of European Jews. Friends describe them as an almost magically harmonious couple.
Unlike Hammarskjold, or Boutros-Ghali, Annan is not an intellectually formidable figure; his tact often keeps him from saying anything even remotely interesting. Annan is not, in any case, an abstract thinker. Iqbal Riza, his chief of staff, says that the Secretary General "goes more on instinct and intuition than on calculation." His gifts are the gifts of character -- attentiveness, self-possession, clarity, an utter lack of pretense and a kindness that seems to spring from an impulse of protectiveness. One reporter I met in Baghdad told me of being pushed around by an Iraqi security agent and how, when Annan saw this happening, he detached himself from a knot of diplomats and gently touched the man's shoulder to get him to stop, which he did.
Annan comes from a world in which self-restraint is a fundamental attribute of strength. In ours, of course, it tends to register as a lack of gumption. He told me he was "amused" to be asked over and over if he was tough enough to face down Saddam Hussein.
Annan landed at the Saddam Hussein International Airport just outside of Baghdad at 6:30 on the evening of Feb. 20. A violent orange sun was just setting over the Tarmac, which was utterly empty and split here and there by weeds. He was met by Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, in military uniform -- not an encouraging sign of the Iraqi posture. Annan and Aziz each made brief remarks to the media and then were driven to the villa that had been assigned to the Secretary General, a big whitewashed structure with plaster chipping off the veranda. Over the next several days I would pass a good many hours in the villa's foyer, which was filled with such marvelous bits of racy European kitsch as a three-paneled painted mirror featuring a Regency dandy with a curled wig and a glass of punch. Four Iraqis from the protocol department squeezed together on one of the couches, chatting and drinking sweet tea.
When the negotiations began the following day at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Aziz and Annan were supposed to meet for half an hour and then join their staffs. Instead, they met for an hour and 20 minutes, occasionally calling in their legal counsels to mark up the draft agreement that Annan had brought with him. After months of intermittent conversations, both understood quite clearly where the limits of the possible lay, and they were able to clear lesser issues out of the way. The Iraqis had restated their position on the presidential sites, which Shashi Tharoor, one of Annan's closest aides, characterized as, " 'Come in, look at them, satisfy yourself thoroughly, see what they are and leave us in peace.' " This was a formulation that Annan couldn't accept. The "agreed advice" he'd been sent off with plainly stated that there could be no time limits placed on the inspections. Tharoor also said that he still had no idea where or when the Secretary General would meet with Saddam Hussein.
I spoke to Annan that afternoon in the large, scruffy garden behind the villa. He turned his chair to face straight into the sun; he has a phototropism that seems to amount to a form of homesickness. (When he lived in Geneva, Annan says, he used to light a fire every day to simulate sunshine.) Annan asked how the journalists were doing; he wanted to know if our hotel was all right. Given the immense pressure he was under, he seemed almost eerily calm. I was reminded of Tharoor's description of him as "a yogi." Annan had clearly made a leap of identification that morning with Iraqi sensitivities over the inspection of the presidential sites, which they had presented as a matter of not only national security but national dignity as well. "Talk to some of your Arab friends," he said to me, "ask them to talk about dignity. It's like Chinese losing face -- it's that important. It's not a joke. The sense of humiliation or losing your dignity or losing face -- they would die or go to war over that." Annan might have added, but of course did not, that he himself came from a culture in which dignity was paramount.
I asked about the pressure he was feeling from the Clinton Administration. Before he left for Baghdad he had spoken with both President Clinton and Secretary of State Albright. Clinton was reported to have told Annan not to "jam" him. Annan, however, denied that Clinton had admonished him and said that the White House had promised to correct that impression. (It never did.) With Albright, he conceded, "the tone was different." She had admonished him not to be taken in by Iraqi lies. Some in Annan's camp considered Albright the leader of the war party. "Is it unfortunate that she called Saddam the most evil man since Hitler?" I asked.
"Who?"
"Albright." Annan's eyebrows shot up, and he said, "Well," and then he thought better of saying anything at all, and he started to laugh. Annan often wound up staring warily at my tape recorder when I asked him about Albright. Annan is deeply grateful to her for the central role she played in his nomination, and in any case he would never breathe a syllable of derogation about her. But for a man so exquisitely attuned to matters of personal dignity, Albright's relentless questioning must have been grating. "Her style is a bit demanding," says an official close to Annan, "and he's at the receiving end of those demands." And an American official close to Albright says that she was worried that the Secretary General would give in to his yielding nature; she saw her job as yanking him back.
The negotiations that began Saturday morning lasted until 2 A.M. At that time, Shashi Tharoor considered the chances of success about 51-49; Nizar Hamdoon, Iraq's U.N. representative, says that he would have laid similar odds. Both sides had known from the beginning that only President Hussein could reverse the Iraqis' insistence on limited, once-and-for-all inspections of the presidential sites. That night, Tariq Aziz finally let it drop that Saddam Hussein would see Annan the following day. There was a brief meeting at the Foreign Ministry that Sunday morning, and then Annan's team returned to the villa to wait for President Hussein's motorcade. Annan's spokesman, Fred Eckhard, asked him about arrangements with the media, and Annan snapped, "You guys just don't understand" -- the only time throughout the long weekend that a wavelet disrupted his smooth surface.
Soon after reaching the Presidential Palace, Annan suggested to Saddam that they meet without their aides. "The Secretary General was extremely wise to have requested to see him alone," says Lakhdar Brahimi, a former Algerian Foreign Minister who was serving as Annan's personal envoy in Iraq and who has known Saddam since 1973. "If you told Saddam Hussein, in front of other people, 'Unless you do this, a strike is inevitable,' he's the kind of man who would say: 'I can't give in to threats. So be it, and goodbye.' But in private you can tell him about it."
Saddam may have felt that he could make concessions to an African that he could not bring himself to make to a Westerner. Annan says that Saddam's manner was "very correct, very calm, almost serene." Perhaps Saddam had already accepted the principle of open-ended inspections of the presidential sites before they even sat down. The Russians had already told Hussein that even they would not support him if he insisted on time limits. But he made it clear, as Aziz had before, that he was making concessions out of a feeling of personal trust for Annan. In the coming months, as the Iraqis look to Annan to make the case for ending sanctions in exchange for compliance, this trust may create a burden of expectations that Annan will not be able to satisfy.
The following morning, I showed up at the villa at 8, and Annan agreed to meet with me briefly. He had been up late telephoning heads of state and foreign ministers to brief them on the Memorandum of Understanding. At 2:30, while he was trying to get a little sleep, Albright had called and insisted he be woken up. Most of the leaders he spoke with were euphoric, Annan told me; Albright was not. He didn't get much sleep after that.
I was ushered into an elegant sitting room, where I found Annan sitting bolt upright on the edge of an Empire couch, as if in rigid defiance of his obvious exhaustion. When I asked how he felt about the negotiations, his face lighted up with a combination of bewilderment and delight. "It's really quite something," he said. "The concentration and attention, the creativity that you need to move people along and to convince them." Annan's diplomacy of self-abnegation required a draining sensitivity to the moods and psychic needs of others. As Hammarskjold once wrote, "The others' 'face' is more important than your own."
Sitting with his hands in his lap, as elegant and immobile as always, he went on to say: "What comes out of this, in my sense, is, We say Iraq is isolated from the international community, but the international community is also isolated. We want them to comply, but I'm not sure we make the effort to understand what is going on. I believe that we have demonized Iraq, and maybe with some justification. But to not go beyond that.. . ." Annan wanted the world, and especially the Americans, to engage Iraq as he had.
That morning, Annan also had a meeting with the Iraqi Vice President, Taha Yassin Ramadan, to discuss the U.N.'s oil-for-food program. The program permits Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil; the U.N. uses the proceeds to buy food and medical supplies. Recognizing the catastrophic effect of the sanctions, and looking perhaps for a carrot to offer in exchange for compliance on the inspections issue, the U.N. Security Council had recently voted to permit Iraq to pump $5.2 billion worth of oil over the next six months, up from $2 billion. But the Iraqis had complained that their oil industry was too crippled to pump all that oil and had asked to meet with Annan to renegotiate the deal. I was able to slip into this meeting with the Secretary General's delegation. Ramadan cracked a few jokes about the international media, and the Ministers of Oil, Trade and Foreign Affairs laughed heartily. Ramadan lectured the Secretary General on the terms of the new oil-for-food regime. The Ministers for Oil, Trade and Foreign Affairs corrected the translator every minute or so. The Secretary General flexed his fingertips and said nothing.
Then it was Annan's turn, and he said: "I was so surprised and even frankly disappointed at the note which came after approval of the $5.2 billion. . . .After the discussions that we had gone through, I would have expected at least a little thank-you for those people here who worked hard and helped make it happen." He told Ramadan, "You should try to moderate your language." He was lecturing the Iraqis on manners! It was a bracing spectacle, and Ramadan took it in perfect, and possibly stunned, silence. Fred Eckhard said afterward that he had never heard his boss talk that way. Some of the people around Annan believe that he "revealed himself" in Baghdad -- that he had begun to act more like a general than a secretary.
It is now widely agreed that Annan made one blunder in the long course of his diplomatic demarche: in his initial press conference on his return to New York from Baghdad, he said, "I think I can do business with" Saddam. It was this comment that moved Trent Lott to denounce not only Annan but also President Clinton, who Lott said had "subcontracted" American foreign policy to the forces of appeasement. Annan says he was only stating a fact -- he just had done business with Saddam. But the reaction proved how pointless it would be for the Secretary General to try to convince America that it is as isolated from Iraq as Iraq is from it.
Annan's triumph would be a personal one, not a vindication of multilateralism and the principle of diplomatic engagement. An Administration official asked him to knock off the Saddam-is-human line, and he agreed.
But Annan never really became radioactive; it was simply too obvious that the agreement he had signed included everything the Americans had asked for and nothing they had feared. An Administration official says that Annan supplied explanations of the agreement, including reassurances that Richard Butler, the chairman of Unscom, would not have his role compromised by the inclusion of "diplomatic escorts" on inspection teams at the presidential sites, nor by the Secretary General's new role in appointing members to those teams.
Butler's own reaction to the agreement was pivotal. He had been privately skeptical of the added diplomatic contingent, and he could have easily torpedoed the plan. But Annan met with him immediately after returning to New York and assured him that his role had not been diminished. He also asked Butler to appear on several of the Sunday television talk shows to which Annan himself had been invited. I asked Butler if he took this invitation as a public gesture of confidence, and he said, "I took it as such, and he meant it at such." Butler went on to lavish praise on Annan. "He brought home the bacon," he said. No less important, the Iraqis behaved according to the letter of the agreement in the first tests of the new procedures.
Bill Richardson credits the agreement to "Annan's personal diplomacy coupled with a formula that only he, through his stature, could sell to the Iraqis." By the time Annan went to Washington, he was a man to be embraced rather than shunned. President Clinton said that he "deserves the thanks" of the American people. Clinton also said, "If we expect to play a leadership role, we have to pay our U.N. dues."
Annan shed peace and gentility all over town. When he emerged from a conference room to greet Senator Jesse Helms, he was followed by a knot of reporters and staff members, and he said, "Don't worry -- we're a large force, but we're a friendly force." On Iraq, Helms told him, "Given what you had to work with, you did a very good job" -- a staggering concession, given Helms's usual views. Annan has plainly made inroads with the crusty chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee: He paid Helms a visit soon after being named Secretary General, and Helms ultimately co-sponsored legislation that would have repaid much of the U.S. debt to the U.N., albeit with a series of crippling conditions (including a proviso that the General Accounting Office would be allowed to examine the U.N.'s books).
Still, Helms is scarcely a convert to multilateralism. When the two men emerged from their meeting, a reporter asked the Senator if the U.S. owed the U.N. a debt of gratitude, and Helms shot back, "The question is, Does the U.N. owe the United States and American taxpayers a debt of gratitude?"
Still, Annan and his staff were ebullient. The President had said that he was committed to getting the arrears paid. Not only Iraq, but even U.N. reform, which had been used in the past to justify withholding funds, was a nonissue. After a long day courting Administration figures and senators, Annan returned to his hotel and said: "A lot has happened between last year and now. As I mentioned to Senator Helms, when we met last year, I said that the U.N. needed reform and needed to be more efficient. At that point, it was promises. Now we've done quite a lot of the things we said we would do." Annan had cut a thousand jobs from the bureaucracy, appointed highly respected officials to top posts, created a cabinet to replace the system in which autonomous officials reported only to the Secretary General. He had, as he said, delivered.
If this had been a popularity contest, Annan would have won. But of course it wasn't. Last year, a group of conservatives led by Representative Chris Smith of New Jersey had insisted that legislation authorizing back payments to the U.N. be accompanied by language prohibiting financing of groups that lobby foreign governments to liberalize abortion law. President Clinton had vowed to veto any bill containing the abortion language, thus killing the whole package. The same thing appears to be happening now. (As of last week, a bill was scheduled to go to conference.) Annan's political advisers were hoping that if the legislation died or was vetoed, Speaker Newt Gingrich would step in and reintroduce the repayments legislation on its own. Gingrich is clearly trying to establish his credentials as an internationalist, but when I mentioned this scenario to a Congressional staff member who has been deeply involved with the issue, he said, "I wouldn't bet the mortgage on it." Representative Smith would oppose such a bill, and he would very likely carry the House. "Whatever the Speaker wishes," he said, "there's no way out." Article 19 of the U.N. charter stipulates that any member who falls more than two years behind in dues loses its vote in the General Assembly. Absent Congressional action, the U.S. will fall afoul of the rule by next January.
It's tempting to blame the whole mess on American politics, as some people in the U.N. do. But this is to forget the larger ideological atmosphere within which the U.N. operates. It's unreasonable to expect any nation with the dominant position America now enjoys to embrace the U.N.'s multilateral principles. But American moralism and exceptionalism only make it harder to accept the self-restraint that comes with collective decision making. As Secretary of State Albright said recently: "We are the indispensable nation. We stand tall. We see further into the future." Why should such a nation permit its vision to be cramped by diplomacy? Why should it stand by while the U.N. satisfies a tyrant's craving for dignity? Senator Lott wasn't the only conservative outraged by Annan's role. When I asked John Bolton, an Assistant Secretary of State in the Bush Administration, about Annan's role, he drew a distinction between the good multilateralism of the gulf war, when the U.S. rallied the U.N. to its position, and the bad multilateralism of today, when the Administration acts as if the U.N. "has a life or existence outside of what the U.S. wants it to do." Bolton would have had the U.S. send Annan to Iraq to deliver an ultimatum, as Perez de Cuellar did in 1991. (Hussein humiliated the Secretary General by keeping him waiting outside his office for hours.) Now, he says, "you can't put the Secretary General back in the closet when it's inconvenient."
Unilateralism is the anti-U.N. position of the conservative foreign-policy elite. At ground level, what's more common is the isolationism of a continental nation. Roscoe Bartlett, a Republican Congressman and one of 13 signatories of a bill proposing to end American membership in the U.N., says that many of his constituents oppose U.N. membership. "They think that our participation in the U.N. is infringing on our sovereignty, infringing on our personal property rights," he said. "They are appalled when they enter one of our national parks and see a sign that says, 'You are entering a U.N. Biosphere Preserve' " -- a reference to a Unesco program. "There are people who genuinely believe that our interests are best served if we become weaker and weaker," Bartlett added, "and the U.N. becomes stronger and stronger, so they ultimately have a bigger army than we do so they can keep the world peace. These people are called globalists, new-world-order, one-world-government people. Our President is a globalist."
Annan had invited me to lunch in his private dining room a few days before his trip to Washington. We ate salad with gravlax and rib lamb chops -- first white wine, then red -- and we were served by a waiter in black tie. Annan was, as always, genuinely warm and utterly unrevealing. Only when I told him about my conversations with Bolton and Bartlett did he show sparks. "I don't know what else they expect," he said. "We have gone through reforms, and then I go to Baghdad and try to defuse the crisis, which is what the U.N. is about. . . .That becomes another reason for not paying. I know Americans, because I've lived here. Americans don't like to be deadbeats. I feel frustrated and saddened, because this is not the America I know. Americans are a generous people, and they like to keep their commitments." He quoted an official of the European Union as saying what Annan himself would never say directly: " 'The way the U.S. is behaving on this issue is destroying trust among nations.' " He was waving a bony index finger at me. It was the closest thing to a sustained outburst I ever heard from him.
What Annan is trying to point to, within the limits of his politesse, is the insincerity of the American, or at least the Republican, position. Annan has, as he puts it, delivered. He has made meaningful headway on reform, though he does have a long way to go. He did not sell out America in Baghdad. He called his critics' bluff, and it turns out to have been, in the end, a bluff. The real point is that for virtually any American politician, the U.N. is utterly expendable. No one will ever lose any votes by bashing the U.N.
It is no longer easy to say what it means to be a great Secretary General, as it might have been 30 or 40 years ago. The great powers, and specifically the United States, would not tolerate another Hammarskjold even if one arose. And the quagmire of Bosnia has offered unforgettable proof of the limits of U.N. peacekeeping efforts in the absence of great-power commitment. What the U.N. needs now, in any case, is not heroism but purpose. Last year, Razali Ismail, a Malaysian diplomat and a former president of the General Assembly, spoke of the danger of "creeping irrelevance." What he meant was that as states define their interest increasingly in economic rather than political terms, institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank come to the fore and the U.N. recedes.
Kofi Annan does not, of course, buy this line of analysis. "My sense is that we need the U.N. today perhaps more than ever," he says. "And despite the perception that the U.N. is under siege, I think the world is going to realize how much we need this organization as we move toward the millennium. We need to insure that we have the norms to regulate relations among states, and we need to take on the whole range of issues that no country, no matter how powerful -- even the U.S. -- can deal with by itself, whether it's the environment, drugs, terrorism, health or sustainable development."
Yet right now, the U.N. plays a secondary role even in most of these matters. Annan has to make the case for the U.N.; he almost has to embody the case for the U.N. This will not be easy for him. Self-advertisement is contrary to his nature, as is melodrama. He is a rather wooden and platitudinous public speaker. I recently heard him give a brief speech in which he used the phrase "joking aside." Only then did I realize that he considered his previous line a joke.
One often hears the idea that Annan must not only embody but transcend the U.N. if he is to rescue the organization from its own marginality. Mark Malloch Brown, a World Bank official who has known Annan since the early 1980's and recently served as chairman of an advisory group for him, says of the Secretary General: "Here's a guy who has been a creature of the U.N. for 30 years, and yet all his life he's been a little bit bigger and greater than those around him. And now you see him flashing in and out of being limited by the U.N."
Not long ago, Malloch Brown says, he warned his friend about the dangers of becoming "a first-year U Thant" -- a kindly, respected figure who allows himself to be confined by "the diplomatic salons on the East River." Iraq, says Malloch Brown, "is the first major step out of the box." But the mission to Iraq, and the colossal diligence and patience and tact it required, may come more naturally to Annan than the mission to the United States he now must undertake. Hammarskjold had it easy by comparison.

LENGTH: 1160 words

HEADLINE: The da Vinci of Data

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SHAPLEY 

 BODY:
It is well past noon and the 286 Manhattan office workers have been kept in their chairs all morning with another four hours to go. Still, they're hooting in guilty laughter as they stare at the confident emcee, who is striding around in front of a large pair of screens.
A blank blue rectangle appears on each screen behind him. "Here it is," announces Edward R. Tufte, the author of three books on information design. "The lowest resolution information interface known to humankind. The dreaded overhead projector." His audience laughs. 
 Now Mr. Tufte reads, sonorously, the four words that have appeared in white type. "Action Plan. Part A." More laughter.
Then Mr. Tufte turns angry, saying that such displays are no better than striptease. "They don't tell the audience anything," he says, adding that presenting information this way is "denying, censoring, masking information, not telling what's really going on."
Thus runs the well-honed sermon of one of the information age's admired prophets, a man who succeeds at proselytizing, winning converts and turning a profit in the process.
Mr. Tufte, who has made his name first in the world of statistics and then in the world of graphic design, has become a one-man industry. In an age when information is a commodity, he is on a quest to recast it as something unique. The quest, thus far, has grossed about $25 million.
In March, while on spring break from Yale University, where he is a professor of political science, Mr. Tufte (pronounced TUFF-tee) packed from 300 to 500 listeners at each of four all-day seminars. Each paid $300 to attend. Mr. Tufte has given 25 to 30 such seminars a year since 1993, grossing an estimated $9 million.
A take of about $390,000 for four days of work might seem enough. But the sessions have an additional benefit. His clients, who receive free copies of his books, sometimes end up serving as surrogate salesmen for the works of Mr. Tufte's Graphics Press, a homegrown imprint he operates from the garage of his home in Cheshire, Conn., and from a warehouse.
He published the first book, "The Visual Display of Quantitative Information," in 1983, after withdrawing it from Harvard University Press, because, he said, it would not let him participate in the design. He took seven years to prepare the second, "Envisioning Information," published in 1990, and another seven years for the third, "Visual Explanations," published last year.
The 1997 and 1983 books were No. 7 and No. 8 on the 1997 best-seller list for the on-line bookseller Amazon.com. His 1990 book was No. 36. The three have sold 505,000 copies, he said, including 100,000 copies of the newest book. They retail for $40, $48 and and $45 respectively, putting his gross take at $16 million -- a figure he does not dispute.
This for a man who 15 years ago was best known for four titles on political economy, who did some election-year statistical consulting for organizations like The New York Times and who had to take out a second mortgage on his house to publish "Visual Display."
The question is why, in the late 1990's, are these oversized, pricey books on data art, one of which is 15 years old, selling like hot cakes? The answer is that his skills seem uniquely suited to the moment: he knows how to turn seas of information into navigable -- even scenic -- waterways.
The answer he himself gives shows an ego as multidimensional as any of his graphics. The books sell, Mr. Tufte said, "because they are such beautiful books." What he seeks to do is produce collectors' items: a map of Swiss mountains in the second volume had to pass though the printer's press 23 times before Mr. Tufte was satisfied.
But analysts in the publishing industry say Mr. Tufte has followed the path of other successful self-publishers. Vanity presses and small publishers have generated more and more sales while the top publishing houses' share of the market has shrunk. The number of self-published books has tripled over the last 10 years, said John Kremer, the editor of Book Marketing Update.
To sell his first book back in 1983, Mr. Tufte designed an advertisement and published it in Scientific American. Within days, his post office box in Cheshire was jammed with orders, giving him enough income to put covers on the first print run of 5,000.
His second book, "Envisioning Information," cost $700,000 to design and produce, he said. The take from its sales could be $5 million.
The books are successful, Mr. Kremer said, because "Tufte has titles he is passionate about.
"He's going to a target market he knows will be passionate about the same subject," he said.
Bonnie Scranton, graphics director for Newsweek magazine, who worked for Mr. Tufte for three years, said: "With the invention of desktop publishing, and more access to data banks that people couldn't access before, more people are using visual solutions. There's an information explosion. So he appeals to people who are scientists, or lawyers, people in all sorts of professions who never had to do design before."
The crowd that heard Mr. Tufte in the Marriott Grand Ballroom this month was testimony to this new aspect of American work. Mark Hicks took a co-worker from the New York Stock Exchange because they use screen displays to monitor the placement of orders from the trading floor.
There were also two neuroscientists from New York University, an airline executive, and a vice president at J. P. Morgan.
Audiences become silent as Mr. Tufte leads them through the part of his new book that reproduces the faxes Morton Thiokol engineers sent to NASA on the eve of the 1986 launch of the space shuttle Challenger. If the engineers had shown the correlation between low air temperature and damage to rocket O-ring seals in past launches in a single chart, NASA might have agreed not to launch the shuttle in what the space agency knew would be record cold weather, Mr. Tufte contends.
Mr. Tufte also rails about most World Wide Web sites. His main complaint: that computer executives and programmers take away most of the screen space with buttons and banners. Because content is ignored, "the most common activity at Web sites is fleeing the Web site," Mr. Tufte told his New York audience.
Then he opened his new book to a graphic showing bad page design and an information-rich Web page he had designed. One of the sites he recommends because it delivers more information on the early screens is amazon.com -- which happens to feature his books.
After his presentation, Mr. Tufte seemed exhilarated. "Just as I did with publishing, I am expanding my teaching to reach people directly," he said.
There was a rare silence before he answered a question about making so much money. Then he said: "The economic success is a happy byproduct of doing the books and telling people about them. It's fine to be productive economically, but I would do it anyway because I believe in this."

(Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times); Edward Tufte has made millions on seminars and books like "Envisioning Information," "The Visual Display of Quantitative Information" and "Visual Explanations." (Angel Franco/The New York Times)
