SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1679 words

HEADLINE: For $19.95, Slate Sees Who Its Friends Are

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
It is a clear, shining day in Washington, a world away from the Seattle rain. The budding cherry blossoms hint at spring. And Michael Kinsley, the editor and creator of Microsoft's on-line magazine Slate, is pacing the bare parquet floors of a one-bedroom apartment, considering whether to rent it.
Mr. Kinsley has been feeling out of touch with the buzz of the Beltway these days and, perhaps to reconnect, he has agreed to occasionally return to his chair on CNN's "Crossfire," where he became a celebrity liberal for butting heads with the conservative Pat Buchanan. 
 An apartment rental? Crossfire redux? Is Michael Kinsley getting cold feet? Has the uncharted boundlessness of cyberspace left him pining for the knowable confines of the capital?
On the contrary, Mr. Kinsley, 47, insists. He has become a zealous convert to the Pacific Northwest -- Slate is based in Redmond, Wash. He bought land. He carries one of those wallets that closes with Velcro.
He recycles. He has even taken up snowshoeing.
Nevertheless, Mr. Kinsley could be forgiven for feeling a little skittish at the moment. Earlier this month, the gate came down on free visitors to Slate; now people who want to read the magazine have to pay for it.
It is not a lot of money in the scheme of things: $19.95 for a year's subscription and the magazine still offers a free "front porch," its home page.
But paying anything at all is radical stuff for the Internet, and the venture is being watched closely as a test of the potential profitability of the Internet.
"The going price on the Internet now is free, and to charge anything more than that you have to have a project that is very unique," said Bill Bass, an analyst at Forrester Research Inc., a technology research company in Cambridge, Mass. "A lot of the stuff that's worked well on line has a financial purpose or is a game or pornography. And Slate doesn't fall into any of these categories."
Slate (www.slate.com) is radical in its way -- not just because it is trying to get readers to pay but because it has set out to help define a category that did not exist, a product straddling several worlds. It arguably has the depth and analysis of print, the immediacy of radio and television, the bells and whistles of Web sites. Some articles are carefully conceived, some go out on the Web without editing. Slate calls itself a weekly yet updates its contents daily.
Mr. Kinsley says he is learning as he goes along, about things like how to strike the right tone.
"There is a voice of the Web that's developing -- I've taken some hits for complaining about its insularity and smugness," he said. "But there is also its casualness and informality, and we certainly have evolved over the last year and a half more in that direction and away from traditional magazine pieces."
There are print-oriented people who find Slate too "Webby," cyber-savvy people who find it too mired in old models. "It's still to me very inside the media elite -- it's like they're ricocheting things off each others' computers," said James Wolcott, a media critic who was tough on the magazine in Vanity Fair last year. "One of the things really missing from it, what Salon really has, is a pop sensibility."
In going to paid circulation, Slate is largely out there on its own. While a few publications like The Wall Street Journal and the Economist charge for their on-line versions, general interest publications with Web sites are in a wait-and-see mode. The economics seem attractive -- no paper, printing or postage costs -- but there have already been casualties. Recently, the webzines Word and Charged folded before even trying paid subscriptions.
And over the last few months, the Microsoft Corporation has scaled back its Internet media efforts, including layoffs at Sidewalk, its on-line city guides. As a result, many people in the publishing world are wary of placing their bets on the future of Slate. "If they pull it off, there are going to be a lot of publishers out there dancing in the streets," Mr. Bass said, "because nobody on the content side is running profitably right now."
Mr. Kinsley said navigating such new territory "makes this very interesting but also very hard."
"It's as if you were founding a paper magazine and said, O.K., we chopped down the trees, now what?" he said.
Slate has planned to go paid since its inception in June 1996. Mr. Kinsley backed away once before -- in February 1997. Finally, the moment felt as right as it ever would. "It seemed to me, we'd been putting it out for over a year and it was time to fish or cut bait," Mr. Kinsley said. "It's important to us to break even and to be a business, not someone's charity case."
To Microsoft, the move is not just philosophically important but financially necessary. Advertisers are proceeding with caution when it comes to Slate because the audience numbers remain relatively low.
"It became clear that, on an ad-only basis, it wasn't going to work," said Peter Neupert, Microsoft's vice president of news and publishing. "I didn't see it scaling big enough and the ad marketplace accepting it quick enough to meet our objectives in terms of turning the corner."
Slate and Microsoft said they had already received more than 17,000 subscription orders and hoped to reach 20,000 over the next few months. But that number is a far cry from the 95,000 circulation enjoyed by The New Republic, where Mr. Kinsley worked on and off for almost 20 years. Or the 218,000 currently enjoyed by Harper's, where Mr. Kinsley briefly served as editor in 1981. How much readership Slate has lost since the transition on March 9 is difficult to gauge because of the vagaries of Internet measurement. In January, when the Monica Lewinsky story first broke, the site received 270,000 visits, many from repeat readers.
The current subscriber response gets the magazine to a mere $340,000 in revenue; Slate's annual operating costs have been estimated at $5 million by analysts. The subscriber response is not a number that gets advertisers excited. Slate would not disclose ad revenue figures.
"We're not even talking about critical mass here," Paula Brooks, the media director at the ad agency Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, said. "A magazine with 100,000 circulation is not truly viable."
Slate will now have to spend money to win new readers, just like print publications; it plans to market the magazine with ads on other sites and with targeted E-mail. And given the hurdles ahead, Rogers Weed, Slate's publisher, said he is prepared to ultimately accept defeat.
"It's very possible that the Web is just not the place for publications like Slate that have a more limited appeal," he said.
Slate's writers, many of whom have left mainstream publications for cyberspace, may be less quick to surrender. It has been hard enough to see Slate's audience drop since going paid, however unavoidable.
"This is much more of casting your bread upon the waters," said Jodie T. Allen, Slate's Washington editor, who came to Slate from The Washington Post and covers Congress. "The aides don't know who I am anymore."
While Slate has developed a loyal following among many people in the news media and politics, some say the magazine has yet to develop real influence. "Mike Kinsley could make the earth move with his column in The New Republic," said Stephen G. Smith, the editor of National Journal. "He can't do that with Slate."
To gain more clout, Mr. Kinsley has to figure out how to make the new medium work for the largest possible audience -- i.e., how to get people to read long pieces in a fast-moving medium that you can not easily curl up with on the couch. "That's our biggest problem," Mr. Kinsley said. "You have to reward people. You have to offer them things they can't get on paper to compensate."
That is why Slate offers audio poetry readings along with its featured weekly poem, film clips with some movie reviews. And why, in its printed edition -- which has a circulation in the low hundreds -- Slate often reminds readers what they are missing out on electronically.
Slate has also tried to be more Web-specific, offering "hot links" to let readers click on interesting tangents. In an essay on Gertrude Stein, for example, readers were invited to "Click here for an excerpt from 'Lifting Belly,' a witty unpublished love poem she wrote to Alice B. Toklas."
"In print, these would have to be footnotes," said Judith Shulevitz, Slate's New York editor. "But on the Web, they come off as a secondary level of discourse."
Depending on whom you talk to, Slate's move to paid subscriptions is either brave or foolhardy. "They may make it because they have the deep pocket to wait out the market until it matures," said Stefanie Symon, the co-founder and executive editor of the Web magazine Feed, who also expects to switch to paid subscriptions eventually.
While Microsoft and Slate may have been eager to develop a new revenue stream, both said they expect that bringing Slate into the black will take patience.
"I have made it clear to them that the experience of the magazine world is that it takes seven or eight years," Mr. Kinsley said. As to whether he will stick around until then, he said: "I could well, I could well not. Have I ever done anything for seven or eight years?"
Mr. Kinsley said he began feeling a little bit out out of the loop when the Monica Lewinsky scandal broke. "The average person on the street in Washington can do about eight layers of interpretation on Lewinsky," he said. "So you sort of feel out of it if you can only do five or six. It reinforced the notion that it's important to spend more time here."
For the moment, however, Mr. Kinsley said he likes hiking in the mountains and wearing plaid flannel shirts to the office. And despite continuing speculation about whether he will grow restless, the editor's colleagues say his commitment is passionate. "People do not have any idea how much work he has put into this," Ms. Shulevitz said. "And how hard it would be to walk away."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Kinsley, the editor and creator of Microsoft's on-line magazine Slate, has tried to integrate the strengths of both traditional and electronic journalism. (Therese Frare for The New York Times)(pg. D1)
Chart: "What Kinsley Has Wrought"
With Slate, Michael Kinsley is trying to meld traditional publishing forms with the immediacy and special qualities of the Internet. Here are some of the forms he has created.
 
BRIEFING SECTION
 
TODAY'S PAPERS -- A summary of what is in the day's Washington Post, New York Times and Los Angeles Times, Wall Street Journal, U.S.A. Today, posted in the wee hours of the morning.
 
THE WEEK/THE SPIN -- A look at the week's major news events and how the news is being played. May include "The Starrometer" or "The Clintometer" which track the fortunes of Kenneth Starr or President Clinton.
 
THE GIST -- An intense briefing on some subject in the news, i.e., the tensions in Kosovo, the case against the poet Ted Hughes and Is a lawyer like Robert Bennett allowed to lie for his client?
 
CHATTERBOX -- Slate's gossip column -- mostly about politics and the media -- by Mickey Kaus.
 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT -- Reviews of the reviewers: how the critics come down on movies, theater, books, opera.
 
PUNDIT CENTRAL -- How the TV commentators weighed in on the weekend talk shows like "Meet the Press" and "Inside Washington."
 
SLATE NEWS QUIZ -- A question of the day. ("Click here by noon to e-mail your answers.")
 
RECYCLED -- Slate periodically recycles articles from its archives that are given new life by the news.
 
DISPATCHES AND DIALOGUES
 
Includes unedited messages from people in places far and near as well as published exchanges about various topics like NATO expansion or the Asian bailout.
 
UTILITIES
 
Includes "The Fray," where Slate's readers can communicate with one another. (pg. D7)

HEADLINE: Equal Work, Less-Equal Perks;
Microsoft Leads the Way in Filling Jobs With 'Permatemps'

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash.

 BODY:
They hold high-prestige, high-technology jobs at Microsoft's plush campus. They often do the same work as the Microsoft Corporation's permanent employees, developing CD-ROM's, designing World Wide Web sites and writing software manuals. Yet they do not qualify for Microsoft's coveted stock options, and their health and vacation benefits are pale imitations of those enjoyed by regular Microsoft workers.
They are long-term temps -- a seeming oxymoron, but in fact a new and growing phenomenon in the American work force, embraced by many corporations, especially high-tech ones, including Microsoft, AT&T, Intel, Hewlett-Packard and Microsoft's Seattle neighbor, Boeing. 
 Microsoft is perhaps the leading practitioner of the trend, employing about 5,000 temps, including 1,500 long-term ones, meaning they have worked for the software colossus for at least one year. These temps work next to Microsoft's 17,000 domestic employees.
Some prefer the flexibility and the higher take-home pay that temp status affords, but many assail temping as a backdoor way to create a two-tier work force. The benefits that the lower tier loses out on, many temps say, far outweigh whatever extra pay they take home.
"It's a system of having two classes of people and instilling fear and inferiority and loathing," said Rebecca Hughes, who worked for three years as a temp at Microsoft, helping edit its CD-ROM on health care.
With work lives strung together by three-month contracts, some temps have worked at Microsoft for more than five years and have seized on an awkward term to describe their awkward status: permatemps.
John Schussler has received a half-dozen promotions since going to work as a tester for Microsoft in 1992, looking for bugs in the endless lines of computer code that make up the company's software products. Now a program manager, he oversees the 18 people who run Cinemania and Music Central On-Line, the company's movie information service and 24-hour music store.
But he does not have the one thing he wants most: a permanent Microsoft job and the benefits that go with it. "Why is it that the guy next to me, who does the same work as me, is a permanent employee and can afford to buy a house, and I'm still in an apartment?" he asks.
Microsoft insists that Mr. Schussler's temp agency, Rho Tech, is his employer, although he works on the Microsoft campus, is supervised by Microsoft managers and uses Microsoft equipment. He says he has almost no contact with Rho Tech, which deducts his taxes, sends his paycheck and provides a bare-bones health plan.
In this era of intense competition and change, management theorists have recommended that corporations stick to their core capabilities and maintain core work forces. The corollary is that companies should hire out for noncore activities.
Microsoft's temps may feel their contingent status more keenly than other temps, largely because the software giant's well-known policy of giving stock options to employees has made many of the temps' co-workers millionaires, thanks to Microsoft's soaring stock price.
From the start, Mr. Schussler said in a recent interview, he made clear to management that he wanted a permanent job, known as "headcount" in Microsoft jargon. "Everyone knows headcount at Microsoft is the Holy Grail," he said.
But his managers repeatedly told him that while they were eager to keep him because of his good work, they wanted to fill the limited number of permanent slots allotted them with the scarcest commodity in high tech: programmers.
Sharon L. Decker, director of Microsoft's Contingent Staffing Group, defended the company's use of temps, saying many would rather be temps than permanent employees.
"There's a recognition that this kind of free agent approach is growing -- people want to be able to negotiate their own employment," she said. "These workers like the flexibility. They like the ability to work for six months and then go skiing."
But Ms. Hughes, the editor, said Microsoft used temps principally to skimp on benefits. "If Microsoft cannot afford to treat all its employees well," she said, "then no company in the history of the world could."
 
The Math
Filling Jobs, Saving Money
 In 1986, the number of temps employed each day was 800,000, but, according to the National Association of Temporary and Staffing Services, the number soared to 2.5 million last year or about 2 percent of the work force. At least 200,000 of them are long-term temps.
By some estimates, temps now represent at least 10 percent of the work force at one-fifth of American corporations.
Managers argue that using temps is ideal for the modern market's demands for efficiency and flexibility. Many employees say it dovetails with their desire for independence and for stimulating challenges.
Peg Cheirrett, president of the Wasser Group, which supplies temps to Microsoft, said using temps in a volatile industry was humane because they had no false expectations. "When people know it's a temporary arrangement," she said, "someday when the assignment ends, there's not a sense of a broken trust."
Ms. Decker rejected the idea that the company used temps to save money on benefits. Microsoft, she said, is encouraging temp agencies to provide more generous benefits. But even the improved benefits pale next to Microsoft's.
Ms. Decker also asserted that many temps earned more an hour than regular workers -- an assertion many temps challenge. Temps may earn $18 an hour as testers and $50 an hour as hot-shot programmers.
A technical editor might earn $30 an hour at Microsoft. This means the worker will cost about $70,000 a year -- $60,000 in basic wages and $10,000 in benefits, including Social Security and unemployment taxes and bare-bones health, 401(k) and vacation benefits. If the temp works 200 hours overtime, that could mean $9,000 extra, although workers complain that a new Washington State regulation allows companies to stop paying computer professionals time-and-a-half for overtime.
In comparison, a permanent editor might have a $57,000 salary, but could cost Microsoft $94,000 a year -- $17,000 for a richer benefits package, including vacation, holidays and generous 401(k) contributions, plus discount stock purchase plan and stock options that might be worth $20,000 or more. Salaried employees do not receive overtime pay.
In this way, Microsoft might save $24 million for every 1,000 temps it uses, excluding overtime.
Irene Pasternack, a technical writer at Microsoft, said she preferred temping to a permanent job. "I have two small children at home, and this gives me much more flexibility than a regular worker has," she said. "The other benefit is it's easier to take more time off for vacation."
Under the law, corporations are free to use long-term temps, but these workers are increasingly suing companies, asserting that they deserve the same benefits as regular workers. The temps' claims touch on a murky area: whether their employer is a temp agency or the agency's client, that is, the company where they work. The courts and the Internal Revenue Service are wrestling with these issues; the answer hinges on who controls the worker.
In interviews with more than three dozen long-term temps -- most insisted on anonymity for fear of being dismissed -- many complained that companies relied on temps to loosen their ties to workers. Employers, for instance, do not have to pay severance to laid-off temps.
"It's one more strategy in which companies are seeking to avoid their responsibilities to their workers," said Amy Dean, the A.F.L-C.I.O.'s chief organizer in Silicon Valley.
 
The History
A Ruling Leads To Reclassifying
Microsoft and many other companies embraced the use of long-term temps in the early 1990's, after the I.R.S. told the companies that they had erroneously classified thousands of people who were working full time at company facilities as independent contractors. After the I.R.S. found that these workers were common-law employees, it ordered the companies to pay overdue taxes.
In response, many companies switched these contractors to temp status, often telling them to sign up with a temp agency, which then sent the workers to their old companies and old jobs.
Microsoft is locked in a five-year-old legal battle with hundreds of independent contractors and temps who insist they should be considered regular employees and receive the same benefits as regular employees.
Ms. Decker said 30 percent of Microsoft's temps have worked there for more than a year, and 8 percent for more than two years.
Microsoft officials suggest that the large number of long-term temps is an accident, noting that the company has dozens of nearly autonomous groups, with many using temps who are expected to leave when a group finishes with them. But many temps hop between groups.
John McGowan Jr., a Cleveland lawyer who advises companies on temps, said: "If you're talking about recruiting, on a regular and recurring basis, a whole work force that you're saying are not your employees, you're opening a Pandora's box. If you're doing it as an end run around employment laws, it can come back to haunt you."
 
The Law
Issues: Back Pay, Future Status
 In January, the Supreme Court dealt Microsoft a major setback by refusing to hear its appeal in a lawsuit that raises daunting questions about high-tech America's widespread use of temps.
Stating that Microsoft's contingent workers were regular employees, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco ruled, en banc, last July that Microsoft had wrongly denied millions of dollars in benefits to hundreds of workers who were independent contractors.
The plaintiffs' lawyers assert that the court also ruled that Microsoft owed benefits to thousands of temporary employees, too. But Microsoft is challenging this interpretation.
The stakes are high, because the circuit court has stated that the plaintiffs -- the former independent contractors, and perhaps the temps, too -- are entitled to participate in Microsoft's discount stock purchase plan, which has provided participants with fabulous returns.
Under that plan, regular workers can buy its shares at a discount of 15 percent or more. The plaintiffs argue that if they were treated as regular employees instead of contractors, they each would have bought hundreds of shares when the stock sold for a tenth of today's price. The plaintiffs are seeking an award of hundreds of millions of dollars from Microsoft.
The appeals court also ruled that Microsoft was arbitrary in excluding contingent workers from its 401(k) plan, in which Microsoft provides a 50 percent match, up to 6 percent of an employee's income.
The court rejected Microsoft's argument that the plaintiffs did not deserve benefits because they had signed agreements stating they had no employer-employee relationship with Microsoft and were not due company benefits. The court ruled that since the workers were common-law employees, they should qualify for benefits because the benefit plans said they covered all common-law employees.
Frightened by the implications, companies and industry groups rallied behind Microsoft. "These people are earning more on a per-hour basis than regular employees to help them pay for benefits," said Mark Nebergall, vice president for tax policy at the Software Publishers Association. "They can't complain that they're getting higher salaries and then turn around and say they deserve regular benefits, too."
In arguing that long-term temps are due the same benefits as regular Microsoft workers, the plaintiffs say that temp agencies differ little from payroll services that merely send paychecks and deduct taxes. "A payroll agency is not an employer at all," Stephen K. Strong, the plaintiffs' lawyer, said. "They work on Microsoft's campus. They work full time under Microsoft supervisors. They are producing Microsoft products. If it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's a duck. They are undeniably Microsoft employees."
 
A Temp's-Eye View
Painful for Some, Fine for Others
 In Microsoft's corporate directory, temps have an "A--" before their E-mail addresses to designate them as agency employees. In Microsoft parlance, they are called "A dashes," but many dub themselves "alien dashes" and "dash trash."
During peak periods, many temps have to work 70- and 80-hour weeks. This has caused some temps to complain that Microsoft cavalierly chews them up because it has scant loyalty to them.
"There is such a painful human impact," said Richard Pauli, who spent five years as a temp at Microsoft. "When you know these are temp positions, there's this attitude of really burning people out."
Phil Huston, who recently completed two and a half years as a technical writer at AT&T Wireless, likes temping. "I don't have to sweat the office politics the way you do when you're a permanent employee," he said. "And because I've moved from company to company, I've learned a ton of skills."
Yet the differences, however petty, are manifest. Permanent workers wear blue badges, temps orange. Temps are not invited to the annual picnic, do not get discounts at the company store and are not supposed to use Microsoft's basketball courts.
"You don't get an outside office if you're not a blue badge," Mr. Schussler said. "That means you don't get to see daylight."

HEADLINE: Study Criticizes Illinois's Rules For Legislators

BYLINE: By BILL DEDMAN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 28

 BODY:
In the Illinois State Capitol, in Springfield, farmer-legislators write the agriculture laws. Doctor-legislators propose the laws on H.M.O.'s. The beer-distributor-legislator sponsors a law limiting beer sales over the Internet.
Like most other states, Illinois has little regulation of the economic interests of legislators and relies on public disclosure to keep the lawmaking honest. But a new study has questioned the rules that govern such citizen lawmakers. 
 "The law is so ridden with loopholes that it leaves the entire system institutionally suspect when it comes to conflicts of interest," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the nonpartisan Center for Public Integrity, based in Washington.
In conducting the study, the center sent researchers to Springfield to analyze the economic disclosure statements of the 178 members of the General Assembly. It hopes to do the same in all 50 states. The study found such situations as these:
*Legislators routinely propose and vote on legislation that affects their pocketbooks. Bankers, soybean farmers and product-liability lawyers, for example, are involved in setting rules for their industries.
*The law does not require disclosure of many potential conflicts. Business interests of legislators' spouses and dependents are not disclosed and neither are the amounts of stock holdings. Lawyer-legislators are not required to disclose their clients.
*The state ethics law is little enforced. The center found many instances of legislators' failing to disclose business interests. None have been disciplined, state officials say.
Unlike the United States Congress, which mostly forbids outside employment, state legislatures are generally composed of people with other careers. As legislative pay has risen, however, more legislators are working full time. In Illinois, where legislators are paid $45,000, plus as much as $10,000 for leadership work, about half are full-time politicians.
As in most other states, Illinois law cautions lawmakers against voting on matters in which an economic interest "presents a substantial threat to his independence of judgment." Clearly, most states forbid lawmakers to vote on legislation affecting, for example, a single company when they own the company. But on legislation affecting an entire industry, states let the lawmakers decide what is a substantial interest.
Some see the issue differently. What the Center for Public Integrity finds objectionable is "newsworthy but not unethical," said Robert Stern, administrator of the Council on Governmental Ethics Laws, which drafts model legislation on ethics for states.
And the center's viewpoint is opposed by Alan Rosenthal, a professor at Rutgers University who has written on state ethics laws.
"That point of view is based on distrust because you assume someone is feathering his own nest," Mr. Rosenthal said. "But you don't have to be a teacher to vote for higher wages for teachers."
In Illinois, the Governmental Ethics Act gives two options to legislators with a conflict: abandon the financial interest or abstain from voting. Legislators interviewed on Friday said they did not know of any colleague who had taken the first route. Some legislators do recuse themselves. Others announce that they have a conflict and then vote.
"I do not consider refraining from action," said State Representative Ron Stephens, Republican of Troy and a pharmacist, who has proposed rules on who can write prescriptions. "The whole purpose of the act is just to reveal the information, so the voters can judge that as they may."

HEADLINE: Moynihan Backs Vallone In Primary for Governor

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 29

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the elder statesman of New York Democrats, will endorse the New York City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, for governor on Monday, giving Mr. Vallone the imprimatur of someone who is popular in all regions of the state and with voters of all parties.
Aides to both men said today that the endorsement -- an extremely rare gesture for Mr. Moynihan -- would take place in Buffalo, at a windshield wiper factory that is moving jobs out of state. The site offers the sort of imagery that is likely to fill the campaign as Mr. Vallone and other Democrats attack Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, over the weak upstate economy. 
 The setting and the endorsement also underscore Mr. Vallone's recent efforts to strengthen his standing upstate, where he is largely unknown, and where public opinion polls show him trailing far behind Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross for the Democratic nomination.
Mr. Moynihan has a stature in the region that no other Democrat can match. A longtime resident of Delaware County, he routinely carries solidly Republican towns and farming areas upstate that rarely vote Democratic, and that overwhelmingly supported Mr. Pataki in 1994.
"This endorsement is important, because people respect Moynihan," said Kevin McCabe, Mr. Vallone's chief of staff. "When the rest of the state is as familiar with Peter Vallone as the Senator is, they'll be equally supportive."
Mr. Moynihan seldom makes an endorsement in a contested primary, and indeed, he tends to hold himself aloof from electoral politics. In the 1992 Senate race and in last year's New York City mayoral contest, he did not back anyone until after the primaries, and then did not campaign for his party's nominees against the Republican incumbents, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"Senator Moynihan thinks highly of Peter Vallone and his positions on job creation and education, the kinds of things that are needed to rebuild New York State, particularly the Southern Tier, western New York and the rural north," said Tony Bullock, Mr. Moynihan's chief of staff.
In taking sides so early -- the primary is more than five months away -- Mr. Moynihan may be trying to help an old friend emerge as the clear leader in the field so that Democrats can avoid the sort of tough primary that has hampered them in the past.
Party leaders say the Senator may also be looking to short-circuit the candidacy of Ms. McCaughey Ross, a Republican-turned-Democrat who is the only primary contender ahead of Mr. Vallone in public opinion polls. Many of the state's top Democrats doubt the sincerity of her party conversion after a long feud with Mr. Pataki, and they argue that she would be a poor standard-bearer, spelling disaster for other Democrats running on the same ticket in November.
The endorsement is the second setback in just a few days for the Lieutenant Governor, who finished a distant second Saturday in a straw poll of upstate party activists gathered in Ithaca. The event was seen as a harbinger of upstate sentiment at the state party convention in May, where Ms. McCaughey Ross, unlike Mr. Vallone, will be relying heavily on upstate delegates to win an automatic place on the ballot. If she does not get 25 percent of the delegates' votes, she can get on the ballot only by collecting tens of thousands of signatures, a difficult process that can cost more than half a million dollars.
Mr. Vallone and Mr. Moynihan have a warm relationship that predates Mr. Moynihan's first election to the Senate in 1976. Mr. McCabe described Mr. Vallone as being the same sort of centrist Democrat -- or at least as pragmatically liberal -- as Mr. Moynihan, albeit without the Senator's famed erudition. "Peter Vallone is the working man's Pat Moynihan, and Pat Moynihan knows that," he said.
Another Democratic contender, James Larocca, a former State Commissioner of Transportation and Energy, played down the importance of the endorsement today. "I understand that there is a long-term relationship there that goes back to when Pat first entered politics," he said. "I think Peter should be pleased by the endorsement, but I don't know that endorsements play that large a role."
Whoever the Democrats nominate will have an uphill fight against Mr. Pataki, who fares very strongly in public opinion polls, and has raised money at a far faster pace -- more than $12 million so far -- than any other candidate in the state's history.
Polls show Ms. McCaughey Ross leading the Democratic field, based largely on having the highest name recognition by far. She also has the largest campaign fund, more than $2 million supplied by her husband, Wilbur L. Ross Jr., a prominent investment banker.
Mr. Vallone runs second in the polls, with most of his support in New York City, and he is the only other Democrat who has raised nearly as much as the Lieutenant Governor. Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, is running third, but he has raised little money.
Mr. Larocca, who won the upstate straw poll Saturday, has widespread support among party officials, but has little money and is a distant fourth. Richard A. Kahan, former chairman of the state's Urban Development Corporation, barely registers in the polls.

HEADLINE: After Clinton's Trek: Fear of a Crushing Embrace?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, March 29

 BODY:
One of the central themes of President Clinton's trip to Africa is partnership, which is widely welcomed here as a break with the paternalism of the past.
But as the President departed from South Africa today for Botswana, he left behind a major question: What kind of partnership? The United States is so enormous, so rich and so powerful that it can all but crush the comparatively tiny nations and economies of this continent in its embrace. 
 A determination to avoid this lay behind President Nelson Mandela's unequivocal statements last week that South Africa would choose its friends as it saw fit, whatever Washington may think about Cuba, Iran or Libya, and that his Government found unacceptable the African Growth and Opportunity Act, a trade bill that has passed the House and is awaiting Senate approval.
Mr. Clinton did not bridle at Mr. Mandela's blunt if affectionate language. Indeed he spoke in poetic terms of the South African's nobility of character in his toast at a state banquet. Recalling Mr. Mandela's 27 years as a political prisoner, Mr. Clinton said, "Though you were locked in prison for a long time, you opened others' minds and hearts."
On an emotional level, most South Africans welcomed Mr. Clinton equally warmly. He was likened by many older people here to his political hero, John F. Kennedy -- the last American President to take a broad interest in Africa, stimulated by his brother Robert and his energetic Africa specialist at the State Department, G. Mennen Williams.
Yet for all the expressions of mutual respect, the disagreements are real, and the South Africans, proud of their new freedom, are unwilling to be treated as a mere surrogate.
Mr. Mandela made it clear, said an approving editorial in today's Sunday Independent newspaper, that South Africa wanted "a relationship with the United States on its own terms, rather than terms dictated solely by America's self-interest."
The trade bill backed by the President, its critics in the Government here believe, would compromise the sovereignty of African governments by opening American markets completely only to those countries the United States judged to have embraced political and economic reform fully enough. That might penalize countries that choose to follow a path not approved by the International Monetary Fund, for example. To Mr. Mandela and others here, that smacks too much of colonialism.
In addition, the singling out of half a dozen or more countries for special treatment would make the achievement of African unity, already problematical, almost impossible.
By choosing six reforming countries to visit on this trip, Mr. Clinton strengthens the hand of a new generation of African leaders and encourages others to emulate them. But at the same time his policies could push countries like Nigeria deeper into isolation.
Finally, the South Africans worry that the trade bill could sharply increase the power of multinational companies at the expense of the fledgling African economies.
In Washington's view it is pointless to try to persuade American companies to invest here unless they are assured that the African renaissance is real and lasting.
Another dimension to the disagreement, only hinted at in public these last few days, is the balance between trade and aid. Mr. Clinton has promised to try to restore aid to its historically highest levels, but that will be hard to do in the present political climate in the United States. It is not easy for the South Africans to understand this, given the staggering dimensions of American prosperity.
Thabo Mbeki, the Deputy President of South Africa and Mr. Mandela's anointed successor, pushed hard during a meeting with Mr. Clinton for more aid, arguing that trade alone is likely to prolong African economies' reliance on the export of raw materials rather than more profitable finished products.
What South Africa thinks matters, and not only because of Mr. Mandela's stature as a world leader.
President Clinton avoided Gabon, Nigeria and Angola on this trip; they have governments that fall well short of Washington's criteria for acceptability. But with South Africa, they account for 84 percent of United States trade with sub-Saharan Africa. A trade bill that excluded all four, for one reason or another, would not amount to much.
That gives Mr. Clinton and Congress reason to see what they can do to meet Mr. Mandela's objections.
As Mr. Clinton said, "winds of change and good fortune" are blowing here, 38 years after the British Prime Minister, Harold Macmillan, told an all-white Government, to no avail, that it must heed the "wind of change" blowing in Africa.
Mr. Clinton appeared to have convinced South African leaders of several things, whatever the disagreements: That he cares about Africa, that he wants the United States to play a leading role in the continent's development and that he considers this country one of Africa's leaders.
Best of all, said Greg Mills, director of the South African Institute of International Affairs, the President's trip has prompted "the beaming of positive African images to an otherwise largely ignorant United States audience."

HEADLINE: A New Debate on the Fate (And State) of Puerto Rico

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: GUANICA, P.R.

 BODY:
On a stone set on a pedestal in Guanica, a small town in southwestern Puerto Rico, a plaque commemorates "the landing of the American troops under Gen. Nelson A. Miles on Guanica Beach, July 25, 1898."
Today's Guanica bears many other marks of that invasion -- a United States Post Office, cross-cultural storefront signs like "Ayala Funeral Service" and residents like Florencio Suarez-Williams, the grandson of one of the American occupiers. 
 "He was a good man," Mr. Suarez-Williams, 75, said proudly of his grandfather, Capt. Abraham B. Williams, a doctor from Florida. "He could have gone on to seek military glory, but he stayed here to help people."
But a century after Spain ceded Puerto Rico to United States rule after losing the Spanish-American War, Americans and Puerto Ricans are less certain of their feelings for each other than is Mr. Suarez-Williams. Prodded by the centennial of the Spanish-American War this year, international disapproval of any vestiges of colonialism and the failings of the status quo, both the United States and Puerto Rico seem to want change. But in trying to redefine their relationship, both are sizing up each other as if 100 years have not been long enough to commit or part ways, or even get to know each other well.
For the first time, Congress is seriously considering a bill that would allow the island of nearly four million people to vote on whether it wants statehood, independence or the current commonwealth association. The bill has been approved by the House.
However, Congress itself is sharply divided over whether to accept a possible 51st state. And for the first time in Puerto Rico, the major political parties agree that the status quo is no longer acceptable, but they remain almost equally split between statehood and some form of association with the United States.
The issue of self-determination has bogged down in Washington on questions about the economic, political and cultural cost of incorporating a Spanish-speaking land.
In Puerto Rico, a decision about the island's fate is deeply wrapped in a sense of identity. Miguel Hernandez-Agosto, past president of the Popular Democratic Party, which was the architect of the current "free associated state" status created in 1952, argues that the century-old association with the United States has created a hybrid: a territory that regards itself as a nation, Americans who feel Puerto Rican, a Latin American culture used to North American standards and values.
"This is not a barrio of the Bronx," said Mr. Hernandez-Agosto, 70. "This is not a question of who favors Hispanics and who doesn't. This is a country with roots, with an idiosyncrasy, with pride, that transcends its boundaries.
"Puerto Rico treasures and defends its own identity," Mr. Hernandez-Agosto said, "but it also treasures and defends its U.S. citizenship."
Commonwealth supporters like Mr. Hernandez-Agosto want more autonomy and to keep their island from succumbing to what he calls "the cultural genocide" of statehood or the instability of complete disassociation. The commonwealth alternative won 48 percent of the vote in a nonbinding status referendum in 1993. But there are two other aspirations: statehood, supported by 46 percent of the referendum voters, and independence, backed by a passionate minority of 4 percent.
What seems like a perennial debate over political status has gained momentum in Puerto Rico as frustrations grow. It is a status that has given Puerto Ricans American citizenship but denied equal rights and obligations. Puerto Ricans cannot vote in Federal elections and do not pay Federal taxes or receive Federal benefits comparable to those in the states unless they move to the mainland. The status has brought economic benefits that have led to a strong middle class and has allowed about three million Puerto Ricans to migrate to and from the states, but has also created a dependence on Federal aid, like food stamps.
In Guanica, a town of about 20,000 where the main street is named "25 de Julio" for the day the Americans arrived, Mr. Suarez-Williams and his sister, Libertad, both advocate statehood. Ms. Suarez-Williams argued that the United States freed Puerto Rico from the tyranny of the Spanish monarchy and instilled the democratic values that it cherishes today. But she said the current commonwealth status renders Puerto Ricans impotent to make their own decisions or influence those made for them in Washington because they cannot vote for President or Congress.
"The greatest benefit of statehood would be that Puerto Ricans could develop a sense of self-esteem with a government that is not trampling them," said Ms. Suarez-Williams, a former high school teacher. "If you don't have strong self-esteem, you are in a state of conformity and incapacitation."
But two years at a community college in Wichita, Kan., convinced Hilka Mercado, 19, a student who works as a waitress at the Blue Marlin Restaurant and Pub here, that the cultures are too different to be joined closer than they are now.
"They don't know where Puerto Rico is," she said of the people she knew in Kansas. "To them Puerto Rico is part of Mexico. To them I'm black. They say I speak Mexican. You can't be that ethnocentric. How can you want to part of people who don't want you?"
Ms. Mercado supports a commonwealth that would give Puerto Rico more autonomy. But Pedro Juan Vargas, 86, the town's historian and a supporter of independence, said Puerto Rico was entitled to "its own sovereignty and everything the United States wants for itself."
Mr. Vargas said he did not expect radical change because, he argued, the United States finds the status quo in its interest. Puerto Rico, he said, represents a major market for American products, an outpost for American military bases and "a blood tribute" paid by the Puerto Ricans who fight America's wars. "If we were a burden, they would have gotten rid of us long ago," he said.
Senator Bob Graham, a Florida Democrat and a co-sponsor of the plebiscite bill, said that Puerto Rico posed a test of the United States' commitment to self-determination and that his bill should pass as "a statement of recommitment to the principle of the Declaration of Independence -- that people should have a say in their destiny." But he said he had warned his colleagues not to vote for the bill if they were not ready to abide by a binding plebiscite.
The legislation passed the House earlier this month by the slimmest of margins, 209 to 208, after 11 hours of debate in which Democrats, Republicans and representatives of Puerto Rican descent argued on both sides of the issue. (Most Republicans voted against it and most Democrats for it.) Its chances in the Republican Senate appear slimmer. The Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources has not scheduled hearings on the bill but is conducting a "workshop" on Thursday to familiarize members with the issue, said Derek Jumper, a committee spokesman.
The Popular Democratic Party in Puerto Rico, opposes the plebiscite bill in Congress, charging that some of its terms favor statehood. It is studying a proposal by Mr. Hernandez-Agosto for an alternative status that would transfer to Puerto Rico some of the powers now under Federal jurisdiction. The party wants exemptions from some Federal laws that it says hamper Puerto Rico's economic development and flexibility for the island to enter into its own international trade deals to create new jobs.
But opponents call those proposals largely cosmetic. They include Luis A. Ferre, the former governor, a Republican Party chairman in Puerto Rico and founder of the pro-statehood New Progressive Party, which is in control. Mr. Ferre said that if Puerto Ricans were to remain American citizens and subject to Federal law they should have full vote and say.
Statehood advocates have made a plebiscite such a priority since Gov. Pedro J. Rossello took over in 1992 that they have pushed for the removal of tax exemptions for American companies, increased English instruction in public schools and played down the island's sense of nationhood, all to help pave the way for acceptance into the union.
"We're not like other Latin Americans," said Mr. Ferre, 94. "We Puerto Ricans, without realizing it, have changed. We're the product of the peaceful fusion of two cultures. We're already incorporated."
But just as determined is the pro-independence camp, which in the past has used violence to send a message. Juan Mari Bras, a lawyer and a pro-independence leader, has legally renounced his American citizenship. He said members of Congress who expressed concern about fomenting another Quebec or worse with statehood have reason to worry.
"The independentistas are not going to accept statehood with their arms crossed," said Mr. Mari Bras, 70. "One nation does not fit into another. It's that simple."
In Guanica, preparations are already under way for the centennial commemoration of the takeover by the United States. While independence advocates plan a march to repudiate the invasion, the ruling statehood advocates are gearing up for a celebration.
Mr. Vargas, the historian, is not planning to attend any events. Nor is he following the goings-on in Congress with the plebiscite bill, he said.
"Ever since General Miles entered through Guanica everything has been promises, promises," he said. "Puerto Ricans realized the sad reality that all that happened in 1898 was that we exchanged monarchical masters for democratic ones."

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
Kicking and Screaming, Baby Boomers Begin to Talk About Aging

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 29

 BODY:
It was a workshop to get baby boomers to talk about what was billed as "the A word" -- aging.
"I'm not going to one of those nursing homes," one woman called out from the back of the room.
"I'm not going unless they have caffe latte," another woman insisted. 
 The annual conference of the American Society on Aging, which ended on Saturday at the Hilton Hotel here, brought together more than 3,000 participants for six days of workshops, discussion groups, and speeches by such experts as C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General; Jeanette C. Takamura, the Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for Aging, and Richard Browdie, Pennsylvania's secretary of aging and the society's new director.
The speeches were chock full of statistics illustrating the rapid graying of America: by 2011, the number of Americans 65 and older will double. A baby boomer turns 50 every 7.6 seconds. There are 61,000 Americans 100 or older, according to the United States Census.
The conference itself offered daunting numbers: More than 800 workshops covering a range of subjects that included Social Security, long-term care, nursing home reform, gay grandmas, women and estrogen, and "Men: myth, crisis, doubt and mature spirituality."
But baby boomers being baby boomers, those at this workshop made it clear things are going to have to change for them.
"There will be a Starbucks in every nursing home," said one of the handful of men in the room, Stephen Sapp, a professor of religious studies at the University of Miami.
 
Happily Inactive
What about people who want to kick back and relax a little in their final decades? What about 85-year-olds who don't want to run marathons, learn languages, go ballroom dancing, or otherwise participate in the "active retirement life style?"
The question was put to Rabbi Sam R. Seicol, director of religious services at the Hebrew Rehabilitation Center for Aged in Boston, in his session on "religion, spirituality, and aging." Rabbi Seicol said, "We've got a resident, we can't get him out to programs."
"He's not depressed," Rabbi Seicol said. "He comes out when he wants. He's got his computer, his VCR, his stereo boom box. He's got his CD's. He's happy."
 
Care Program Is Big Draw
For the members of the American Society on Aging, who had gathered from across the country, the top attraction was a nationally recognized comprehensive care program for low-income, frail, elderly people run from a building at 1333 Bush Street.
"It's like going to mecca for everybody in the field of aging," said Bob Eckardt, an official of the Cleveland Foundation, a philanthropic organization, who made the pilgrimage to the building on Saturday.
The program, which has been praised as a model for long-term care by President Clinton and is being duplicated across the country, is called On Lok, which is Cantonese for "peaceful, happy abode."
Jennie Chin Hansen, the executive director of On Lok, led Mr. Eckardt through the building of spacious, light-filled rooms, the medical clinic with its wide, comfortable beds, the Asian garden where Alzheimer's patients can safely enjoy the outdoors and the kitchen where Jimmy Luu, a chef prepared Western- and Eastern-style meals.
Most of the program's 700 people only go to On Lok for the day, because they prefer returning to their homes at night.
 
'What Do I Do Next?'
"I'm 77," Betty Friedan announced to a ballroom filled with gerontologists, social workers, academics, physicians, nurses, ministers, rabbis, entrepreneurs and writers.
The author of "The Feminine Mystique" and "The Fountain of Age" paused for a long moment. "I am?"
"I'm still thinking, 'What do I do next?' " Ms. Friedan said in her speech. "I have fantasies. Partly, I plan my own funeral. Then I think, 'That's sick.' The other part of me is writing an indignant op-ed about these sex scandals. What's the big deal?"
Ms. Friedan shared the lectern with Robert Butler, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author and president of the International Longevity Center, who, in his speech, quoted everyone from Leo Tolstoy ("Old age is the most unexpected of all things that happens to a man.") to Maggie Kuhn ("I try to do something outrageous every day."). Dr. Butler and Ms. Friedan talked about the philosophy of the new long life and "new paradigms of aging."
The shift on aging was one of the slogans of the conference, which took as its theme "charting a course for the age boom."
Aging was once about "all those poor old people who are going to be around" sick, degenerating, needing care, and draining the economy, Ms. Friedan said, "as if age is only a matter of care and pathology."
Aging now involves "a new third of life," she said, and a new frontier.
"It's not going to be old, senile people," she said, "but vital people."
People like Senator John Glenn, 76, who is preparing to go into space again.
"I don't think anyone will look at their grandfather in the same way after John Glenn gets back," Dr. Butler said.

HEADLINE: Fortunes Improve for Upstate Cities That Symbolized Decline

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

DATELINE: TROY, N.Y., March 25

 BODY:
For years, there was no greater cliche of urban decline than this old industrial city on the Hudson River. Often described as the most financially distressed city in the country, it earned municipal notoriety five years ago when its officials used a maneuver that amounted to a mortgage on City Hall to try to close a deficit.
But after endless grim reports, the news here in the last few weeks has been surprisingly upbeat. After two years of balanced budgets, debt restructuring, contract renegotiations -- and generally reduced expectations -- Troy's Mayor, Mark P. Pattison, publicly declared an end to the fiscal crisis early this month. And a Wall Street rating company, Moody's Investors Service, upgraded Troy's municipal bond rating one step, to B1 from B. 
 Here, and in a handful of other upstate cities with suffocating financial woes, the crisis atmosphere of the last few years is beginning to lift. Some experts on municipal finance are saying that the combination of the strong national economy, increased state aid and more disciplined fiscal management has meant that Troy and cities like Buffalo, Newburgh and Niagara Falls, while still financially weak, have turned a corner.
"A couple of years ago, there was a terrible downward spiral," H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller, said in an interview. "We've stopped that."
No one is saying the upstate cities have anything like a secure future, and it is far too soon for residents to notice much in the way of cleaner streets or new basketball hoops in public parks. Virtually all the cities still face the long-term problems that made them symbols of urban decline in the first place, including shrinking populations, weakened tax bases, insufficient jobs and expensive municipal services.
It is also unclear whether the new fiscal stability would last if the national economy soured. That would pinch the state's financial health, cutting its income, and would almost certainly dampen the state's appetite for providing the cities with financial assistance.
But some officials say an end to the emergency mentality means they can now try to confront the fundamental issues that are affecting most urban areas. "Having stabilized, it is now possible to move forward and address those other issues" said Mr. McCall, whose office works closely with most of the state's troubled cities. "You couldn't even address those other issues while they were hemorrhaging."
The city manager of Newburgh, Harold J. Porr 3d, said, "What it means for the people of Newburgh is that before there was no hope, and now there is a belief that things will get better."
The Moody's report, which has drawn wide attention across the state, declared early this month that the financial outlook was "stable" in six New York State cities that have been synonymous with financial crisis: Troy, Buffalo, Newburgh, Niagara Falls, Utica and Yonkers.
Some of the improvement, Moody's found, has been a result of an improving economy, although the upstate economy is still trailing the national boom. In each of the six cities it studied, Moody's found that unemployment rates have fallen from highs of five years ago.
In Troy, for example, the unemployment rate fell to 7 percent in 1996, the last year for which data were available, from 8.9 percent in 1992, while the state unemployment rate in 1996 was 6.2 percent. Of the six cities studied, the 1996 unemployment rates exceeded the state unemployment rate in all except one, Yonkers, where unemployment fell to 5.5 percent from 8.3 percent in 1992.
Moody's was least enthusiastic about financial progress in Utica, and it did not analyze the finances of cities that have been among the stronger performers in the group, like Syracuse and Rochester.
In addition to Troy, Moody's also upgraded the bond ratings of Newburgh and Niagara Falls, which have been among the most financially troubled of the state's cities. On a scale from Aaa to C, Moody's upgraded Newburgh and Niagara Falls' rating to Ba1 from Ba.
The bond ratings of all three of those cities remain below the investment grade rating of Baa. But Marcy S. Block, Moody's manager of municipal bond ratings for the Atlantic Coast, said that, for the financial markets, the notion that the finances of New York State's cities might be improving was a novelty after years of crisis. "You were kind of wondering when it was going to stop," she said.
In some of the cities with improving financial health, the impact on the lives of the residents has been minimal. But there are some signs. In Niagara Falls, officials say hopes for redevelopment seem more realistic than they have in years. In Newburgh, Mr. Porr said, the value of the assessed property in the city grew last year for the first time in eight years.
In most of the cities, pressing financial problems continue. In Buffalo, which has had a slight budget surplus for the last few years, a long-running legal fight with the teachers' union has left unresolved whether the city might ultimately have to pay millions of dollars it has not budgeted. Yonkers, which had a budget surplus last year, could face substantial additional costs because of a long court battle over desegregation, according to the State Comptroller's office.
In old cities like Troy, a few years ago, there was little relief from urban doomsayers. In this city of 55,000 people, at least, that is changing, said Dr. Jeanne H. Neff, president of the Sage Colleges, which includes Russell Sage College for Women in Troy. "All you would hear were stories about Troy's decline and fall," she said. "Now, there is a tremendous sense that this is a moment in time when Troy can claim a much brighter future."
The optimism is often expressed subtly. In an act rich with local symbolism, private and state money is being used to restore a granite staircase that leads from the hilltop campus of the nationally known Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute to Troy's downtown. For decades, as Troy deteriorated, so did the staircase until it finally fell into disuse years ago.
But there are few notable city-financed economic development projects here. Instead, Mayor Pattison said, the city is trying to encourage private investment by emphasizing the government's return to fiscal stability. He said a group of new shops, including a large downtown furniture store and a new cultural center that is under construction in a row of buildings that have long been empty, were signs that his strategy is working.
That strategy, he said, was to "sweat the details" and pay attention to what he acknowledged were boring components of municipal life, like the adequacy of a water main. "If you want to have investors in the city of Troy, they're going to have to have confidence that the underpinnings are as stable as possible."
Partly, Mayor Pattison said, he emphasized the mundane business of government because returning to financial health was so costly that there was no money for dramatic ventures. And partly, he said, his approach was a sign that, though there is fiscal stability, the underlying challenges to urban life remain.
"The crisis is behind Troy," he said. "The financial challenges are still in front of us. It doesn't get easier from here."
In his first year in office, 1996, he was facing an $8 million shortfall in a $34 million budget. His solution included an immediate property tax increase of 21 percent and a 38 percent hike in water rates. Years of troubles had reduced sanitation and parks workers and other city service crews to skeleton levels. But he asked for and got concessions from all the municipal unions except the police. He is in a bitter contract dispute with the police union.
The public anger about tax increases and declining services leaves little room for added revenue for new projects and little ability to make new cuts. The Democratic Mayor's critics, including a Republican Councilwoman, Carmella R. Mantello, say his obsession with the details of getting the city's finances in order has meant that too little attention has been paid to long-range planning.
Mr. Pattison dismissed his critics, saying that he, too, hoped Troy might have a brighter future than he can now promise.
He said places like Troy have been taught over the last few years that they must be realistic. Getting back to financial stability, he said, only showed how little control most cities can have over their futures because they are too strapped to do much more than survive as they are buffeted by powerful trends like the decades-long flight to the suburbs.
"What will happen to small cities -- cities in general -- is, I think, a very open question," he said. "We as a society are going to have to make certain decisions about what we want to do about cities."

HEADLINE: Lake's Fleeting Greatness Graces a Faded City;
Wave of Welcome Publicity for Plattsgurgh

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., March 27

 BODY:
As the ferry made its way from Vermont to New York, across the choppy waters of Lake Champlain, Kirk Polhemus, a deckhand, issued a judgment heard over and over these days in the North Country. "It may not be a great lake," he said, "but it's the best lake."
These very words are heard so often here that it seems the Chamber of Commerce has written the script for discussing the dispute over a Federal law that briefly made Champlain an official Great Lake, the equal of Superior, Huron, Erie, Ontario and Michigan. That legislation, overturned in Congress last week, was the brainchild of Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat. He was seeking Federal funds from the Sea Grant program, which finances aquatic research at universities that border the Great Lakes or the ocean. 
 Senator Leahy slipped seven words into the bill last month -- "The term Great Lakes includes Lake Champlain" -- and thus unleashed a storm of protest in the Middle West, where politicians from the shores of the five larger lakes rebelled at sharing their "greatness." Now the law has been rewritten, stripping Lake Champlain of that superlative but giving Vermont access to the Sea Grant money nonetheless.
"If you get the money, you don't need the status," said Chris Walfield, a desk clerk at a motel here, who, like most residents on the New York side of the lake, found the whole episode kind of silly.
But the brouhaha, despite sneering editorials across the country, was a bonanza for the Chambers of Commerce on both sides of the lake, a perfect example of the public relations credo: Say what you want about me as long as you spell my name right.
The coast-to-coast publicity was welcome in Plattsburgh, a faded city reeling from the loss of its Air Force base and the Canadian shoppers who are staying home because of the unfavorable exchange rate. In recent weeks, tourism and civic officials have had ample opportunity to proclaim their lake a scenic, unspoiled gem, more like Lake Tahoe or Geneva than industrial waters like Lake Superior, Michigan or Erie, which was once so filthy that it caught fire in places.
And even in Burlington, Vt., a more prosperous and cultivated city than Plattsburgh and well known for its natural beauty and recreation, travel writers from Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Maryland have come calling. They will no doubt tell their readers about the silos and snow geese, the moose and maple sugar, the piney woods and picturesque marinas, to say nothing of the fall foliage season when both Vermont's Green Mountains and New York's Adirondacks blaze with beauty.
Arguably, the publicity that came from Senator Leahy's attempt to rewrite the geography books did more for the New York side of the lake than the Vermont side. Vermont is a small state, with Burlington its economic, educational and cultural hub and Lake Champlain one of its defining features. New York, by contrast, includes the Statue of Liberty, Niagara Falls and everything in between, and thus the lake and the city on its western shore get far less attention, both from the public and the national and statewide politicians.
The mayors on both sides of the 490-square-mile lake, Peter Clavelle in Burlington and Clyde Rabideau in Plattsburgh, agree that Vermont is way ahead of New York in developing and promoting its lakefront. "New York is a huge state so it's hard to get recognition," Mayor Rabideau said.
Mayor Clavelle agreed. "The lake is much more important to Vermonters than New Yorkers," he said. "But that's mainly a matter of scale."
One civic leader who spans the divide is Stewart Ledbetter, the news director of WPTZ-TV, an NBC affiliate that serves both cities and is always hearing complaints from New Yorkers that the station favors Vermont and vice versa. Mr. Ledbetter said that "New York is playing catch-up in realizing the value of waterfront activity to the overall tourist economy," but has a unique opportunity since the former Air Force base, occupying two miles of lakeshore, is now available for private development.
The two cities are as different in character as white bread and wheat bread or cornflakes and granola. Burlington is a hip place, with fine restaurants and cultural activities that draw residents of Plattsburgh across the lake on ferries that run to the Vermont side year round. Burlington won the battle with its New York neighbor in the 1950's for a huge I.B.M. plant and is thus an employment mecca.
Plattsburgh has the look of an industrial city fallen on hard times, boasting too heartily about a new wine bar and a renovated train station. Yet people who live here rave about affordable real estate, natural beauty and down-to-earth neighbors -- not the snooty urban refugees who are more likely to settle in Vermont.
"It's a completely different culture over there," said Mark Barie, head of the organization that is redeveloping the Air Force base. "They see themselves as a playground for skiers, hikers, nature buffs. They're less practical and more esthetic. Here it's dollars and cents and common sense. They wear L. L. Bean clothes so they look like we always looked, but without the label."
The lake, which Mr. Ledbetter crosses several times a day going from his Burlington newsroom to the one in Plattsburgh, "is one of the few commonalities, except the weather, that strikes a chord on both sides," he said.
It is a long, narrow and deep body of water -- 107 miles from Whitehall, N.Y., to the Quebec border, anywhere from half a mile to 14 miles wide and up to 400 feet deep. The scene of significant battles in the American Revolution and the War of 1812, Lake Champlain is considered by divers to be one of the great troves of unexplored shipwrecks.
While far smaller than Ontario, the smallest of the Great Lakes, it is No. 6 in the United States in size and shares many geological and environmental characteristics with its larger cousins, enough to prompt the United States Geological Survey to endorse Senator Leahy's bid. All six lakes were carved by the same glacier, during the Pleistocene ice age, more than 10,000 years ago. All six share the same drainage basin, emptying into the St. Lawrence River.
The six lakes also have identical rock formations, flora and fauna and similar environmental plagues, among them zebra mussels, sea lamprey, phosphorous runoff and mercury pollution. The Sea Grant money, which must be bid for in a yearly competition, will be spent finding ways to clean up the lakes and arrest future problems.
But Middle Western politicians balked at sharing the Great Lake designation. Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, insisted that the hullabaloo was not "a tempest in a teapot" but rather "a matter of our identity." Senator John Glenn, an Ohio Democrat, mimicking a slight that was hurled at Dan Quayle during a Vice-Presidential debate, said: "I know the Great Lakes. I've traveled the Great Lakes. And Lake Champlain is not one of the Great Lakes."
Senator Leahy and others guessed that the Middle Westerners took more offense than New York's senators, whose state sits at the edge of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario, because they have less to brag about. "New York has a lot of other things going for it," the Vermont Senator said. "For the Midwestern states, the Great Lakes is all they have."
In a rare burst of candor, Senator Leahy described the compromise struck last week as a win-win situation for him, not only because Vermont got the Sea Grant eligibility, but because, after the vote to rescind Champlain's "great" status, he is now owed favors by his colleagues in Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, Indiana, Illinois, Minnesota and Pennsylvania. "He didn't get to be a senator all these years by being stupid," said Chris Lamitie, a ferry employee, taking a break at the Galley restaurant on the dock here.
Donna Holt manages the six-seat clapboard restaurant, serving sandwiches on her daughter's home-baked bread. Mrs. Holt, who has lived most of her life here, had the unlikely experience of being in Wisconsin, where her husband was waiting for a heart transplant at a veterans' hospital, when the Great Lakes dispute flared earlier this month.
At first Mrs. Holt and her husband were flabbergasted by the fury of Wisconsin's citizens. "Then we realized that beside the Green Bay Packers, the lake is their big item," she said.
Then Mrs. Holt offered her own version of the unofficial "I Love Champlain" campaign. "I can't think of anyplace I'd rather be, except maybe in January and February," she said. "To me it's a great lake -- always was, always will be."

American arms manufacturers, who stand to gain billions of dollars in sales of weapons, communication systems and other military equipment if the Senate approves NATO expansion, have made enormous investments in lobbyists and campaign contributions to promote their cause in Washington. A1
 
Infighting Rocks Khmer Rouge
The remnants of Cambodia's Communist Khmer Rouge movement have turned their guns on one another, and the jungle stronghold that has withstood repeated Government offensives is now torn by factional fighting. The turmoil comes at a moment of political tension in the capital, where Prince Norodom Ranariddh is scheduled to return after fleeing a coup last July. A3

As a White House envoy announced that he would return from the Middle East to brief President Clinton on the reaction to new peace proposals, American Jewish leaders said they had been assured by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright that the United States would not present Israel with an ultimatum for a West Bank withdrawal. A3
 
Oil Erodes Armenia's Power
Armenians won a 1994 gamble to gain control in Nagorno Karabakh, part of neighboring Azerbaijan, but the regional political structure in the Caspian Sea basin is threatening Armenia's hold. The rush for the untapped oil reserves of countries in the area and billions of dollars in planned investment have loosened Russia's grip on the region and turned oil-rich Azerbaijan into a new hub of regional influence. A6
 
Plot Thickens in South Africa
The mystery around the arrest of a former anti-apartheid guerrilla who is a Government official deepened with President Nelson Mandela's announcement that he had received a report linking the former guerrilla, several army generals and his former wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, to a plot to overthrow the Government. But Mr. Mandela said the report was probably a hoax. A7
 
28 Die in Peru Plane Crash
A Peruvian air force plane carrying villagers stranded by flooding crashed into a shantytown in the northern city of Piura, killing 28 people, President Alberto Fujimori said. Fifteen people survived and seven were unaccounted for. The pilot told the control tower that one engine had shut down and that he would try to land. (AP)

Iran criticized Prime Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik of Norway for having met with the writer Salman Rushdie, who has been condemned to death by Iran for blasphemy. The official Iranian news agency IRNA quoted a Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying that the meeting "constituted support for Rushdie's desecration" of Islamic sensibilities. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: REGION;
Port Authority Reports Rise in Volume of Cargo

 BODY:
The volume of goods shipped by sea through ports controlled by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey rose 4.5 percent in 1997, the agency has reported.
The increase in general cargo, which includes goods like bananas and automobiles but not bulk commodities like oil and salt, was the result of the continued strength of the economy, Lillian C. Borrone, the agency's director of port commerce, said on Friday. She also attributed the increase to a labor agreement that reduced fees paid by shippers into a longshoremen's pension fund and a new rail link at the agency's container port in Elizabeth, N.J. 
 Ninety percent of the cargo is shipped through Jersey City, Newark and Elizabeth, Ms. Borrone said.
