HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA;
World War I Museum's New Drive on the Home Front

BYLINE: By Shirley Christian 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 30

 BODY:
Two weeks after World War I ended on Nov. 11, 1918, a group of Kansas City civic leaders decided to create a memorial to those who had served. A fund drive was held, and in less than two weeks it raised $2 million, then a substantial sum.
Schoolchildren collected pennies. A lumber magnate, R. A. Long, led the drive and made the largest single donation, $70,000. A local politician named Harry S. Truman who had returned from the war as an Army captain was a contributor. Gen. John J. Pershing and four other Allied military leaders took part in the site dedication in 1921 before 200,000 people. President Calvin Coolidge spoke at the dedication of the monument in 1926, but the crowd favorite was Queen Marie of Romania, a granddaughter of Queen Victoria and a heroine of the war. 
 "Complete, unbridled patriotism created this," said Doran Cart, curator of the Liberty Memorial Museum of World War I, an architectural wonder several times the size of the Lincoln and Jefferson Memorials and home to an unmatched collection of artifacts from the war.
With a tower soaring 217 feet from the center, the Liberty Memorial became Kansas City's commanding landmark from a hillside overlooking Union Station. Although other monuments to World War I were built around the country, none are believed to approach this one in size and grandeur, and no other has a museum attached. A Chicago architect, H. Van Buren Magonigle, won a national competition to design the Liberty Memorial, which Edward Durell Stone likened to the Acropolis and the monuments of Paris.
Since 1994, however, the memorial has been closed to the public because of deterioration of its underlying supports, attributed to a poor drainage system and 1920's construction techniques. Embarrassed that it neglected the memorial for so long, the city is trying to raise $60 million from public and private sources to reconstruct the underground supports, restore and update the structures and add a major new space to display a collection that ranges from 1,200 propaganda posters to rare German artillery pieces. The plan is to create a museum for the 21st century that will combine the relics of the war with modern interactive technology, keeping alive the event that laid the framework for much of 20th-century history.
Sixty million dollars does not sound like an unmanageable sum in a growing metropolitan area with a thriving economy, where numerous public and private projects costing several times that amount are under way or ready to start. But Ollie Gates, a businessman who is president of the Parks and Recreation Commission, said that aside from a $2 million donation from R. Crosby Kemper, a banker, and "a hundred thousand here and there from the city budget," no other money was definitely in the pipeline.
He asked the city to appropriate $5 million over the next two budget years and requested $10 million from a state fund for veterans' matters. He said that the city had explored the possibility of Federal aid but that members of the state's Congressional delegation said the city already had an overly long Federal wish list. Some civic leaders think a sales tax may have to be submitted to voters on behalf of the memorial. Meanwhile, an advertising agency is planning a private fund-raising effort.
Still, some of those involved are motivated by personal memories that remind them of the importance the memorial played 70-some years ago, including Charles Waldron, who as a 12-year-old was the Boy Scout aide to Missouri-born General Pershing at the site dedication in 1921. Now 89 and still active as an insurance agent, Mr. Waldron recalls riding beside the general in a black touring car with the top down.
"He was very friendly; he talked very crisply," Mr. Waldron said. "He was one of my inspirations later, when I went into World War II, and came home a full colonel. He was a hell of a guy, a real man's man. The car was very likely a Cadillac. I think that's why I still drive Cadillacs today."
The Liberty Memorial became a museum almost by accident. In 1920, even before the first shovel of dirt had been turned at the site, people began to send objects related to the war. They still do, often because they want the objects to be preserved and know of nowhere else to send them. The United States Army Center of Military History in Washington has called the Liberty Memorial the only museum "whose sole purpose is to provide a history of the World War I period."
"We have an artillery collection that is probably without peer," Mr. Cart said. "We have two guns that are the only known examples of their type: a Bavarian 15-cm. howitzer and an Austrian 8-cm. bronze tube gun. We can cover any aspect of the war, from the home front to the battlefield. We don't have an airplane; I'd like to have one. The Imperial War Museum in London and the Smithsonian have airplanes."
Mr. Cart said the posters were especially important because in that era they were "the" medium of communication for governments trying to gather citizen support for the war effort. Uniforms came from all the belligerent countries. People also sent German helmets, maps, official orders and memorandums. There are about 20 German field guns.
There is a horse-drawn ambulance, a British naval deck gun, a signed autobiography of Eddie Rickenbacker and a full field kitchen. There is a handwritten note from King George V welcoming American troops to England, and one of the brass boxes containing candy and cigarettes that Princess Mary gave British troops in 1914.
In 1993, someone in Tennessee donated a dismantled troop boxcar. "It's called a 40-and-8," Mr. Cart said, "because it was supposed to hold 40 men or 8 horses. The Americans always complained that they had to get aboard right after eight horses had been carried."
Very recently, a Kansas City man donated a naval officer's dress sword from the war, along with a photo of his father wearing it.
The document archives include more than 12,000 photographs of almost every activity and country associated with the war, and 2,000 postcards; a wide variety of newspapers; more than 600 maps, including those of specific battle areas, and a category called "ephemera," which includes the hotel bills for Queen Marie's visit to Kansas City.
Never dreaming that the collection and archives would reach their current size, the creators of the memorial included two buildings of just 2,500 square feet each, one on each side of the tower, with a courtyard connecting them. Murals were painted in one, and the historical collection went into the other. But it was quickly overwhelmed by the size of the collection, and can currently hold only about 10 percent of its items.
Most of the others are in warehouses and the limestone caves that lie beneath Kansas City. When the memorial was closed in 1994, two shopping malls lent free space where a small part of the collection is on public display.
Stephen Abend, the architect whose firm has been retained to oversee the restoration and expansion, said that the crumbling supports are under the 274-foot-wide courtyard between the museum building and the Memory Hall with its murals, but that the tower itself is not threatened because it is sunk 80 feet into bedrock.
If the rehabilitation succeeds, it will provide 140,000 square feet of space. Of that, he said, 40,000 square feet will be gallery and exhibition space, more than 15 times what is now available.
Ralph Appelbaum Associates of New York, which designed the permanent exhibitions of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, has been retained to design the interior exhibition space.
Roy Inman for The New York Times
The tower of the Liberty Memorial Museum of World War I.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Fears of Increasing Inflation Send Market Gauges Lower

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Fears of rising inflation and Asian economic woes pushed major stock market gauges lower yesterday for the fourth straight day.
A decline in Treasury bond prices and the subsequent rise in long-term interest rates also affected stocks. Bond prices fell after news of a record 4.8 percent jump in home sales in February stirred inflation fears ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee. 
 Although the Fed is not expected to raise its target for short-term interest rates today, the housing data -- as the latest sign of continued economic growth -- increase the likelihood that the next move in interest rates could be higher, analysts said.
In addition, the dollar rose against the Japanese yen as investors showed their disappointment with Japan's latest economic plan.
In the market yesterday, interest- rate-sensitive issues like banks and financial services companies declined. J. P. Morgan, American Express and the Travelers Group led the Dow lower. Consumer noncyclicals like Coca-Cola, General Electric and Procter & Gamble rose, as did some drug company stocks like Pfizer, American Home Products and Rexall Sundown, a vitamin and consumer health products manufacturer.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 13.96 points, to 8,782.12. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.89 points, to 1,093.55. The Nasdaq composite index declined 4.92 points, to 1,818.70; and the Russell 2000 small-company index lost 0.91 point, to 476.24.
Several market analysts, however, said that investors should not be disheartened by the market's modest declines.
"The market went up for eight consecutive weeks," said Tom Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "I think it's time to pause. Sometimes it's important to consolidate before the next big run."
Mr. Galvin still expects stocks to move higher. He recently increased his forecast for the Dow to 10,105 this year from 9,200. He expects the S.& P. 500 to hit 1,350, up from his earlier prediction of 1,095, in the next 12 to 18 months. He changed his suggested asset allocation, lifting stocks 15 points, to 65 percent of a portfolio, decreasing bond investments by 10 points, to 30 percent, and reducing cash by 5 percent.
Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company, said of the recent declines, "This is extremely minor in the context of where we're coming from."
In the last four days, the Dow has lost 122.32 points, or 1.4 percent, and the S.& P. 500 has lost 12.1 points, or 1.1 percent. But the gauges have risen 22.6 percent and 24.7 percent, respectively, since their recent lows on Oct. 27. And the Dow is up 2.8 percent so far this month, while the S.& P. gained 4.2 percent in March.
"It's a tiny decline," Mr. Pradilla said, adding, "This is nothing that should worry investors."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Dip in Defensive Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were lower yesterday, amid defensive trading ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's committee on monetary policy, at which the course of interest rates in the months ahead may be determined.
While few analysts expect a change in monetary policy, some concern about an increase in interest rates remains in the market, causing buyers to demand a "risk premium" in the form of higher yields. 
 Adding to the cautious tone was nervousness about economic data to be released this week. The National Association of Purchasing Management releases its monthly index of manufacturing activity tomorrow, and the Government reports on employment on Friday, giving the market its first look at the economy's performance in March.
The 30-year bond fell 9/32, to a price of 102 2/32, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction to the price, up to 5.98 percent, up from 5.96 percent on Friday and the highest level in three weeks.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, says his firm's economics group still foresees an unchanged Federal Reserve monetary policy this year as economic growth slows to around 2.5 percent and consumer prices rise by a very modest 1.75 percent.
 Rates at yesterday's regular weekly bill auction were higher than at the previous sale, with the new three-month bill awarded at the average rate of 5.050 percent, compared with 5.030 percent a week earlier. The six-month bills were awarded at an average rate of 5.075 percent, up from 4.990 percent. Analysts called the auction a little weaker than expected.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Considers if Disabilities Act Covers H.I.V. Case

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
The Supreme Court took up its first case under the Americans With Disabilities Act today, and the argument over whether the law covers people who have H.I.V. but who show no symptoms of disease served mainly to underscore the statute's complexities.
The 1990 law forbids discrimination against anyone with a disability, which is defined in part as "a physical or mental impairment" that substantially limits a person in "some major life activity." It also provides that someone who "poses a direct threat to the health or safety of others" need not be served in a medical office or other public accommodation. 
 In this case, a dentist who refused to treat an H.I.V.-infected patient in his office is arguing both that the woman was not disabled within the meaning of the law, and that in any event, his refusal to treat her anywhere but in a hospital was justified by his reasonable fear of infection. Two lower Federal courts rejected both arguments, ruling in favor of the patient, Sidney Abbott, in her discrimination suit.
During the arguments today, Justices expressed puzzlement or concern over almost every aspect of the case, from the lower courts' analysis of Ms. Abbott's condition to the statistical basis for assessing a dentist's fear of contracting H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, from a patient. .
The lower courts had accepted Ms. Abbott's argument that the "major life activity" in which she was "substantially limited" was reproduction; she testified that her decision not to have children was based both on her fear of passing the virus to a baby and of not living long enough to rear a child.
Justice David H. Souter was outspoken in his doubt about this analysis. He told Ms. Abbott's lawyer, Bennett H. Klein, that while her decision was based on "a very responsible moral judgment," it was a nonetheless a "self-imposed limitation" rather than a physical limitation of her condition.
"I don't find it that easy to transfer the moral limitation she's placed on herself to the limitation the statute talks about," Justice Souter said.
Mr. Klein replied that the law did not require the complete inability to perform a "major life activity." For example, he said, "breathing" was accepted as a major life activity under the statute, even though people with impaired respiration are obviously still breathing.
"The statute doesn't require the preclusion of the activity," he said. "The fact that there's a volitional aspect doesn't preclude it from being a substantial limitation."
Justice Stephen G. Breyer asked, "Are you disabled under the act if you know that the minute you leave the house, you will infect the whole city with bubonic plague?"
"I think so," the somewhat startled Mr. Klein replied.
"I would think so, too," Justice Breyer said.
Justice Antonin Scalia objected, "That's not obvious to me."
In this appeal, Bragdon v. Abbott, No. 97-156, the Court was confronting not only its first case under the Americans With Disabilities Act, but also its first case related to AIDS or H.I.V. The wariness and unease the Justices displayed might be explained by their knowledge -- reinforced by the many friends-of-the-court briefs -- that almost any ruling would set an important precedent not only for the legal status of AIDS and H.I.V., but for how the law applied to a wide range of conditions. At issue is not only the definition of disability, but also the meaning of the exception offered to medical workers and others who fear a "direct threat" from a person with an infectious disease.
John W. McCarthy, the lawyer for Randon Bragdon, the dentist who in 1994 refused to treat Ms. Abbott in his Bangor, Me., office, argued strenuously that the lower courts' interpretation required dentists to take unacceptable risks.
"Some risks are acceptable" in society, Mr. McCarthy said, arguing, as an example, that deaths among workers building bridges are inevitable. But he said dentists should not be forced to risk their lives by treating patients with H.I.V. infection.
Both the American Medical Association and the American Dental Association filed briefs asserting that patients with H.I.V. can be treated safely in medical and dental offices using standard precautions against infection. There was much debate during the argument about the nature of the risk. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported that there is no documented case of a dentist or hygienist being infected with H.I.V. from a patient. Mr. McCarthy said that there were seven such cases, and that the risk was understated and underreported.
One question for the Court is whether risk should be assessed by public health professionals or whether practitioners should be able to act individually.
Urging the Justices to find that asymptomatic people with H.I.V. infection are not disabled, Mr. McCarthy said the law should be interpreted in light of its "context and purposes." He said Congress was concerned about disability that impairs "day-to-day independent living and economic self-sufficiency." From that perspective, he said, limitations on learning, hearing, working and breathing were covered, while reproduction was not.
Justice Anthony M. Kennedy asked how the law should apply to a disease that will inevitably produce limitations in the future. Mr. McCarthy replied that the law did not take account of future disabilities.
When Mr. McCarthy said an eating disorder would probably be covered under the law, Justice Breyer said: "Then why not reproductive activity, which includes a person having a sex life." Sexual activity, he said, was "regarded in this society as a major life activity."
The Clinton Administration entered the case on behalf of Ms. Abbott. Lawrence G. Wallace, a deputy solicitor general, called the lower court's approach to the case exemplary.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Britain Moves to Combat 'Millennium Bug'

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 30

 BODY:
Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today an accelerated program to forestall the catastrophic essential service lapses, business losses and communications blackouts that he said could be caused by the year 2000 computer date change crisis known as the Millennium Bug.
Saying he was concerned that small and medium-size businesses were lagging in their awareness of the gravity of the "technical time bomb," Mr. Blair told a London conference on the subject that the Government would spend $160 million for new centers for information technology assistance, for increased financing for the Government's Action 2000 campaign and for the training of 20,000 "bug busters" to help companies correct the problem. 
 The Government will offer grants to train young people, the older unemployed or retired people to help companies and in the process help them start their own careers in information technology, he said.
In keeping with his projection of the country as modern and competitive in an age of high-speed worldwide technology, he said Britain would assist a move to educate countries abroad that have not taken into account the seriousness of the consequences of inaction.
"We need to act internationally," Mr. Blair said, "because in a global economy other countries' problems are our own."
He said Britain was contributing $16.5 million to a proposed World Bank fund aimed at generating action in developing countries, and he said that as the current president of the European Union, Britain would press the case at future meetings of the community.
The Millennium Bug potentially affects millions of computers and other electronic devices that will not read 2000 as a valid date because their internal software is programmed to read only the last two digits of any given year. That means they would interpret 2000 as 1900, which could cause the computers to corrupt data, crash programs or fail to operate at all.
Huge amounts of records and statistics, including those of stock and pension accounts, could be compromised as computers came to a halt. Any industry with time-sensitive data, from nuclear reactors and hospitals to financial institutions and retail businesses, could be harmed.
"Without careful preparation, there could be major disruption to essential services such as benefit payments, or even to emergency services such as hospitals, the fire and the police," Mr. Blair said.
Mr. Blair said that Britain was "leading the way in tackling the Bug."
Britain, of course, is not the only place trying to avert a Millennium Bug problem. Many other Governments and companies around the world are also spending money on computer upgrades. In the United States, officials responsible for year 2000 conversion efforts have estimated it will cost $2.3 billion just to fix the Federal Government's computer systems. The General Motors Corporation expects to spend up to $500 million and Chase Manhattan Bank expects to spend $300 million.
Several critics greeted Mr. Blair's announcement today with warnings that his action was already too late. Richard Coppel, chief executive of Prove It 2000, a major consulting group, said loosing "dedicated amateurs" on the problem risked complicating it further. He said the Government was "well intentioned but lacks any understanding of how the program might be practically applied."
Cheryl Gillan, the Conservatives' spokesman on Trade and Industry, also faulted Mr. Blair for waiting too long, saying: "It is now a question of damage limitation. The Government cannot afford to waste any more precious time."
Brian Cotter, the spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, said, "The Government's posturing belies their own inaction over the Bug."
Mr. Blair said the overall cost of adjustment to the public sector would reach $5 billion. A Forum of Private Business survey showed that only 53 percent of its 23,700 member companies had checked their hardware and operating systems to see if they were prepared for the Millennium rollover date and only 27 percent had begun to make the changes.
While the Millennium Bug has prompted a lot of general doomsday scenario predictions, a case at the giant retail concern of Marks & Spencer is the one that has so far most attracted consumers' attention. The chain's stock inventory system scrapped an entire consignment of corned beef because its sell-by date was "02," and the computer system assumed it was 96 years old.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Homes Soar to Record High

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
Sales of new homes soared to a record high in February, the Government said today, as the robust economy, low mortgage rates and warm weather enticed buyers.
Single-family home sales rose 4.8 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 893,000 units last month after a revised 5.2 percent gain in January, the Commerce Department said. February's annual rate was the highest on record, surpassing the 880,000 set in March 1986. 
 Economists said the report underscored tremendous momentum in the economy despite weakness in exports by American business to Asia.
The home sales pace topped the rate of 817,000 in February 1997 by 9.3 percent. The news follows a report last week that sales of existing homes also jumped to a record last month.
In its report, the Commerce Department said the supply of available homes dwindled to a record low 3.8-month supply from 4.1 months in January.
The regional breakdown of sales showed the clear influence of the weather as the Northeast and Midwest, which enjoyed springlike weather in February, saw the biggest gains.
Sales jumped 25.5 percent in the Midwest, 19.2 percent in the Northeast and 15.7 percent in the West. But sales fell 12.3 percent in the South, which was hit by severe storms caused by the El Nino weather pattern.
The median price of a new home rose 5.8 percent, to $153,400, from $145,000 in January and 7.3 percent from $143,000 in February 1997.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Norway Pledges to Take Part In Worldwide Oil Supply Cuts

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
An emerging coalition of oil-exporting countries seeking to reduce production and raise prices was significantly strengthened yesterday when Norway, a major exporter, said it would cut its output as much as 100,000 barrels a day.
And members of the main-line Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting at a special session in Vienna yesterday, approved cuts totaling about 1.25 million barrels a day, or 4.3 percent of the group's output of 28.8 million barrels a day. Current world demand totals about 74 million barrels. 
 Norway's agreement means that two major exporting countries outside OPEC -- Mexico and now Norway -- support efforts to lift the price of oil, which had fallen below $13 a barrel at one point before rebounding somewhat.
Nonetheless, crude oil prices fell yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, dropping 55 cents, to $16.21 a barrel, as traders were apparently uncertain that the producing countries would actually follow through on their pledges and that the cuts would be large enough.
After news of the agreement among OPEC members, which came last night in Vienna, oil prices fell slightly in trading on exchanges that were open at night.
"Most people don't think it's enough," Doug Stetzer, a broker at ED&F Man International in New York, said of the proposed cuts.
All OPEC members have pledged their support of the effort, which began a week ago with an agreement by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico.
Marit Arnstad, Norway's Oil and Energy Minister, said that his country's cuts would not be made until mid-April and depended on other producing nations' living up to their promises to reduce output. The OPEC members said they would begin the cuts tomorrow.
Norway has supported OPEC-initiated export cuts in the past in an effort to increase prices. What is unusual in this round of cuts, however, is that the initiative was taken by Mexico, which helped bring about the agreement of the Venezuelans and Saudis, each of whom had been waiting for the other to make the first move.
Vahan Zanoyan, president of the Petroleum Finance Company, an energy consulting group based in Washington, said yesterday it was still unclear whether greater cooperation was emerging between OPEC and major non-OPEC producers.
"I really believe that it is premature to even suspect that," he said, recalling previous efforts to achieve cooperation.
He added that Norway was less dependent on oil revenue for its economic well-being than some other major producing countries -- particularly Mexico, but also many OPEC members. The Norwegians might therefore not have as pressing an incentive to stick by an effort to increase prices.
All the producers are struggling to reduce a world surplus of oil caused by an unusually mild winter; the economic crisis in Asia, which reduced expected growth in demand, and rising exports by many producing countries.
Though the price of crude oil fell in recent weeks to the lowest level in nine years, it has rebounded a bit on expectations of a supply cut. And that effect may have begun to be felt at the pump. The United States Energy Department said yesterday that the average price for regular gasoline increased to $1.03 a gallon this week, up 3 cents from last week.
Normally it takes about one month for the price of crude oil to be passed through to the retail level, so the jump was called unusual.
The average retail price, however, was still 17 cents lower than in the same period last year.

HEADLINE: Fund Investors Are Returning To Riskier Bets

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
After several months of more cautious and conservative investing, mutual fund shareholders and managers are growing bold again.
According to industry groups that track fund cash flows, the amount of new money invested in several types of aggressive stock funds in the United States and abroad rose steadily in February and March, as a surge in technology stocks led American share prices to record highs. 
 Mutual fund portfolio managers have also been taking a less cautious stance. The amount of uninvested cash in stock portfolios fell to 5 percent of assets in February, down from 5.5 percent a month earlier and 5.7 percent in February 1997. By keeping less in cash, fund managers demonstrate that they are less concerned about investor withdrawals.
The return to more aggressive fund choices marks an end, at least for now, to the nervousness among fund investors since October, when weakness in Asian economies pushed the United States stock market into a quick decline. The resulting turmoil caused new investments in small-capitalization and aggressive growth stock funds to fall as investors channeled more money into less risky ones.
"I really believe individual investors thought Asia was going to slow the U.S. market significantly, and so they became more conservative with their fund investments," said Charles Biderman, president of Trim Tabs Financial Services, a Santa Rosa, Calif., company that tracks cash flows. "It was only in the middle of March that they gave up that fear completely."
According to data released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, a fund trade group, equity mutual funds took in a total of $24.2 billion in February, nearly two-thirds more than in January and well above the group's previous estimate of $19.5 billion for February.
Some of those gains came from aggressive growth stock funds, which in January had net withdrawals by investors but received $1.6 billion in net new deposits last month, the institute reported. Global stock funds added $3.7 billion in February after cash outflows of about $1 billion in January.
Cash flows into hybrid funds, a more conservative group that invests in both stocks and bonds, fell by one-third in February, to $1.9 billion.
Those trends continued this month, according to Trim Tabs and AMG Data Services, another independent company that tracks short-term cash flows. In recent weeks, both companies have reported that aggressive stock funds have added new cash, while the amounts flowing into moderate and conservative stock funds are flat, at best.
As investors shied away from aggressive stock funds last fall, they increased purchases of shares in bond funds. So while the amount of money flowing into taxable bond funds is up sharply from its level a year ago, it has fallen over the last two months. Taxable bond funds added $5.6 billion in February, down from $7.2 billion in January, the Investment Company Institute said.
Trim Tabs reported that bond funds of all types added about $3.8 billion in March, down from about $6 billion in February.
The Investment Company Institute also reported that municipal bond funds added $656 million in net new investments in February, about one-third of the January amount. By comparison, in the first two months of 1997, about $575 million flowed out of municipal funds.
This month, the Investment Company Institute revamped its categories for measuring cash flows. In addition, it eliminated from its calculations the assets put into funds of funds -- those that invest in a portfolio of other mutual funds. Previously, those assets, which totaled $26.3 billion at the end of February, had been counted twice in measuring assets and cash flows.
The institute moved several classes of funds that invest in both stocks and bonds into a separate, hybrid category. Previously, most of those were included in the bond fund totals.
While the institute had previously reported that bond funds added $11.3 billion in new cash in January, the revamped January totals included only $7.2 billion in taxable bond funds. A further $3.1 billion was invested in the hybrid funds in January, while $1.8 billion flowed into municipal bond funds.

HEADLINE: Wrangling Over the Federal Budget Outlives a Dying Deficit

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
Last year's balanced budget agreement was supposed to make it all so simple. After years of bitter partisan warfare over taxes and spending, President Clinton and the Republican leadership in Congress agreed on a five-year plan that gave both sides most of what they wanted, with enough left over to eliminate the Federal deficit.
The deficit is evaporating even faster than expected, thanks to the strong economy and the tax revenues it is generating. But the ideological and political confrontations over how to apportion the money raised by the Federal Government are as intense as ever, and members of both parties see themselves headed for a high-stakes showdown with considerable implications for this fall's Congressional races. 
 At issue is whether the two parties can find a way to keep their pledges of fiscal discipline and find money for more of what they have always craved -- tax cuts on the part of Republicans, social programs for Democrats and old-fashioned pork-barrel spending for both.
Franklin D. Raines, the White House budget chief, said today that the White House and Republicans appeared to be heading toward a major confrontation in September, when Congress will try to complete its spending bills for next year.
Not only are there a raft of unresolved partisan disputes, Mr. Raines said, but the White House and the Republican leadership do not have any negotiating forum in which to address their differences, as they did last year when teams from the two sides met regularly to hash out the balanced budget deal.
"I'm very concerned that we don't even have a process by which we could get a good result," Mr. Raines said. "It's a hazardous path we're on with very few working days in Congress left to resolve it."
Mr. Raines even suggested that the outcome could be another standoff of the sort that led to the Federal Government's being shut down in 1995. He indicated, though, that it was more likely to turn out like 1996, when the Republicans, eager to finish their work and go home to campaign, cut a flurry of last-minute deals that gave the Administration much of what it wanted.
Richard E. May, former Republican staff director of the House Budget Committee, said Republicans even had a name for what it cost them to come to an agreement in 1996 so they could leave Washington to campaign: an "exit fee."
Mr. May said it would not be surprising if the Administration tried the same negotiating tactic this year. But he said this time the Administration would have a difficult time making the case that its domestic proposals will not shatter the spending limits that both sides have agreed to abide by. And he said the situation still remained very confused because of uncertainty about whether Congress will pass legislation intended to curb smoking, largely by forcing a sharp increase in cigarette prices, a move that would raise billions of dollars that both parties want to dedicate to their priorities.
"This is a bizarre year for the budget," Mr. May said.
It is a measure of how many cross-currents are at play that not all of the disputes are strictly partisan. Already the White House sees money for its proposed new education and child care programs being whittled away by a bipartisan push to spend far more on highways and mass transit than last year's budget deal envisioned. The transportation bill is the only major piece of legislation to pass the Senate so far this year, and it is one of the few bills with bipartisan support in the House.
"Transportation is an important domestic priority, but we must strike a balance so that we do not allow one priority to squeeze out other critical investments such as education or undermine our fiscal discipline," Mr. Clinton said in a letter sent to Speaker Newt Gingrich on Saturday.
Fiscal conservatives within the Republican Party are just as worried about the strong momentum behind the transportation bill, saying it goes back on their commitment to reduce the size and power of the Federal Government.
"This bill is really a hog," said Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee. "We believe this bill is, in fact, an abomination." His objections were brushed aside by Mr. Gingrich and the rest of the Republican leadership.
Some of the battles are more traditionally partisan. The White House's expansion of education and child care programs would rely on the revenues that would flow from the tobacco legislation.
But Republicans are divided about how any tobacco money should be used, with Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico leading a push to use the money to shore up Medicare, and many other Republicans determined to use the money for tax cuts.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan Plans for Big Bang, A Financial Overhaul
In Japan the Government of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and ordinary citizens are preparing for the Big Bang, a financial restructuring to begin tomorrow.
The goal is to transform Tokyo into a financial center as vibrant as New York or London and to give new flexibility to Japan's rigid. Mutual funds are to become available and the barriers between banks and brokerage houses are to be broken down. Page A1. 

Norway to Cut Oil Output
Norway, a major oil exporter, joined the coalition of oil exporting countries that plan to cut production to drive up prices. Members of OPEC, meeting in a special session in Vienna, approved cuts totaling about 1.25 million barrels a day, or about 4.3 percent of their output. Still, crude oil futures fell 55 cents, to $16.21 a barrel. D12.
 
Tougher Tobacco Bill
Cigarette makers denounced a comprehensive tobacco bill that is much tougher on the industry than a settlement it reached with state attorneys general in June. A1.
 
New-Home Sales Soar to Record
Sales of new homes soared 4.8 percent to a record annual rate of 893,000 in February, thanks to the robust economy, low mortgage rates and warm weather. D7.
 
Stocks Decline on Inflation Fear
Stock prices declined for the fourth straight day as investors worried about possible inflationary pressures and Asia's economic malaise. The Dow industrials slipped 13.96 points, to 8,782.12. D12.
 
Treasury bond prices fell ahead of today's Federal Reserve policy meeting, pushing the 30-year yield to 5.98 percent from 5.96. D12.
 
Broker Dismisses Two Executives
Salomon Smith Barney told employees that it had dismissed two executives after concluding that they had used the company's electronic equipment to transmit pornography. D9.
 
Holding the Chips at Hilton
Hilton Hotels' head of gambling operations, Arthur Goldberg, received a $1 million salary last year, almost twice as large as that of the chief executive, Stephen Bollenbach. D11.
 
New Data Encryption Delayed
Adoption of a new data scrambling standard for protecting sensitive financial transactions, including banks' electronic funds transfers, has been delayed, following scientists' discovery that the code could be cracked. D9.
 
Hospital Industry Seeks Protection
The hospital industry, hurt by a series of investigations and large penalties under a Federal fraud statute, is waging a battle on Capitol Hill to make it more difficult for prosecutors to sue health care providers. D6.
 
Millennium Debugging in Britain
Britain announced an accelerated $160 million program to avoid any catastrophic lapses in essential service, business losses and communications blackouts caused by the year 2000 computer date change. D4.
 
Reader's Digest in a Makeover
Reader's Digest, after decades of listing its articles on the cover, is taking on a zippier new image, with color photography inside and out, a modernized typeface and a table of contents that doesn't appear until page 2. "We're not changing the soul and the heart of the magazine," said Gregory Coleman, worldwide publisher. "We are updating the look." D10.
 
A New Network for South Africa
Midi Television a group that is 20 percent owned by Time Warner, won the license to build a new, free television network in South Africa. D10.
 
Swiss Banks Seek to Narrow Talks
Big Swiss banks, after agreeing to talks on a so-called global settlement of Holocaust-era disputes, are seeking to narrow the focus to accounts untouched since World War II. A15.

HEADLINE: SENATE IS OFFERED SWEEPING MEASURE TO FIGHT SMOKING

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 30

 BODY:
With bipartisan support, Senator John McCain today offered a comprehensive tobacco bill that could form the basis of ground-breaking legislation meant to sharply reduce the number of Americans who smoke.
The measure, containing no restrictions on private lawsuits, faced withering attacks from the cigarette manufacturers on one side and public health authorities on the other. 
 But Mr. McCain, Republican of Arizona, who heads the Commerce Committee, said he hoped to have found a middle ground that could win broad support. "It's tough medicine for a tough problem," he declared at a news conference.
The measure would impose a fee on tobacco companies to force up the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.10 over the next five years, penalize the tobacco companies if the number of teen-age smokers did not fall to specified levels, impose strict limits on cigarette advertising and give the Food and Drug Administration broad authority to regulate tobacco.
The main concession to the industry was an annual ceiling of $6.5 billion on the amount the cigarette manufacturers could be required to pay in civil damages. Claims exceeding the ceiling would be owed in subsequent years.
The legislation is much tougher on the tobacco industry than the settlement the manufacturers reached with state attorneys general last June. The bill would raise the price of a pack of cigarettes by almost twice the amount in the June agreement and would not contain that settlement's prohibition against class-action lawsuits seeking damages for smoking-related illnesses.
With the bill's introduction today, it replaced the June settlement as the package around which further deliberations will revolve.
Mr. McCain said that the Commerce Committee would vote on the legislation on Wednesday and that he had received assurances from the Republican majority leader, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, that the bill would be brought to the Senate floor.
The House of Representatives has seemed to be marking time on tobacco legislation until the Senate acts.
The McCain measure was the product of weeks of horse-trading. As late as Sunday night, the negotiators had not resolved the question of whether to give the cigarette manufacturers protection from lawsuits in exchange for their agreement to restrict advertising voluntarily.
The industry urgently wants such protection, but Mr. McCain decided against it: "The consensus was that this was the most viable option."
J. Phil Carlton, a top lawyer for the tobacco industry, said the measure would lead to "a massive contraband market" and "almost certainly drive companies into bankruptcy."
"It cannot serve as the basis for a realistic and comprehensive national tobacco policy," Mr. Carlton said at a news conference.
On the other side, former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, one of the country's most prominent public health authorities, said: "I cannot support this bill as it stands. Its programs to reduce the number of children who smoke are too weak and its protections of the tobacco industry are too strong."
Several Democratic lawmakers, including Senators Kent Conrad of North Dakota and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, said that the bill was unsatisfactory and that they would try to amend it.
Mr. Conrad, who represents the Senate Democratic leadership on tobacco issues, said in an interview tonight that he was pleased that Mr. McCain had dropped provisions that would have given the cigarette manufacturers immunity from class-action lawsuits based on smoking-related illnesses and other private suits seeking punitive damages from the companies for past practices.
But Mr. Conrad said that the cigarette price increase was too small and that the penalties were too low on companies that did not meet annual goals for reducing youth smoking. Mr. Conrad favors raising the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.50 over two years.
Promising frequent efforts to amend the legislation, Mr. Conrad said, "We're going to give our colleagues a chance to vote and vote and vote."
The White House took a measured approach. In a luncheon speech, Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, said that the Clinton Administration was pleased with many aspects of the legislation. But he said that the Administration hoped to increase the penalties on the companies if smoking goals were not met. The bill would limit the penalties to $3.5 billion a year.
Rahm Emanuel, a senior adviser to President Clinton, called the bill "promising but not perfect."
Despite the opposition, Mr. McCain has won substantial backing on his committee.
He has solid support from the Republicans. And at his news conference today, he was joined by two important Democrats on the committee -- Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, one of the few lawmakers who have expressed a degree of sympathy for the tobacco industry, and Ron Wyden of Oregon, perhaps the committee's most ardent opponent of the industry.
Also present were two state attorneys general who have been active in taking on the tobacco companies, Michael C. Moore of Mississippi and Christine Gregoire of Washington.
Mr. McCain said that he had checked with all the members of the committee and that he had "an overwhelming majority on both sides of the aisle" on his side.
Asked about the industry's complaints, Mr. McCain replied, "I could not craft a proposal that would be vetoed or modified by their concerns."
Whether the strong support on his committee can be turned into a majority on the Senate floor is another matter. Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, could be a serious obstacle. He is not enthusiastic about tobacco legislation, and he has a history of tying up legislation that he opposes.
The bill would require the tobacco companies to pay more than $500 billion into a Government fund over the next 25 years, compared with $368.5 billion in last June's settlement. The cost would be passed on to smokers, and as a result the price of a pack of cigarettes would be raised in annual increments that would reach $1.10 a pack in five years.
When inflation and scheduled excise-tax increases are factored in, according to Treasury Department calculations, the average price of a pack of cigarettes nationwide would reach $3.58 in 2003.
The goal is to reduce teen-age smoking by 25 percent in five years and 45 percent in 10 years.
The McCain bill does not address how the money would be spent. Some Republicans want it all to go into Medicare. Others favor tax breaks to encourage small businesses and individuals to purchase health insurance.
President Clinton wants some of the money to go for education and child care. Public health advocates want most of it to be spent on antismoking advertisements and smoking cessation programs.

HEADLINE: Republican Budget Feuds

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress have developed a habit of fighting with each other more than with the White House. Now their feuding threatens passage of emergency spending for disaster relief and for American forces in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf.
In the House, restive conservatives have draped the emergency bill with budget cuts in Administration programs like housing and AmeriCorps. They know such cuts will force President Clinton to veto the bill, but do not seem to care. They have forgotten that the same tactics of holding a vital disaster-relief measure hostage to their agenda backfired last year, tarring Republicans as obstructionists. 
 In the Senate, the issue of spending has sent Republicans in a different direction altogether. When the emergency appropriations bill was approved by the Senate last week, it contained no separate call for budget cuts. In fact, the bill grew in size as Republican senators added spending for boll-weevil eradication, military aircraft acquisition and other items. Most significant, the Senate attached $17.9 billion for the International Monetary Fund as leading conservatives like Ted Stevens of Alaska warned that the money was needed to stabilize financial markets in Asia.
The Senate bill, with its I.M.F. rider, passed 84 to 16 last week. But the lopsided vote is unlikely to impress House Republicans. Again, they seem incapable of passing something on its own merits. They insist that they will not approve money for either the I.M.F. or the United Nations unless approval contains yet another separate provision barring American aid to family-planning groups overseas that advocate abortion. No matter that a long list of internationally minded Republicans have joined with Alan Greenspan to plead for the I.M.F. funding as necessary for a healthy global economy.
Watching House members engage in the self-destructive act of tying up much-needed legislation, Speaker Newt Gingrich seems incapable of acting. He announced over the weekend that he would seek re-election to the House and to the post of Speaker, but most politicians expect him to run for President. Whether he leaves the House or stays, Mr. Gingrich clearly feels he cannot stand up to the obstreperous ultra-conservatives in his conference who bemoan every compromise with the Administration as an unconscionable sellout.
But if Mr. Gingrich aspires to the Presidency, or if Congressional leaders aspire to full partnership on the budget, they first have to show they can govern. Holding up essential legislation to settle scores is not the way to do it.

HEADLINE: CBS Considers Manhattan and Jersey City for New Studios

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In what may shape up as the next trans-Hudson battle for big business, the CBS television network is considering several sites in Manhattan -- and one in Jersey City -- for a new broadcasting center to replace its 35-year-old studios on West 57th Street, near 11th Avenue, according to several people involved in the negotiations.
Leading the list of options for the network, several of those people said, are Donald J. Trump's Riverside South project on the West Side of Manhattan, from 59th Street to 72nd Street, and the Newport complex of apartments and offices on 600 acres on the Jersey City riverfront. The network's plans were first reported yesterday in The New York Post. 
 "We consider staying in Manhattan to be the preferred option, but we need to look at the financial implications of each scenario," said Jack Bergen, the network's vice president for communications. While acknowledging that Newport and Mr. Trump's project are under consideration, he said other Manhattan sites were also among the network's options. Neither he nor any of the other officials involved in the negotiations would specify the other sites.
The network will be required later this year by the Federal Communications Commission to begin producing digital television programs, and must invest heavily in equipment for the new technology. Although it accepted a $49.5 million package of tax breaks and other incentives from New York City in 1993 to upgrade its 57th Street studios for the new technology, it has not done so, and Mr. Bergen said network executives have concluded that a new building would be better suited for the technology.
CBS would be required to reimburse the city for all of the financial incentives it has received if it moves to New Jersey, city officials said. Although it was not clear yesterday whether the incentive package could be transferred to another site in Manhattan, several officials said some form of city incentives were all but assured.
"We don't expect them to move out, and we regard this as a great opportunity for the city," said Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, who said he met with CBS executives two weeks ago to discuss their options. He said the city hoped not only to persuade the network to stay, but also to "piggyback" its new studios with those of other entertainment companies, creating an even larger complex. But he said questions about whether financial incentives would be offered, or what form they would take, had not been resolved.
Officials at Cushman and Wakefield, the brokerage firm representing CBS in its search, said the network has taken an interest in Newport Centre Three, an office building in the Jersey City complex on which construction is to begin next month.
But in Jersey City, it appeared unlikely that negotiations had reached the point where CBS was seeking any government incentives, because the company had not yet spoken directly to Newport's developer, Samuel J. LeFrak. He began building the vast riverfront complex 14 years ago.
"I have not spoken to them personally," Mr. LeFrak said. "CBS's fingerprints may be there, but it doesn't mean their signature is there." New Jersey officials could not be reached by telephone for comment last night.
Mr. Trump, by contrast, said he had met with CBS executives and was convinced that they would sign on for at least 1.5 million square feet of studio space in his project. "I have a great feeling about CBS," he said yesterday.
If the network's search narrows -- as some officials said they believed it would -- to a choice between Jersey City or Mr. Trump's project, it could prompt a replay of the battle that was waged in the 1980's to persuade NBC not to move to New Jersey.
Although NBC ultimately accepted a package of city incentives to remain in its studios in Rockefeller Center, it had threatened to move to New Jersey or to be the first large tenant of Mr. Trump's West Side project, which was then to be called Television City and provide space for several broadcasting companies.
Since then, the project, with its name changed to Riverside South, has emerged from a series of political battles and revisions as a plan for 18 riverfront towers, most of them residential. Only the southern end of the area, from 59th Street to 62d Street and from West End Avenue to the West Side Highway, is now designated for broadcasting studios.
Mr. Trump said yesterday that he had decided to change the name of the project again, this time to Trump Place, a designation that he said would capitalize on the prestige of his name.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan, to Revitalize Economy, Prepares to Reshape Its Markets

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 30

 BODY:
In one of its most ambitious undertakings, the Japanese Government plans this week to set in motion a far-reaching program that it hopes will infuse the country's financial landscape with the prowess of its manufacturing industries.
The rules of the game start changing Wednesday in a phased, three-year process called the Big Bang. For the Government of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, April 1 is the opening shot in an effort to transform Tokyo into a financial center as vibrant as New York or London. 
 The change is also aimed at shattering the rigidities of the Japanese economy, which has been strained by weaknesses in the banking system, most notably hundreds of billions of dollars in soured property loans amassed over the years.
Scores of measures, embraced in a 10-pound, 2,132-page tome now working its way through Parliament, are intended to bring mutual funds to the man and woman in the street, break down barriers between banks and brokerage firms, encourage insolvent financial institutions to close down and allow brokers to compete with the Tokyo Stock Exchange by starting their own mini-exchanges to trade stocks. It amounts to a grand bid to create more efficient markets, and, if successful, could end up changing Japanese investing habits the way those of Americans have been transformed over the last quarter-century.
The Government hopes that by the year 2001 it will have begun to coax many of the nation's savers into investing a chunk of their savings in new ways. Those savers have sequestered in near-zero-interest savings accounts a total of about $9 trillion -- a sum greater than the annual output of the American economy. Even a fraction of that could send global stock markets soaring.
Much of the program is not yet fully formed, and its completion is by no means certain.
Until recently, Japan's financial industry has been a strait-jacketed society, governed less by shareholders than by Government officials, who stifled competition with stiff regulations and by sharing new ideas among the banks. Major banks consulted one another so much that they ended up expanding overseas in a herd, making property loans at the same time and then watching in horror as those loans soured simultaneously. Even now, they announce profits and losses all together in a group meeting.
The Government aims to transform that into a freer, more open system. By the year 2001, it hopes far more variety will be offered to ordinary citizens.
Still, the Japanese remain largely risk-averse investors, particularly after the collapse of their stock market from its dizzying heights of the early 1990's. It is entirely possible that the Big Bang at the outset will produce a flood of new financial instruments that no one will feel comfortable buying.
But some younger people are eager to embrace greater risk in exchange for a return higher than the less than three-tenths of a percent interest paid by banks. Yuki Aoyama, an office manager at a small company, recently visited the Tokyo Stock Exchange to learn more about the Big Bang.
"I'm tired of the scandals at the Japanese banks and securities companies," Ms. Aoyama said. "After April, we can open an account overseas. Having money in Japan will do you no good. Banks are places where you keep your money just to prevent it from being stolen." "Of course, there will be foreign exchange risk," she added. "But we need to make our own decisions on whether to bet on high-risk, high-return products. That is real capitalism."
American and European financial companies, from Merrill Lynch & Company to Fidelity Investments, are rushing into the market in the hope of wresting funds from Japanese banks. They are betting that the Japanese savers are fed up with a dearth of choice and are planning to offer a range of American-style mutual funds and sophisticated asset management, wrapped up in bolder marketing.
The master plan was inspired by earlier efforts to liberalize markets in the United States and Britain. In the United States, the move was called May Day, after the date in 1975 when brokerage commissions were deregulated. In Britain, markets were freed in the Big Bang of 1986 that helped fortify London's status as a pillar of international finance.
Japan hopes to modernize its markets as well, but it will not be easy.
"We have all been living in a protected environment, like a society of young children," said Nobuyuki Koga, a director at Nomura Securities Ltd., Japan's largest brokerage house. "But from now on, only those who think for themselves and act by themselves will survive. And it is a big question whether everyone who belonged to that society can grow up and become an adult."
Indeed, the Big Bang might fizzle into a Little Rattle. There are potential minefields ahead for the authorities, who have already shown some ambivalence about giving up so much control to the markets. Partly as a result, deregulation will be spread over three years, officially beginning by freeing up some brokerage commissions and making it easier for individuals to open accounts overseas.
It will end in 2001, if all goes as planned, with a better stock settlement system, broader financial empires, greater disclosure, an expanded watchdog agency over the financial industry -- and probably a lot fewer banks and brokerages.
But of the 200 brokerage firms in Japan, analysts ask, will the Government let half of them disappear?
"Why not?" responded Eisuke Sakakibara, Vice Minister of Finance for International Affairs. Insolvent and weak institutions will simply have to merge, be purchased or disappear in an orderly fashion, he said in an interview. "Right now we have 19 internationally active Japanese financial institutions," he said. "But I would not be surprised to see that number reduced to below 10 over the next two to three years."
"There's no choice now -- we have crossed the river, we have burned all the bridges," Mr. Sakakibara added. "The global standard has to be established here. There's no other way. I don't see any other way but to continue to deregulate this Tokyo market. And we can do that."
Can they?
Japan has been bringing out deregulation packages for years, yet bureaucratic controls are so strong and social attitudes are so averse to layoffs and bankruptcies that past drives have often fallen flat. Critics point out that the Big Bang has hit snags even before it has begun.
Indeed, as a last act under the old system before Big Bang rings in the new fiscal year on April 1, the Government has hinted it will spend nearly $8 billion to buy stocks and help prop up the stock market. Banks and brokerage firms fold substantial amounts of stock into their capital bases, so the Government is trying to help minimize losses when banks record their stock prices on March 31.
The Government protests that its first priority is to bolster the tottering financial system, which was thrown into turmoil last fall with the failure of four financial institutions.
Likewise, to avoid too much carnage in the new rough-and-tumble marketplace, the Government is delaying full competition in brokerage commissions, liberalizing them first only on transactions over $390,000 before completing the process in 1999. But while some brokers are at a loss over how to cope, the prospect of a fight-to-the-death has caught the attention of others.
"It breaks our hearts, but we're pushing ahead with restructuring, said Osamu Horibe, director of Takagi Securities, a midsize brokerage firm that has shut down branches and let go more than half its workers over eight years. "There may be victims, but I hope the company I love will not be one of them."
This restructuring may in turn ripple through the financial system and, ultimately, change the entire Japanese economy. For instance, if banks told corporate clients that they would not lend money unless the companies increased their return on capital, then companies might work harder to lift profitability.
"The number of banks we end up with is less important than the rules by which they lend money," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist in Japan for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, and his guess is that banks will set stricter guidelines that will raise efficiency in all sectors.
Certainly fiercer competition, particularly from foreign firms, is likely to heighten efficiency in Japan. Even the Tokyo Stock Exchange is vulnerable. Under current plans, brokers will be able to challenge it by setting up their own mini-exchanges to trade individual stocks, even in their own offices, to save costs.
Moreover, banks will be able to enter the insurance business, and insurance conglomerates will be allowed to try their hand at extending loans. Banks will be able to sell mutual funds, which were traditionally sold by brokerage firms, and Government approvals will no longer be required on each new type of fund.
Traditionally, money was something one did not talk about in public, and many people are profoundly uncomfortable with the idea of buying riskier stocks, mutual funds or bonds. Japanese invest only about 2.6 percent of their household assets in mutual funds.
But now consumers will be hit with a new marketing barrage. Even some 24-hour convenience stores are preparing to go into the foreign exchange business. Brokerage firms are already wooing investors with the prospect of lucrative opportunities in the booming markets in the United States and Europe. So some Government officials fear an outflow of money, as individuals begin investing in Treasury bonds, which are offering three times the yield of Japanese Government instruments.

HEADLINE: 2 Developers Bid Top Dollar For What's Left in Times Sq.

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Outbidding a dozen other developers, Mortimer B. Zuckerman and George Klein have won the rights to buy the last two development sites in Times Square, but at a price that vastly exceeds that of similar buildings in the booming, neon-encrusted neighborhood, said real estate executives and a top state official.
The deal, if completed, would mark the culmination of a much-ballyhooed but long-delayed redevelopment effort that began 16 years ago, when city and state officials sought to clean up Times Square with plans to build four giant office towers, to be filled, they thought, with financial corporations. 
 That plan died after the real estate market collapsed a decade ago, and for years many people wondered whether the office towers would ever be built.
But now, with Times Square awash with tourists, new theaters and entertainment companies, the four towers appear headed for completion. Instead of bankers, the people roaming the halls are likely to be media and entertainment executives and lawyers who handle their business.
One tower is under construction, to be occupied by Conde Nast Publications and the law firm Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom; a second, whose main tenant will be the Reuters news and information services organization, is due to start soon.
Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Klein are poised to develop the final two buildings, on sites on the south side of 42d Street, just east and just west of Seventh Avenue. The developers reached an agreement in principle with the sites' owner, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, to buy control of them for about $330 million. The two developers, who joined forces shortly before the March 11 deadline for bids on the two sites, plan to demolish the existing buildings and construct two towers of nearly one million square feet each. Among the potential tenants are Disney and Home Box Office, both of which are looking for new office space in Times Square.
Prudential is expected to hammer out the terms of the deal during the next week with a joint venture formed by Mr. Zuckerman, Mr. Klein and the Blackstone Group, an investment bank. Mr. Zuckerman, the chairman of Boston Properties and the publisher of The Daily News, is expected to be the majority owner of the project. Prudential and the Zuckerman-Klein group declined comment.
Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Klein submitted an offer for both parcels that was large enough to pre-empt all the other prospective buyers, including the developer Jerry Speyer and the investor Steven C. Witkoff, who had recently intensified their efforts to win control of the sites.
Real estate executives say both developers are desperate to regain center stage in the city's real estate theater, after gambling when real estate was booming in the 1980's only to falter after the stock market crashed in 1987. To do it, Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Klein are paying about $180 a buildable square foot. That is twice the amount paid by Reuters for a similar site on the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street less than six months ago, and nearly four times what the Durst Organization paid for the site of the first tower, at 43d and Broadway.
"This deal provides them with an opportunity to get back into the public spotlight in an area which is highly sought after by both local and national tenants," said Charles R. Foy, a lawyer specializing in land use with Whitman Breed Abbott & Morgan. "They're paying a very high price for a highly visible project in order to capture what may be the last opportunity in this market."
The price raises the question of whether the developers would have to charge high rents, or ask the city for more tax incentives to attract tenants, real estate executives say.
Mr. Zuckerman's attempts to build an oversized tower at Columbus Circle died in 1994 after a recession and a decade of battles with celebrities and civic groups. From 1982 to 1996, Mr. Klein shared the development rights to all four towers with Prudential, but lost a chance to develop any one of them when Prudential decided to abandon real estate.
"I'm glad they both won," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch. "Ultimately, justice prevails."
Prudential, which had once given up hope of ever recouping the $433 million it put into Times Square redevelopment during the past decade, now stands to break even or make a little money, if the latest deal goes through. In the last two years, the insurance company sold two of the four development sites it controlled for a total of $150 million. The latest deal would bring Prudential's take to $480 million.
The latest two parcels inspired intense competition among developers and investors, not only because development sites are so rare in Manhattan, but also because the parcels are laced with tax breaks under the state's 42d Street redevelopment project that are worth hundreds of millions of dollars. With so few large blocks of office space available in midtown, rents are rising.
"Times Square has replaced Fifth Avenue as the place where people want to be," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University.
The most valuable of the two sites that Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Klein plan to develop is the southwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, where a 40-story office tower is planned on a parcel now occupied by the Disney Store and next door to Disney's New Amsterdam Theater. Disney is expected to retain its retail store in the new building.
The second site, an irregularly shaped island bounded by Seventh Avenue and Broadway, 41st and 42d Streets, presents more of a challenge because it sits above a complex of subway tunnels, which will make excavation complicated. It is now the site of Hansen's Times Square Brewery. A 49-story tower is planned.
The fortunes of Times Square have taken a roller coaster ride during the last two decades. In the early 1980's, the city and the state had hoped that the development of four large, heavily subsidized office towers would rejuvenate the area and wipe out the peep shows, T-shirt shops and pornography theaters that dominated 42d Street. But Prudential and Mr. Klein's plans ran into neighborhood opposition and a string of 47 lawsuits in the 1980's.
By the time the recession hit in the early 1990's, Prudential had poured $433 million in land acquisition, theater renovation and retail space, and lost its desire to build. The revival of Times Square was led, instead, by Bertelsmann, the giant German company; Disney, and other entertainment companies.
Much to Mr. Klein's dismay, Prudential decided to sell the four development sites rather than build. In 1996, Douglas Durst paid the insurance company $70 million, about $50 a buildable square foot, for a parcel on the east side of Broadway, between 42d and 43d Streets, where he is now building a 50-story tower.
Last year, Prudential sold a second site, on the west side of Seventh Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets, to Reuters and the Rudin real estate family for another office tower.

GRAPHIC: Map of Times Square showing sites of new development: A deal would mark the culmination of a 16-year renewal effort. (pg. B9)

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 202 words

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Whitman to Streamline Operation of Programs

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced yesterday that the state government would be reorganized to streamline the administration of some programs.
One change would shift the New Jersey Redevelopment Authority, which finances urban projects, from the Department of Commerce to the Department of Community Affairs, which oversees the State Urban Coordinating Council, said Jayne O'Connor, a spokeswoman for the Governor. Community Affairs, which is the state's primary link to municipalities, would also take over the Office of State Planning, now a part of the state Treasury Department, to help local governments achieve statewide land use goals, Ms. O'Connor said. 
 In addition, school bus safety and inspection programs are to move from the Department of Education to the Department of Transportation, and all state arts and cultural institutions would be gathered under the Department of State.
The Governor has already merged the Departments of Banking and Insurance, and has eliminated the Departments of Higher Education and the Public Advocate. The new changes, which the Governor's office said would not necessitate layoffs, will go into effect in 60 days unless they are opposed by lawmakers.
